fields.subject: Gilwon-'SEAZOR: A Robust Privacy-Preserving Secure Anonymous Zone Routing in Military Wireless Ad Hoc Networks(MILCOM13)
fields.content:
Reviews: 

======= Review 1 ======= 

> *** Comments to Authors:: Please provide comments to the authors that exp
lain your numerical ranking: 

This paper presents a new protocol to provide secure and private communicat
ion within ad hoc networks. 

There are some slight errors with the writing in English, which makes some 
of the text difficult to understand. In particular, this reviewer is not s
ure of how the authors define the concept of privacy. What is the threat m
odel for privacy in the paper? What are the expectations of privacy in a h
ostile environment? Is it the goal of the authors to maintain the privacy 
of the individual warfighter or just the communication node? 

When this reviewer has seen the concept of "privacy-preserving" techniques,
 it is in the context of identifying individual behavior within aggregated 
data (e.g., data mining). 

The authors may benefit from reviewing the following paper for a discussion
 of privacy in networks. 

S. B. Wicker and D. E. Schrader, "Privacy-aware design principles for infor
mation networks," Proceedings of the IEEE, vol. 99, pp. 330-350, 2011. 

The introduction tries too hard to sell the connection to MILCOM. There is
 an important benefit of MANETs. It is suggested that the authors review t
he following articles to improve the clarity of their presentation. 

M. Gerla, "From battlefields to urban grids: New research challenges in ad 
hoc wireless networks," Pervasive and Mobile Computing, vol. 1, pp. 77-93, 
2005. 

J. L. Burbank, P. F. Chimento, B. K. Haberman, and W. Kasch, "Key challenge
s of military tactical networking and the elusive promise of MANET technolo
gy," IEEE Communications Magazine, vol. 44, pp. 39-45, 2006. 

K. Namuduri, Y. Wan, M. Gomathisankaran, and R. Pendse, "Airborne network: 
A cyber-physical system perspective," in First ACM MobiHoc Workshop on Airb
orne Networks and Communications, Hilton Head, SC, USA, 2012, pp. 55-60. 

W. H. Robinson and A. P. Lauf, "Aerial MANETs: Developing a resilient and e
fficient platform for search and rescue applications," Journal of Communica
tions: Special Issue on Advances in Communications and Networking, vol. 8, 
pp. 216-224, 2013. 

The authors present their new protocol, but then only provide a qualitative
 discussion of their approach. Is there an appropriate quantitative metric
 that could be used for their analysis? How does this new protocol compare
 to techniques from the literature? 

The analysis provided in Section IV seemed more like a discussion on just s
ecurity. Again, without a clear definition of privacy in the context of th
is paper, it is not clear whether the authors have successfully developed a
 privacy-preserving technique. 

> *** Technical Contribution: Rate the content based on its technical stren
gth. 
Acceptable - Valid work but limited contribution (3) 

> *** Advancing Technologies / State-of-the-Art: Rate the novelty or contri
bution to military communications. 
Some new concepts (3) 

> *** Relevance and Timeliness: Rate the relevance of the topic and the imp
ortance to military communication applications. 
Somewhat relevant (3) 

> *** Quality of Presentation: Rate the organization and readability of the
 paper. 
Organization and/or writing could be improved (3) 

> *** Accept/Reject Recommendation: Do you feel that this paper should be a
ccepted or rejected? 
Reject (0) 

======= Review 2 ======= 

> *** Comments to Authors:: Please provide comments to the authors that exp
lain your numerical ranking: 

The paper topic is very relevant to the MILCOM community. Paper idea is to
 use a variety of asymmetric encryption strategies, particularly group encr
yption, that are aligned to the intra- and inter-zones of the ZRP protocol
. However, the writing style likely masks the paper’s contributi
ons. The paper promises a lot but waits until page 4 to explain its contri
butions and then lacks room to quantitatively describe its potential benefi
t. 

The protocol at first blush appears to be susceptible to various traffic an
alysis threats. For example, the paper includes a timestamp such that mess
ages are rejected if it is “invalid.” However, what makes 
the timestamp invalid is not defined. Timestamps are inherently risk in cy
ber and provide opportunities for rushing attacks and replay. The timestam
ps appear to be sent in the clear providing a clear marker that can be used
 to trace packets as well as perform traffic analysis. 

Cleaning up the writing style will significantly improve readership and pro
vide additional room that can be used to expand on the paper’s cent
ral innovations. Pay particular attention to passive voice and extra words
 (e.g.” In order to illustrate clearly as in Fig. 1 an example of m
ilitary application is as follows” may be written as “Consi
der the following example.”). Some sentences do not make sense. (e
.g. “One can figure out that military units could possibly be ke
pt tracking by adversary attacks with different types of nodes.”) M
oreover, it is difficult to understand some of the author’s definit
ions. For example, typically, insiders are directly participating in the 
MANET and may provide data forwarding services. Outsiders are not particip
ating in the MANET but attempt to infer MANET details from observed traffic
. 

Breaking down the three core claims of that the paper addresses: 

Vulnerabilities of existing protocols: Weak. Little new insight. Clarity i
s a problem. 

Define and characterize SEAZOR: Introduce late (page 4). The protocol desc
ription summarized in Figure 3 is a good start. But there are inconsistenc
ies between the text and the notation (e.g. PK_tempo which this reviewer ca
nnot find in the table of definitions or figure). Again clarity may be un
dermining the value of the work. 

Demonstrate benefits of SEAZOR over other: At best, the comparison is qual
itative and lacks quantitate results demonstrating the strengths and weakne
sses compared to other approaches. No attention is given to the signaling 
overhead of the additional encryption mechanisms on overall system performa
nce. Node mobility, which changes zone membership is also not examined. W
ith encryption-based techniques, protocols are susceptible to assymetric re
source consumption attacks. Under these attacks, the adversary can easily 
generate a “bad” stream of traffic. Nodes are forced to pe
rform CPU intensive crypto algorithms on this data stream that results in l
ower throughput. 

> *** Technical Contribution: Rate the content based on its technical stren
gth. 
Marginal - Simple contribution with some flaws (2) 

> *** Advancing Technologies / State-of-the-Art: Rate the novelty or contri
bution to military communications. 
Some new concepts (3) 

> *** Relevance and Timeliness: Rate the relevance of the topic and the imp
ortance to military communication applications. 
Relevant (4) 

> *** Quality of Presentation: Rate the organization and readability of the
 paper. 
Needs work (2) 

> *** Accept/Reject Recommendation: Do you feel that this paper should be a
ccepted or rejected? 
Reject (0) 

======= Review 3 ======= 

> *** Comments to Authors:: Please provide comments to the authors that exp
lain your numerical ranking: 

This paper studies the anonymous routing problem in ad hoc networks. There 
has been a large body of works in this research area, and I cannot see the 
novelty of the proposed solution which is based on the zone routing protoco
l (ZRP). Besides, the direct use of group signature for privacy-preservatio
n has been been discussed in existing literature, which makes the contribut
ion quite limited.As for the presentation quality, the writing of this pape
r is unacceptable. Grammar mistakes can be found all over the paper. Analys
is and experiments on performance evaluation are also lacking. 

> *** Technical Contribution: Rate the content based on its technical stren
gth. 
Unacceptable - Questionable work with severe flaws (1) 

> *** Advancing Technologies / State-of-the-Art: Rate the novelty or contri
bution to military communications. 
Yet another paper on... (1) 

> *** Relevance and Timeliness: Rate the relevance of the topic and the imp
ortance to military communication applications. 
Relevant (4) 

> *** Quality of Presentation: Rate the organization and readability of the
 paper. 
Unacceptable organization and/or writing (1) 

> *** Accept/Reject Recommendation: Do you feel that this paper should be a
ccepted or rejected? 
Reject (0)

fields.subject: Son - "Robust Distributed Power Control for Cognitive radio based on Industrial Wireless Sensor Networks", rejected, ATC 2013
fields.content:
Rejected

Review 1 (Reviewer E)
1. Strong aspects (Comments to the author: what are the strong aspects of the paper)
This paper studies power control, modeling the considered scenario using tools from convex optimization.
2. Weak aspects (Comments to the author: what are the weak aspects of the paper?)
This paper is very long and wordy especially in the first part. Moreover a lot of grammatical errors and typos are present in all the paper. The whole presentation should be improved. The problem studied has been extensively investigated in cognitive radio literature, although authors use a different framework with industrial wireless sensor networks. Problem P1 is non convex, as well as P2. But in Section 4 authors introduce two new variables, y and z, and then they can apply an algorithm in the dual domain to design an heuristic. This crucial change of variables (not even defined) is not explained at all, and therefore it is difficult to follow.
3. Recommended changes (Recommended changes. Please indicate any changes that should be made to the paper if accepted.)
Please see my comments above.
4. Submission Policy (Does the paper list the same author(s), title and abstract (minor wording differences in the abstract are ok) in its PDF file and EDAS registration?)
yes

Review 2 (Reviewer D)
1. Strong aspects (Comments to the author: what are the strong aspects of the paper)
The paper jointly solves the power control and channel uncertainty problems in cognitive radio sensor networks. The channel uncertainty is modeled as a bound range of values called the uncertainty region. These uncertainty regions are integrated into the optimization problem which calculate the allocated power for each secondary user. This idea is interesting and original.
2. Weak aspects (Comments to the author: what are the weak aspects of the paper?)
However, the paper is not well written. There are many incoherent points in terms of notation used by the text and the ones used by the equations making the paper very difficult to understand and follow. In addition, there are many english errors and typos in the whole paper. Problem of notation: Page 2, section II.A, h(i,j) is used to denote the channel gain in the text while Equation 1 uses g(i) without any explainaion. Figures 1 and 2 are not explicitly cited and explained in the text. There is not secondary users in Figure 2 and I cannot find the text explaining this figure because the figure number is not explicitly mentioned in the text. The same problem of incoherence can be found between the text and Equation (2) in page 3. The same problem of incoherence of notation continues in section IV. In section V, the paper said that the simulation parameters are presented in Table 1 while there is not Table I in the paper.
3. Recommended changes (Recommended changes. Please indicate any changes that should be made to the paper if accepted.)
The authors should revise the paper with a good coherence for the notations used in the text and the equations. The paper should be easy to read and easy to understand.
4. Submission Policy (Does the paper list the same author(s), title and abstract (minor wording differences in the abstract are ok) in its PDF file and EDAS registration?)
No. The order of authors is not the same.

Review 3 (Reviewer C)
1. Strong aspects (Comments to the author: what are the strong aspects of the paper)
This paper presents dynamic spectrum allocation for cognitive radio sensor networks under both interference constraint at primary receiver and QoS constraint at each cognitive receiver.
2. Weak aspects (Comments to the author: what are the weak aspects of the paper?)
The model of cognitive radio-based industrial wireless sensor networks is similar with cellular CRN as described in [12]. Some notations (e.g., $g_i$, $h^{ss}_{ii}$, C1, C2, ..) are explained while some redundant ones (e.g., $G^{ss}_{i,0}$) are presented. Therefore, it is difficult to the reader to track. Specially, there is no connection between Problem (P2) (transmission power control) and equation (17) with the utility function.
3. Recommended changes (Recommended changes. Please indicate any changes that should be made to the paper if accepted.)
The authors have to fix as Reviewer's comments.
4. Submission Policy (Does the paper list the same author(s), title and abstract (minor wording differences in the abstract are ok) in its PDF file and EDAS registration?)
Yes.

fields.subject: Agi - IEEE CL - Reconstruct Unrecoverable Data in Real-Time Networks using Bezier Curve
fields.content:
Paper Title: “Reconstruct Unrecoverable Data in Real Time Networks using Bezier Curve” 
 
-------------------Reviewer 3:
The authors propose a method to reconstruct unrecoverable data using Bezier curves. The method is applicable to real-time distributed systems in which retransmission is not feasible. 
In its present shape, unfortunately, I can’t recommend the paper for publication in IEEE Communications Letters. Here are some of my arguments 
1)  Lack of proper explanations and comparisons. Although error recovery is one of major problems in communications, it is not explained why the proposed method has advantages to any other method, like LDPC or BCH coding. For example, data which are correlated may be compressed and then used with lower rate, higher correction BCH codes, rather than to be approximated. Is it worse than Bezier approximation without compression? And then, approximation could still produce errors – what are error requirements, is this strategy viable? 
2)  Lack of specifics. It is not clear what sort of data is under study, and for what systems the methods can give advantage over other known methods. My guess is that approximation would be good for very smooth data, but modern video-formats are already compressed and may not fall into that category. The authors need to explain it clearly. 
3)  The subject is not very much relevant to Communications, in my opinion. A general reader may not be able to understand why this problem is of importance, and what applications could be. 
4)  Although there are comparisons in Section IV, they don’t give us clear conclusions. Would really like to see some comparisons between all known approximation methods to understand why Bezier method is the best. 

-------------------Review 4:

The paper proposes to shape the transmitted data using a Bezier curve. Then, when residual errors 
remain after classical FEC decoding, this approximation can be used to recover. The paper is well 
written with good English. 
However, the scientific justification for such a technique is not provided. In fact, by the provided elements in the paper, the results are not reproducible. Please provide a clear mathematical description on how the encoding and decoding process of the Bezier fitting is processed. The authors put more effort and space in the paper on the higher level algorithm and Handshaking rather than detailing the heart of the contribution related to the methodology of using the Bezier curve. In addition, some claims of the paper regarding existing error corecting codes are to be modified. If indeed BCH codes have a limited correcting capability, higher layer coding like Raptor codes and even 
fountain codes are comparable to the proposed system in terms of target functionality. Therefore, the paper should provide at least a justification or the advantages for choosing the proposed method rather than well established solutions. A comparison to this type of solutions would be a real plus. This comparison can target error rate performance and complexity. Typical comparison metrics for such coding schemes relies in comparing the performance in terms of bit error rates or frame error rates versus required parity or used parity and signal to noise ratio. This is not the metric used in the paper. Instead there is a measure of reliability in the paper without a mention of the type of errors and their distribution. Therefore, it is quite difficult to assess the performance of the proposed solution. No clear complexity comparison with respect to the before mentioned methods is provided. Therefore, once again it is quite difficult to assess such a proposal.
As a conclusion, without detailing the proposal at the transmitter and at the receiver side and without any comparison results in terms of performance and/or complexity with respect to existing methods, I find it difficult to accept the publication of the paper. 

The remaining reviewers' comments are attached.

fields.subject: Agung - IEEE CL - Dynamic Rate Adaptation for IEEE 802.11g
fields.content:
Reviewer: 1
Comments to the Author
The submitted paper deals with the topic of enhancing
reliability and real-time capabilities of IEEE 802.11g wireless links in an industrial scenario. 
Though the addressed topic is of significant importance for enabling implementation
of wireless extension of real-time ethernet segment, the paper does
not meet the required overall quality, lacks of scientificity and originality.

DETAILS

The main concern with this work is that it seems more like a collage work from papers of others, rather than an original contribution of the authors. Indeed, any presented assumption throughout the paper is a reference to results presented in other works. The only apparently new result is the second table. However, the authors do not explain how this has been obtained, and no reference is provided. If this is an authors' result, please state it clearly and explain how you got it. The whole work is based on the RA algorithm presented by ref. 6, and on the use of this table. The methodology is therefore questionable.

I want also highlight that some figures appearing in the paper are actually copied by authors from some of the papers referenced in the bibliography, but without either explicit declaration or proper citation of the source of the figure,

From a technical point of view, in many parts the paper adopt very strange/wrong assumptions,
or introduce a reasoning without any context information.
Some example:
- it assumes a Rayleigh channel model, without referencing to other models
and providing a very hasty justification.
- authors state that random traffic has been generated. This shows that authors
are not very confident with industrial network analysis, where typical traffic
profile and performance figures differ from those of general purpose IT networks.
- authors considers legacy ARF (without any description) and SARF (proposed by ref. 6),
describing why these should provide negative results with respect to their technique.
This description is however (at least) obscure.

Therefore, the work results very confusing, difficult to read and understand. Given also the highly questionable originality of the paper, I cannot suggest its acceptance to the journal.

Finally, a note on its presention quality.
The writing is very poor for a journal publication. There are plenty of orthographic
and grammar mistakes. Some examples are:
...arrival of packet will without error...  ...wass...  ...whcih...

and many others.
The paragraph at mid second column of page 3 which starts with "In SARF [...]" is totally
unintelligible, for example.

 
Reviewer: 2
-----------------------------------
Comments to the Author

This paper proposes a new rate adaptation algorithm for IEEE 802.11g devices.

===Originality and novelty===

Rate adaptation for legacy 802.11a/b/g networks is a heavily studied research field. There are multiple studies published for more than a decade. The authors did not compare their algorithm with state of the art algorithms like RRAA, SampleRate, MiRA, ESNR. They chose as their base of comparison ARF algorithm, which is among the oldest algorithms.


===Technical quality and correctness===

I did not find any new insight/contribution in this paper. All the results that authors claim are well known. The authors mainly focus on what they did rather than why they did it this way. There are also several open questions. Why your solution is for 802.11g? Why not for 802.11a/n? Why you compare your algorithm with ARF while earlier you describe SARF? Why there are no throughput evaluation results?

===Presentation quality===

Presentation needs some work, as there are several spellings and grammar mistakes. For example “ir will choose” in Section 3. Moreover some statements need to be more clear (e.g., “3.5 generations” in Section I).

fields.subject: Agung - WiP ETFA2013 - Rate Adaptation
fields.content:
REVIEW 1
This paper proposes a method to optimize the rate adaptation in 802.11n WLANs. Even though it has a more or less clear structure in terms of sections, the contents of the sections are sometimes quite confusing. The style of writing and the grammar should be improved, e.g. abbreviations such as AMC, SARF, ACK, etc. must be introduced. The existing typos "NSR - SNR", or "QSPK - QPSK" and several others must be removed.

The contribution of the paper is ambiguous and it is not clear how the proposed method really works. For instance, it is described in the abstract that the SNR values are transmitted by using ACK/BACK frames, but in the paper an explicit periodic exchange of this information is mentioned. The latter will add a lot of overhead to the wireless network which is not desired and should be avoided. The detailed explanation of Rayleigh fading does not contribute at all to the main objective of this work and should be only summarized. Moreover, it must be explained how the proposed values in table II were derived. The last paragraph in column 1 of page 3 is completely out of context, if I am not mistaken.

Finally, the evaluation part of the paper is quite weak. The experiment to derive the results is not explained at all and the main essence of the obtained results is not clear to the reviewer. You should elaborate further on this. Fig. 1 must be improved, because it is hardly readable in the current version.


REVIEW 2
The algorithm presented by authors is a combination of classical RBAR algorithm simple predictor and a heuristic approach introduced in ARF like algorithms.
It's worth pointing out that none of them was mentioned in the paper. The proposed algorithm is based on the receiver based channel estimation which require a modification of the ACK frame and thus modification of the IEEE 802.11 standard. Despite authors claim it is not a trivial task. Additionally such a modification makes modified cards incompatible with of the shelf equipment.
One of the weak points of the algorithm is a heuristic used for the frame retransmission. Using such a simple retransmission pattern makes algorithm vulnerable to performance loss caused by inability to distinguish a reason of transmission failure especially in networks with higher collision probability (more than 5 stations).
Despite the title the algorithm is rather addressed to the IEEE 802.11g networks. Almost nothing is known about the goal function of the proposed algorithm. Similarly no information is provided about the radio communication environment used in the simulation (Doppler spectrum, correlation between MIMO branches (if used) etc. ) and the traffic structure in the industrial wireless networks.


REVIEW 3

In this paper authors present a method to optimize the rate adaptation (RA) algorithm in 802.11 WLANs for industrial application. In particular, the SNR threshold and ACK/BACK information from receiver are used to increase the system performances.

Author propose to use a commonly used method, the SNR threshold, with an algorithm presented in the paper [7]: this is not a strong novelty, but, because this is a WIP, can be acceptable. The main drawback of the paper is how is written and how it isn't clear. The proposed algorithm is understandable, but it's not clear how results have been obtained. Moreover, in Section 3 the equation (6) is not correctly described. Authors speak about the standard 802.11n, but all the tables refer to a 802.11g data rates set. Finally, the paper is not so clear and almost a page is not used.
In my opinion, a strong revision of the paper has to be done to accept this paper.

Comments:
This paper is not well written, some illustrations of the notations are missing. For example: EC, CT, TM, TPD, PM, AM, and so on. The proposed idea is simple and interesting. One issue to the reviewer is that the paper did not discuss the of network workload of the different nodes and the network bandwidth on the schedulability of the system. That is, in a typical real-time system, each task should have a formal specification of its workload, i.e. execuriton time, period, deadline requirements, and the system should have an available resource specification, e.g. maximum bandwidth. The proposed scheme targets the real-time switched Ethernet for naval combat system. The proposed idea shall guarantee the deadline requirements to be meet. This issues seems is not discussed in detail in this paper. The quality of the paper can be further improved if the real-time guarantee is considered further.

Here are some other comments:
1.      The proposed scheme relies on a spanning tree collection and a “hello” messages to provide high-speed convergence time. Why adopts spanning tree as the topology? It seems there are still many other topologies can be applied.
2.      The illustrations of some equations are not clear. For example: in equation 10, how to derive the value of P(rM_i^n | CT).
3.      In page 5, the proposed scheme set “Tree” consecutive times, then, the switch will decide that there is a connection problem between two switches. But, why use three? Why not 2 or 4?
4.      It seems that the proposed idea did not provide QoS. As shown in the Table I, different traffics have different deadlines. Also, they don’t equal importance. We suggest authors consider the priorities of traffics to provide the QoS.
5.      How to guarantee the traffics can meet deadline? If the network topology of the naval combat system is huge and traffic workloads are heavy, how to guarantee them.
6.      For the recovery time analysis, we suggest authors shall illustrate them in more details.
7.      Does the proposed scheme have backward compatibility? If yes, please illustrate them in more details.
8.      In simulations, there are 9 switches in the topology. However, there are only 10-30 traffic sources. In a real world naval combat system, we believe the amount traffic sources must much bigger.
9.      Authors shall redraw figures. All figures are not clear. For example, in the Figure 1, the words are too small.
10.     It seems that the simulation results are only based on only one simulation. It would be better if authors simulate them with 10 or 100 times, and average them.
11.     The proposed scheme only compare with the traditional TTEthernet. It would be better if authors compare it with some timely work.
12.     Why the message deliver probability of the single message transmission mode is only 0.5 (while period>4ms)? It seems the message deliver probability is set too low.
13.     What it is EC, TM, TPD, PMs, AMs? Please describe them in more details.

fields.content:
Reviewer A Comments: 
================== 
Suggestions which would improve the quality of the paper but are not essential for publication: 
Idea is interesting and well presented but I will suggest minor corrections: 
- Maybe the Introduction and particularly Conclusion parts are too short. 
- I will suggest a better compartson with other Path Control Scheme of Swarm Robot Systems with explicite emphesise why proposed model is better. Is it just a novel method or it is a method that is better than existing methods? 
- Also better explanation of equations (1) - (4), They have been mentioned in only one sentence. 
- It was not explained how Fuzzy Rules (Table II) for obstacle avoidance has been derived. 
Also some minor technical corrections 
- Figures 2 and 7 is hardly readable 

Reviewer B Comments: 
================== 
Suggestions which would improve the quality of the paper but are not essential for publication: 
1) dampers could be included in Figure 1? 
2)the quality of Figure 2 cóuld be improved? it (texts and images) is not that clear 
3) larger fonts of texts could be chosen for Figure 6 and other figures. 
4) the format of tables should be consistent 

Changes which must be made before publication: 
This work presents a control algorithm using the spring-damper impedance and fuzzy logic for the path and formation control scheme of swarm robot systems. The spring-damper impedance control model of swarm robots has been established, the controller for obstacle avoidance has been developed using fuzzy logic. The experimental tests have been conducted to verify the control algorithm. The work is suitable for being published on the journal, but the following comments and questions have to be addressed before being accepted for publication. 
1) Page 1: ‘slave robots form a triangle with a master robot as its center’. The master robot is located at the center of the triangle, or it is located at the top vertex as show in Figure 1? Please make it clear to readers. 
2) Page 1:’ formation control of the network-based swarm robots is calculated by the front and rear robots and interrelation between them.’ That means the formation control of the robots is only related to the front robots and rear robots, and has nothing to do with robots on the left and right sides? 
3) Page 1:’the noise in the speed measurement, or uncertainty due to errors in the model can be included.’ How are they included in the model and controller design? The reviewer did not see the issues have been addressed in the work. 
4) On the spring-damper impedance model, for example Equation (1), the reviewer’s understanding is that the model should be P ̈=-2〖ζω〗_0 P ̇-ω_0^2 P based on the physical meaning as the damping force and spring force is opposite to the velocity and displacement? How is the model implemented in the terms of control strategies (it is PD controller or other specific controller?) ? 
5) More explanations should be given to Equations (2)-(4)? How are the equations derived? 
6) How is the spring-damper impedance control model integrated into the fuzzy control for obstacle avoidance? What is the connection between the parameters of fuzzy controller and the parameters in the motion equations of robots (spring-damper impedance)? They are separated or integrated in the controller design? (formation and obstacle avoidance) 
7) How are equations (5)-(11) integrated into the controller algorithm? 
8) Image system should be detailed a little more (hardware and software). The FOV of vision system can cover all the robots and how? What is the resolution and accuracy? 
9) In the Abstract: ‘simulation results show the advantages of the proposed scheme.’ It is ‘simulation results’ or ‘experimental results’? 
Again, the reviewer hopes the above issues can be addressed with details so that readers can understand the work better.

fields.subject: Agung-IET WSS - Male-Silkmoth-Inspired Routing Algorithm for Dense Wireless Networks
fields.content:
Reviewer: 1
Comments to the Author
This paper proposes an interesting insect behavior routing algorithm for dense wireless networks. However, a comparison with other bioinspired algorithm should improve the paper largely. Notwithstanding the foregoing, the paper is suitable for publication at IET-WSS.

Reviewer: 2
Comments to the Author
The authors propose a male-silkmoth inspired routing algorithm. A typical shortest-path algorithm and a zigzag-path algorithm have been used. Novelty of the proposed work by the authors is unclear. In Section II (B), the authors must clearly highlight the differences and/or extension in the proposed work and that of [12], [13], [17], and [18]. Nevertheless, the authors use “shortest-distance” algorithm but have never mentioned specifically which algorithm has been used? A number of algorithms and schemes have been used in the proposed work without proper references of which part of scheme had been applied where and how? The authors must first highlight the problem focused and what has actually been proposed. The manuscript lacks clarity and focus.

Reviewer: 3
Comments to the Author
Reviewer's comments

The author proposes an insect behaviour routing algorithm for dense wireless networks

1.      In the abstract the author states that this algorithm is used for “dense” networks. It needs to be clarified that whether the proposed algorithm is suitable for small number of nodes.
2.      The mapping of “Bombyx mori” with the proposed algorithm is missing.
3.      In section II B the authors have stated about “zigzag” path. Why there is a need to have a “zigzag” path? The geometry of zigzag path needs to be discussed.
4.      In algorithm 1 the author have stated that “Perform any shortest path algorithm ”. There are various shortest path algorithm exists. Exactly which algorithm is used? Different types of shortest algorithms perform differently. If any specific algorithm is chosen, it needs to be justified.
5.      The proposed algorithm must be explained with the help of an example.
6.      It is required to exhaustively test the proposed algorithm. The author must compare the proposed algorithm with the existing one, which will prove the innovativeness of the algorithm
7.      Fig. 6 and 7 are not cleared. The resolution of the fig. Must be improved.
8.      Does the zigzag path used to obtain fig 6 is random or it is having any specific parameters? This needs to be specified.
9.      The possible applications of the proposed algorithm need to be discussed.
10.     Since the proposed algorithm is applied to wireless sensor networks, the effects energy consumption needs to be discussed. It must be compared with other algorithm. Because energy consumption is always an issue in WSN
11.     In section IV B the author states that “However, in the modified DSR algorithm, the connectivity of each node is checked to find an alternate hop in order to make a zigzag-path”, the modifications to DSR protocol are not clear.
12.     In the paper authors have discussed 2 protocols. But in abstract only one is reflected
13.     As the algorithm is mainly applied for “dense” nodes, what is the point in discussing its performance for 2 nodes (Section IV B) If the algorithm can be used for small number of nodes then the abstract and title both should be revised
14.     In section II D the authors have considered CSMA/CD protocol. Why?
15.     In section III author says that “The DSR protocol is almost similar to AODV”, which is totally incorrect statement. If author still agree above statement it needs to be justified.


It is found that the author's similar paper Similar paper “Male-Silkmoth Inspired Routing Algorithm for Dense Wireless Networks” had been already published at http://nsl.kumoh.ac.kr/include/sub.php?m=65&mode=Read&serial_no=201201060001&com_id=bi0001&menu_cd=30&class_cd=53&Page_Num=&left=&item=&find=&m=65 on 2012-06-01

The abstract of both the papers are almost same. The above paper was a conference paper.

It seems similar paper is already presented in ICTC 2012 (conference). The paper is listed in a related document at address: http://2012.ictc2013.org/data/ICTC_2012_Program_v1.pdf‎

I am strongly recommending to reject this paper.

fields.subject: Nhon - IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics - Real-Time Message Scheduling for ISA100.11a Networks
fields.content:
Reviewer: 1 
Comments to the Author 
There are some small typing errors: 
- Figure 5: The "2" is missing in the enumeration "1,3,4,5" 
- Page 5 , line 44 right column: ... a value that depends on k is added to w. There is a space missing in front of the w. 
- Page 6, line 20, right column: ... a Poisson distribution with an inter arrival time of 6?. The unit "s" is missing. 
- Page 5, Formula 2. Ncol and Ncont should be better explained. Should Pc not be the number of collisions divided by the total amount of packages sent. 

Reviewer: 2 
Comments to the Author 
This paper proposes two scheduling methods for shared time slots of the ISA100.11A standard. In traffic-aware message scheduling (TAMS), network devices are divided into groups and are allowed to access the channel in specific cycles. In contention window size adjustment (CSWA), the contention window is adjusted based on the probability of collisions. 

A significant limitation of the work is that it can only be applied to star topologies, while many industrial sensor networks are multi-hop mesh networks. 

The research problem is not well defined. The paper needs to provide a self-contained overview on how the shared time slots are scheduled and how CSMA/CA is implemented in ISA100.11A. Sections II.C and II.D need to be reorganized. 

Technical depth is lacking in the proposed approaches. TAMS simply divides network devices into different groups and let them access the network in different cycles. It is based on inappropriate assumptions. For example, the calculation of Pc in equation (2) is simplistic. Some important parameters such as backoff, contention window and delay time are ignored here. 

CSWA is not well presented and the intuition behind the protocol is unclear. 

Simulation settings are unrealistic. The simulation tool OPNET Modeler 16.0 is not well described. It is unrealistic to assume there is no communication error at all. Given the number of network devices as large as 200, it is not reasonable to assume all nodes can listen to each other’s transmission signal. The evaluation fails to show that the proposed approaches are effective in real-world networks. 


Reviewer: 3 
Comments to the Author 
The paper describes two extensions to the ISA100.11a standard for 
scheduling sporadic messages. In case of collisions during such 
transmissions when in CSMA mode, the authors propose either to adjust 
the contention window or to group nodes in distinct clusters accessing 
the channel at different times. The two schemes are designed to 
alleviate contention and hence reduce collisions, improving delivery 
and latency. The authors report simulation results comparing their 
modifications to the behavior of the original ISA100.11a standard. 

Unfortunately, the paper falls very short in terms of novelty and 
methodology, especially in the evaluation. Specific issues are: 

0) Why at all bothering with extending the ISA100.11a standard? The 
authors seem to take for granted that some improvements are needed, 
but never really tell the reader why. As far as a random reader 
knows, ISA100.11a may be just fine for the applications it 
targets. A stronger initial motivation for the work is needed. 

1) The TAMS schema is largely a straightforward application of existing 
slot assignment algorithms. Besides, it is unclear how the 
multi-channel operation of ISA100.11a would co-exist with such a 
schema, nor I understood how key parameters of the protocol are 
estimated at run-time, such as the number of contention slots 
involved in a collision (N_col). 

2) The CWSA method looks like a trivial adjustment of the contention 
window, already seen many times in the literature. More generally, 
I am skeptical as to how significant this may be even in the 
context of the authors' work, given that at least based on the 
current evaluation, the TAMS schema always outperforms 
CWSA. Therefore, what is the point of CWSA? 

3) A common issue of both solutions above appears to be the authors' 
lack of knowledge and understanding of the state of the art. The 
authors are invited to better consult existing works on MAC 
parameter adaptation and tuning for 802.15.4 networks, for example: 

Marco Zimmerling, Federico Ferrari, Luca Mottola, Thiemo Voigt, and 
Lothar Thiele. 2012. pTunes: runtime parameter adaptation for 
low-power MAC protocols. In Proceedings of the 11th international 
conference on Information Processing in Sensor Networks (IPSN '12). 

Pangun Park, Carlo Fischione, and Karl Henrik 
Johansson. 2010. Adaptive IEEE 802.15.4 protocol for energy efficient, 
reliable and timely communications. In Proceedings of the 9th ACM/IEEE 
International Conference on Information Processing in Sensor Networks 
(IPSN '10). 

Based on a deeper study of the state of the art, the authors are 
also invited to re-work their comparison against related work, 
which right now merely looks like a laundry list with no discussion 
about what sets the authors apart. 

5) Finally, the evaluation leaves much to desire. The results are 
essentially meaningless given the very idealistic setting. A star 
topology with perfect communication link, indeed, leaves open 
questions such as whether and how the authors' schema may work in a 
more complex multi-hop setting with unreliable channels, which is 
far more realistic than what the authors consider here. 

Finally, the presentation also requires some work, as typos and 
grammar errors are present all over the paper.

fields.subject: Llinh-Routing Protocol over Lossy Links for SP100.11a-Based Industrial Wireless Sensor Networks-AHSWN
fields.content:
Reviewer B:

Strong Aspects:

The paper addresses the routing over Lossy Links for Wireless Sensor Networks, and considers both energy consumption and latency issues.

Weak Aspects:

Major: There are extensive studies about routing in Wireless Sensor Networks. Many of them also considered energy consumption and latency issues. More detailed related work is encouraged to justify the novelty and originality.

Major: The relation between 3.1, 3.2, and 3.3 is not clear enough. Especially for 3.2, how does latency reflect as only end-to-end latency makes sense? For 3.3, solving ILP is high time complexity which is not efficient in realistic scenario.

Minor: Page 12, equation 8, what does pij stand for?

Recommended Changes:

Please see weak aspects above.


------------------------------------------------------

------------------------------------------------------
Reviewer C:
In this article, the authors proposed routing and topology control algorithms based on the SP100.11a for industrial wireless sensor networks (IWSNs), aiming to reduce the energy consumption and packet latency of IWSNs. The energy & latency issues of IWSNs are well motivated and significant, and a great deal of related work has been done previously. For the idea proposed by this paper, it is relatively new. However, its performance may be questionable, and some theoretical proof and more convincing experiments results are expected. As well, more explanations about the algorithms and simulation results should be given, because I don’t know what the authors want to express only from the algorithms or figures. In addition, the paper’s written and organization should be improved. For more detailed information, please check the following detailed comments:
 
(1)     I recommend to use a notation table including all the symbols (e.g., T_R, d_c, d_t, etc.) in this article.
(2)     The authors said they proposed their routing protocol based on SP100.11a. However, I do not observe much about SP100.11a in the system model and algorithms design phrases.
(3)     What is the major contributions/advantages, compared with related works? Please list them in the article.
(4)     In the second paragraph of page 4, “The blacklist of links for G^e and G^l are …” should be “The blacklist of links for G^e and G^l is …”.
(5)     In page10 & 11, more explanations about the algorithms should be given. In addition, the examples should be illustrated in details to display the complete constructing progress.
(6)     In the last paragraph of page 9, the second sentence “The nodes measure the radius d_t of the transisional region…” should be “The nodes measure the radius d_t of the transitional region…”.
(7)     In section 3.3, the authors formulate the ILP problem. How do you solve this minimization problem?
(8)     On the evaluations,
• The evaluation results are not convincing. First, the setup is too simple. Second, the contrast experiments are not sufficient enough. Third, the result descriptions & explanations are missing.
• In Figure 8 & 9, the authors list the performance of SAEL-G^e SAEL-G^l. However, the comparative experiments are ignored, and I cannot distinguish which one is better.
• More information (e.g., setup, result descriptions and explanations, etc.) should be given for Figure 10 & 11.
• In the second paragraph of page 17, the second sentence “For this simulation scenario, the … at 2%” should be “For this simulation scenario, the … to 2%”.
(9)     More carefully designed pictures should be given, and the organization (e.g., location, title) of these pictures should be improved.

fields.subject: Scheduling Algorithm for Downlink Network of Military Satellite Systems
fields.content:
Reviewer: 1 
Comments to the Author 
The paper investigates a dynamic scheduler for downlink network of military satellite systems. A performance evaluation of the proposed solution is conducted using Opnet. 
The presentation of the paper is very poor and the results are not convincing at all. For example, Figures 8 to 11 show queuing felays as a function of incoming rates. Delays change in a way that does not seem to be linked to the rate (e.g. Fif. 9). Maybe I miss something but I don't see the reason for that. Maybe the simulations are not representative of what is going on. 
Concerning the proposed approach, presentation of existing schedulers is very unclear for someone who does not know them (I know them). The same occurs for the presentation of the new scheduler. 
I suggest that the authors fully rewrite these presentations. They should also conduct a deeper simulation study. 

Reviewer: 2 
Comments to the Author 
The paper presents a network scheduling algorithm for nodes that 
communicate over satellite links used for military purposes. The proposed algorithm, called Dynamic Weighted Deficit Round-Robin (DWDRR) builds on top of existing round-robin-based scheduling techniques and it is presented as a way to implement a simple, fair and priority-aware scheduling mechanism to multiplex network packets. DWDRR uses Exponentially Weighted Moving Average (EWMA) to dynamically calculate the quantum for each node at each scheduling pass. The idea of expanding on existing RR techniques to keep the implementation of the scheduler simple while enforcing fairness and priority-awareness is interesting. Nonetheless, the paper has several 
weaknesses detailed below. 
First, the paper does not clearly state what is the problem that is being solved. It is easy to understand that satellite communication is a crucial component in military operations and that real-time network solutions are needed. However, what is not clear is why the problem of scheduling network flows on satellite links is different from scheduling real-time flows on different types of networks, such as wired and/or point-to-point wireless. 
Second, the paper fails to review the consistent amount of related works about scheduling techniques for time-sensitive network flows (see works on UF-DRR and Proportional Fair). Moreover, the work about WFQ and PGPS that is mentioned to be in "initial stages" refers respectively to three works from 2002 to 2011, but: 1) Well established implementation techniques, simulation results and implementations on open-software routers exist for WFQ (see: Performance evaluation of the simplified WFQ to multiplex a huge number of queues, 2012; Implementation of WFQ in a distributed open software router, 2011; A Simulation Study of the WFQ Scheduler in a 
DiffServ Node under LRD Traffic, 2008); 2) none of the works [5] to [7] are directly connected to either WFQ or PGPS. In general, references in the paper seem to be randomly placed (see references [1] and [2]). 
Next, the section that should review the background and, in particular, the DRR and WDRR algorithms, are not well organized. As a result, having a good understanding of the mentioned algorithms is impossible from the paper itself. For example, Fig. 2 contains three steps of the DRR algorithm, but only the first step is (briefly) explained, so that it is impossible to understand the rule according to which Q is updated cycle after cycle. The explanation provided for WDRR is slightly better, but the meaning of last paragraph of II.C is still obscure. 
The explanation of the proposed algorithm is also lacking. The high-level idea is simple and thus easy to understand, but the details of the work-flow are not included and the figures reporting the flowchart (Fig. 4), as well as the figure with a block-view of the scheduler (Fig. 5) are not even referenced in the text. Similarly, no mathematical analysis of the proposed algorithm is provided in the subsection called: "mathematical analysis of the proposed algorithm": this section only contains some statements about how the exponentially moving average is used. Instead, this section should contain the mathematical framework that needs to be set in place to analyze the proposed algorithm. 

At a high-level, DWDRR seems to have some desirable properties to be a good candidate scheduling algorithm for network flows. However, some major points need to be clarified and well supported: 1) if it is based on some estimation technique to update the value of Q, how can we guarantee that fairness is ensured? 2) what is the upper bound on the link utilization that can be achieved with DWDRR? 3) Why the nodes are not affected by starvation when DWDRR is used as a scheduling algorithm? 

The carried evaluation has several problems. Once again, Fig. 6, 7, Table I and II are not referenced in the text. Moreover, the graphs in Fig. 8 to 11 seem to suggest that the proposed algorithm performs better - in terms of queuing delay - only on the lowest class of priority. The (poor) results obtained on priority classes 1-3 are not explained and, overall, it is not clear why, for classes 1-3, data are so noisy. It would be helpful to understand what is the sample size and number of runs, as well as what is the confidence/deviation of the results. All this is missing. The experiments about packet loss look a bit better. However, all the graphs seem to suggest that, even though DWDRR performs better, the improvement margin is still pretty low: less than 0.02% for class 1 flows; less than 0.5% for class 2 flows and so on. So, is it still a good approach given that the increase in queuing delay for class 1 can be higher than 20 ms with respect to DRR? 
Finally, there is a number of problems in the writing style. I am reporting some of them below, but overall the paper needs to go through a complete reviewing process. 

Bad lexical selection: 
- "The problem with the existing WDRR is spasticity [...]". Spasticity is a medical word and I am not sure how it can be referred to algorithms. 
- "The quantum supposed to be assigned are [...]". The use of "supposed" is quite informal and does not fit well in a scientific work. 

Oversimplification of concepts 
- "if it is implemented in an overloaded environment [...], real-time performance can not be guaranteed. Thus, an algorithm that transmits data as quickly as possible is required". Real-time is not about transmitting data as fast as possible, but with a predictable timing behavior. Also, in network terminology, transmission time refers to the time needed to propagate a signal through the medium, not the time required by the scheduling algorithm to handle messages. 
- "When RR assigns the quantum to each node, node 2 and node using a priority networks connection such as weighted round 3 are in the idle and overloaded states, respectivley. Therefore, it is an inefficient scheduling algorithm. However, if frequency and priority are considered in this algorithm, the transmission is more efficient and has a low wastage". This may be true, but need to be supported with either an example, extended explanation or with a reference to a (pertinent) related work. 

Unrealistic statements: 

- "For example, if an enemy intercepts the information of our military forces, they can invade important military bases [...]. Conversely, we can deploy various strategies for an invasion". I assume that this paper is not being written in the context of an active war. 
- "Further, the hard real-time requirements must be satisfied in an overloaded environment which changes from peace to war rapidly". No matter how fast diplomatic relationships can evolve, a change of scenario from peace to war does not happen very often and typically requires hours to days. So, the network infrastructure is not overloaded due to the frequent changes of status (peace to war), but maybe because the communications for military and civil purposes can share a subset of links. → 군 전용 위성이라는 가정이 없음


Reviewer: 3 
Comments to the Author 
The paper presents a new network scheduler algorithm for military networks. The proposed algorithm, called “Dynamic Weighted Deficit Round Robin” (DWDRR), which is based on the Weighted Deficit Round Robin (WDRR) algorithm, adjusts dynamically the quantum size according to the instantaneous traffic characteristics. The system comprises an observer module that analyzes the traffic continuously and computes the adjustment to the quantum values. The estimation of the traffic characteristics is based on an Exponential Moving Average infinite impulse response filter. 
The proposed scheduling algorithm was implemented in OPNET. The authors present simulation results for a military-inspired scenario. The evaluated performance indicators are queueing delay and packet loss ratio. 

The base idea presented in the paper, which consists in adapting the quantum size of WDRR to the instantaneous traffic characteristics, is interesting.. However the paper has several serious flaws in terms of structure, readability, technical contents and validation. 

The quality of the writing is extremely poor. There are several sentences that are completely unintelligible and many others require a lot of effort from the reader to make sense of. 

The related work is also poor. The authors only present standard approaches like WRR, DRR and WDRR, omitting other closely related contributions (e.g. [1], below). The same criticism can be applied to the simulation results, since the proposed algorithm is compared only with DRR and WDRR. In addition, the descriptions of DRR and WDRR are not clear. For example, what the authors define as quantum is usually called the deficit counter, the actual quantum value is not explicitly stated, the graphical symbology used in figure 2 is not explained, etc. 

The presentation of the DWDRR algorithm, in section III, has several flaws that make many aspects of the proposal unclear. The algorithm depicted in figure 4 is not explained in the text and has many parameters that are not defined (e.g. RAND_A, CNT, Qadd, ...). The estimation of the additional quantum value (section III.C) is also not clear at all. The text refers some parameters (B_{AV}, Q_F) that are not visible in equation 1 and it seems that a “1-\alpha” term is missing in it. Furthermore, the output of equation 1 is not explicitly defined and it is not attributed to any variable. 
Finally, the paper does not present any sort of formal analysis of the proposed scheduling algorithm. 

The evaluation of the proposal is also inadequate. To start with, the simulation parameters are not completely defined. For instance, the traffic patterns are not described (only bandwidth bounds) which is a severe flaw since the main purpose of the proposed algorithm is precisely to cope with traffic pattern variations. On the other hand, the authors refer in the text that the algorithm performance is strongly dependent on the values of parameters “TM” and “\alpha”. However the paper does not mention which values have been used. Still in this topic, a sensitivity analysis of these parameters, essential to evaluate the practical usefulness of the algorithm, is not included in the paper. 
The results themselves are not completely convincing. The relative performance of the algorithm is erratic, performing sometimes worse and others better than the other algorithms. Even when it performs better, it is only marginally. Therefore, in the reviewer's opinion, the relative performance of the proposed algorithm is far from proven. 

The bibliographic references have several mistakes (e.g. missing authors [13], incorrect names (also [13]), incomplete identification of the event [5], ...), denoting lack of care in the preparation of the manuscript. 

Bibliography: 
[1] Teck Meng Lim, Bu Sung Lee, Chai Kiat Yeo, Weighted deficit earliest departure first scheduling, Computer Communications, Volume 28, Issue 15, 15 September 2005, Pages 1711-1720, ISSN 0140-3664, http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.comcom.2004.12.015. 

AE Comments: 
Associate Editor 
Comments to the Author: 
(There are no comments. Please check to see if comments were included as a file attachment with this e-mail or as an attachment in your Author Center.)lpattillo36804@gmail.com

fields.subject: Tan- AD HOC NETWORKS Journal
fields.content:
Do Duy Tan, D.-S. Kim "Interference-Aware Relay Assignment Scheme for Multi-Hop Industrial Wireless Networks", in submission, Ad-Hoc Networks, 2013 

Reviewer #2: This paper presents a relay selection scheme that takes into account the channel state information and the packet buffer level. A probabilistic analysis is conducted towards collision probability.  Network performances, in terms of packet delivery ratio, energy consumption and delay, are evaluated in OPNET simulator, which adds credits for the paper.The main problem with the paper is its lack of novelty, i.e., it presents a minor deviation from past works in the area of cooperative relay selection and protocols. It also lacks of implementation/simulation details.The best relay selection scheme proposed is a minor deviation from literature, such as reference [13], in the sense that the proposed scheme additively considers the buffer level.The paper claims one benefit of the proposed scheme is that if the destination successfully decodes the packet from the source, then there is no need for the relay to retransmit the packet. This seems quite obvious;many works on Hybrid ARQ (automatic retransmission request) have already tackled the problem by enabling relay only in case of decoding failure.The influence of relay interference is (very) insufficiently addressed in the paper, although the title of the paper clearly says "interference-aware". Interference analysis is not presented, and even in the protocol level, the paper provides very vague arguments regarding a feasible implementation of the interference learning/management procedure, see page 17-18.The probabilistic analysis of collision is based on [13]. A simple M/G/1 queue model is also provided to consider the buffer level. However, the validity of the queue model is unknown, especially in a cooperative network context in the paper: (1) with source and relay, packet arrival may not be exponentially distributed. (2) in case of failure, packet does not actually depart the queue and MAC layer will retransmit the packet. A carefully characterization of the queue is needed. The simulation studies network performance showing the scalability. But it is very confusing that the paper says that the MAC protocol used is CSMA/CA for 802.11, because (1) relays have different contention timer (2) interference-aware scheme also necessitates modifications to the MAC layer. How to modify the timer, the network allocation vector (NAV) in MAC is not addressed. How to learn interference level through MAC operation in order to select relay is also not clearly addressed. These details are necessary to understand and validate the simulations presented.

Reviewer #3: This paper proposes an interference-limited relay assignment scheme for multi-hop wireless networks that exploits cooperative diversity to cope with problems of wireless channels and to enhance data transmission reliability.  The paper seems to have good contribution, however, it needs the following
1-compare the results with the very recent papers that deal with relay assignment.
2-revise the introduction considering the recent papers.
3- many parts are just repeated to each other, the paper is too long for such contribution.
4- correct the spelling and grammatical errors.
5- the reference list is not very recent. It should be revised and very recent published paper should cited.
6- Some typos in references, correct the format.

fields.subject: Linh-WCNC2014
fields.content:
Tung-Linh Pham, Dong-Seong Kim, "Heterogeneous Relaying Scheme for Lifetime Extension in Wireless Sensor Networks", waiting for submission.

Abstract: This paper proposes a novel heterogeneous relaying scheme that enhances network lifetime for two-hop wireless sensor networks (WSNs). Relaying is a spatial diversity technique which can achieve high energy-efficiency; hence it has become an attractive approach for lifetime extension in wireless networks. In this study, relay nodes are deployed either amplify-and-forward (AF) or decode-and-forward (DF) protocol between a source and a destination randomly. By estimating channel gain and residual energy of relay nodes, the source node can determine the best assistant relay to retransmit failure packets to the destination. As a result, relay nodes can keep the balance of energy dissipation and extending the network lifetime. Numerical evaluations show that the proposed scheme is fully effective in terms of the energy conservation for WSNs.

Related Reviewers' comments

Reviewer A

> *** Strong Aspects: Comments to the author: What are the strong aspects of the paper?

This paper proposes a relay selection scheme for relay networks where a source node communicates with a destination through a set of possible relays. Both AF and DF relays are considered in the scenario. Proposed approach intends to increase the network lifetime. Results reveal that it outperforms other schemes in the literature.

> *** Weak Aspects: Comments to the author: What are the weak aspects of the paper?

 Several weak aspects are identified:

- The paper does not really fit very well under the scope of the special session, devoted to interference and design of future hetnets. The paper does not really deal with a heterogeneous scenario (i.e. involving multiple cell types, multiple technologies, etc.), but simply the communication through a relay. The paper does neither deal with interference aspects.

- The paper takes paper [8] as a reference for their development, and in fact the system model in section II is very similar as in [8]. However, when looking at expression (5) (obtained from [8]), it is not clear the relationship with the received signal in expression (4), since apparently this expression is not really in line with the corresponding expression (2) in [8]. In particular, the paper assumes that the multiplication factor of hri,d·ysr,i is sqrt(Pi)/(1+Ps*|hsri|^2), while in [8] the multiplication factor is sqrt(Pi/(1+Ps*|hsri|^2)). Moreover, the units of (4) are not very clear, since the first term is a signal level (volts) divided by a power level (watts). To be physically consistent, the units should be volts. All these elements need to be clarified.

- The proposed strategy assumes that the residual energy of each relay is known at the time of making the decisions. However, it is not explained how is this information obtained. 

- In Fig. 2, in order to know whether it has to be silent or to forward the packet, each relay needs to know gammas,d at the destination node. How is this value obtained? Is it the actual gammas,d or is it an estimation based on hs,d?

- In eq. (3), hsri should be apparently hsd.

- Given that [8] is a relevant reference for this paper, I would suggest adding the strategy in [8] as a reference for comparison in the results section.

- English style needs to be improved throughout the whole paper.

> *** Recommended Changes: Recommended changes. Please indicate any changes that should be made to the paper if accepted.

As indicated under wak aspects:

- clarify expressions (4) and (5) in relation to [8]

- explain how to know the residual energy of the relay

- explain how the relay can know gammas,d at the destination

- revise eq. (3)

- include strategy in [8] as a reference for comparison

- improve english style

 Reviewer B

> *** Strong Aspects: Comments to the author: What are the strong aspects of the paper?

Performs competently a trade-off analysis between relaying options


> *** Weak Aspects: Comments to the author: What are the weak aspects of the paper?

Assumption of known channel gains leads to non-robustness; gain estimation has errors.

Unclear what "heterogeneous" means here. The fact that "network that consist of both AF and DF relay nodes" does not make it henerogeneous, it makes it a mixed-relay-type system.

> *** Recommended Changes: Recommended changes. Please indicate any changes that should be made to the paper if accepted.

English grammar is bad throughput.

Reviewer C

> *** Strong Aspects: Comments to the author: What are the strong aspects of the paper?

The authors use the term heterogeneous to describe a network with relay nodes that use both AF and DF protocols. It basically evaluates and decides which protocol is better for cooperative transmission and then defines the best relay based om the power transmission and residual energy.

> *** Weak Aspects: Comments to the author: What are the weak aspects of the paper?

It is not clear to the reviewer that the term Heterogeneous applies in this scenario. Some relevant references would be useful.

It is not clear in the text the type of the relays in the other two methods in the performance evaluation section. They are the same as in the case of LEHR scheme? 

The notion of Network Lifetime is not explained properly. What exactly are the values in the vertical axis in figures 4 and 5?

There is no discussion on the complexity of the proposed scheme with respect to the other two. 

The papers has some language errors.

> *** Recommended Changes: Recommended changes. Please indicate any changes that should be made to the paper if accepted.

Reviewer D

> *** Strong Aspects: Comments to the author: What are the strong aspects of the paper?

The paper is "nice and clean". The subject is developing a heuristic relaying algorithm for a two-layer relay network with a mixed population of amplify-and-forward and decode-and-forward relays. The analysis is simple and appears to be correct.

> *** Weak Aspects: Comments to the author: What are the weak aspects of the paper?

i) the system architecture is a bit simplified, and also the impact of errors in the estimation of the channel are not discussed.

ii) the authors compare the performance of their method with two alternative pre-existing ones, but they only analyze performance metrics (energy and survival time) for which it is clear form the very start that their algorithm is superior. What about latency, hop numbers or achieved bit rate?

> *** Recommended Changes: Recommended changes. Please indicate any changes that should be made to the paper if accepted.

See "weak aspects" above. One metrics curve with more criteria would be very welcome.

fields.subject: Phuong-ICGHIT2014
fields.content:
Minh-Phuong Tran and Dong-Seong Kim, "Distributed Power Control Scheme for MIMO Cognitive Industrial Sensor Networks", accepted.

Abstract: Cognitive industrial sensor networks (CISN) have emerged as a promising solution to address the spectrum-related challenges of wireless sensor networks (WSN). Moreover, cognitive radio (CR) gives us a possibility to maximize the utilization efficiency of limited spectrum resources. However, because the wireless devices coexist in the same radio environment, there are harmful channel conflicts among users. In this work, power control is designed for MIMO underlay cognitive radio-based industrial wireless sensor networks in which single primary users (PUs) coexists with multiple secondary users (SUs). With perfect knowledge of local channel information, the optimization problem is solved effectively. We propose an algorithm for controlling power in cognitive industrial sensor networks.

Related Reviewers' comments

Review 1 (Reviewer A)
======= Review 1 ======= 

> *** Relevance and timeliness: Rate the importance and timeliness of the topic addressed in the paper within its area of research. 
Acceptable (3) 

> *** Technical content and scientific rigour: Rate the technical content of the paper (e.g.: completeness of the 
analysis or simulation study, thoroughness of the treatise, accuracy of the models, etc.), its soundness and scientific rigour. 
Marginal work and simple contribution. Some flaws. (2) 

> *** Novelty and originality: Rate the novelty and originality of the ideas or results presented in the paper. 
Minor variations on a well investigated subject. (2) 

> *** Quality of presentation: Rate the paper organization, the clearness of text and figures, the completeness and accuracy of references. 
Readable, but revision is needed in some parts. (3) 

> *** Strong aspects: Comments to the author: what are the strong aspects of the paper 

Power control is one of the important field in cognitive industrial sensor networks where cognitive users are constrained by both a maximal interference level and the QoS of itself. 

> *** Weak aspects: Comments to the author: what are the weak aspects of the paper? 

1./ This paper should rewrite the reference section and fix some errors about notation, spelling and so on. 

2./ The author should provide the simulation results for giving a deep sight about this algorithm. 

> *** Recommended changes: Recommended changes. Please indicate any changes that should be made to the paper if accepted. 

The author see the weaker field. 

> *** Submission Policy: Does the paper list the same author(s), title and abstract (minor wording differences in the abstract are ok) in its PDF file and EDAS registration? 

Yes, it does. 

======= Review 2 ======= 

> *** Relevance and timeliness: Rate the importance and timeliness of the topic addressed in the paper within its area of research. 
Acceptable (3) 

> *** Technical content and scientific rigour: Rate the technical content of the paper (e.g.: completeness of the 
analysis or simulation study, thoroughness of the treatise, accuracy of the models, etc.), its soundness and scientific rigour. 
Valid work but limited contribution. (3) 

> *** Novelty and originality: Rate the novelty and originality of the ideas or results presented in the paper. 
Some interesting ideas and results on a subject well investigated. (3) 

> *** Quality of presentation: Rate the paper organization, the clearness of text and figures, the completeness and accuracy of references. 
Readable, but revision is needed in some parts. (3) 

> *** Strong aspects: Comments to the author: what are the strong aspects of the paper 

This paper proposed an algorithm for distributed power control for MIMO Cognitive industrial sensor networks. 

> *** Weak aspects: Comments to the author: what are the weak aspects of the paper? 

- The proposed approach has not been verified by the numerical results. 
- The notation for the number of antennas is not unified, i.e., each receiver has "r" antennas, but in Table 1, number of antennas is "p".

Pham Thi Minh Thu, Dong-Seong Kim, Termite-Inspired Optimization Unbalanced Radius Scheme for Zone Routing Protocol in Mobile Ad-Hoc Networks, accepted, the 2014 International Conference on Green and Human Information Technology (ICGHIT)

Abstract—This paper proposes an optimization unbalanced radius scheme inspired from building hill behavior of termites. In typical termites building hill strategy, after a termite walks through a path, it will leave pheromone, therefore the amount of pheromone of a path displays how much this path is used by termites. By apply this characteristic into construct zone of each node in Zone Routing Protocol (ZRP) the balanced radii in all directions will be replaced by unbalanced one. With more nodes in the direction has higher probability to become destination are stored in intrazone routing table, our proposed scheme allows to enhance data packet delivery ratio, mitigate delay (discovery route delay) and reduce control overhead.

======= Review HETNETS Workshop 1 ======= 

> *** Strong Aspects: Comments to the author: What are the strong aspects of the paper? 

This paper proposes an interference-aware routing algorithm to balance routing costs between primary and secondary networks and the authors assess the performance of their algorithm in terms of improvement in average throughput, end-to-end delay, and packet delivery ratio. 

In addition, the authors claim that there is no study like the one they present such that it is focused on the optimal routing flows in cognitive radio networks (CRN) under the adverse effect of multiple 
overlapping transmissions. 

Thus, on the strong side of the paper we have originality and performance of the proposed solution. 

> *** Weak Aspects: Comments to the author: What are the weak aspects of the paper? 

Technically the paper seems to be sound. Some improvements could be done in the use of English, though. 

> *** Recommended Changes: Recommended changes. Please indicate any changes that should be made to the paper if accepted. 

I would recommend to the authors to re-read the paper and try to improve the use of English.

Good. (4) 

> *** Technical Content and Scientific Rigour: Rate the technical content of the paper (e.g.: completeness of the analysis or simulation study, thoroughness of the treatise, accuracy of the models, etc.), its soundness and scientific rigour. 
Solid work of notable importance. (4) 

> *** Novelty and Originality: Rate the novelty and originality of the ideas or results presented in the paper. 
Some interesting ideas and results on a subject well investigated. (3) 

> *** Quality of Presentation: Rate the paper organization, the clearness of text and figures, the completeness and accuracy of references. 
Readable, but revision is needed in some parts. (3) 

======= Review HETNETS Workshop 2 ======= 

> *** Strong Aspects: Comments to the author: What are the strong aspects of the paper? 

The topic tackled by the authors is timely and relevant. 

> *** Weak Aspects: Comments to the author: What are the weak aspects of the paper? 

The main problem with this paper is that the authors do not provide sufficient information about the context of the problem, what exactly the algorithm aims to achieve, which knowledge is needed to execute the algorithm, etc. The paper starts from a model and jumps immediately into an algorithm and simulation results, without sufficient background information. It gives the impression that several aspects of the paper are unsound, because not mentioned or explained. 

Some examples: 
- context: the introduction contains several statements on CR technology, but a clear definition of a CRN and a clear problem statement are lacking. A SU will not use spectrum in use by PUs in order not to interfere. Clearly explain why overlapping transmissions are possible and can cause interference. 
- clearly explain the relation between the model and the algorithm 
- which knowledge is needed by the algorithm: is it centralised or distributed, do you need to know all the positions of PUs and SUs, etc 
- more detailed explanations: e.g. "the algorithm allows selected routes that are corresponding to the fair costs for routing performance in CRNs" => what does this mean? 

Further, the paper is unbalanced. At lot of attention is given to the system model, whereas the algorithm is only briefly touched, although this is the main focal point of the paper. The notations used in Table 1 make the formulas not straightforward to read: X is used for position, subset of nodes, with one or two indices. 

Finally, some language errors need to be corrected. 

> *** Recommended Changes: Recommended changes. Please indicate any changes that should be made to the paper if accepted. 

As stated above, major attention should be given to: 
- concise description of CRN 
- clear problem statement: which problem do you want to solve and what causes this problem 
- link between model and algorithm 
- more details on the algorithm and the input it requires 

> *** Relevance and Timeliness: Rate the importance and timeliness of the topic addressed in the paper within its area of research. 
Good. (4) 

> *** Technical Content and Scientific Rigour: Rate the technical content of the paper (e.g.: completeness of the analysis or simulation study, thoroughness of the treatise, accuracy of the models, etc.), its soundness and scientific rigour. 
Marginal work and simple contribution. Some flaws. (2)
