Some interesting ideas and results on a subject well investigated. (3) 

> *** Quality of Presentation: Rate the paper organization, the clearness of text and figures, the completeness and accuracy of references. 
Substantial revision work is needed. (2) 

======= Review HETNETS Workshop 3 ======= 

> *** Strong Aspects: Comments to the author: What are the strong aspects of the paper? 

Within this manuscript, for the cognitive radio networking scenario with a number of primary users and secondary users, the authors have proposed a routing geometry algorithm that is interference-aware and can approximate the interference percentage during the multiple overlapping transmissions. The proposed interference-aware routing algorithm has been verified to be efficient and fair even under overlapping interferences. 

> *** Weak Aspects: Comments to the author: What are the weak aspects of the paper? 

Within this manuscript, one of the core parts of the proposed interference-aware routing algorithm is the “so-called” PIA (percentage of interference approximation algorithm), for which only the feasible links with under 40% percentage of interference are considered. However, through the whole manuscript, there is no clear explanation on why and how the value 40% (percentage of interference) is chosen and determined. Is there any special reason on choosing this value 40%, why not 45% or 50% or even 60%? Based on different values of PIA, the routing performance might be totally different? 

> *** Recommended Changes: Recommended changes. Please indicate any changes that should be made to the paper if accepted. 

Based on my abovementioned comments, the authors are strongly suggested to explain the key reason for choosing and determining the suitable value of the percentage of interference and then carry out the relevant simulations by using the corresponding PIA values.

fields.content:
Editor's comments 

The authors propose a relay selection scheme which incorporates rate estimation in the selection metric and investigate its performance through simulations in OPNET. Relay selection is an important tool to boost the performance of cooperative communications while avoiding the strict synchronization requirements of all-active relaying protocols. Therefore, the paper addresses a timely topic. However, the technical contribution of the paper does not reach a sufficiently high level to warrant publication in an IEEE journal. Relay selection has been extensively studied in the literature and, besides the four publications cited in the Introduction section, there are are many other works in this area. 

The presented work here is incremental in nature and also includes many idealistic assumptions in the physical layer. For example, the calculation of Eq 2 requires the estimation of channel coefficient which is probably assumed to be perfect in simulations. Eqs (3)-(5) are also written under the assumption of perfect decoding at the relay which is obviously not always possible in realistic settings. Furthermore, there are many typos and grammatical errors throughout the text. 


Reviewer: 1 

Comments to the Author 
In this paper, the authors proposed a relay selection scheme for wireless cooperative networks, where the source exploits the CSI of the path from the source to relay and from the relay to the destination as well as to choose the most reliable node to become the relay. The simulations were conducted to confirm that the proposed scheme perform better than that of the direct transmission. 

In general, the technical contribution of the paper is marginal. 

Reviewer: 2 

Comments to the Author 
The paper proposed a relay selection scheme for wireless cooperative networks to distribute the traffic of packets from the source nodes to the sink. Channel estimation was applied to obtain the channel information of the two-hop neighbors. However, the contribution of the paper seems not significant enough to grant publication in this journal.

fields.subject: Syamsul - Embedded Systems Letters
fields.content:
AE Comments to Author:

Associate Editor: Gordon-Ross, Ann
Comments to the Author:
All reviewers have similar concerns and criticisms of the proposed work. In summary, the paper is difficult to read due to poor organization, grammar, and flow, the contributions are  are ambiguous, and there are serious concerns with the results comparisons.

Reviewer(s)' Comments to Author:

Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
The paper proposes a data reconstruction method based on interpolation using Bezier curves. The method is compared with reconstruction methods employed in the field of compressive sampling.

As a general comment, for the reader it is hard to follow the rationale of the authors and to acquire a complete picture of the presented work as essential information seems to be missing from the paper.

1. It is not clear for the reader what is actually being proposed as there are ambiguous indications given in the paper; more specifically, from the abstract and introduction it seems that Bezier curve based interpolation is proposed as an alternative to the reconstruction methods used in the field of compressive sampling, while in Section III one may understand that the Bezier curve method is an addition to some reconstruction method.

2. It is not clear what the authors refer to exactly with the term "Compressive Sampling". Usually this term refers to a large field in signal processing including different signal acquisition modalities and a large variety of signal reconstruction methods.
The authors should be more precise in this regard as they seem to refer to sparsity-based reconstruction, which is often used in - but not limited to - the field of compressive sampling.

3. The authors should clearly state which "Compressive Sampling" method/algorithm they considered in the comparison with their proposed method. Without this information it is difficult (if not impossible) to assess the validity of the comparison of Section II.

4. The description of the method given in Section I-B is not sufficient to reproduce the proposed method. It is not clearly stated what "received data D" refers to, what the "key factor T" is and how its being constructed. The same applies to the "Equation Space Matrix" and the "Graph Space Matrix", whose exact indication of purpose and mathematical description are missing. Either references should be added or a complete description should be given.

5. Figures 4(a)-(c) : The performance of the proposed method can not be assessed in general from the results given in Figure 4, as essential information is missing from the description.
- The authors should indicate whether the five data points shown represent an excerpt from the reconstruction of a larger signal vector, and how they can be representative for a larger data set.
- What kind of "random data" was used. (One might have some doubt about the applicability of compressive sampling methods to "random data" in general) Further, it would be interesting for the reader to know how the reconstructed signal vector is assembled from the 5 samples wide reconstruction windows used in the proposed method.

6. Fig. 4(a): The original and the compressive sampling data seems to be missing from the plot.

7. It's not clear to the reader on what grounds the comparison illustrated in Figure 5 was performed; In fact, the comparison seems to be unfair, as the proposed method uses 4 sampling points to reconstruct 5 data points, which implies a maximum compression rate of 0.8, while for the "compressive sampling method" a compression rate of 0.1 was considered.
Under these conditions the comparison in Figure 5 seems to be meaningless.

An interesting addition to the presented material could be an estimation of the computational complexity of the different algorithms considered.
These results could enrich the comparison and maybe reveal interesting design related trade-offs relevant for embedded system designers.

Overall, the paper in its present form appears to be of little scientific value, mainly because the authors do not provide enough information that would allow the results and conclusions to be verified.

Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
This paper presents a method to reconstruct data using a Bezier curve for compressive sampling. Although the paper addresses an interesting topic of data reconstruction from compressive sampling, the paper has various flaws which need to be addressed before publishing in a journal. Below are my detailed comments:

1. The paper language and writing needs major improvement. Currently the paper has many grammatical errors that make it very difficult to understand this paper. Below are a few examples:
(i) Page 1, line 36-37, first column, needs to be rewritten as: "...where the sampling frequency is equal to twice the maximum frequency in the signal..."
(ii) Page 1, line 47, second column, the sentence should be "A Bezier curve is a method which uses.." instead of "'A Bezier curve is a method which is using..."
(iii) Page 1, line 50, second column, "a Bezier curve can be defined", "a" should be in small letters as opposed to capital "A" currently in the paper.

2. Introduction of the paper is not coherent. The first paragraph discusses distributed systems and then data reconstruction without mentioning data sampling or compressive sampling or the motivation for data reconstruction problem.

3. Related work discussion is superficial.

4. Bezier curve definition and illustration lacks clarity.

5. The proposed approach in the paper also lacks theoretical substantiation.

6. Page 2, line 42, first column, "Starting from received data D", it is not clear whether this data D are samples or points, only stating data D is very vague.

7. Organization of the paper is poor. Currently only three sections, Introduction, Results, and Conclusion. The proposed contribution is also mixed with Introduction.

8. Define the acronyms in Table II, e.g., CS (compressive sampling) and BC (Bezier curve).


Reviewer: 3

Comments to the Author
The paper presents a method to improve the reconstruction of the data sampled and compressed using compressive sensing technique. The authors describe the algorithm used and provide an example to show the effectiveness of their work.

The paper contains some interesting and insightful ideas, nevertheless it has also several and severe weaknesses and cannot be accepted as is. I would suggest a new resubmission after a complete revision of the paper.  Here are the main comments and  weaknesses of the paper:

- The use of Compressive sensing seems mainly an excuse to apply the Bezier curve interpolation. There is no reason why the propose approach cannot work also for a sub sampled signal, without compressing sensing.  The authors  should  explain better what is the role of compressive sampling techniques in this paper, otherwise it seems  that the contribution of the paper is just an implementation of a Bezier curve for interpolation.

- The description of the algorithm is not clear and also some definition are missing or incomplete. For example:
a) What are Q1 and Q2 in Figure 2?
b ) What is the role of Matrix T? How the value of the elements of this matrix have been chosen? Why?
c) What are the role of Matrices ESM and GSM? Again, how did the authors select the value of the elements?


- The simulation results the authors have presented are simply insufficient.
First of all, presenting results over a sine wave is completely useless, both for the length of the sine wave and for the other signals.

- The performance calculated on the images (Fig. 5) are insufficient to estimate the error of reconstruction.
An assessment about the accuracy of the reconstruction and the contribution of ICT in this role is fundamental , but cannot be extrapolated by only one experiment. It should be a statistic metric which results from an average between multiple tests.

-Finally, what is the SNR of the reconstruction?

fields.subject: Agi - International Journal of Electronics and Communications
fields.content:
Thank you for giving us the opportunity to consider your work.

Prof. Dr.-Ing. Ralf Lehnert Editor-in-Chief International Journal of Electronics and Communications

Ms. Ref. No.:  AEUE-D-13-00584 Title: Decoding Scheme of Error Correction using Fake Error Addition: 4G Cellular System International Journal of Electronics and Communications

I regret to inform you that the reviewers of your manuscript have advised against publication, and I must therefore reject it.

For your guidance, the reviewers' comments are included below.

Reviewer #1:

The title of the paper is a bit misguiding, as it states that the paper relates to 4G cellular systems although only WiMAX is discussed. The authors mention this in the text, but the title would still need to be changed. Also, the main contribution of the paper is the retransmission scheme. This should be visible from the title.

The authors state that as long as the error rate in a given channel is far below the error correction capability of the LDPC code, the overall throughput efficiency can be improved if the proposed method is applied to the system. The reviewer finds this assumption to be rather strong, since the transmission parameters are generally optimized in networks to make the most of the available bandwidth, so the error rate in the channel should on average not be far below the error correction capability. The authors make no statements as to what happens if a retransmission fails. Additionally, based on the level of code trimming (3 - 7%) presented in the simulation results section, it seems that the receiver would potentially need to store quite many unrecovered codewords in a buffer for really being able to benefit from the proposed retransmission scheme. Intuitively, this seems to complicate the system quite notably. Although the proposed approach is fairly interesting, it is not discussed how it would impact on the receivers, i.e., hardware and memory requirements, increase in complexity, etc. The authors should discuss these topics in the paper and also potential risks with using the retransmission scheme. The authors should also discuss in more detail why and how the proposed approach is better than a regular retransmission.

The use of references could be improved. The authors state something and then list a number of references without commenting anything on those references. In general, a reader will want to know briefly how each reference strengthens the arguments in the paper. Additionally, almost all references are listed in the introduction, while there are places later in the paper which would need references.

The text in section 2.3 on page 4 is partially repeated on page 5. These parts should be modified in order to avoid repetition.

Figure 1 does not notably help the reader in understanding the paper. A more thorough explanation of that figure would be useful. Figures 2 and 3 are quite complicated and should be explained in more detail. Furthermore, it is unclear what the E and M matrices in Figure 3 are, as they are not defined in the paper.

Figure 5 needs more explanation. In Figure 12, it is not clear how the different trimmed codes can be seen in that figure.

In section 2.2 in definition 1, the variable H has not been defined. Unless the reader is familiar with LDPC codes, the reader will not know what H refers to. Lemmas 1 and 2 seem to be redundant, as they are not utilized in the paper. Additionally, not all variables used in those lemmas are defined in the paper.
The simulations are rather simplistic, as they seem to be made in a setting where LDPC decoding is done after transmission over an AWGN channel. In the reviewer's opinion, they should have been made in a WiMAX environment in order to analyze the true benefit of the method proposed. The simulations are also made only for a single code length and code rate, while it would be beneficial for the paper to present results for LDPC codes with different parameters. Furthermore, the results show a quite varying performance (specifically the 5% trimmed code in Figure 10) which should be more thoroughly analyzed. Maybe the variations would be smaller if longer simulations were run?

The results only show the number of decoding iterations required for successful decoding. What the paper really needs is results on how much the proposed method can improve the efficiency in the transmissions, since the authors claim that there is such an improvement. In the simulation results section, not all references to the figures in the text are correct (the authors refer to Figures 3 and 4, but these should probably be Figures 9 and 10). These need to be updated. The results are presented both in words and in the figures, i.e., what is seen in the figures is also written in the text. To some degree this is OK, but it would be more interesting to read about the impact of the results, rather than to read in words what is immediately seen in the figures.

Reviewer #2:

English is poor, the paper is hard to read.

fields.subject: Tung - IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications
fields.content:
Dear Prof. Kim:   

I write you in regards to manuscript # Paper-TW-Feb-14-0192 entitled "Efficient Routing in Interference-Aware Cognitive Ra dio Networks" which you submitted to the IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications.   

After reading your submission and discussing it with another expert colleague, I conclude that, in its current form the manus cript is well below the standard expected for the Transactions. This conclusion is based on several reasons. First and most no ticeable is the low level of English; while the paper is not unreadable, there are a large number of instances of incorrect gra mmar and style throughout the entire manuscript, which makes the text hard to comprehend (for instance, a good typical ex ample is the sentence "In first, the impact of interference on the primary and secondary networks is investigated through the use of the cumulant of the aggregate interference as the interference model" from the abstract, which has several English mi stakes).   

More importantly, the overall amount and depth of the contribution falls significantly short from the expected level of accepte d papers. I note that your paper consists of just a little bit over 19 pages (in single-column double-spaced format), compared to the maximum limit of 30 pages which is normally closely approached by most successful submissions and gives a good ind ication of the expected volume of the contribution. While we accept all kinds of contributions related to wireless networks - fr om purely theoretical to experimental implementations - every contribution must contain an original idea/concept of interest to the readership of the journal and be justified in detail.   

In the case of your manuscript, it is not clear what exactly the significant original contribution consists of, and the manuscrip t itself makes only a very brief explanation about what is novel in the proposed algorithm compared to existing ones. In my u nderstanding, the manuscript starts with a relatively lengthy discussion of the system model in sections II and III, which doe s not seem to be an original contribution but merely an exposition of some required already-known concepts (if my understa nding is incorrect, the paper would need to highlight this and be then structured completely differently, providing a focus on comparison with related work on interference modeling and analytically justifying the novelty of the proposed model). Then, section IV ("Proposed algorithm") seems to present the key new algorithm of the paper, but it is very brief and uses vague a nd high-level language with almost no technical detail; even the detailed algorithm listing on page 13 uses extremely vague s entences (such as "10. Minimize the links with Dijkstra's algorithm"; "11. Based on all selections, establish the flows for routi ng to the network"), which do not unambiguously define the exact steps required for anyone wishing to implement the algori thm. The proposed algorithm is then not supported by any analytical or experimental contribution, and is only evaluated usin g a simulation study consisting essentially of a single scenario (with minor variations of the number of sources and mobility model), where the performance is compared only to a basic case and not to any other proposals in the extensive existing lite rature on routing in cognitive radio networks, some of which are in fact mentioned in the Introduction. This falls well short of what is normally expected of papers published in this Transactions, and cannot be considered as a comprehensive study of y our key novel idea, sufficient to argue and justify its value and importance and warrant an archival publication.

fields.content:
Reviewer(s)' Comments to Author:

Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
A male-silkmoth-inspired routing algorithm is proposed in this paper. The idea is new, but the motivation is not clear, and its feasibility is in doubt. What is the advantage of mimicking male-silkmoth's flying pattern? It is not convincable that this routing protocol can save energy. Actually, it is shown in Figure 8 that this protocol consumes more energy than a shortest-path routing protocol. Then, what is the superiority of this routing algorithm when compared with the shortest-path routing protocol? In Figure 7, the zigzag path achieves higher throughput than shortest path, and the reason should be clarified.

The evaluation in this paper is not sufficient. It is significant to compare the male-silkmoth-inspired routing algorithm with classical routing protocols in wireless mesh networks or ad hoc networks, such as DSDV, DSR, AODV, et al. More routing metric also should be measured, e.g., throughput, routing setup time, packet loss rate, et al.

Does the male-silkmoth-inspired routing algorithm adapt to dynamics nature in wireless networks? Since wireless links are usually intermittent, how to maintain these information timely? How does the male-silkmoth-inspired routing algorithm locate physical positions of nodes to select a zigzag path? What is the selection metric?

The readability of the paper should be improved, and several grammatical mistakes should be corrected.

Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
This paper proposed an insect behavior routing algorithm，which the algorithm is based on the behavior of the male-silkmoth with finding a source of pheromone. cal behavior to large-scale wireless mesh networks。 The authors  use a mesh topology for implementing the algorithm, and the simulation results show the algorithm is effecient under certain conditions.

Reviewer: 3

Comments to the Author
The authors have proposed a routing algorithm for the Wireless Mesh Network based on the behavior of an insect called  Male-Silkmoth. The overall presentation and writing of the paper is not up to the mark. The reviewer asks the authors to look into the following  comments and improve the quality of the paper.

1.The introduction section failed to clearly identify the motivation. Why should you chose male-silk-moth based routing that other generic routing protocols for WMN like Hybrid Wireless Mesh Protocol. Its is better to re-write the introduction so that the problem definition and contributions are clearly visible. Then, a separate related works section can be added.

2.Why did you consider DSR as the base protocol for WMN. DSR is a reactive routing protocol which could be a good choice networks where nodes are mobile. But, in WMN, nodes are generally static and proactive protocols are likely choice.

3.How the source node computed the total number of hops required for a specific destination?? In section II-B the authors said that “the number of hops for any destination can be used for assessing the total number of hops”. How can this be possible?

4.Why always, after the traveling i/2 nodes, zigzag routing is introduced. What is the rationale behind this? I mean , if there are 10 hops, then up to five hops shortest path routing will be performed and after that, zigzag starts. So, my question is why after 5 hops, why not after 7 or 8 hops??

5.In the simulation, a 100x100 wireless mesh network is considered, however, the authors stated that the topology is constructed on the basis of wireless sensor network!! So, does the node characteristics are of WMN or WSN?? Moreover, the authors need to consider that  in  a typical WMN, there should be one or more gateway nodes and majority of the traffic flows are  between a WMN node and the gateway.

6.The reviewer does not think MATLAB is the best available  tool to simulate wireless network routing protocols. Rather the author should simulate using ns-2/3 or omnet or opnet to get a more accurate simulation results.

7.Please consider the result shown in Fig. 7 which compared the throughput of shortest and zigzag path. Your proposed routing algorithm consists of both shortest path at the beginning and then, a zigzag pattern. So, why did you consider only shortest path and only zigzag path separately. Whereas in Fig 8. bio-inspired routing is considered along with zig-zag and shortest path.

8.Need to consider other performance metrics like end-to-end delay, packet-loss-ratio etc.

9. Finally, there are some typos and the quality of English need to be improved.

fields.subject: Tung - Wireless Networks
fields.content:
BEE: Bee-Inspired Algorithm for Zone Radius Determination in Independent Zone Routing Protocol for Mobile Ad Hox Networks
Comments for the Author:

Reviewer #1: This paper proposed a zone radius determination algorithm that emulates the characteristics of bees foraging for nectar to reduce the computational complexity, the routing overhead and enhance the network connectivity via the convergence time in MANETs. The proposed algorithm is novel. However, there are still some problems:

1. Section 2 is too short. The problem formulation is not clear. Please rewrite this section.

2. Overall, the introduction clearly introduced the ZRP and IZRP algorithms and the motivation. But why do you mention again about the related work after stating your work and contribution? It looks weird.

3. You claim that your algorithm can rapidly estimate its own optimal zone radius. Can you prove the optimum?

4. In the simulation, the network includes the various number of nodes from 5 to 30 nodes spreading randomly in the square area. Can you add some results in more complex network topology? For example, there are some holes in the network. This can show the robustness of your algorithm.


Reviewer #2: I don't think there is enough novelty compared with the previous work "Zone routing determination for izrp based on bee-inspired algorithm".
All the algorithms and most of the content are the same. This paper does not deserve publication in this journal.

In terms of the content, section 2 is too short for an independent section, and there is no formulation in fact.
Section 3 and section 4 has no connection. You should first clarify your problem and then explain why you use the bee-inspired algorithm.


Reviewer #3: In this paper, the authors proposed a zone radius determination algorithm which emulates the foraging behavior of the bees. By communicating radii information with adjacent nodes, a node can find its optimal zone radius. The authors claimed that the proposed algorithm achieve lower computational complexity, lower routing overhead and faster convergence than the original zone radius determination protocol.

However, compared with the authors' conference paper (see reference [10]), the contribution of this one is limited since the authors do not add much new content. Besides, there are some serious problems regarding the theoretical analysis and English writing, which are listed below.

a) How does the Algorithm 2 and Algorithm 3 correspond to the ABC (Artificial Bee Colony) algorithm? Specifically, which part or module do the employ bees, onlooker bees and scout bees correspond to in the proposed zone radius determination algorithm, respectively?

b) How are Equation (4) and Equation (5) derived?

c) In section 4.1, what is the definition of connection ratio? Is the connection ratio equal to 1 since you have assumed that all nodes are connected?

d) Both section 4 and section 5 need much work to be clear as there are numerous grammar mistakes. Better consider a rewrite.

e) Fig. 8 is confusing. How does it show that the modified IZRP converges faster than the original IZRP?

fields.content:
Reviewer(s)' Comments to Author:


----------------------- REVIEW 1 ---------------------
PAPER: 7
TITLE: Dynamic Load Balancing Algorithm for Industrial Wireless Networks
AUTHORS: Sardor Hojiev and Dong-Seong Kim

OVERALL EVALUATION: -1 (weak reject)
REVIEWER'S CONFIDENCE: 4 (high)

----------- REVIEW -----------
This paper deals with a load balancing mechanism that permits migrating nodes from overloaded APs to APs with a lower load.

The subject is interesting and results could be valuable.

However, the paper is in a very early stage (probably, too early even for a work-in-progress).

The text is not adequate, and this makes understanding your reasoning quite difficult.

Specific aspects:

- Section 2: you use S to denote the set of APs, then you refer to it as A.

- fractional association matrix: it is defined in [8], but as a binary association matrix.

- You state that it is possible for an IEEE 802.11 STA to associate to more than one AP at the same time, is it so?
In that case, could you refer to the part of the standard that says this is actually possible?

- you state that [5] uses coefficients x(a,u) in order to evaluate the load. I checked that paper, and I wasn't able to find the related statement.

- all your maths are quite difficult to follow. It is not clear what the different quantities exactly refer to, what is their dimensionality, their actual meaning (not the intuitive meaning), etc.

- this also means that it is quite difficult assessing the correctness of your algorithm (which is indeed extremely simple), as well as its effectiveness based on results.

The paper has to be reworked in depth---both the text and the explanations.


----------------------- REVIEW 2 ---------------------
PAPER: 7
TITLE: Dynamic Load Balancing Algorithm for Industrial Wireless Networks
AUTHORS: Sardor Hojiev and Dong-Seong Kim

OVERALL EVALUATION: -2 (reject)
REVIEWER'S CONFIDENCE: 4 (high)

----------- REVIEW -----------
The paper describes an approach to balance the load in a wireless network with several access points by allowing users to switch between access points in order to balance the load. Load balancing is done by a threshold scheme.
I cannot recooemdn acceptance of the paper for the following reasons:
- The approach has an idelaized view on the world which probably does not hold in practice.
  Usually the number of access points which can be reached is restricted due to channel
  interference in particular if modern 802.11 protocol variants are used. Furthermore it
  rarely happens that different APs with the same link quality can be accessed at the same
  time. Interference or varying transmission conditions are not taken into account instead it
  is assumed that all wireless links have the same quality. These conditions are unrealstic and
  will not work in practice.
- The simulation model uses exactly the mentioned unrealistic conditions such that the
  experimental results are not helpful. Simulation results are given without confidence
  intervals which is not acceptable.
- Language and writing style requires some improvement.


----------------------- REVIEW 3 ---------------------
PAPER: 7
TITLE: Dynamic Load Balancing Algorithm for Industrial Wireless Networks
AUTHORS: Sardor Hojiev and Dong-Seong Kim

OVERALL EVALUATION: -2 (reject)
REVIEWER'S CONFIDENCE: 4 (high)

----------- REVIEW -----------
The paper describes an algorithm for dynamically balancing load between some APs serving a set of wireless stations. The algorithm is aimed at improving the overall throughput of the system.

The structure of the paper (motivation, problem formulation, algorithm description, simulation results) is OK, but the English is very poor and the paper results very hard to read. English errors and typos are spread on the text and make it quite difficult to understand its meaning. Moreover, the notation and scenario descriptions are sometimes too concise and, in general, quite confused. As a consequence, the idea presented by the authors is quite hard to understand and it is my opinion that the paper should be rejected.

Specific comments:

- What is the "fractional association matrix"? First the authors say "At any given time a wireless station can be associated with one AP", then they say "Wireless station can associate one or more APs at the same time", what is the meaning of "associated to an AP"? Why is the association matrix "fractional"?

- Is the wireless stations traffic supposed to be periodic? I am not very sure about the definition of "load", the authors define it as a "time", is it a fraction of the AP "serving period"?

- The implementation description is not very clear. "Who" is supposed to carry out the different steps of the algorithm?


----------------------- REVIEW 4 ---------------------
PAPER: 7
TITLE: Dynamic Load Balancing Algorithm for Industrial Wireless Networks
AUTHORS: Sardor Hojiev and Dong-Seong Kim

OVERALL EVALUATION: -1 (weak reject)
REVIEWER'S CONFIDENCE: 3 (medium)

----------- REVIEW -----------
First: Please ask a native english speaking person to aid with proof-reading. Many places even the meaning can be difficult to grasp due to wrong words and strange paragraphs. But this is easy to fix though.
More important: It seems to be more or less old news. Running a periodic test on a simple measure for overload conditions, and then balancing the load, WILL improve for example throughput (which you look at).
Please consider other industrial networks. Look at different QoS standards already in place, what can they offer? What can you do with different producers ? (Bursty behaviour is likely the biggest problem, so what about that?) How is the transient situation during migration affect the worst case response times for example?
It is an interesting field to look at, I encourage the authors to keep working at it!

The paper proposes a dynamic load balancing algorithm for

the traffic is known and scheduled offline? In the 
introduction, a statement that industrial networks have 
considerable advantages of load balancing is given, together 
with a reference to [2], which seems to discuss fault 
detection using BCH codes? Why do we only consider 
throughput as metric, when delay and jitter are more 
important for industrial wireless networks? Finally, it is 
not clear what differs this work from previous work. For 
example, reference [5] seems to solve the same problem, but 
the current paper makes no attempt of explaining what the 
differences are.

Comments:
The paper suffers from several weaknesses.

Pros:
- Relevant to ETFA

Cons:
- Language is poor. There are a lot of typos and grammar
errors that make the reading unconfortable. The help of a
native English proofreader is imperative.
- The ''load'' metrics is mentioned for the first time in
the Introduction, but is defined only in Sect.2. Moreover,
the rationale behind this definition is not enough
elaborated in the paper.
- As the Authors themselves admit in the Conclusion, there
are some assumptions that limit the general validity of the
results.
- The way of choosing the threshold values is unclear.It
sounds too heuristic.
- Does the proposed approach consider the possibility of
using load balancing to make up for an AP affected by
interference? Is it able to deal with this case?
- Why in Sect. 3 is the balancing process performed every 10
seconds? There is no justification for such a choice.
- There is no mention about the generated load or any other
parameter that could be used to replicate the results of the
simulations. The claim of superiority compared to ref.[4] is
not substantiated by a thorough discussion.

Comments:
This paper addresses the dynamic load balancing problem applied to industrial 
WLAN context. More specifically it is proposed a new algorithm to do it can 
migrate stations among APs. In order to balance the load through the wireless 
network the proposed approach checks each AP’s load periodically. It uses two 
levels of thresholds to decide if each AP is overloaded or underloaded. Then, the 
underloaded APs receive the overbalance traffic from the overloaded APs that is 
distributed uniformly. Thus, the algorithm is considered as centralized.

The proposal was validate using simulation from the OPNET simulator, but the 
setup of experiment is not described in adequate depth. The results are not 
convincing and it was mentioned any details about the hand-off problem. In this 
direction, it is relevant to analyze the amount of the traffic migration demanded 
for the proposed algorithm. This can disable the proposal.

Comments: DDS is a publisher-subscriber based network middleware that proposes mechanisms for handling QoS. The problem that the authors dealt with is scalability and stability of the simple discovery protocol (SDP) of DDS, since each time a new node appears or an existing node disappears, there is a need of numerous massage exchanges. Bloom filter is a well-known probabilistic hash table mapping technique. I can lead to uniform key distribution but with a big drawback that it does not support key deletions. This is why dynamic Bloom filter has been proposed by using dynamically several Bloom filters. This paper proposes the idea to use dynamic Bloom filter to reduce the number of message exchange of SDP of DDS. Experimentation using OpenDDS has been conducted. Performance in terms of the number of UDP packets and latency is measured and compared with the native SDP and SDP using Bloom filter. The results show that SDP using dynamic Bloom filter has similar number of UDP packet than SDP using simple Bloom filter; and it reduces the latency in case of one join and one leave node per second (1.0/1.0 churn rate). The idea seems nice. However the paper suffers from several drawbacks. It lacks a comparison with the authors’ previous work using modified counting Bloom filter [ETFA2013]. In table 1, it seems that MD5 is used. But it is necessary to explain what are the five different hash functions. Only one churn rate is measured (1.0/1.0). It will be interesting to add more churn rates to see the trend (e.g. 0.5/0.5, 2.0/2.0, but also 0.5/2.0) and fully evaluate the proposal. Some acronyms are not defined: GDS, DCPS. There are many sentences that are non-sense and have grammatical errors. For instance, in the introduction section, paragraph 2 and 3. The referencing is quite strange. In particular, a scheme based on dynamic Bloom filters (DBF) is proposed to improve DDS scalability by reducing sent and stored messages in the network. A simulation approach has been carried out. A more detailed description of the mechanisms should be presented as well as a better comparison with the SDP-Bloom solution. Surely, the language in the paper needs to be improved.

Thank you for submitting your paper to IET Communications. The peer review process is now complete. My decision is therefore to decline your paper with encouragement to submit a substantially revised paper.  I appreciate that this decision will be a disappointment, but hope that you find the referees' comments (given below) useful in improving your paper.

If, following comprehensive revision, you should choose to submit your paper again, please go to http://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/iet-com. Enter the Author Centre and go to 'Manuscripts with Decisions'. Click on 'Create a Resubmission' next to the paper number and follow the instructions given.

The feasibility of central dictionary manager is in doubt. In a wireless mesh network, it is unreasonable to use a central control node, especially the network has a large scale. Dear Prof. Dong Seong Kim:

We regret to inform you that your paper #1569930503 ('Real-Time Image Transmission in Military Networks Using Bezier Curve') has not been accepted for MILCOM 2014.  Every year a large number of excellent papers are submitted to MILCOM and the competition for inclusion in the program is very stiff.

The reviews are below or can be found at http://edas.info/showPaper.php?m=1569930503, using your EDAS login name dskim@kumoh.ac.kr.

Thank you for your interest in MILCOM 2014.  We encourage you to consider future MILCOM conferences for presenting your work.

Best Regards,

William Miniscalco
MILCOM 2014 Unclassified Technical Program Chair

Peter Bocon
MILCOM 2014 Technical Program Chair

Qinqing (Christine) Zhang
MILCOM 2014 Deputy Technical Program Chair

======= Review 1 =======

> *** Technical Contribution: Rate the content based on its technical strength.
Acceptable - Valid work but limited contribution (3)

> *** Advancing Technologies / State-of-the-Art: Rate the novelty or contribution to military communications.
Some new concepts (3)

> *** Relevance and Timeliness: Rate the relevance of the topic and the importance to military communication applications.
Somewhat relevant (3)

> *** Quality of Presentation: Rate the organization and readability of the paper.
Good organization and writing (4)

> *** Accept/Reject Recommendation: Do you feel that this paper should be accepted or rejected?
Accept if room (3)

> *** Comments to Authors:: Please provide comments to the authors that explain your numerical ranking:

A reasonably interesting and relevant paper on a new method of image compression.

The compression ratio is reasonable when compared to the samples called out in the paper, however no comparison was given to the more commercial bench marks such as JPEG.  It would be reasonable to expect the author to have run the same image through the most common tools for comparisons sake.

======= Review 2 =======

> *** Technical Contribution: Rate the content based on its technical strength.
Marginal - Simple contribution with some flaws (2)

> *** Advancing Technologies / State-of-the-Art: Rate the novelty or contribution to military communications.
Little new here (2)

> *** Relevance and Timeliness: Rate the relevance of the topic and the importance to military communication applications.
Somewhat relevant (3)

> *** Quality of Presentation: Rate the organization and readability of the paper.
Needs work (2)

> *** Accept/Reject Recommendation: Do you feel that this paper should be accepted or rejected?
Reject (0)

> *** Comments to Authors:: Please provide comments to the authors that explain your numerical ranking:

The article proposes an image reconstruction method based on Bezier Curve interpolation. The aim of this method is to provide a high quality reconstruction from undersampled image data. Processing a reduced amount of data has a direct impact on the transmission energy efficiency and transmission time.

In general, the novelty of the presented approach is very limited. The authors do not suggest any modifications to the standard Bezier Curve interpolation method. Furthermore, the title ‘Real-Time Image Transmission’ is a little bit misleading, because the focus of the article is on the reconstruction performance rather than enhancements in data transmission.

The writing style further limits the comprehensibility of the entire paper. Besides grammatical weaknesses, the meaning of some sentences, like e.g. ‘Bezier curve also used for smoothing hand-writing in electronic method to make smoother’ (Section II.C.), and paragraphs, e.g. the first paragraphs of sections II and III, remains unclear.

Regarding the presented results, the evaluation lacks a thoroughly description of the test set. Does the sampling rate of 10 percent in the CS setting coincide with the amount of data used for the Bezier Curve interpolation? If the measurements for the CS based reconstruction are Fourier coefficients, what is the difference to DFT reconstruction? It seems to me, that the reconstructed images shown in Fig. 4b and 4c do not reflect the potential of sparse signal coding. Which algorithms were used here for comparison? I would suggest to first compare the proposed method with standard compression techniques like JPEG or with some simple interpolation methods. Then, one can evaluate the tradeoff between data rate, processing time and reconstruction quality. By the way, to assess the reconstruction quality given a ground truth image, quality metrics like PSNR or structural similarity might be easier to interpret for the reader.

To conclude, in my opinion this article does not have the potential for publication because of the lack of novelty and the deficiencies in the description of the evaluation.

======= Review 3 =======

> *** Technical Contribution: Rate the content based on its technical strength.
Acceptable - Valid work but limited contribution (3)

> *** Advancing Technologies / State-of-the-Art: Rate the novelty or contribution to military communications.
Little new here (2)

> *** Relevance and Timeliness: Rate the relevance of the topic and the importance to military communication applications.
Relevant (4)

> *** Quality of Presentation: Rate the organization and readability of the paper.
Organization and/or writing could be improved (3)

> *** Accept/Reject Recommendation: Do you feel that this paper should be accepted or rejected?
Accept if room (3)

> *** Comments to Authors:: Please provide comments to the authors that explain your numerical ranking:

This paper presents a technique to reconstruct images using Bezier curves. It proposes to use the interpolation property of Bezier curves to minimise errors in case of compressed sampling. The idea is interesting. However, the simulation results are only shown on 100x100 images; it would be interesting to see the performance on real High Definition data. Overall, grammar and English need to be improved.

======= Review 4 =======

Yet another paper on... (1)

Feedback from the Reviewers

Comments:
i) It is not clear why the suggested scheduling is "hybrid" 
energy-aware scheduling. Based on the introduction, my 
impression is that the suggested one is hybrid of preemptive 
and non-preemptive scheduling, but I cannot find how the 
authors combine these two in their method. ii) The detail 
algorithm/equation to solve the problem described by the 
equation (15) is not described. iii) In Section IV, the 
authors discuss more about the number of preemptions than 
the energy consumption. Thus, I am confusing what the focus 
of this paper is.

    The authors apply sound technical approaches ------------------------------------- [2 - I am neutral]
    New ideas are convincingly and logically described ------------------------------- [1 - I disagree]
    Results are convincing ----------------------------------------------------------- [1 - I disagree]
    Considering the issues above, this work should be presented  --------------------- [1 - I disagree]
    
Comments:
[notation: (page,column), where column can be (L)eft or (R)ight]

The paper presents a scheduling approach characterized by
energy-awareness and a low preemption level.
The paper has a rather poor English quality. The
presentation is often unclear, and some concepts seems to
belong to a different paper (the references to the packet
scheduling and size).
The results depicted in figures 3, 4 and 5 seems to suggest
that the proposed approach has almost the same performance
of PTS. Indeed, the performance of the two algorithms should
be more clearly compared, and the authors should better
explain the comparative results. In other words, the
simulations fail to clarify the actual benefits of the
proposed method.

In page 1, item 4 of the enumerated list, the authors say
that mutual exclusion is mediocre in non-preemptive systems.
What do you mean as "mediocre" in this case? The statement
seems misleading. A rewriting may help.

Figure 1 reports a taxonomy of scheduling algorithms
referred to packet scheduling, not task scheduling. The
figure is useless: was it included by mistake?

The paragraph after Figure 2 is quite cryptic. It should be
rewritten.

In (2,R), what is a "sporadic speed"?

In (3,L) the authors refer to the term "packet size", which
seems to be not correlated with the discussed topic.

Typos

(1,R) : inputoutput -> input/output
(2,L) : devided -> divided


C. Clarity of presentation:
    English grammar and spelling are proper ------------------------------------------ [2 - I am neutral]
    Mathematical symbols and equations are easy to understand ------------------------ [2 - I am neutral]
    Figures and tables are well constructed and informative -------------------------- [1 - I disagree]
    The paper is well organized ------------------------------------------------------ [1 - I disagree]
    Considering the issues above, the paper is readable ------------------------------ [1 - I disagree]
    
T. Technical innovation and relevance
    The authors cite other relevant publications ------------------------------------- [3 - I agree]
    Authors describe relevance of work to the research field ------------------------- [3 - I agree]
    The authors apply sound technical approaches ------------------------------------- [2 - I am neutral]
    New ideas are convincingly and logically described ------------------------------- [1 - I disagree]
    Results are convincing ----------------------------------------------------------- [1 - I disagree]
    Considering the issues above, this work should be presented  --------------------- [1 - I disagree]
    
Comments:
The paper describes a hybrid energy-aware scheduling 
algorithm based on a renewal process in real-time systems.

Despite the fact that I'm involved in real-time systems 
research for over a decade, I didn't understand the real-
time systems aspects in the paper:
- The system model mentions task priorities \rho_i, but the 
paper also addresses EDF. The paper compares EDF and PTS, 
but it is not clear how the thresholds for PTS are 
determined.
- Liu and Leyland do not consider dependent tasks, i.e. B_i 
= 0 in [12], hence [12] on p. 13 seems wrong.
- [4] discusses limited pre-emptive EDF, the equation f_i^
{(j)} = s_i^{(j)} + C_i only holds for non-pre-emptive 
execution, however.
- Why are tasks allowed to miss their deadlines (last 
paragraph on p. 3)?
- How come EDF performs so bad (compared to PTS and the 
proposed method)? Does the experiment use limited pre-
emptive EDF (from [4]) or the pre-emptive version?
- How come the energy consumption DECREASES (rather than 
INCREASES) with increased utilization? This is counter-
intuitive. Is that due to additional deadline misses?
- Add at least a graph with the number of deadline misses 
for each of the considered approaches.


C. Clarity of presentation:
    English grammar and spelling are proper ------------------------------------------ [1 - I disagree]
    Mathematical symbols and equations are easy to understand ------------------------ [1 - I disagree]
    Figures and tables are well constructed and informative -------------------------- [2 - I am neutral]
    The paper is well organized ------------------------------------------------------ [2 - I am neutral]
    Considering the issues above, the paper is readable ------------------------------ [1 - I disagree]
    
T. Technical innovation and relevance
    The authors cite other relevant publications ------------------------------------- [2 - I am neutral]
    Authors describe relevance of work to the research field ------------------------- [3 - I agree]
    The authors apply sound technical approaches ------------------------------------- [2 - I am neutral]
    New ideas are convincingly and logically described ------------------------------- [1 - I disagree]
    Results are convincing ----------------------------------------------------------- [2 - I am neutral]
    Considering the issues above, this work should be presented  --------------------- [2 - I am neutral]
    
Comments:
The paper presents an optimization method to select the
renewal length that minimizes the energy consumed of a
sporadic real-time system. The appraoch is shown to
significantly improve over EDF in terms of number of
preemptions and energy consumption, with performance
comparable to the preemption threshold scheduling scheme. 

I haven't been able to properly understand the presented
technique, due to the paper being poorly written. In
particular, it is not clear to me how does the proposed
scheduling scheme work and what are the design parameter to
select. It seems that the authors are trying to select the
optimal lengths of the ON and OFF states, which may be
mapped to a limited-preemptive scheduling scheme. But this
is not clearly explained in the paper. 

If the paper is to be accepted, I strongly suggest the
authors to clarify the contribution, model and design space
description, properly explaining how the preemptions are
reduced. 

In the experimantal section, the authors may want to compare
against a somewhat similar technique described in:
Bambagini et al. "An Energy-Aware Algorithm Exploiting
Limited Preemptive Scheduling under Fixed Priorities", SIES
2013, Porto, Portugal, June 2013.

This paper tackles a "hot topic" in underwater networks right now, which is spectrum management.  

The issue is important and timely.

> *** Weak aspects: Comments to the author: what are the weak aspects of the paper?

There are important references to existing literature in underwater cognitive networks missing.

The authors do not acknowledge or compare their work with existing work in underwater cognitive networks.  Therefore, it is difficult to know the differences and novel ideas being presented.  In fact, this paper seems to  take some information from these existing work and did not cite them!

The figures are of low quality and need to be improved.

The simulation settings are unclear and some are listed in another paper which does not make it easy for the reader to follow.  Also, some settings such as the number of nodes in such a small deployment area are not realistic.  The authors need at least a justification as to why they are using these settings.

> *** Recommended changes: Recommended changes. Please indicate any changes that should be made to the paper if accepted.

I would recommend that the authors review the existing literature, two papers of interest are listed below, and provide a discussion and comparison.  It is not clear what is new in this work without this comparison.  

I've never heard of OPNET Modeler 16.0 being used for underwater simulations, the authors should provide a brief explanation on this choice.

Dear Prof. Kim:

I write you in regards to manuscript # TII-14-0511 entitled "A DDS Node Discovery Scheme with Dynamic Bloom Filters" which you submitted to the IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics.

Much to my regret, I have to inform you that, based on the recommendation of the Associate  Editor in charge of this manuscript, the submitted manuscript has not been accepted for publication in the IEEE Transaction on Industrial Informatics. The comments  are included at the bottom of this letter.

Thank you for considering the IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics for the publication of your research.  I hope the outcome of this specific submission will not discourage you from the submission of future manuscripts. We also hope that you will still continue the support of this journal in various aspects.


Sincerely,
Dr. Mo-Yuen Chow
Editor-in-Chief
IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics
chow@ncsu.edu

******************************
**********************
Encl.:
Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
The authors proposed to use dynamic bloom filters to identify nodes for data distribution service. However, the concept of dynamic bloom filters has been reported in reference [17], the data distribution service itself is not a new issue, and the improvement of DBF in DDS over standard BF is insignificant to this reviewer even for the simplified case study. The contributiom seems insginificant to be accepted by T-II.

The paper is also subject to other issues such as the insufficent literature coverage and language issue. For example, what is 'GDS' means on the first page? 'dyynamic' should be corrected.

Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
This paper proposes an extension of the node discovery scheme in data distribution service (DDS): SDP-Dynamic Bloom, to improve DDS scalability by reducing the number of sent and stored messages in the network.

In the Introduction, it needs more analysis about the related works. For instance, what node discovery scheme methods of DDS exist in the existing researches, what is the motivation of the proposed method ...

From Section 2 to Section 4, it just introduces the DDS, SDP, and BF. Maybe it is better to reduce the proportion of these contents in the total paper.

Moreover, what is the whole flow diagram of the proposed scheme in Section 5? What are the differences between the proposed scheme and the existing scheme?

As to Section 6, the simulation and the analysis are not sufficient, so that it is lack of convincing to support the outstanding conclusions. There are just the experiments under the 0.0/0.0 and 1.0/1.0 joins/leaves ratio. What about the results under the ratio from 0.0 to 1.0?

The English of this paper can be further improved.

fields.content:
Dear Prof. Kim:

Manuscript ID TII-14-0451 entitled "Rate Adaptation Algorithm for Multicast Communication in Tactical Networks" which you submitted to the IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics, has been reviewed.  The comments  are included at the bottom of this letter.

Much to my regret, I have to inform you that, based on the recommendation of the Associate  Editor in charge of this manuscript, the submitted manuscript has not been accepted for publication in the IEEE Transaction on Industrial Informatics. However, a new manuscript may be submitted  which takes into consideration these comments.

Please note that resubmitting your manuscript does not guarantee eventual acceptance, and that your resubmission will be subject to re-review by the reviewer(s) before a decision is rendered.

You will be unable to make your revisions on the originally submitted version of your manuscript.  Instead, revise your manuscript using a word processing program and save it on your computer.

Once you have revised your manuscript, go to https://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/tii and login to your Author Center.  Click on "Manuscripts with Decisions," and then click on "Create a Resubmission" located next to the manuscript number.  Then, follow the steps for resubmitting your manuscript.

Because we are trying to facilitate timely publication of manuscripts submitted to the IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics, your revised manuscript should be uploaded as soon as possible.  If it is not possible for you to submit your revision within a reasonable amount of time, we will consider your paper as a new submission.

I look forward to a resubmission.

Sincerely,
Dr. Mo-Yuen Chow
Editor-in-Chief
IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics
chow@ncsu.edu


****************************************************
Encl.:
Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
This paper proposed a rate adaptation algorithm for multicast communication. In the case, the adopted approach is based on physical layer adaptation. More specifically, the transmitter receives information feedback from the receivers about the current communication state (RSSI and delay) then the proposed algorithm adjusts the modulation rate in order to improve the communication performance. It is important to say the proposed is addressed to IEEE 802.11 networks.

The multicast communication used in this paper starts with the transmitter sending an RTS frame, then the multicast receivers reply with synchronized CTSs. The CTS frames were modified to include information about the state of channel. So the transmitter sends its data and the receivers reply with synchronized ACKs. This is very interesting communication mechanism, but it is not a contribution of this paper.

Thus, the more interesting aspect of the proposal is strongly based on OFDMA with multicast ACK, that was proposed previously in references [18] and [19] and it was named as OMACK. It is important to note that the OMACK and the algorithm proposed here have very similar performances, as can see in results shown in Section IV.

The contributions of the paper are basically the mechanism of RSSI adaptation in transmitter (Algorithm 1) and the data retransmission mechanism (Algorithm 2). The work can be improved if the authors analyze others adaptation strategies and evaluate their performance.


Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
*Summary

This paper proposes a novel rate adaptation algorithm for multicast communications targeting tactical networks. The work combines two different parameters (RSSI and delay) to select a proper data rate and employs an OMACK technique to improve the solution's reliability and timeliness. The rate adaptation algorithm is validated by means of a comparative simulation analysis. Although the addressed issue is an important research topic of wireless communications, the presented results do not show a significant step forward in the improvement of the state of the art.

*Organization, language and written presentation:

The paper requires a significant language revision. Although it is written in a style that can be generally understood, it encompasses several repetitive sentences, typos and phrases with bad construction.

*Comments

The paper lacks a proper characterization of the requirements of tactical/military networks. The text provides several hints about how stringent such requirements are regarding transmission delays and packet errors, but they are never defined. This fact impairs the analysis of the proposed solution's effectiveness because it is not possible to verify if the obtained results are good enough to support this type of networks.

It is stated that the TCP-Friendly Multicast Congestion Control (TFMCC) protocol exhibits a good performance. However, the developed solution performance was not compared to this protocol. This protocol should be included in the comparison or a more elaborated justification to leave it out must be provided.

In Equation 6, the data packet length is constant? It is not clear and has implications on the algorithm performance. If the packet length is variable so are the processing times in the transmitter and receiver (PT_Tx and PT_Rx). How was it implemented in the simulator?

The simulation scenario must be better characterized, preferably by means of a figure where the positions of the different stations are defined. In addition, a table containing the parameter values of interest used in the simulation must also be provided.

Finally, when compared to the OMACK alternative, results show a small improvement. The causes supporting this fact should be further discussed together with possible improvements.

Some typos (not all):
{p. 2} – "Such condition result in" should be "Such condition results in"
{p. 2} – "MAC layer method use s frame/packet" should be " MAC layer method uses frame/packet"
{p. 2} – "Other studies [9] have been presented RA algorithms" should be "Other studies [9] presented RA algorithms"
{p. 3} – "and checks whether packet loss has occurred" should be " and checks whether a packet loss has occurred"
{p. 3} – "method is that that the" should be "method is that the"
{p. 5} – "to each sector, which resultings in transmission delay" should be " to each sector, which results  in transmission delay"
{p. 7} - "The proposed method offers performance compared to the dynamic-rate OMACK scheme" should be "The proposed method offers an improved performance compared to the dynamic-rate OMACK scheme"
{p. 7} - "if the retransmission of data fail," should be " if the retransmission of data fails,"

(...)

Reviewer: 3

Comments to the Author
In this paper authors present a rate adaptation algorithm for directional multicast communication in tactical networks. In particular, the proposed solution is based on the received signal strength
indicator (RSSI) and on delay constraints that are sent by receivers in the network. Some results, based on simulations, are presented to show how the proposed method can work.

The main drawback is this paper is completely out of the scope of the IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics. The title mentions “Tactical networks” and there is nothing related to industrial application or something that can be referred to.

Scope: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics focuses on knowledge-based factory automation as a means to enhance industrial fabrication and manufacturing processes. This embraces a collection of techniques that use information analysis, manipulation, and distribution to achieve higher efficiency, effectiveness, reliability, and/or security within the industrial environment. The scope of the Transaction includes reporting, defining, providing a forum for discourse, and informing its readers about the latest developments in intelligent and computer control systems, robotics, factory communications and automation, flexible manufacturing, vision systems, and data acquisition and signal processing.

Moreover, the paper is not clear: some sections don't describe well the proposed algorithms and, sometimes, strange parts are present without a reason (e.g. the weighting part in Section V). Also results are not sufficiently original compared to previous papers ([18][19]).

AE Comments:
Associate Editor
Comments to the Author:
This paper proposes a rate adaptation algorithm to improve wireless communications in tactical networks. The domain of Industrial Communications is mainly related with the transmission of information for factory automation. However, if we consider a broad sense on the “Industrial” keyword, it is in my opinion acceptable to address applications where data is retrieved from physical elements and commands are transmitted to control a process or a system. Tactical networks are, as far as I understood, used in military applications. Can these be considered Industrial? May be yes. But then a clear overview of the application, of its requirements and how the “Industrial” label can be attached to it should have been provided, what did not happen. So, even not being so strict as reviewer 3, I consider, agreeing with reviewer 2, that all the motivation to do this work, the characteristics of the applications, the requirements and so are mandatory to accept such a paper.
Besides this problem with the paper, reviewers have highlighted a significant amount of weaknesses that impair the paper publication such as the reduced incremental contribution from the OMACK work, the lack of comparison among techniques, the small difference in results, etc. I would reinforce these with some more situations:
a)      As there are no requirements, it is not possible to verify if the results are acceptable for the application.
b)      Indeed, the authors speak about reliability but they do not discuss this parameter at all during the paper. Just as an example, one easily thinks about the question of how does the application cope with the failure of transmissions to part of the nodes?
c)      The authors refer twice two methodologies to perform the rate adaptation: sequential and direct. They adopt direct. But they do not discuss nor validate the choice. No cost function or even qualitative arguments to assess/justify the validity of the choice are presented.
d)      Section IV, which should be very important, shows several problems: a poor/light/incomplete description of the simulation scenario; a superficial evaluation of the results; a confusing text in the last paragraph.
In conclusion, looking at the three revisions and at my view of the paper I believe that the adequate proposal is “Reject & Resubmit”. Of course a possible resubmission implies that a clear justification of the interest of the subject to Industrial Informatics is provided.

Hi guys,

Here are review comments of my rejected paper from IEEE Communications letter.
Hope this will be helpful for you.


Dear Author(s): 

The review of the referenced manuscript, CL2014-1717, is now complete. I regret to inform you that based on the enclosed reviews and my own reading of your manuscript, I am unable to recommend its publication in IEEE Communications Letters. 

Both reviewers have clearly indicated that the paper is poorly written. This comment applies not only to the standard of English in the paper but also to the clarity of the technical exposition; many equations and concepts are not properly explained. Also, the proposed design has not been placed in a proper relation to the related work in the literature. Finally, both reviewers have noted a lack of explanation of the role of the BCH code in the design. I agree with all of the reviewers' points. For these reasons, your paper may not be resubmitted for review. 

The reviewers' comments are found at the end of this email. 

Thank you for submitting your work to the IEEE Communications Letters. 

Regards, 
Mark Flanagan 

Editor 
IEEE Communications Letters 

Reviewer: 1 

Comments to the Author 
This manuscript presents an algorithm design for detecting faulty nodes using a Markov chain model with a three-state inference mechanism. The proposed design is evaluated with a set of simulations. The reviewer cannot recommend the acceptance of the manuscript at its current stage, for the reasons listed below. 

(1) The main design makes some sense (e.g., the state machine in Fig. 1 and the Markov-chain based probability inference), however, its connection with the BCH code is not clear. In fact, it is not covered in the design. 

(2) The background (and related work) of this paper is not clear. The presentation is not reader-friendly - some equations are not well explained. Besides, the choice of some key parameters seems ad hoc. 

(3) There are some grammar errors and writing issues. For example, "which is depends on ...", "is enhanced the reliable ...", "$\tao^{good}$ and $\tao^{warning}$ are time limit...", etc. 


Reviewer: 2 

Comments to the Author 
In my honest opinion, the letter is poorly written. 

The abstract does not clearly communicate what it should do: scenario, goal of the letter, and expected results. 

In the introduction, the scenario should be clearly introduced, e.g., what is a faulty node, what is its importance, etc. Moreover, the differences with respect to the literature should be clearly stated. 

Warning and good states are introduced without being explained. Maybe one should refer to [9], but the letter should be self-contained. 

The algorithm for faulty node detection is not clear. Where is the BCH? What has been obtained from literature and what is novel? Some of these questions need answers. 

The results are very poor and advantages with respect to the literature are questionable. A deeper analysis is needed.

Sincerely,

Nirwan Ansari, TPC Chair
Edit Kaminsky Bourgeois, TPC Vice Chair

========================

======= Review 1 =======

> *** Strong Aspects: Comments to the author: What are the strong aspects of the paper?

In this paper, the authors propose a novel communication model, which takes advantage of overhearing nodes during the forwarding process in order to improve the throughput.
In fact, a source node sends a packet to the next hop and at the same time-slot it sends other packets to its assistant nodes (overhearing nodes).  An assistant node is defined clearly in II.D.
The results obtained show that the total throughput is increased.

> *** Weak Aspects: Comments to the author: What are the weak aspects of the paper?

Hereafter, I will enumerate the main remarks:
•       The proposal is based on TDMA approach. The authors should define how the synchronization is ensured and evaluate the cost in term of energy.
•       It is not clear how many sources can be deployed at the same time and how the proposal reacts?
•       An assistant node can be assigned for different nodes at the same time. This collision is not considered in the paper. How an assistant node mange more than one node.
•       The confidence intervals of the results must be calculated.
•       If we assume a dynamic routing protocol, a next hop is not fixed. Hence, the set of assistant nodes is updated periodically with respect to the routing protocol. The authors should study the impact of updating the latter set in terms of convergence time and energy.
.

> *** Recommended Changes: Recommended changes. Please indicate any changes that should be made to the paper if accepted.

•       It is not easy to read the paper and specifically the Figures are not clear. The idea is to increase the size of figures

> *** Relevance and Timeliness: Rate the importance and timeliness of the topic addressed in the paper within its area of research.
Acceptable. (3)

> *** Technical Content and Scientific Rigour: Rate the technical content of the paper (e.g.: completeness of the analysis or simulation study, thoroughness of the treatise, accuracy of the models, etc.), its soundness and scientific rigour.
Marginal work and simple contribution. Some flaws. (2)
