fields.subject: Agi - Journal of Parallel and Distributed Computing
fields.content:
Manuscript Number: JPDC-14-21
Title: Faulty Node Detection with Interval Weighting Factor for Distributed Networked Systems
Corresponding Author: Prof. Dong-Seong Kim
All Manuscript Authors: Agi Prasetiadi, M.Eng; Dong-Seong Kim, Ph.D 
----------------------------------

Dear Prof. Kim,

I am sorry to say that I am following the recommendation of the Associate Editor assigned to your paper and we are rejecting your manuscript for publication in Journal of Parallel and Distributed Computing.  At the bottom of this email please find comments from the reviewers.  We hope that their comments will help you in your future endeavors.

While you may be disappointed by this decision, I would like to urge you to continue to consider Journal of Parallel and Distributed Computing for publication of future manuscripts.

Sincerely,

Sanjay Ranka, PhD
Editor
Journal of Parallel and Distributed Computing

***********************
Reviewers' comments:

Reviewer #1: 1. Summary of Review

The paper---an extended version of  a short communication published in
IEEE Communications  Letters, 17:620-623, 2013---presents  a mechanism
based on the  combined use of CRC  and BCH codes to enable  nodes of a
distributed networked control  system to detect the failure  of one or
more of their peers. The failure  detector proposed is based on a very
simple ideia:  all nodes of  the distributed networked  control system
iteratively compute BCH codes from exactly  the same input, say D.  At
the initialization of the system,  a master node broadcasts the initial
value of D  to all nodes.  Each  node computes a BCH code  for D, lets
call  it BCH(D),  and  sends  back to  the  master  a different  1-bit
fragment  of  BCH(D).   The   master  collects  the  1-bit  fragments,
reassembles BCH(D).   The error  detecting information  obtained after
de-fragmentation and extra  information coming from the CRC  is used to
implement the  failure detection.  Failure  detection is based  on the
statistical characterization of the  patterns of errors collected from
the reassembled  BCH codes and CRC  codes. An important aspect  of the
proposed solution  is that one of  the CRC bits is  substituted by the
1-bit BCH  fragment. Substitution of  a CRC bit  by a BCH  bit implies
that the CRC code's ability  to detect errors is weakened.  Simulation
has been used to assess the  effectiveness of the failure detector and
the effect  of the 1-bit  BCH piggybacking onto  the CRC field  of the
frame.  The  results presented are  very initial but seem  to indicate
that  the  proposed  failure  detection  mechanism  works.   The  main
contribution  of  the   paper  is  the  proposition   of  the  BCH-CRC
combination and its use to create an statiscaly characterized failure
detector able  to check  communication and  node failures  via pattern
matching.  The weaknesses of the paper  are (i) the master is a single
point of  failure, (ii)  the implementation  of the  solution requires
changes to the link layer protocol, (iii) related work is missing, and
(iv)  the  rationale behind  the  analysis  of  the patterns  used  to
classify a node  as correct or failed require  better explanation, and
(v) the writing must be thoroughly  revised. 

2. Detailed Analysis

Related work. Analysis of related work is missing.  The paper does not
include a section on related work. This is a major problem as it makes
very difficult  to any reader  to localize the paper's  results within
any of the research areas it touches. It its main contribution related
with failure detection or with error detection/correction in controller
area  networks? Is  the result  more  relevant to  the researchers  in
instrumentation  and  measurement?   It  is the  assessment  of  this
referee that the  paper is very much tilted  towards low-level network
and communications instead of parallel and distributed systems.  Thus,
a well-written related work section is a mandatory requirement for the
improvement of the paper.

The motivation  for the work is  very poorly argued as  the authors do
not  present any  typical reliability  data for  any of  the networked
systems mentioned  to support the need  for an extra level  of failure
detection.  The  assumptions  regarding  synchrony  of  processes  and
network channels also lack evidence. 

Sections 2.1  and 2.2 can be  much summarized as their  content can be
found in almost any textbook on error control coding.

What are  the possible  failures for  the environment  considered?  Do
nodes experience permanent failures?  Transient failures? What are the
possible timing faults?

lines 156-158: BCH codes are generated as pseudo-code? 

line   164-165:   The  BCH   fragmentation-de-fragmentation   mechanism
interferes with the  CRC code computation at the link  layer.  Is this
really needed?  Could the mechanism  could have been implemented  at a
higher level? Why  haven't the authors made a case  for the link layer
piggybacking of the 1-bit fragments?

line 179: Can you define quantitatively "sufficient sampling."?

Figure 4: time unit? 

Figure 7:  The superposition of  the different patterns in  one figure
makes it difficult  to visualize and correlate  the different patterns
to correct or faulty behavior. Axes lack units.

Section  4.2   needs  a  major   rewriting  to  make   it  technically
clearer.  What  are  the  time  intervals  considered?   What  is  the
frequency of sampling? Every frame received? Every two frames? 

line 379: Simulation environment and parameters need completion. What
was the simulation tool used to simulate the system? What was the load
used to generate the frames and  to inject faults? How were the faults
injected in the frames (CRC, BCH)? How many simulations were executed?
What was  the fault coverage of  the simulations both in  terms of the
CRC and BCH accuracy? SNR isn't defined (signal to noise ratio). 

Figure 8:  The discussion of  the results  presented in Figure  8 need
further clarification/discussion. It is not clear how the mis-detection
rate is  related with the  fault judgement criteria  presented earlier
(section 4).

line 395:  "In CRC  case, faulty  nodes are pointed  out based  on the
errors  are   mostly  occur  on   certain  node"  Sentence   is  badly
constructed, rephrase.

Figure 9  Characterization of  the results and  analysis is  poor. The
node whose  communication latencies vary  defines the base  SNR level?
This is not clear from the text.

line  415:  "This misdetection  behavior  can  be avoided  further  if
another filter is applied in the node detection scheme." 

Section 5.2 should include a  better analysis of the faulty behaviors
with better  discussion of  the pattern  matching and  judgement. Once
again, the details  of how the simulation has been  carried out should
be included.

3. Organization and clarity

The  paper is  not  well  organized and  English  is  very poor.   The
technical quality of the paper can  be much improved by: (i) inclusion
of  related  work (ii)  creation  of  a  summary  of all  the  factors
(components) that are used as input for the computation of the results
used  to  assess the  correctness  or  faultiness  of a  node.   (iii)
Quantification  of  the  time   intervals,  sampling  frequencies  and
synchronization  parameters  used  to  create  the  simulation.   (iv)
detailed description of  how the simulation has been  carried out: how
was the raw data generated? 

Examples of poorly written sentences are:

"The CRC code identifies data correctness RECEIVED by the RECEIVER by
calculating the message syndrome."  "However, CRC calculation is based
on  the assumption  that the  node will  always calculate  the message
correctly." This  sentence is  misleading, cyclic redundancy  codes do
not  assume anything  about possible  failures in  the circuitry  that
computes  the   CRC.  Systems  implement  several   failure  detection
mechanisms at different levels, so that  if a failure is not detect at
a  lower level  it can  be detected  at a  higher level.   "This study
considers the effects  of node reliability in a  distributed manner by
predicting the  area in which  an error can frequently  occur."  Area?
what is the precise meaning of AREA here?

line 19:  CRC only guarantees  that the link  layer is able  to detect
errors not the whole system.

line 25: predicting? The solution detects, it does not predict.

line  35:  "Regarding  real  time applications,  sporadic  data  react
unexpected event." What are you trying to convey with this sentence?

lines 69-70: "However, the BCH code  as faulty nodes detector works in
the  sense of  parallel  frameworks."  What do  you  mean by  parallel
frameworks?
line 73: "semi-parallel approach"? What is a semi-parallel system?

line 181-183: "In this case, this paper suggest the data refinement is
supported by outside factor of BCH code."

line  220: "This  error interval  is the  main interest  of the  data
interpretation  of BCH  insertion code  result." Sentence  needs major
rewriting.

line 221: Therefore, one can easily assumed that if the error interval
becomes shorter  time by  time, the  suspected note  can be  judged as
promising faulty nodes." Rewrite.

line 291: patter -> pattern.




Reviewer #2: The paper proposes using a BCH code in addition to regular CRC codes inserted in the messages as a way to separate node failures from communication failures. According to the authors, using such codes would enable early detection of problems, including performance problems.

The contribution is not clear. There is no comparison to related work. It is also difficult to see why this approach is better then trivial approaches for detecting performance faults (e.g., watchdogs or even simple periodic heartbeats). If the paper assumes specific scenarios in fieldbus networks, this is not clear.

The paper needs considerable rewriting, for example:

- Figure 1 should represent the key argument for motivating the paper, but it is not well explained and seems to add little information.

- Figure 6 legend is "Something about filtering process"





Reviewer #3: The paper addresses the problem of faulty node detection in distributed networked systems.
The detection is performed by inserting redundant informations (CRC and BCH code) in each message transmitted.
An algorithm is provided together with an experimental evaluation.

I have the following issues with the paper:

- The paper is hard to follow due to typos and unclear sentences. A proof-read is necessary.

- There is no clear specification of the system design and the system model section is a bit obscure. I did not understand the following:
    (i) which type of failures the authors are tackling, e.g. process crash? channel down? message loss? value faults?
    (ii) synchrony assumption in the network e.g. synchronous system or asynchronous? Mostly synchronous? 
    (iii) network topology or system configuration e.g. are all the nodes connected? there is a well defined topology?
Looking to Figure 2 I can assume that there should be some hierarchical structure but I do not understand if this is a logical structure or a physical one and if it is permanent or not.

- Some crucial concept are not introduced before being used. Therefore, a reader, that is not completely confident with the subject, is not able to understand. As an example, the authors speak about CRC and BCH from the introduction without explaining that this are two coding techniques, they talk about CAN and Fieldbus without providing hints on the systems. This restricts a lot the set of readers that can understand the paper.

- It is not clear to me which type of guarantees the solution is able to provide in terms of detection. Usually, when dealing with failures, Completeness and Accuracy of the detection should be specified. In other words, are you able to eventually detect any real failure? are you accurate in the detection? This is not clear.

- The simulation environment is not clear making difficult to really understand the goodness of the results. In addition, some plots are not readable (Figure 11) or confusing (Figure 9).

- A related work section is missing. This makes impossible to assess the contribution, novelty and originality of the work, especially considering that there exists a huge literature about failure detection in distributed systems.

fields.content:
Relevance
   3: Little relevance
The paper studies cooperative relaying in wireless networks that is indeed a relevant field of research. However the paper' proposal need some work to be understood (some comments are provided below).
________________________________________
Novelty
   2: Derivative
Authors should consider to review Prof. Robert Schober's (to name an example) works about buffer-aided relay networks. This is not actually the same, but very related. This work exploits diversity and properties of wireless communications to increase throughput and reduce delay, that are also the goals of Prof. Rober Schober's works. Practical demonstrations of the benefits of buffer-aided relaying has been also recently presented in a simple scenario: “Link-Aware Opportunistic D2D Communications: Open Source Test-bed and Experimental Insights into their Energy, Capacity and QoS Benefits”.
________________________________________
Contribution
   2: Minor contribution
The paper proposal is not correctly explained. The authors need to clarify some issues pointed out below.
________________________________________
Presentation
   2: Needs work
The paper follows the template and the presentation is in general correct (some work could be also done in trying to clarify explanations), but the English needs to be improved. Figures could also be improved by reducing the number of markers.
________________________________________
Recommendation
   2: Reject
Only accept if there is room. Authors needs to clarify some basic principles of their proposal and improve explanations, English and presentation.
________________________________________
Comments
Abstract needs to be improved. This is not clear how the proposal works based on the text provided in the abstract. Please also consider the use of precursor and succesor when you refer to next-hops nodes and previous-hops nodes. 
Authors need to clarify the differences between helper node, cooperative node and relay node, since they claim they do not have the same functionalities. 
In the system model section there are many parameters that need to be introduced.
In the assistant node selection section, authors claim that an assistant node has to satisfy the condition to have the "greater SNR per link from the source". In a practical setting, how will the neighbouring nodes know the SNR of other stations?
In the cooperative relaying scheme, authors needs to clarify how the proposed scheme avoids the collision of the ACK transmitted by A1 and A2 if they transmit it at the same time.
Authors need to justify that the considered conditions: 100 nodes with radio range of 30Km can be found in real scenarios. 
Actually, the scenario seems to be 30x30Km2 and then Source and Destination are likely to communicate without the help of any relay or assistant station. 
They should also demonstrate if any system dedicated to public safety satisfies the radio parameters (packet size, slot duration, etc.)
Relevance
   4: Good match
________________________________________
Novelty
   3: Incremental
________________________________________
Contribution
   3: Worthwhile contribution
________________________________________
Presentation
   2: Needs work
Many editorial and language flaws. 
1. in eq.1 phi is not explained and dashed gamma used in description is not present 
2. Algorithm 1 seems to be incorrect or incomplete. In the case when SNR thresholds are not met for the first iteration the considered node is also added to the assistant nodes set. There is no justification to this in the text. Why should there always be at least one assistant node? 
3. eq.3 is invalid pi cannot be equal to pi times P. 
4. P subscript gamma is not sufficiently explained. Why the p.d.f of P follows an exponential distribution? 
5. Level of detail in the description of simulation scenarios is insufficient. Three simulations are mentioned but no information of how many packets were considered is given.
________________________________________
Recommendation
   2: Reject
This paper is of poor quality and requires a lot of work.
Relevance
   5: Perfect match
This work is well suited for this conference.
________________________________________
Novelty
   2: Derivative
All concepts presented in this paper are based in previuos works. However, authors presents a novel efficient relay scheme for tactical multi-hop wireless network (TMWN).
________________________________________
Contribution
   4: Solid work
Authors presents a valuable contribution in order to enhance the number of relayed packets 
for tactical wireless network.
________________________________________
Presentation
   4: Clear
This work is very well written.
________________________________________
Recommendation
   4: Accept
Without doubt, this work should be accepted.

fields.content:
Review scores
Relevance
2: Barely related
The paper addressed a topic that is highly studied in the literature, which is the routing in MANETs. Anyway, this is a hot topic yet that requires additional research. The paper addresses routing overhead by adding GPS information in the RREQ messages. This is not a novelty, and the authors need to justify whether this information would be also valid in high mobility scenarios. In addition, the paper needs to justify whether the way they propose to get the location of the destination is really efficient (the RREQ needs to be spread through the entire scenario)

Novelty
3: Incremental
The paper may benefit from the discussion with other routing protocol proposed in the literature. For example the papers presented at 
"Y.Ko and H. Vaidya, “Location-Aided Routing (LAR) in mobile ad hoc networks”, in Wireless Networks, Vol. 6, No. 4, pp. 307-321 , 2000." and 
"B. Coll and J. Gozalvez, "Energy Efficient Routing Protocols for Multi-Hop Cellular Networks", Proceedings of the 20th IEEE Personal, Indoor and Mobile Radio Communications Symposium (PIMRC'09), 13-16 September 2009, Tokyo (Japan). " 
that exploit location to reduce signaling load/routing overhead and increase energy-efficiency in different scenarios.

Contribution
2: Minor contribution
The paper contribution may be incremented if the authors discuss how this work differenciate from related work (in addition to those already included in the paper).

Presentation
4: Clear
The paper is in general clear and easy to follow. Some work is needed to revise English.

Recommendation
3: Possible accept
The paper might be accepted. From this reviewer opinion, the contribution is incremental and the paper could benefit if further discussion with prior works (as the ones indicated above) is conducted.

Review scores
Relevance
 4: Good match
Novelty
3: Incremental
Contribution
3: Worthwhile contribution
Presentation
4: Clear
Recommendation
3: Possible accept
Comments
I have done a completed revision of “Location Aided Zone Routing Protocol in Mobile Adhoc Networks”. This paper proposes the use of geographical information to limit the area for discovering a new route presenting a better performance in terms of routing overhead and end-to-end delay. 
Regarding this article, some points are written below that could help authors to improve the article.

1- No confidence intervals have been shown in Figures 3, 4, 5 and 6. It is important to show them.

2- A comparison between LAZRP with SBZRP and TZRP (Both SBZRP and TZRP are created to reduce useless control packets in ZRP as well) could give us an idea if the new algorithm proposed by authors is not only better than ZRP but is also better than the previous ones (SBZRP, TZRP) that are specially created for the same purpose, otherwise, we are not being fair in our comparison.

3- How this modification made by authors could affect the packet losses? (In case it affects) 
For example, authors should plot a graph that shows the packet losses against number of nodes using LAZRP and ZRP.

4- It is important to demonstrate how both conditions of the straight line d are reflected in the equation (1) as well as inequation 3 is not well explained.

5- In references, NS2 and bonnmotion are not referenced knowing that both of them are used as network simulator and movement generator respectively by authors to make their simulations.

Review scores
Relevance
3: Little relevance
Novelty
2: Derivative
Contribution
2: Minor contribution
Presentation
2: Needs work
Recommendation
3: Possible accept
Comments
Following issues should be handled in final manuscript: 
(1) The authors should do more about literature surveys. In location-based systems, the authors should look at topology control algorithms, GPS-based or GPS-free mechanisms, and so forth. 
(2) The authors should perform more intensive simulation-based comparison with related contributions. 
(3) The authors should improve the English representation.

Review scores
Relevance
4: Good match
Novelty
3: Incremental
The authors make propose LAZRP, a routing protocol for Manets which is based on ZRP, while takiing into account location information.

Contribution
2: Minor contribution
The authors present a protocol that intends to enhance the performance of ZRP (by ensuring less overhead for route discovery). The protocol operation proposes to use the location information of destination. The operation of the protocol is based on the assumption that " 1) the opposite side with destination D is non-rebordercasting side and 2) the side with destination D is rebordercasting side". However, even if a "side" is geographically closer to destination, that does not guarantee that a route exists in that direction at every stage. 
The operation of the protocol is not mathematically sound. In fact, no analytic proof was given for the convergence of the protocol.

Presentation
2: Needs work
The figures are too small, and therefore hardly readable. Many typos need to be corrected. Also many sentences are not grammatically correct. Ex. "In this stage, rather than 
blindly broadcasting RREQ packets, ZRP using bordercating, which allows the RREQ packets to be directly transferred to peripheral nodes."

Recommendation
2: Reject

fields.content:
Dear Prof. Kim:

Manuscript ID JCN14-DIV2-152 entitled "BEE: Bee-Inspired Algorithm for Zone Radius Determination in Independent Zone Routing Protocol for Mobile Ad Hoc Networks" which you submitted to the Journal of Communications and Networks, has been reviewed.  The comments of the reviewers are included at the bottom of this letter.

The reviewers have suggested some major revisions to your manuscript.  Therefore, I invite you to respond to the reviewers' comments and revise your manuscript.

To revise your manuscript, log into https://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/jcommnet and enter your Author Center, where you will find your manuscript title listed under "Manuscripts with Decisions."  Under "Actions," click on "Create a Revision."  Your manuscript number has been appended to denote a revision.

You may also click the below link to start the revision process (or continue the process if you have already started your revision) for your manuscript. If you use the below link you will not be required to login to ScholarOne Manuscripts.

https://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/jcommnet?URL_MASK=1c07d1c95f6e42c49e1fdfaf1c789a7b

You will be unable to make your revisions on the originally submitted version of the manuscript.  Instead, revise your manuscript using a word processing program and save it on your computer.  Please also highlight the changes to your manuscript within the document by using the track changes mode in MS Word or by using bold or colored text.

Once the revised manuscript is prepared, you can upload it and submit it through your Author Center.

When submitting your revised manuscript, you will be able to respond to the comments made by the reviewer(s) in the space provided.  You can use this space to document any changes you make to the original manuscript.  In order to expedite the processing of the revised manuscript, please be as specific as possible in your response to the reviewer(s).

IMPORTANT:  Your original files are available to you when you upload your revised manuscript.  Please delete any redundant files before completing the submission.

Because we are trying to facilitate timely publication of manuscripts submitted to the Journal of Communications and Networks, your revised manuscript should be uploaded as soon as possible.  If it is not possible for you to submit your revision within three months, we will have to consider your paper as a new submission.

Once again, thank you for submitting your manuscript to the Journal of Communications and Networks and I look forward to receiving your revision.

URL: http://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/jcommnet

Sincerely,

Dr. Jalel Ben-Othman
Editor, Journal of Communications and Networks jalel.ben-othman@univ-paris13.fr

Reviewer(s)' Comments to Author:

Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
Though I have liked the presentation of the paper, my concern is that the authors have a previous conference paper on the same issue. It's not clear to me what aspect in the concept has been advanced in this journal version. It is perfectly okay to make a journal version but the difference should be at least 30% or more. No clear explanation is available on this point; hence, I like to know where the improvements have been done and what are the differences with this paper?:

Tung Thanh Le, Do Duy Tan, and Dong-Sung Kim, "Zone routing determination for IZRP based on bee-inspired algorithm", 2012 15th International Conference on Information Fusion (FUSION), 9-12 July 2012, pp. 750 - 756.

Only one statement is found, "Compared to the previous work in [10], which has been demonstrated the effectiveness of computational time of the proposed algorithm, this extended paper shows the efficiency of the proposed algorithm in terms of convergence time2 since it is better than the IZRP algorithm."

But, this is not enough or more explanations are needed.

Minor revision.

Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
- In the whole manuscript, the term "optimal" is used carelessly. The proposed algorithm for radius determination is a meta-heuristic, so there is no guarantee that any optimal radius can be found. Moreover, the authors have not provided the mathematical formulation of the optimization problem for which they have proposed a meta-heuristic approach (ABC).

- Description of the algorithms (1, 2, and 3) are very unclear. Inputs are not explained in detail. Notations are not defined properly, for example in Table 1, parameters with different indices are introduced while in their definition the index is not mentioned (what are i and j in L_ij ?).
- In equation (2), k is not specified.
- Parameter setting of the simulations are not given. For example, what is the impact of MCN on the algorithm performance?
- In section II-B, it i stated that a "protocol" is convex function of zone radius. It should be protocol traffic.
- Is the theoretical finding in section II-B (equations (4) and (5)) about the difference in computation time of the two methods supported by the simulations results in section III?
- Figures 4 and 7 need legend to be understandable.
- English of Section III needs improvement (e.g. "the network performance is performed ...").
- In section III-A, what is meant by the assumption that all nodes are connected? Are they all assumed to be in the direct transmission range of each other?


Reviewer: 3

Comments to the Author
Authors have proposed a Bee nature inspired algorithm for Zone Radius Determination in Independent Zone Routing Protocol for Mobile Ad Hoc Networks.
The authors have claimed and demonstrated the results to be useful for further implementation of MANET.  The proposed algorithm is able to find out the optimal route from their hives to nectar sites but in the simulation.
How the proposed bee can be incorporated in any MANET route discovery protocol? What are the hardware parameters that authors should discuss in the paper?
Also, how the calibration is achieved on a real transport and routing protocol is not very much clear from the paper. Authors should also discuss real energy consumption or efficiency in the paper.
The quality of the English language still could be improved. The population generation n=Z(ρ); need further explanation with respect to real traffic in MANET along with distribution pattern.
Most of the papers cited are around 2010-2012. Update the references.

fields.content:
Dear Prof. Kim:

Thank you for submitting your manuscript Paper-TW-Feb-15-0259, titled "Efficient Cooperative Relaying Selection Scheme based on TDMA for Military Tactical Multi hop Wireless Network," for possible publication in the IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications.

Your manuscript has been reviewed by the Executive Editorial Committee and Editor-in-Chief, and we have come to the joint conclusion that your manuscript is not appropriate for publication in the Transactions for the following reasons:

- Insufficient novelty
- Incremental work

Specifically, this work investigates cooperative relaying in a multi-hop setting. The contribution is limited since the system model considered is over simplified in a tactical network setting. For instance, mobility is ignored, multi path fading is ignored, no interference between nodes. Moreover, the analytical results provided are not novel and is mainly simulation results-based. As a result, your manuscript will not be further considered for publication.

We are sorry for not being able to bring you better news, and we look forward to other possible contributions from you in the future.

Thank you again for considering our journal.

URL: http://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/twc

Sincerely,
Jeffrey G. Andrews

Dear Prof. Kim:

I write you in regard to manuscript # TNET-2015-00063 entitled "Geographical Awareness Hybrid Routing Protocol in Mobile Ad Hoc Networks" which you submitted to the IEEE/ACM Transactions on Networking.  Your manuscript will not be published in the IEEE/ACM Transactions on Networking for the following reasons:

All papers submitted to our journal undergo a first assessment to determine their overall suitability to our journal. This is meant as a mechanism to streamline the editorial process and provide quick feedback to authors so that they can send their papers to alternate venues without incurring excessive delays. Unfortunately, as a result of this assessment, I have to regretfully inform you that your paper has been rejected for publication in the journal.  The main reason is that it does not contain significantly novel technical results that would be of interest to our readers.  You may want to consult prior issues of the journal to get an idea of the contributions that are typically accepted for publication in our journal. While this is not required, papers submitted to ToN are often submitted previously to a leading conference, and reviews from the conference may provide useful feedback which can be used to improve the quality of the paper before submission to ToN.

Thank you for considering the IEEE/ACM Transactions on Networking for the publication of your research.  I hope the outcome of this specific submission will not discourage you from the submission of future manuscripts.

Sincerely,
Associate Editor, IEEE/ACM Transactions on Networking

fields.content:
Dear Mr. Tran, 

I am writing to you concerning the above referenced manuscript, which you submitted to the IEEE Sensors Journal. 

This manuscript has been rejected at the discretion of the editor prior to being sent for full review. 

If you have any questions regarding this decision, please contact me directly. 

Thank you for considering IEEE Sensors Journal for publication of your work. 

Sincerely, 

Prof. Kiseon Kim 
kskim@gist.ac.kr 

https://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/sensors 

Reviewer: 1 

Comments to the Author 
The paper considers an adaptive spectrum handoff scheme based on proactive spectrum sensing (PSS). In the proposed scheme, each secondary user (SU) identifies a primary-user receiver (PR) with coexistence terminal or hidden terminal. If the PR is a coexistence terminal, the SU can continue his/her communication without vacating the wireless channel currently used. If the PR is determined as a hidden terminal, the SU vacates the channel and tries to find another wireless channel by spectrum handoff. In order to process the spectrum handoff, the authors also propose the efficient recovery spectrum handoff (ERSH) algorithm, which consists of a handshaking process, the construction of channel hopping sequence, and spectrum handoff channel allocation. The performance of the proposed scheme is investigated by Matlab-based simulation. 

The idea of the PR classification is interesting and may be novel. However, the technical presentation of the paper does not meet the quality of a technical journal paper. The followings are some of problems of the paper. 
(1)	In Introduction section, the background of cognitive radio (CR) technologies are presented, however, these are well known aspects of CR technologies and not informative. The authors should describe the background of CR technologies as concisely as possible. 
(2)	There are many grammatical mistakes and typos. There are also several redundant expressions. The quality of English is not satisfied for a technical paper. 
(3)	In Section III, A. network model, the authors assume that a channel quality varies according to an ON-OFF process, where the ON/OFF period follows an exponential distribution. However, this assumption is not used in the following sections. Where is the ON-OFF channel model used? Simulation experiments? Channel estimation algorithm? 
(4)	In Section IV, mathematical presentations are problematic. 
-	Time epochs t_1, t_2, and t_3 in equations (4) and (5) are not defined. 
-	The energy of the signal is defined in (4) and (5) with notations X_1 and X_2. In (6), however, E_1 and E_2 are newly introduced. Is X_i the same as E_i for i=1 and 2? 
-	What are C_1 and C_2 in (7)? What is the definition of \theta_i? 
As a result, it is hard to understand what subsection A describes. 
(5)	In p. 5, left column, line numbers 44 and 47: 
Line numbers 20 and 21 of Algorithm 1 are referred to without mentioning Algorithm 1. 
(6)	In p. 5, left column, (3) BCI update, step 2: 
The authors mentioned a random access protocol for broadcasting a list of spectrum handoff channel candidates. In general, the random access protocol for broadcasting causes a delay for packet transmission, degrading the throughput. Therefore, the authors should present the details of the random access protocol, discussing how the performance of the proposed scheme is affected by the random access protocol. 
(7)	Fig. 4 represents an example of ERSH algorithm, however, it is not clear what Fig. 4 shows. The explanation of 3) Spectrum handoff channel allocation is also unreadable. 
(8)	In handshaking procedure of the ERSH algorithm, an SU generates a beacon with random backoff time. This is also overhead of the proposed scheme, however, this overhead is not discussed in numerical examples section. 
(9)	In construction of the channel hopping sequence, the authors consider the channel hopping sequence, however, no summary is presented. Why the details of the channel hopping sequence are out of scope of the paper? 
(10)	In Section V, Simulation, how do the authors determine parameter values in Table I? 
(11)	In simulation experiments, the behavior of PUs is not explained. Because the performance of the proposed algorithm significantly depends on the PU activity, the authors should explain how PUs behave during simulation. Is ON-OFF process is used for PU activity? 
(12)	Figure 5 shows all the four schemes, however, one of counterpart schemes is lacked in Figs. 6 to 8. 
Figure 6: no result for ProSpect. 
Figure 7: no result for Prospect. 
Figure 8: no result for Greedy channel selection. 
The effectiveness of the proposed scheme claimed in conclusion cannot be confirmed due to the lack of results in the figures.

Review:	The paper describes a spectrum sharing technique for UWB systems. Though the contents and result of the paper seem correct, the paper lack direct relevance to the theme of the conference. The introduction lack a direct connection between factory communication systems and how the proposed solution might fit into it. Moreover, the problem statement is not streamlined and it has been hard to find the problem hidden onto the second page.
The authors have shown that the two prevalent schemes are active or reactive for handoff in state of the art , but at the end the solution of this work uses the signal strength itself as an indicator for handoff. This makes the contribution of the paper more diluted. A rewrite of introduction section and a concise problem statement can go a long way in presenting the actual contribution of the paper.

Review 2:
Overall evaluation:	2: (accept)
Reviewer's confidence:	3: (medium)
Reviewer's confidence:	3: (medium)
Review:	The WiP proposes an algorithm to use the spectrum handoff efficiently in Cognitive UWB context. The problem and the proposed approach are explained adequately. The simulation results indicate that the proposal is promising.

Review 3:
Overall evaluation:	-1: (weak reject)
Reviewer's confidence:	2: (low)
Reviewer's confidence:	2: (low)
Review:	The paper describes a method to share the spectrum between licensed and secondary users, so that the second ones can re-use the spectrum not used by the first ones without penalizing them. The method is based on channel state estimation (two-state Markov chain) and sensing. When secondary nodes nodes detect that the spectrum band in use is not free they carry out an hand-off procedure.
In addition to describe the methods proposed, the paper has simulation results that evaluate spectrum bandwidth efficiency and hand-off delay.
The structure of the paper has deficiencies, making it hard to figure out properly the exact problem addressed by the authors. It also has several concepts that are not properly introduced, making the paper non-self-contained. This is particularly noticeable in section II.B.
The relevance of the contribution to the WFCS scope is also not clearly established.
There are some parts of the proposed method that are not properly justified on the text. E.g., in the flowchart of figure 3, it is not explained why Ns is limited to 5. The selection of the reward function is also not properly justified.

Review 4:
Overall evaluation:	-1: (weak reject)
Reviewer's confidence:	3: (medium)
Reviewer's confidence:	3: (medium)
Review:	This paper discusses an algorithm for spectrum handoff in cognitive radio.
The paper is not clearly a WIP in the sense we understand the concept. It is a closed work that includes simulation results. The paper seems a reduced version of a longer one with a too summarized presentation of most of the aspects which makes it hard to read and, in consequence, difficult to evaluate. 
The previous considerations apply to all the paper. The paper doesn’t show the motivation to conceive the algorithm. The upgrade to the state of the art is not clear. The system model is not adequately defined and “the synchronous slot structure” (TDMA?) is not defined and as we imagine it, it seems too friendly for the applications. In section III, the spectrum sensing is not properly analyzed and is not very clearly described. Subsection B is also quite unclear and conditions such E1=E2 are quite unrealistic. A1 and A2 are first defined as integers and then as sets of channels! The “network is in state j” is also not explained. The algorithm description in subsection D is also not clear and some figures are left unexplained (maximum number of sensing actions = 5).
Finally, I couldn’t understand how the authors sustain the statement in the abstract that the “proposed … algorithm significantly outstrips the existing … schemes” when no comparison is presented in the simulation results. Worse than that is that no intention is stated in the conclusions to do so in the future which would be understandable in a WIP paper. 
I also consider not adequate to state in the conclusion that “the … scheme can be easily implemented on existing devices …” without having discussed this point during the paper.

Review comments:

Review 1:
Overall evaluation:-2: (reject)
Reviewer's confidence:4: (high)
The paper focuses on the topic of routing protocols for MANETs.
In particular the author focuses on an algorithm LAZRP, a location--aided
variant of ZRP.

The paper contains some interesting hints. However in my opinion this work 
is totally out of the scopes of the conference, and does not take into account in any way
the typical issues, assumptions, scenarios and performance indices of factory communication systems.

Indeed, the Section III contains the description of the experimental setup, and it appears immediately clear that the paper has been conceived for a general wireless communication audience. In fact, the simulation parameters make a little sense in an industrial scenario, as well as the performance indices considered should have been much better detailed and contextualized in a typical industrial application.

For this reason, I think that the paper does not add any advancement to the knowledge in factory communication systems field.


Minor comments:

- labels on figures' axes
- measurement units
- simulation parameters

Review 2:
Overall evaluation:-1: (weak reject)
Reviewer's confidence:4: (high)
This paper has a few issues that indicate that the authors have not yet done sufficient homework.

When ZRP asks all peripheral nodes to disseminate a route request, it can be guaranteed (except for message losses) that the request will reach the destination and a path will be set up. However, if just a few peripheral nodes disseminate the route request, it is possible that the destination is unreachable through those nodes (the only path could be through one of the other peripheral nodes). This has not even been acknowledge. To detect this in simulations it is important to consider zones of no communication and longer paths.

Another aspect is that the results that are shown seem to be more influenced by network saturation, which affects equally both approaches, than the true difference among the approaches under normal network conditions. In fact, under normal load conditions, the difference is very small.

Finally, equations 1-3 are trivial, so as algorithm 1, and should not be in the paper...

Review 3:
Overall evaluation:1: (weak accept)
Reviewer's confidence:4: (high)
The paper proposes a method to improve the zone routing protocol (ZRP) when used in MANETs so that it generates less overhead by utilizing location information. The addressed problem is clearly defined, as is the related work. The proposed solution is adequately evaluated, considering the normalized routing overhead and the end-to-end delay, and the applicability of the solution is well explained. However, the grammar of the paper must be improved considerably. Also note that abbreviations defined in the abstract, need to be defined again in the introduction. Do not use the heading Acknowledgement if you have nothing to write there.

COMMENTS FOR THE AUTHOR:

********

Reviewer #1: This paper proposes a zone-based routing protocol, called Geographical Aware ZRP, by extending the ZRP scheme with the cluster management. The proposed scheme consists of Intra-zone (IARP) and Inter-zone (IERP) routing algorithms. IARP provides local zone discovery while global route discovery is operated with IERP. The hybrid routing scheme intends to enhance network performances in terms of routing overhead and end-to-end delay.

This version of the manuscript could not be recommanded for publishing in the WINE due to the following comments.
1. A number of researches had been investigated for mobile routing. For examples,
(1) Cluster-based routing.
(2) Hierarchical management for routing.
(2) Geo-routing.
The authors are encouraged to refer above previous works in Introduction.
2. It would be nice if the authors provide a good table that highlight previous schemes and provide the main characteristics of the proposed mechanism when compared to previous schemes. In addition, the contributions of the proposed scheme should be clearly highlighted.
3. More experiments to show the performances compared with the related work are also expected. Specially, the evaluation should compare with ZRP[7], SBZRP[8], AODV [3], TZRP [9], Geo-routing or Hierarchical management for routing.
4. The authors are encouraged to consider the scalability and mobility with higher speed in the algorithm designs for IARP and IERP, respectively, and the experiment designs are also required.
5. The proposed scheme inherits the advantages of proactive and on-demand routing protocols. However, it will also inherit their disadvantages. The authors are expected  to explain clearly why the disadvantages of them can be reasonably reduced with cost-efficiency. This question makes the operations of the approach as well as the major contribution unclear.
6. Authors should explain the major differences in the advantages of the strategy using Exps. (1) to (3) in the RREQ packet broadcasting to the k-hop strategy. I think they are similar.



Reviewer #3: Author improve the presentation of the manuscript and in case of geographical routing protocols location is the one of the prime factor so try to consider it so that you can get more accurate results.


Reviewer #4: This paper proposes the use of GPS coordinate for routing in MANET. It assumes all nodes have GPS coordinates readily available and then uses Zone Routing Protocol (ZRP) but with a smaller set of peripheral nodes. It simply draws a line across the source node S perpendicular to the line connecting Source and Destination and only forwards the packet to the peripheral nodes towards the direction of the destination node S. 

It reduces the number of routing messages, while increase the size of each message.
It shows a slight reduction in overhead.

The paper is well written and relatively easy to read. The survey of related work is comprehensive.

However,

0) The idea is simple extension of ZRP.

1) Why use a straight line, if a narrower section of peripheral nodes a selected, then the overhead can be reduced even further.

2) What is \rho on page 3?

3) What is the intuition of equations (1)-(3) describing the line? This is the most important part of the paper, but too little words are used to describe how the equation is derived.

4) What does "with condition of time stamp" mean?

There are some grammar mistakes.

fields.content:
Reviews
Review 4
Review:	%%%%%%%%%%%%
%% SUMMARY
%%%%%%%%%%%%

The paper proposes an scheduling algorithm, called the Dynamic Weighted
Deficit Round Robin (DWDRR), for improving the QoS of communications
between a military satellite and several military ground stations.
Specifically, authors propose to modify an algorithm, called the Weighted
Deficit Round Robin (WDRR), which is currently used for this kind of
communications. The already existing WDRR is a sort of cell scheduling
method similar to the ones used in high speed switching networks (like
ATM), in which the quantum size assigned to each stream buffer is static.
In contrast, the main idea of the new DWDRR algorithm is to dinamically
adapt, in each communication cycle, the size of the quantum assigned to
each stream buffer taking into account the characteristics of the stream
traffic in previous cycles. In such a way, the new DWDRR algorithm can
better adapt to changes in the traffic requirements of the above-mentioned
military satellite communications. The paper also presents some simulation
results obtanined using an OPNET model. Those results show that, when
compared to WDRR (and yet another algorithm called DDR), the proposed DWDRR
algorithm reduces the packet loss rate as the incoming traffic rate
increases. 


%%%%%%%%%%%%
%% PROS
%%%%%%%%%%%%

- The paper is well motivated and the related work is fairly addressed.

- The proposed algorithm is simple, yet technically sound.

- The paper presents some preliminary simulation results that support the
claims made by the authors concerning the advantages of the proposed
solution.

%%%%%%%%%%%%
%% CONS
%%%%%%%%%%%%

- The writing of the paper in general needs to be improved. On the one
hand, the order of some parts of the manuscript is confusing. On the
other hand, is is necessary to explain in a clearer way both the mechanisms
and limitations of the related work, and the modifications proposed by the
authors.

- Some figures are not referenced, nor explained in the text.

- More references are needed.


%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
%% SPECIFIC COMMENTS
%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%

- Page 1, Introduction, 1st paragraph. Do the references provided by the
end of the paragraph actually address the issue of invasion strategies?

- Page 1, Introduction, 3rd paragraph. Authors argue that military
communications between a satellite and ground station require high
reliability instead of a best effort approach. However, here they claim
that what is needed for these communications is an "efficient" scheduling
algorithm. Shouldn't this algorithm be a one that enforces reliable
communication rather than efficiency. Maybe the problem of this discussion
is that author do not appropriately use the concept of "reliability" and
mix it with the use of the concept "availability". 

- Page 1, Introduction, 3rd paragraph, 4th sentence. What do authors refer
to as the "The proposed method". The sentence is ambiguous.

- Page 1, Introduction, 4th paragraph, 6th sentence. There is a grammatical
problem here.

- Page 1, Section II.A, 1st paragraph, last sentence. It would valuable if
authors provide a reference here.

- Page 2, Figure 2. This figure is not referenced, nor explained in the
text.

- Page 2, Sections II.B and II.C. The formulation and the explanation of
the scheduling mechanisms and characteristics of WRR and WDRR are
confusing and need to be improved. May authors elaborate further on them?
In any case, please note that authors do not explain Figure 2; thus this
figure cannot actually help in understanding the problems they want to
explain here. In this sense, this figure occupies and space that could be
used for better explaining the mechanisms, advantages and limitations of
the WRR and the WDRR scheduling algorithms.

- Page 2, Section III.A, last sentence. It is hardly to understand what
authors explain here. What authors explain here is an advantage or a
disadvantage of the DWDRR algorithm.

- Page 3, Figure 4. This figure is not referenced, nor explained in the
text.

- Page 3, Section III.C, 1st paragraph, 4th sentence. Please, may you
provide a reference here.

- Page 3, Section III.C, formula (1). The meaning of some of the
parameters, e.g. TM and alpha, is not explained. Moreover, authors should
improve the explanation of the meaning of parameters Bp and BAV. 

- Page 3, Section IV.A, 2nd paragraph. Please, may you
provide a reference here.

- Page 4, Section IV.B., last paragraph. Please, may you explain the
conclusions here in a clearer way?
Review 1
Review:	This paper proposes an adaptive traffic scheduling method on a weighted Round-Robin scheme that copes with heterogeneous real-time sources.

The problem is relevant for the conference but the authors justify it solely within the scope of military systems which are not relevant for the conference. Thus, it would be nice to see the same problem placed in a more conference-relevant scope.

There are many similar efforts in the community, in different scopes, that the authors should consider. Some very recent pointers, that may help in following other related works, are [1-3] below. In particular, note that the authors problem is similar to the optimization of partitions and their dynamic adaptation.

One aspect that seems strange is that the results are shown over incoming rates that are outside the defined requirements! Are the requirements wrong? Would the same results be achieved in the range of the stated requirements?

Also note that equation (1) is broken and it is not clear how the two parts should be joined. 

Nevertheless, it seems a typical learning filter with a forgetting coefficient. In particular, T_M and alpha seem to influence the learning process in the same way. Thus why two parameters?

The English language is relatively poor and needs a major revision.

[1] Quan Leng, Yi-Hung Wei, Song Han, Al Mok, Wenlong Zhang, and Masayoshi Tomizuka. Improving Control Performance by Minimizing Jitter in RT-WiFi Networks. RTSS 2014
[2] Zahid Iqbal, Luis Almeida, Moris Behnam. Designing Network Servers within a Hierarchical Scheduling Framework. SAC 2015
[3] L. Oliveira, R. Graça, J. Martins, Luis Almeida. Managing High Loads in WiFi with Automatic Synchronization and Bandwidth Control. INDIN 2015
Review 2
Review:	The paper is well written. The DWDRR method is a small improvement over what was referenced in the paper [12]-[15]. It would have been useful to see more of a comparison under a wider range of conditions, especially against the constrained scheduling referenced in [15].
Review 3
Review:	The paper suffers from several major weaknesses.
First, related literature is not properly taken into account. Several papers are cited in a not appropriate way and their relevance to the considered work is unclear. Second, the paper does not provide basics informations that are needed to understand the value of the contribution that the paper provides. Last, but not least, presentation is poor, with a language that in some parts makes the paper hard to read and understand. As a side note, the focus on military applications only, without any effort to highlight any similarity with applications relevant to the topic of the track, i.e., industrial communications, makes the general interest of the topic for the ETFA audience quite limited.

Reviews
Review 4
Review:	Pros.
-The proposed approach is clear. 
-The motivations are good and convincing.
-The paper is within the scope of the conference.

Cons.
- Other works in the literature appear to adopt a very similar approach, for instance Thongthavorn, T.; Narongkhachavana, W.; Prabhavat, S., "A study on overhead reduction for GPS-assisted mobile ad-hoc networks," TENCON 2014 - 2014 IEEE Region 10 Conference, pp.1,5, 22-25 Oct. 2014. However, this work is not compared to the one proposed in this paper.

- In Sect. IV, it is not clear how the Normalized Routing Overhead is defined and calculated and in Fig. 3 the unit of the end-to-end delay on y-axis is not shown.

- In the sentence "...to obtain a new route often by bordercasting them to other nodes in the network..." it is not clear (at this point of the paper) what bordercating means, so the Authors should clarify it.

- In Sect. IV, the sentence "In sum, end-to-end delay of LAZRP is shortened than conventional ZRP protocol by 43.1 percent for 2-hop scenario and 44.8 percent for 3-hop scenario." is not clear. In fact, no high improvements appear in the cases from 50 to 70 nodes. This should better explained and clarified.
Review 3
Review:	The paper introduces a location based approach to improve the performance of ZRP in MANET.

The approach is fairly presented for a WIP and first simulation results are given. In total the paper should undergo a deep review of English. Despite the fact that I am also a non-native speaker, the use/not use of a,the,... makes it hard to read.

Detailled comments:
section I:
would be nice to have a description of the abbreviation ZRP
"It not only inherits advantages of hybrid routing protocol type
but also utilizes the location information provided to almost
mobile devices nowadays." --> This sentence is wrong. Especially the end.

section II/B:
"1) the opposite side with destination D is non-rebordercasting side and" D is not part of this side. It seems that there is an error.

section IV:
"when the traffic load is higher;" the authors should specifiy more specific values and discuss them when this effect is significant.
Review 1
Review:	This paper proposes an improvement of the Zone Routing Protocol (ZRP), which is an IETF draft of 2002. The main idea is to use the node location to reduce the routing protocol overheads, since only nodes towards the destination are “flooded” for the route request (RREQ). The authors have carried out a simulation study (using NS-2) to verify the improvements. 
The paper is rather well written and easy to read. It’s link to the industrial communication aspect is unclear since it only focuses on the routing protocol evaluation (so networking oriented) and there are no issues on the QoS or real-time properties that industrial applications care about. The simulation results confirm the intuition on the improvement about the overhead reduction. What lacks is a deeper analysis of the obtained results. What is the impact of the node mobility? What is the impact of reducing the potential forwarders on the routing reliability (i.e. we can not find a path when restricted to the subset of potential forwarders, while it could exist other paths when all the potential forwarders are considered?)
Geographic routing protocols have been extensively studied in wireless sensor domain. The authors should also include some more important results on the domain. For instance, how to deal with the geographic hole? How to make the protocol robust?
Review 2
Review:	The proposal is interesting as a WiP within the context of ZRP (Zonde Routing Protocol) and given the applicability to the coordination of mobile robots, it fits well the scope of the conference.

However, there are a few issues the authors should consider.

Despite some benefits shown with simulation, the real benefit is not clear the benefit in practice. In particular, the paper misses a plot with the number of unsuccessful route requests in all cases. It is expected that the proposed method will fail more, particularly with less nodes and if obstacles are added to the environment. In fact, in industrial scenarios, the obstacles will be many and the relationship between geographical direction and routing will be lower.

In such cases, it may happen that the only available routes leave the source in a direction that is opposite to the source to destination geographical vector.

A minor aspect is related to the plots that do not show important parameters, namely number of nodes when varying connections and number of connections when varying nodes.

The English language has frequent errors that hurt the readability. Please, correct thoroughly.

fields.subject: Phuong-ETFA2015-wip
fields.content:
Reviews
Review 1
Review:	- What is the credibility of your simulation results?
- Please include in plots (Figures 4-6) the error bars.
- An additional comment (or even better new plot with a new comment) about handoff delay obtained for higher values of packet arrival rate (>0.2) for both random sensing and proposed scheme will strengthen the presented results
Review 3
Review:	Dear authors: Your contribution is basically very good and worthwhile for publication at ETFA.
But even for a reader with appropriate expertise it is very difficult to read and understand this paper. 

My general recommendation: Reduce the content partially and explain the remaining parts in more detail. E.g. skip one of the 3 figures in the result chapter.

1) Correct some grammar errors: , ... and also the interference ..., ... not interference with ...

2) Chapter I: Paper organization is missing

3) Fig.1: Transmitter and receiver are used in a confusing way. --> A transmitter sends and doesn't receive !!! Label hidden and coexistence terminal.

4) Chapter III, B: Explain your "sounding signal"

5) Fig. 3, 4, 5, 6 are too small
Review 2
Review:	- A more detailed survey of related works would be more suitable and provide a better comparison with the proposed scheme (not just using random sensing).
- Why was SV selected as the channel model?
- Simulations seem to represent case studies - how "complete" are these simulations?
- Simulation parameters should be referenced.
- How was the number "5" obtained (at the top of the third page)?
- English and grammar should be revised.
Review 4
Review:	The paper lacks a proper problem formulation. CR and UWB are nicely introduced and their benefits for industrial networks are described and referenced. However, the combination of CR and UWB is not obvious (has it been done previously?) and the particular problems with spectrum sensing for CR in UWB is not described (I know that spectrum sensing for CR is difficult in frequency-hopping systems, so I expect it to be difficult also for UWB). None of the references seem to concern CUWBINs. Most importantly, the paper does not describe why the spectrum handoff needs to be improved (what is wrong with the current method? which methods exist today? when making the spectrum handoff more effective, what does that imply? shorter delay? lower complexity? using less energy?). In short, a text in the introduction that described what is new with your paper and why has it not been done previously, is lacking. However, when we come to Section IV Simulation results, we get some sort of indication as the results are compared to handoff with random sensing. This is good, but you need to mention handoff with random sensing and describe how it works already in the introduction, to complete the problem formulation. In addition, the language and, in particular, the grammar needs much work.

Apart from that, the paper nice, the proposed handoff algorithm is well described, the performance measures seem relevant and the paper does contain results - but a proper problem formulation is needed.

Prof. Jalel Ben-Othman

fields.content:
.======= Review 1 =======

> *** Technical Contribution: Rate the content based on its technical strength.
Marginal - Simple contribution with some flaws (2)

> *** Advancing Technologies / State-of-the-Art: Rate the novelty or contribution to military communications.
Little new here (2)

> *** Relevance and Timeliness: Rate the relevance of the topic and the importance to military communication applications.

> *** Quality of Presentation: Rate the organization and readability of the paper.
Needs work (2)

> *** Accept/Reject Recommendation: Do you feel that this paper should be accepted or rejected?
Reject (0)

> *** Comments to Authors:: Please provide comments to the authors that explain your numerical ranking:

The authors describe what is ultimately a bandwidth-aware routing technique for any cognitive networks where the traffic demands of primary users obey a Poisson process. The primary weakness of the paper is that there is no comparison made to other protocols. The authors state that "no studies have been conducted on bandwidth-aware localized routing for UCASNs." That may be true, but the authors need not limit themselves to protocols for underwater networks. Indeed, there is nothing UCASN-specific about the protocol. It only depends on the fact that the traffic demands of primary users obey a Poisson process and that the link bandwidths are known. In the absence of a standard protocol against which to compare the results, it is not possible to evaluate this work.

======= Review 2 =======

> *** Technical Contribution: Rate the content based on its technical strength.
Marginal - Simple contribution with some flaws (2)

> *** Advancing Technologies / State-of-the-Art: Rate the novelty or contribution to military communications.
Little new here (2)

> *** Relevance and Timeliness: Rate the relevance of the topic and the importance to military communication applications.
Somewhat relevant (3)

> *** Quality of Presentation: Rate the organization and readability of the paper.
Organization and/or writing could be improved (3)

> *** Accept/Reject Recommendation: Do you feel that this paper should be accepted or rejected?
Reject (0)

> *** Comments to Authors:: Please provide comments to the authors that explain your numerical ranking:

This paper presents a bandwidth-aware routing algorithm for friendly communication in UCASN. It would be very helpful if the authors provided a technical description of what "friendly" means in the context of UCASN. The authors mention that no other studies have been made in this area (so no comparisons are possible) but then conclude "our approach not only remarkably improves the utilized throughput but also dynamically adapts to network conditions". The numerical results sections is somewhat confusing. Is the author's solution presented in Figures 5-8 the "max bandwidth possible" solution or the optimal solution (neither seems to achieve the upper bound very often) ? The units of Bandwidth should be Hertz but the authors describe bandwidth as "The random bandwidth are uniformly distributed in the interval (0,40) Kbps" which sounds more like a data rate than a bandwidth. Figure 4 shows 100 nodes deployed but the performance plots x-axis is shown as a function of number of nodes. Did the authors simulate networks from 2 up to 100 nodes or was the network size fixed at 100 nodes ? From a practical perspective, can this algorithm be computed across the whole network in a distributed fashion or does one master node need to have all the network information ? What is the overhead of this algorithm in terms of the information that needs to be shared to other nodes ?

======= Review 3 =======

> *** Technical Contribution: Rate the content based on its technical strength.
Acceptable - Valid work but limited contribution (3)

> *** Advancing Technologies / State-of-the-Art: Rate the novelty or contribution to military communications.
Little new here (2)

> *** Relevance and Timeliness: Rate the relevance of the topic and the importance to military communication applications.
Relevant (4)

> *** Quality of Presentation: Rate the organization and readability of the paper.
Needs work (2)

> *** Accept/Reject Recommendation: Do you feel that this paper should be accepted or rejected?
Accept if room (3)

> *** Comments to Authors:: Please provide comments to the authors that explain your numerical ranking:

The paper addresses the problem of routing in a resource-constrained underwater network with severe spectrum under-utilization. The problem is relevant with the recent advent of underwater technologies and demand for civilian/commercial/military underwater applications. The authors propose a bandwidth-aware routing algorithm for spectrum-efficient and cognitive underwater sensor network that limits interference to primary users (including but not limited to marine animals) in the underwater environment. The analysis seems technically sound and the limited evaluation results, though could have been improved in presentation, support the argument. However, the reviewer is not clear on how this analysis is any different than tons of previous wireless network analysis work in general. The wireless networks are equally constrained in resources though the operating environment is more severe underwater. The paper ought to differentiate itself from such analysis when both optimization problems can map to a mixed-integer linear programming problem. Furthermore, it seems that the bandwidth-aware routing can be formulated as standard textbook resource allocation and routing problem and solved (approximation) via LP duality. The authors claim that "no studies have been conducted on bandwidth-aware localized routing for UCASNs". It may be so for the UCASNs, but the problem seems to have a canonical map to an existing textbook problem. Just because the application is unique, does not make the solution unique. Therefore, the results depicted must be compared to some existing approaches to really show that it is unique and better than the current state-of-the-art solution to the generic problem even if that state-of-the-art approach was motivated using an application other than the UCASNs. Overall, the reviewer feels (major comment) there is not much novelty with this work, and (minor comment) the paper writing needs improvement. For example: the first sentence in the Introduction ("UANs have received" not "have been received"), the first sentence in the second paragraph of Introduction needs better prose ("other important questions coming up is that where are signals from in the ..."), and so on.

fields.content:
Reviewer: 1 

Comments to the Author 
The paper presents a Markov chain based method to detect a faulty node in a distributed system. But there are quite a few problems with the paper - 

1. the paper doesn't really clarify how the proposed method can be applied to the broad area of distributed system monitoring, it seems it only target coding errors, in that case 'distributed system' is really an overstatement 

2. Many writing, sentence construction issues - e.g., 'to be faulty condition by itself'; equation 1 - element (3,3)?? 

3. The proposed method is not clearly explained, it is rather confusing, many symbols/items are not introduced properly - catalyst matrix, 'f' in algorithms, refer to algo s in the write-up, use Definitions, propositions, lemmas to enhance clarity of presentations 

4. the results and conclusions are not very clear or comprehensive, e.g., fig. 6 what's miss-detection ratio, was it supposed to be one of the axes as well? denoting algo s as 1st, 2nd scheme is difficult to relate, explain the counter-intuitive plot (CRC 1st scheme) 

Reviewer: 2 

Comments to the Author 
This paper deals with the problems of faulty node detection using a Markov chain model for a distributed system. Comparing the previous works, this manuscript uses the Markov chain model to compute probability distribution of the states of slaves’ nodes. These will be helpful in some degree for the researchers to study the faulty node detection for distributed systems. I have the following questions on the manuscript. 
1, The novelty and motivation of the work is not well justified. The author should clarify this 
2, The author should be concentrated on the new algorithm with your idea and explain its advantages clearly with most simple words, so that the goals and results of the study are clear to the reader. In other words, some redundant words should be delete. 
3, The author needs carefully edit and pay particular attention to English grammar and sentence structure. For example, in equations (5) and (6), what does q_0 and q mean? 
4, An experiment is supposed to be given rather than a simulation. 
5, How to derive the probability in real-world applications? This is a fundamental assumption for this manuscript. 


Reviewer: 3 

Comments to the Author 
The Markov chain is used to improve the BCH based faulty node detection method.The reviewer can not recommend its acceptance for publication in this important transaction at the present form. The comments are as follows: 
1. P5,"The Markov maximum permission probability of Good-state and Bad-state is [0.375] and [0.625]", why are the permission probability? The author should justify the criterion of the selection. 
2. Fig.3 & Fig.4, "The maximum Warning (bad) time is 16 (22) seconds,....", why the "detection ability has good performance" according the Fig.s? or how the 
performace is evaluated by the time? Also, the unit of the y-axis is E4 sencond, so the "maximum Warning time "should be 16000 seconds, etc. The title of the Fig. is "time for fault detection in number of 0 to 12 faulty nodes", but the "number" can not be found in the Fig.s. 
3.Channel noise level is defined as high noise level(E-4),medium noise level(E-5) and low noise level(E-6), and it is adopted in Fig.3 & Fig.4, but the "channel noise 

level" in Fig.5 is inconsistent. 
4. "Detection ability, c" is used in Fgi.3,4, and "C is eigen parameter" in Fig.5, what is the "detection ability c"? C is defined from 1 to 4, it should be 

discribed in the manuscript. 
5.Fig.3 or Fig.4, "detection ability has good performance regardless of channel noise levels." but, "However, when the external noise is increased to high noise level, nearly 25% of the detection results are incorrect"(Fig.7), what is the difference between the "detection ability" and the "detection results"? 
6."proposed method can ...for realtime distributed systems" ,more explanation is needed for the method using in the "realtime system". 

Reviewer: 4 

Comments to the Author 
This manuscript (TII-15-0898) is concerned with the problem of the probabilistic model-driven faulty node detection for distributed systems. The reviewer can not recommend its acceptance in the present form. Here are some comments: 
1. The manuscript does not cite the latest references, and research developments about the related topics are not fully reviewed. The novelty and the contribution of the manuscript are relatively weak. 
2. The manuscript is not well written and structured. For example, there are some grammatical mistakes such as "during communicate with...", "several environment","one node want..., the other node have to...“, or " Section II describe..." at the page 1. Misuse of "employ" in the text should be avoided.
