fields.subject: Long - IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics
fields.content:
Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
The paper proposes a cooperative relaying selection scheme, where intermediate nodes are chosen to help in relaying source data. Selection is performed based on a dynamic SNR threshold and thus the proposed scheme suits dynamic networks. 

The paper proposes an interesting algorithm, however in some moments the description lacks clarity. Below is a list of suggestions on how to further improve the paper.

MAJOR COMMENTS
It is mentioned in the title that the proposed approach is targeting industrial environments, however no examples are given in the paper. It would be good to give some examples of industrial environments where the proposed scheme can be used. It is especially important since listening to source transmissions and forwarding packets needs additional energy. At the same time it is assumed that the helping nodes are moving and thus should be battery powered and should not have additional energy to perform relaying. Also, in the considered scenario the operating area is 30 km2 large and it would be interesting to know why area of this size was chosen. Moreover, it is mentioned that some of the nodes can be deliberately compromised but no examples of a situation where it can happen are given. 

The second paragraph of introduction talks about relaying, helping and cooperative nodes, but the difference between these groups of nodes is not clear at that point. It would be easier for readers if the differences were explained, or, alternatively only one term was used when it does not play a crucial role for understanding. 

Moving to the related work part, it is not very clear what was done in the referenced papers and what is the difference with the current work. An additional explanation of the work done before, the things missing in the previous investigations and the parts covered in the current paper would improve the readers’ understanding of the current state in the area. 

In Section IV, equation (5) assumes that positions of mobile nodes at the previous time epoch are known, however it is not explained why. ADV messages, carrying information about node positions are mentioned only in the end of page 3, after equation (5) is presented. Moreover, Rayleigh fading is mentioned in the text, but not in any of the formulas describing channel model. Additionally, equation (7) holds for AWGN channel with evenly distributed errors, but not for Rayleigh channel, where errors appear in bursts.

Next, it would be good to add a little more details to Section IV.C. It would be helpful for readers if it was clarified how the equation (9) was built, the meanings of BERprop and BERcoop were explained. It is mentioned in the text that the equation is based on a model from [16], but a couple of sentences explaining the model would help the readers. Next, when the calculation of the average SNR is described, the primary relay node R1 is not mentioned. Is the comparison with SNR between the source and the relay R1 and R1 and the destination done at some point? It is important, since having some unfortunate positions of the assisting nodes it is possible that R1 is the best candidate to forward the packets. This discussion should be added, or if comparison is done, it should be highlighted in the text. 

Next, Section III seems to be too short and Fig. 1 representing time slots assigned to different nodes appears before Fig. 2, which explains the network model. It would be good to have Sections III, V and VI as one, showing the network model, superframe structure, describing the assisting nodes selection algorithm and the behavior of the nodes. Then, cooperative strategies of the nodes would be described together with the time slots assignment. Now, e.g. from the description given in the beginning of the Section V, it is not clear if the source node has 3 time slots for each packet or each source packet should be delivered in three time slots in total. Moreover, it is not clear how many time slots are given to the source and relay and assisting nodes. How the assisting nodes A1 and A2 and the relay node cooperate and decide who transmits? If e.g. both A1 and A2 fulfill all the requirements from Section VI, will only one or both of them transmit? And the relay node R1, does it always transmit or only if neither A1 nor A2 is able to relay the packet? And it is mentioned that assisting nodes might have packets in the queue, which packets are those? Do assisting nodes work as sources as well? Or they can be primary relay nodes for other source nodes? 

Talking about the superframe structure, ADV messages play a crucial role in the algorithm since based on their reception the SNR between the nodes is calculated, however time slots assigned to them are not shown in Fig. 1. Also, when are the ACKs transmitted? It is said in the text that all the assisting nodes send ACKs to the source, but in Fig. 1 as well as in e.g. WirelessHART, each time slot has time to send one ACK only, from e.g. the primary relay node. When do the other nodes have time to send ACKs? And how many listening and sending ACKs nodes are there in the systems? Do all the 100 nodes listen to source transmissions and try to cooperate? If so, than too many acknowledgments should be sent and too much energy is wasted on listening. And since different assisting nodes transmit in different superframes, superframe structure often changes. How do the assisting nodes know which time slot is assigned to them and who does the assignment? 

Also, concurrent transmissions are mentioned in the text, but not explained. They should be described since it is usually preferred to use simple off-the-shelf devices for industrial applications and concurrent transmissions are not necessary possible. Are they supposed to be performed on different channels? Then it is important that possible assisting nodes listen to the correct channels at the correct time, or the number of possible helping nodes will be decreased. 

Moving to the results section, the choice of the operating area size and the parameters presented in Table 1 should be motivated. Which industrial communication systems require 30 km2 coverage? And it is said that two hops are used to transmit the data, but which communication standard can cover 30 km2 area with just two hops? Next, Table 1 says that CSMA/CA was used, while Section III describes the suggested dynamic TDMA. And it is not clear which scheme the proposed protocol is compared to. A conventional scheme is mentioned, but not described. 

To conclude, the paper proposes an interesting approach to select assisting nodes in a dynamic network. However, the system model description is not clear. It would be good to rewrite the system model explaining the considered network, roles of the nodes, the superframe structure and maybe to show an example of how the system should work and how the nodes should cooperate. 

MINOR COMMENTS
There are some grammar mistakes, which should be fixed. For example:
- page 1, left column, line 16: “… idle neighbors receives …” -> “… idle neighbors receive …”;
- page 1, left column, line 22: “… eCoRSS defines a dynamic SNR … and decide which node qualifies …” -> “… eCoRSS defines a dynamic SNR … and decides which node qualifies …”;

Also, there are few difficult to understand sentences in the text, it would be better to rephrase them. For example:
- page 1, left column, line 14: “However, …” -> e.g. “However, if a use has no packet in its queue, the time slot allocated to it can be wasted”;
- page 1, right column, line 46: “In [10], …” -> e.g. “In [10], [11-13] the authors introduced several protocols improving …”.

And, SNR between the source and the assisting node should be higher than the threshold, but in the text the opposite is sometimes said, e.g. on page 3 (line 6), page 5 (line 24) and in Algorithm 2.


Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
For reviewer comments, please refer to the attached pdf.

Reviewer: 3

Comments to the Author
The main contribution of this manuscript is to propose an cooperative relaying selection scheme , called eCoRSS, based on time division multiple access in industrial multi-hop wireless networks. It uses idle neighbors between a source node and a relay node to forward packets in order to improve performance of the proposed scheme. It analyzes selecting strategy and describes algorithms. Simulations show that eCoRSS scheme can improve the performance in terms of the throughout, end-to-end delay, and energy consumption. The document is easily to follow and the topic of the paper is interesting. However, I have some concerns as follows:

(1) In the simulation section, the authors should compare the proposed scheme with some existed schemes. In Fig. 7, they did a comparison with the non-eCoRSS scheme. It needs to explain the non-eCoRSS scheme in detail. 

(2) In Fig. 10, the analysis results coincide exactly with that in simulation. What are the reasons? 

(3) What are the differences between industrial wireless network and general wireless network in the manuscript? 

Overall the paper presents an interesting study of a timely topic. The motivation is clear. The authors are advised to revise their paper accordingly before the paper is published.

fields.subject: Long - IEEE/ACM Transactions on Networking
fields.content:
+ Even if carried out perfectly, the contribution is not at the level expected for IEEE/ACM ToN. In particular, the paper considers only a very restricted scenario (see Figure 1), employs an approach that is well-known in the literature (using idle slots for cooperation), and provides only limited simulation results. This does not rise to the contribution level required for IEEE/ACM ToN.

+ The paper is difficult to read, with problems with the precision right from the start in the System model:

- the authors need to define "mobility epoch" carefully. And I think they mean "mobility epoch of length $\tau$" and not "mobility epoch $\tau$"

- a node moves with a random velocity (which includes direction) in random direction. I am sure the authors mean "random speed in a random direction". But what follows is even more confusing, as the next sentence switches to nodes moving in circles and points to Figure 2. 

- equation (1) is not precise. What does the author mean here by "received signal". Is this a vector? If so, please show the indexing. I would think that y_{n_i} and x_s would need to be vectors, but h_{sn_i} is a scalar. But they all use the same notation.

- if a_{sn_i} is the mean of the noise component n_{sn_i}, as stated after (3), then that means that h_{sn_i}(n\tau) is always zero! I am sure this is not what the authors meant. But this is not simply a typo: I cannot figure out what they mean here. Something is wrong.

- should the 4\pi be outside the (.)^2 in the demoninator of (4)?

- the restriction to BPSK is problematic

- equation (7) only applies to uncoded systems, which are rarely used in practice

fields.subject: Tuan - [JCN] Journal of Communications and Networks
fields.content:
Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
The authors consider cooperative relaying in the context of underwater acoustic communications. It is demonstrated through simulations that it can provide improvements over non-cooperative relaying and shortest-path-first relaying in terms of average end-to-end packet delay, packet delivery ratio, and average energy consumption.

There are several considerations.

Section III.C focuses on capacity limitation. However, the requirement R < C can be conveyed with one sentence or short paragraph. It would be better instead to devote a section on the transmission format. In the performance evaluation section, it is pointed out that the IEEE 802.11 protocol has been adopted. However, this paper focuses on an underwater setting, and readers may not be familiar with details regarding 802.11. In any event, it would improve the readability of the paper, and the subsequent discussion of the cooperative model, to include the most important descriptions regarding the physical layer (transmission scheme, modulation format) and MAC layer.
(Should the link capacity check be relevant/important as it is considered in Algorithm 1, the authors could describe it in more detail in an appendix, taking care that the above considerations have an impact on the capacity. It also appears that the capacity is for a single link, rather than for the cooperative relay model, so the authors could perhaps be careful in describing the particular consideration.)

The last sentence of section IV.A states:
"Here the relay method relies on regenerative cooperation where the relay attempts to detect and recover the original message from the source before forwarding the decoded bits to the destination."
Could the authors please clarify how the destination combines the bits from the source and the relay.

The last sentence of section IV.B.2 states:
"In addition, the stored SNR value corresponding to a neighbor is averaged between the SNR sensed from a CTS packet at the source and the average SNR estimated through overhearing of each neighbor."
Could the authors please clarify which SNR's exactly are being averaged and the benefits of this process.

Could the authors elaborate on the use of Ack-II. It appears the relay selection algorithms 1 and 2 select one relay node. What is the purpose then for other neighbors to first store the source packet in their buffers and subsequently to remove them? (Also would some neighbor nodes not overhear the transmission of Ack-I?)

In the first paragraph of section V.A it is stated that the simulation parameters can be found in related referenced papers. Is it possible to present the parameters in a table, or even an appendix if necessary, as that would make the paper self contained.

Would it be possible to clarify if interference was considered when simulating the routing protocols as that would be a significant performance impairment/limitation. If so, could it be described in more detail.

Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
The paper investigates the use of a cooperative approach to deliver messages in an underwater acoustic sensor network. A multi-hop approach is considered where the best relay nodes are selected in a hop-by-hop way according to the network geometry and channel conditions. Additionally, the use of consecutive ACK packets is explored to reduce the transmission of duplicated packets.

Although the idea of the authors appears to be clear, more details are needed to: 1) Better understand the scenario considered by the authors;  2) better understand the novelty of the proposed solution; 3) have a more clear and deeper understanding of the protocol performance and of the analysis conducted by the authors.

1) When describing the protocol solution the authors always refer to the case of a path with a single relay node (i.e., a path composed of two links). Are the authors considering the case of multiple links and relay nodes from the source to the destination?

2) Are the authors assuming a common destination node (sink) for all the transmissions in the network or the presence of multiple destination nodes is possible?

3)The described solution makes use of: 1) An initial phase to determine the hop count from the destination to the other nodes in the network (HopToDest transmission); 2) a handshaking phase to select the best relay to use according to hop count, channel condition and ToA; 3) the use of acknowledgment techniques to notify about the correct delivery of data messages and reduce the transmission of duplicated packets. All these steps are really similar to what the CARP solution (mentioned by the authors in the related works section) does. It seems that the main difference is in the acknowledge strategy: hop-by-hop for CARP and end-to-end for the proposed solution.
The authors should highlight what is the novelty of their solution with respect to CARP and to similar protocols  already proposed in the literature. They should better describe why their design better fit the needs of an underwater acoustic network. A performance comparison  with CARP and any other relevant solution should be considered to show how effective the proposed design is.

4) The underwater acoustic channel model assumed by the authors makes use of Urick and Thorp formulas. It is a  oversimplified  model (with respect to real-life scenarios) that does not consider the effect of link quality variations over time as well as the presence of asymmetric links. A more accurate model based on real-life traces or on ray-tracing software should be considered. One option could be the use of the Bellhop ray tracer with environmental data loaded from databases available online. This approach has been largely used in the recent past. Moreover,  there is the possibility to use one of the various open source frameworks (SUNSET, DESERT, etc.) exploring this approach.

5) How is the source node computing the ToA for each node? Are the authors assuming a synchronized network or the round-trip delay is estimated for this? How are all the possible relay nodes avoiding to send the CTS close in time thus resulting in multiple collisions at the RTS sender? Are the authors assuming any desynchronization procedure?

6) A TDMA approach is used to reserve the underwater medium but no investigation on the related guard times, TDMA time slot and time frame setting is performed. Several papers have been published in the past showing how TDMA can result in low network performance. Additionally, several papers have been published exploring the use of a TDMA approach with overlapping transmissions - thus taking advantage of the long propagation delay - to improve the throughput of the network. Have the authors considered these solutions or different MAC protocols when  evaluating the performance of the proposed approach? Can the obtained results be improved making use of a different and more sophisticated MAC?

7) Since the time domain is divided in Transmission Durations (TDs) and one TD covers one round of control signal exchange and data frame transmission, how long has this duration to be? What is the delay suffered by the other sources in waiting their own slot to transmit? In which time duration are the ACK transmission taking place?


8) The authors make use of an end-to-end approach to acknowledge the correct delivery of a data message. It is not clear however how these ACK packets are used and how long a source node will wait for the ACK before retransmitting the packet to a relay node (the same previously used or a new one) to then reach the intended destination. What is the overhead and delay introduced by this approach making use of consecutive ACK packets?

9) The simulation result section is quite poor. A high dense network is considered while usually sparse nodes are typical for underwater network scenarios (tens of devices over areas of several kilometers). A time slot of 0.18 seconds is used but it is not clear how many data has to be transmitted in that time slot. The data packet size is set to 200B, what is the size for the RTS and CTS? What is the average number of relay nodes replying to request to send messages? What is the average length of the routes used to deliver the messages? How many source nodes are assumed? What is the traffic rate considered in the network? What is the additional overhead due to the protocol operations? How often is the hop count estimation updated?

10) No performance comparison with similar solutions (e.g., CARP) is considered.

Overall, this paper is not ready for publication. And not just because of the remark above. This work should start with better motivating and explaining why this particular way to exploit node cooperation is effective for underwater acoustic sensor networks. A better description of the proposed solution and of the novelty of the presented approach should be provided. A more accurate and deep analysis of the operation performed by the protocol and the investigation of a larger set of network scenarios should be conducted to better understand the solution results and performance. A more accurate model for the underwater acoustic channel should be considered presenting some of the dynamics typical of this kind of networks. A performance comparison considering solutions proposed for underwater acoustic networks should be investigated.


Reviewer: 3

Comments to the Author
The main concern about this submission is its rather limited novelty. The proposed scheme resembles the Channel-aware Routing Protocol (CARP), which is also briefly cited by the authors in the Related Works section. Arguably, the authors should be more forthcoming in the description of the similarities to the two schemes, highlighting the differences. In the paper, there is no mention of them (e.g., selection of relay candidates, filtering of the list based on link quality, etc.).

The performance evaluation section is also quite underwhelming. Again, the authors seem to ignore other works in the literature and simply compare their scheme with a shortest path first algorithm. Given the similarities, I would have expected that a comparison with CARP or FBR would have been in order.
Other performance metrics such as the route length and the packet latency over covered distance would have been welcome.

fields.subject: Long - IET Communications
fields.content:
Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
The authors propose a new cooperative relay selection scheme (called rate-estimation method) to select the strongest link among relays to both source and destination.

Another paper of the authors with the same title of this work is available (Advanced Science and Technology Letters Vol.41 (Sensor 2013), pp.13-16). In the published paper, they investigate a 2-hops communication system that includes one source, one destination and k candidates for the relay. But, in the submitted paper, the source forwards packets through multi-hop (Large-Scale Wireless Networks) until reaching the destination differently from published paper. The authors should be refer their published paper to in this paper and explain how their previous work differs from this work. If not, rate-estimation parameter “A” will be a bit questionable.

I wonder how the performance of this new cooperative relay selection scheme will be changed, if the channels are assumed to be fast fading instead of steady over time (quasi static). It must be done in the future. If they can do, the work will be more valuable. Nevertheless, I think the paper is enough to warrant publication. 


Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
This paper proposes rate-estimation based relay selection scheme (RERSS) for large-scale wireless networks (LSWNs) that effectively distributes traffic of packets from a source to a sink. 

Comments:

The article is generally written well, however, there is scope for improvement in terms of language presentation is concerned

For e.g. consider revising the sentence for better readability

Due to far distance and interference between nodes in a large-
scale wireless network, direct data-transmission/reception between a source and a sink is difficult. 

Likewise, some portions of the manuscript requires rewriting for better clarity.

In the last sentence of para 3 in intro' energy constraint is also a problem.Please include it.

May I encourage the authors to refer to the following published articles which are close to theory presented in para 4 with respect to CC? This is also to ensure that the presented work is in time-line.

Cooperative communication-aided multi-carrier code division multiple access downlink transmission with transmitter preprocessing: performance results
P Nagaradjane, et. al, IET Communications 7 (Issue 17), 1915 – 1924

Performance of Relay-Aided Multi-Carrier-CDMA using preprocessing based on quantized feedbackv P Nagaradjane et. al, Computers & Electrical Engineering

While writing from node i to j please use standard presentation. In the paper it has been given as i-j. it looks like i minus j.

Notations in the diagram and in the general text should be same. Please correct in in order to avoid cumbersome. For.e.g 'S' and 'R' . This is ensure notation consistency

Likewise, italic and normal font should be maintained . For.e.g, 'R' in (2) is italic. However, in Algorithm 1, it is normal. Please correct it.

Some more insight can be brought in in the results and discussion section, as it is pretty flat.

안녕하십니까? 회원님!

fields.subject: Tuan - IEEE World Conference on Factory Communication Systems 2016
fields.content:
Reviewer 1: 
The paper considers industrial wireless sensor networks and analyzes energy consumption of different cooperative communication techniques. Presented results show that relaying is more energy efficient than e.g. multi-hop transmissions. The paper presents interesting results, but a set of adjustments should be done before the paper can be accepted. In the introduction, when explaining the problem, it is stated that industrial devices are typically battery powered and that prolonging the period of operation, minimizing energy consumption and transmission power are among the most important factors in industrial systems. It would be good to add some additional explanations here and give examples of the industrial environments of interest as e.g. for wireless networks working on power plans reliability and timeliness are the main requirements. Also, introduction describes the problem and gives an overview of the related work, but it does not say what the current paper is about. It would be good to add one more paragraph summarizing the contributions of the paper and the derived conclusions.  
In the System Model section, the adopted channel model is described, however the reasons for choosing Nakagami distribution are not clear. No final conclusion has yet been made about one model describing industrial environments the best, but some references pointing at Nakagami model would help the reader. Also, a more detailed explanation of the considered performance measures is needed. All the indicators of interest are mentioned in different places in the paper, but the paper would be easier to read and understand if all of them, together with adopted assumptions, would be described in one place (e.g. the System Model section). Moreover, when energy consumption is studied, it is assumed that the nodes can adjust the transmission rate and power to reach the required quality of service and compensate for the additional time used (in case of schemes with the relay node). However industrial devices are typically simple and there is not much flexibility in the choice of the transmission rate and power. Furthermore, IEEE 802.15.4 is used as a base for several industrial standards, e.g. WirelessHART, and its typical transmit power is 1 mW, while the results in section V show optimal transmit power of much higher values.  In section IV.B it is not clear why energy spent on transmitting and receiving ACK / NACK packets is ignored. This should be explained in more details and a discussion on how this assumption affects the results should be added. The achieved comparison results are well presented with clear figures. However the supporting them text only describes the observations done from the graphs, but does not explain the trends. More detailed explanations of the reasons for different behavior of the evaluated schemes is needed for all the figures. For example, why outage probability for multi-hop scheme is better than for cooperative schemes? The relay node is located in the same place in both cases and in case of cooperative scheme the source has two chances to listen to the packet instead of only one chance in the case of multi-hop schemes. Also, in the beginning of the section it is stated that the results were achieved by performing Matlab simulations, but the figures look like they were drawn using the data from mathematical calculations (using expressions presented earlier in the paper). If simulations were performed as well, it would be interesting to see if simulated outage probabilities would match the calculations, although it probably would not be possible to simulate for the outage probabilities lower than 10^(-5). And finally, only three performance measures, i.e. energy consumption, transmit power and outage probability, are studied in the paper. It is stated in the conclusions that there can be other performance indicators on interest and some of them will be considered in the future work. However it would be good to add already into this paper a discussion section describing these other measures, possible trade-offs between them and how considering different performance indicators can affect the comparison and conclusions. For example, multi-top scheme would become much more energy efficient if time constrained is lightened, i.e. all schemes are given two time slots, and thus bit speed is not increased for the multi-hop and cooperative schemes. Also, only one position of the relay node was considered and it would be interesting to see how energy consumption of different schemes changes depending on the position of the relayer. It was mentioned in the introduction that the paper by Sadek et al. considered this issue, but a deeper discussion in the results section would make it more complete. 
The reference list includes 6 citations of the papers with the same last author as in the current article. All these references are used only once and in a generic sentence. Thus, the list can be improved by leaving only one or two, the most relevant, references. 
And finally, it is stated that one of the main differences between the current paper and the reference [15] is that the current paper considers a channel with LOS and adds to the calculations a compensation for the extra time slot used by cooperating schemes. However since the conclusions achieved in both papers are quite similar, a deeper comparison between two papers (both, comparison of the setup and the results) would make the contribution of the current article stronger.
The paper is easy to read and understand, however it requires additional proof-reads. There are quite few grammatical errors, typos and unexplained things, e.g.:
- abstract: this paper … and derives …
- abstract: abbreviation IDF is not explained
- section II: … this paper adopts an assumption that the network operates …
- section III, just above (13): extra space before colon
- section III, just above (13): … overall energy consumed to successfully … and to minimize …
- section III, just above (13): … both Ptx and Prx are fixed and depend on …
- section IV: selection combining is mentioned, but not explained
- beginning of section IV.b: … the D node responds to the source node with …
- conclusions: In summary this conclusion not only provides guidelines for relay selection algorithms, but also gives recommendations on when collaborative transmission scheme should be utilized
- letter “S” is used both to refer to the source node and the number of transmissions in multi-hop and cooperative schemes
Also, it would be good to move Fig. 2 so that it appears on the same page with equations (9-12).
Reviewer 2:
The paper considers outage probability and energy consumption for well-known relaying schemes under Nakagami channel fading.There is hardly any novelty in the paper. The relaying schemes are well-known, and the analysis is straightforward. The introduction does not say what the paper is about, and the relevance for WFCS is questionable, as the topic is more appropriate for a communications conference.
Reviewer 3:
This paper analyzes the energy efficiency, outage probability and the optimal transmission power for Industrial Wireless sensor networks. Single hop, Multi-hop, Decode-and-forward and Incremental decode and-forward schemes are considered. A numerical simulation example is presented. Authors need to explain more how their findings differ from those of previous cited works as this is not clear enough in the introduction. Also a comment on the effect on parameters used in simulation on the distances at which observed phenomena occur will be useful. The statement "the data rate must be greater S times than that of single-hop scheme" in section III-B is also not clear.
Reviewer 4:
In this paper, the authors analyze and compare different transmission schemes for WSN in terms of energy consumption. Results show that IDF is the most energy efficient protocol.There is no new contributions in this paper, relative to the related work and particularly the two following papers where we find the same conclusions: Energy Efficiency Analysis and Power Allocation of Cooperative Communications in Wireless Sensor Networks (Wei Liu, Guangming Li, and Lin Zhu).Energy Efficiency in Cooperative Wireless Sensor Networks (Glauber Brante, Marcos Tomio Kakitani and Richard Demo Souza).

fields.subject: Load Balancing Mechanism for WLANs-WFCS 2016
fields.content:
Overall evaluation:	-1: (weak reject)
Reviewer's confidence:	5: (expert)
Do you recommend this paper for TII?:	2: (No)
Review:	In this paper a load balancing mechanism for IEEE 802.11 WLANs is introduced. The mechanism is based on a throughput evaluation and the distribution of traffic to underloaded wireless cells. 

First of all, the paper is lacking a clear structure, and the style of writing and grammar must be improved, including the removal of several typos and the revision of several sentences (e.g. on p.2 -> "... we assumed when some APs are overloaded then some of users associated with the AP should move other under loaded APs."). Please consider a thorough revision and maybe a proof reading by a native speaker. 

Within the introduction, the main motivation for this work is not clearly highlighted and a problem statement is missing. Even though the related work subsection seems to be comprehensive, the discussed research is only briefly analyzed. Hence, it is very hard for the reader to assess the novelty of the presented approach. Please extend the state of the art analysis and consider a discussion at the end, which clearly highlights the existing research gaps in the area of load balancing in WLANs.

In Sect. II you are introducing the approach. The access point controller seems to be a crucial component of the whole system, but it is never been described. What are its core functionalities? It is really the case that a wireless backbone is used to interconnect the APs? This would probably introduce several challenges to be addressed. The explanation of the approach could be also improved. Currently, it is very hard to follow. A major question that came up during the review was how the nodes position is determined. This is a very important information to be considered when shifting a wireless station from one AP to another, because it must be in the coverage area of the new AP. Usually, the handover decision is taken by the wireless station, is there any communication established between the AP and the station to trigger the handover?

Finally, the evaluation is insufficient in the reviewers opinion. The conditions and the relevant parameter of the simulation case study are partly missing, e.g. which channel model did you use? The used simulation model is not validated at all. Moreover, the obtained results are not discussed and the metrics are not clearly defined. Considering this, it is very hard to assess or to reproduce the presented results.

To sum it up, the idea of the paper is relevant, but its novelty remains unclear throughout the paper. Furthermore, the style of writing and grammar and the quality of the evaluation is not sufficient and must be definitely improved.

Overall evaluation:	2: (accept)
Reviewer's confidence:	5: (expert)
Do you recommend this paper for TII?:	1: (Yes)
Review:	The main aim of the authors is to provide efficient algorithm for solving the WLAN load balancing problem, focusing on distribute users amongst a set of APs in order to maximize the system throughput.
To this end, the authors introduce a novel load balancing scheme in order to reduce the load of congested APs by forcing the users located near the boundaries of congested cells to move to neighboring less congested cell. 

The topic is important and interesting and the authors clearly show the goodness of their solution. In order to further improve the paper, I suggest the following comments for improvements:

- insightful and practical implications of the proposed approach can be better explained into the paper.

- the authors could improve the Related works subsection in order to show exactly what is novel about their study. To this end, I suggest to analyze the following papers:
*** Mario Collotta, FLBA: A fuzzy algorithm for load balancing in IEEE 802.11 networks, Journal of Network and Computer Applications, Volume 53, July 2015, Pages 183-192, ISSN 1084-8045, http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.jnca.2015.04.005.
*** C. W. Tsai, S. W. Wang, K. C. Hu and M. C. Chiang, "A modified multiple-search multi-start framework-enhanced micro genetic algorithm for WLAN load balancing," Ubiquitous and Future Networks (ICUFN), 2015 Seventh International Conference on, Sapporo, 2015, pp. 202-207.

- the Conclusion section could be improved. Actually, it seems to rush to the end. The authors need to rewrite the entire conclusion section with focus on both impact and insights of the manuscript.

Overall evaluation:	-2: (reject)
Reviewer's confidence:	4: (high)
Do you recommend this paper for TII?:	2: (No)
Review:	This paper is not related to the scope of WFCS nor TII. It is about load balancing in Wi-Fi to maximize throughput. Nothing is ever mentioned about Factory Communications or any of the topics within the scope of the conference.

Overall evaluation:	-2: (reject)
Reviewer's confidence:	4: (high)
Do you recommend this paper for TII?:	2: (No)
Review:	This paper presents an efficient algorithm for load balancing among WLAN access points. Overload traffic of overloaded APs is migrated to neighboring under-loaded cells. The proposed algorithm is tested with a simulation example. However:

1) No arguments are presented to show that the presented algorithm is the best algorithm to converge to an "optimum" balancing state: How to select the updting period?; the basis of dividing overload equally among under-loaded nodes (equation (20)) although they may have different under-load levels is not clear; is there a possibility of load oscillating back and forth between APs?
2) Paper refers to QoS in previous works, system model, and simulation results, but it is not clear how these will be reflected in the algorithm How are station weights selected? what were their values in simulation?.
3) Performance degradation resulting from collisions is mentioned in paper but not accounted for in model.
4) Simulation results are not compared to other results (e.g. if no balancing algorithm is applied). Unbalance in number of lost packets and delay in simulation results (Figures 5,6) needs explanation.
5) Manuscript needs revision for language mistakes.

Overall evaluation:	-3: (strong reject)
Reviewer's confidence:	4: (high)
Do you recommend this paper for TII?:	2: (No)
Review:	The paper seems to propose a load balancing algorithm for APs deployed on WLANs.
First of all, the quality of the presentation is very bad: the English language is very poor, some symbols are not defined (for example, $r_{u,a}$ and $\omega_u$ in eq. (1)), some figures are not commented at all, etc.).
Second, and even more important: as far as I can understand from the manuscript, the paper is definitely out of the conference scope. As a matter of fact, I do not find any relation with industrial communication systems.

       한글명(영문약어: 영문원어) 형태로 수정 필요, PHP에 대한 용어 정의가 없음. 관련근거 명시 필요

18. 참고문헌 15,  vol과 pp 간 구분표시 없음.

Major Issue
1. 사격제원장치에 모의사격시뮬레이터 데이터를 입력 하는 것보다 사격제원계산장치의 성능을 향상시키는
    것이 실제적인 효과가 높다고 판단됨. 이에 대한 투고논문의 방향성과 의견제시가 필요함.
2. 검증 소요시간과 연동오류 발생 시에 대한 복구방안 명시가 필요함.
3. 포 발사 시 함정별 특성에 따라 Rolling/Pitching의 오차가 현저히 다르게 입력 되고,
    실제 사격오차는 크게 발생 함. 이에 대한 함정별 개별특성에 대한 보상이 가능한 지 명시가 필요함

심사위원 2.
"해군전투체계의 적응형 모의사격시뮬레이터 설계 및 구현"에 대한 논문 평은 다음과 같습니다.

1. 본 논문은 핸구 전투체계 관련 모의 사격시뮬레이터를 구현하는 과정에서 산출된 결과를 정리하여 논문으로 제출된것으로 판단됩니다. 대부분의 연구 내용은 해군 전투체계 관련 LBTS 에서 운용할수 있는 소프트웨어 시스템 대한 내용으로 판단됩니다. 

2. 전체적인 논문의 내용을 살펴보면 대부분이 시스템의 GUI 설명 혹은 SW의 기능에 대한 내용을 다루고 있습니다. 이는 개발된 소프트웨어에 대한 소개에 대한 내용이지 학술지 성격의 논문으로는 어울리지 않는다고 판단됩니다. 특히 제어로봇시스템학회지 같이 제어 시스템을 기본으로 하는 학회지와는 전혀 무관한 분야의 논문이 아닌가 생각됩니다. 따라서 세부적인 내용으로 논문을 판단하지 불가능 하다고 판단됩니다.

3. 저자분께서 군사과학기술학회지 혹은 시뮬레이션 학회지와 같은 곳으로 제출해 보심을 권해 드립니다. 해당 학회지에서는 충분히 좋은 내용으로 평가 되지 않을까 사려됩니다.

fields.subject: Tuan - WFCS WIP 2016
fields.content:
Review 1: 
Overall evaluation: 1. Weak accept
Review:
This paper analyses several communication models in what concerns energy consumption in scenarios where the communication is performed in line of Sight (LOS) or Non Line of Sight (NLOS). The paper is well written and well organized. The adequate propagation models are used and the results seem correct and consistent. The description of the protocols is a bit short and could be better presented if separated from the mathematical models. The discussion of the results is not very clear. Being a WIP the continuation of the work should be better sustained.
Some clarifications are required:
- Clarify why Nf is used in the path loss (Equation 3) and not as additive noise (in equation 2)
- Paragraph following equation 4: N is the noise power (not the Noise Spectral Density)
- Clarify the conditions for the outage event given in equation (5)
- It is not clear the power loss coefficient used in the MatLab simulations
- Pag 4. Paragraph before the VI-conclusions, pag 4 “ In this scenario … transmission rate smaller than 2bits/s/Hz”

Review 2:
Overall evaluation: 0 (Borderline paper)
Review:
The paper presents a physical layer modeling approach to industrial sensor networks, to study energy efficiency in point-to-point communications, both in LOS and NLOS situations, and considering collaborative transmission schemes based on a relay node. 
Overall, the paper presents an interesting study that indicates the situations in which a relay node can improve the link while saving energy. 
On the negative side, it misses relevant related work in the topic (e.g. from S. Girs et al, WFCS 2015). 
Moreover, it seems a squeezed version of a full paper. The theoretical part and results are squeezed into the paper and not sufficiently explained. Thus, this is not really a work-in-progress paper, where the discussion of the idea and related work is more important than results.
The authors do briefly refer to a few lines of future work at the very end but that does not really make this a work-in-progress paper. On the other hand, despite not referred by the authors, I believe the work is still in progress because it needs experimental validation in meaningful application scenarios.
Other comments:
The motivation for low energy consumption in IWSN is not really well grounded. In industrial settings, large scale maintenance operations are always needed, at least once a year. This could include changing batteries in sensor nodes, but in many cases, batteries can be changed more frequently, if needed. The concern with extra low energy consumption better applies to large scale WSN deployed in inaccessible areas.
The authors seem to consider a doubled bit-rate with multi-hop to compensate for the total throughput. However, this is not realistic. In practice, multi-hop links will use the same bit rate and delays will in fact be longer.
There are many inconsistencies in the explanation of the formalism, which need to be improved, as referred below:
Eq 2 provides received signal strength, right? Please, say it explicitly.
Eq 3 is presented as a derivation of Eq 2 (the text says "Therefore...") However, this is not evident. Moreover Eq 3 changes the subindexes from S and D to i and j. This is confusing... Establish correspondence (SD to ij) similarly to the definition you have below Eq 10.
Gamma(m) in Eq 1 and Eq 5 is not explained.
rho is poorly defined at the end of Section II. Call it the probability of a link outage so that it matches Eq 5 and Eq 12. In Eq 5, caligrahic P should equal rho, right? 
Why using caligraphic P ^ asterisc in Eq 9? Eq 9 seems to be equivalent to Eq 5.
IDF is not properly explained. Limited feedback channel is used but how?

Review 3
Overall evaluation: -1 (Weak reject)
Review:
This paper analyzes the energy efficiency, outage probability and the optimal transmission power for Industrial Wireless sensor networks. Single-hop, Multi-hop, Decode-and-forward and Incremental decode-and-forward schemes are considered. A numerical simulation example is presented.
This version of the paper does not indicate clearly the novelty of the results. By giving very few references, the reader will not be able to identify which of the presented results are known in the literature so that he can benefit from new findings in this paper or this work in progress. Language revision is also needed.

Review 4:
Overall evaluation: -2 (Reject)
Review:
I have the following comments to the paper:
- There is a low number of citations (4) of related work
- The introduction and related work section is very short (2 paragraphs)
- The discussion section could be extended 
- I fail to find a proper motivation for why this is a WiP paper

Reviewers' comments (if any):

Reviewer #4: Overall assessment 
The presented paper adresses the forwarding of data packets in a route between a source node and a destination node, with the help of assistant nodes.
The main issue in the review process is that the system model, the scenario, and abstraction level are not consistent. Let make myself clear at this point.
In a cooperation network, you can choose to operate at the physical layer, at the MAC layer, or at the network layer.
In any case, you have to address the allocation process, i.e., how wyou allocate relays, helpers to the route or the source-destination pair.
When you operate at the network layer, the optimization process benefit of the exchange of data packet among nodes but the optimization works at the long-term scale. When you operate at the physical layer, the optimization process might not be able to consider all the relevant network information but the optimization operates at a short-term scale.
In this paper, there is a mix of different approaches. The authors claim that they are adressing short-term variations of the SNR but actually implement long-term methods to adress the issue.
Several points must be specified such as the allocation of assistant nodes to the route.


Introduction 
The authors present several references to justify the relevance of their proposal. First, I don't get how the proposal is related to the references. Moreover, the references are not presented in a coherent way. Indeed, cooperative communications were introduced at the level of a source-destination pair, using one or several relays in order to increases the spatial diversity of the source-destination link. Here, the authors' concern is related to a path between a source node and a destination node. The path consists of a source node, a destination node, and several relays. The issues here are rather related to network and routing issues. This way to consider cooperative communications has been already considered in [1]. The point here is that the authors should be clear about the abstraction level they choose to tackle the issue. As soon as you consider a path and not a single source-destination pair, you address routing and network issues (network as the third layer of the OSI model) rahter than communication issues. The difference should be clearly pointed out. To summarize, the approach needs to be further justified and the authors should motivate the model they focus on.
Moreover, many papers have already address the relay selection issue without explicitly mentionning the mobility of the nodes. The fact that the mobility should be addressed should also be motivated. The seminal work in [2], or other works like [3] already addressed the relay selection issue. My point here is that the model needs to be further motivated.

System model
Do the author have an idea of a realistic scenario presented in the first sentences of the "System Model" section ?
The notation with an asterisk is awkward since it often denote the complex conjugate. We know form the alphabet of emitted symbol that we deal with a BPSK. Please introduce the modulation here. The authors should provide a short explanation of (5). What is the point in considering 57) as a performance indicator rather than (6) ?
I feel a little bit confused with the lable of the node. Indeed, since the early works on cooperative communications in 2003, the "assistant nodes" are refered to as "relay nodes". In this paper, relays nodes are just nodes on a path between a source and a destination. 
The third condition in 2.2 needs further motivation. Moreover, even if the paper presents a method to select assistant nodes, there is a missing step here, in my opinion: assistant nodes should be allocated to the route. I mean assistant node should be aware, somehow, that they must help the forwarding of packets from the source to the sink.
The TDMA approach has been already used in approaches in [4]. Moreover, the amount of time dedicated to the selection process seems to be time consuming (100 slots !).
Moreover, BER is not the suitable indicator in this context because it depends on the modulation type. All the seminal works on cooperative communucations rather use a more general parameter: the outage probability.
The integration of a MRC receiver implies a way to synchronize emitters. This issue is not addressed but is of paramount interest.

Cooperative strategy in a MWN
Again, the allocation of A1 and A2 to the process should be adressed.
I don't get why the source node should transmit its packet during three time-slots since the advantage of having overhearing terminals is that we don't have to transmit the packet several times but once for all. I don't get why relaying nodes A1 and A2 should transmit an ACK to S since they are supposed to be in the range of S. Since they are in the range of S, they should be able to decode successfully the packets from S. Moreover, lot of overhead is needed here and that counterbalances drastically the avdantage of spatial diversity considered in cooperative networks. 

ECoRSS
As we go deeper in the explanation of the protocol, other issues appear in the rationale of the approach. Indeed, the protocol depends on ADV packets. However, we know that the network conditions will vary a lot between the receiving of two ADV packets, and the point of the authors is to adapt dynamically to the network conditions. The ADV-based adaptation is a long-term adaptation whereas the authors refer to short-terms variations of the SNR. This is a contradiction here, in my opinion.

[1] P. Liu, Z. Tao, S. Narayanan, T. Korakis, and S. S. Panwar, "Coopmac: A cooperative mac for wireless lans." IEEE J. Sel. Areas Commun.,vol. 25, no. 2, pp. 340-354, 2007.
[2] A. Bletsas, A. Khisti, D. P. Reed, and A. Lippman, "A simple cooperative diversity method based on network path selection," IEEE J. Sel. Areas Commun., vol. 24, no. 3, pp. 659-672, 2006.
[3] B. Escrig, "Outage probability of an optimal cooperative mac protocol in nakagami-m channels," in Proc. IEEE 7th International Conference on Mobile Adhoc and Sensor Systems (MASS), 2010, pp. 31-40.
[4] A. Azgin, Y. Altunbasak, and G. AlRegib, "Cooperative mac and routing protocols for wireless ad hoc networks," in Proc. IEEE Global Telecommunications Conference (GLOBECOM), vol. 5, 2005.


Reviewer #5: The paper proposed a TDMA based relaying scheme for multiple hop wireless networks, which is important for improving the efficiency of wmn. The paper is well organized and well written. While there are some concerns about the paper

1. This paper compares eCoRSS with another TDMA based work, i.e., cooper-ative relaying TDMA (CR-TDMA) [4]. I would like to see the performance analysis compared with other relevant works.
2. With the introducing of the assistant relaying nodes, the security and network reliability will be affected and should be discussed.
3. In selecting the optimal nodes, other than SNR, should other factors such as traffic load queue, also been taken account?

fields.content:
Dear Prof. Kim

COM-2016-0069

Retransmission Scheme of Error Correction using Fake Error Addition

Thank you for submitting your paper to IET Communications. The peer review process is now complete. The referees and I feel that your paper requires significantly more work and is not acceptable for publication in its current form.  My decision is therefore to decline your paper with encouragement to submit a substantially revised paper.  I appreciate that this decision will be a disappointment, but hope that you find the referees' comments (given below) useful in improving your paper.

If, following comprehensive revision, you should choose to submit your paper again, please go to https://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/iet-com. Enter the Author Centre and go to 'Manuscripts with Decisions'. Click on 'Create a Resubmission' next to the paper number and follow the instructions given.

When submitting a revised manuscript, please ensure that all points raised by the referees have been actioned, and include a detailed covering letter explaining the changes made.  Note that the revised paper will be treated as a completely new submission and sent out for a fresh round of reviewing.

Please note that you have until the 21-Jul-2016 to make improvements to your paper. If you need more time, it is important that you inform the IET office before the deadline so they may be able to grant an extension. If you are having trouble resubmitting your paper, please contact the IET office directly by replying to this email.

Yours sincerely

Prof. Xuemin Shen
IET Communications

Associate Editor
Comments to Author:
(There are no comments.)

Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
The authors proposed an idea of trimming codeword to improve the bandwidth efficiency of transmission, in particular for the transmissions over good channels. Roughly speaking, the proposed trimming scheme removes some coded bits from a codeword so as to reduce the number of required transmission. If the channel quality is in good conditions, i.e., less error will occur during those transmissions, then the removed parts are likely to be recovered by the powerful error-correction capability of the code. Some of my personal concerns are listed below.

1. Since the correlation between the trimmed parity bits and the systematic parts are not considered, it is not clear to me why the trimmed parity bits are required to be distributed and replace the systematic bits. We may consider the following scheme to emphasize this point. Suppose that the post-processing of an LDPC encoder only removes some systematic bits of a codeword and we transmit the partial codeword. At the receiver, a uniform binary random number generator is used to guess the removed systematic bits. If the information bits are uniformly distributed, then each of the guesses will be correct with fifty percent chance. Afterwards, the decoder is enabled to decode such received codeword. To me, it seems no difference between the proposed scheme and this scheme. And in fact, such a random guess strategy has been applied to help the decoding of punctured codes; their main idea is also to reduce the retransmission by exploiting the powerful correction capability of channel codes.

2. I agree with that sometimes the data protection is provided more than the needs. In this case, bandwidth efficiency is not so well. Therefore, puncturing is usually adapted to alleviate this situation. Puncturing is commonly used in convolutional codes because it can simplify the procedure of finding good puncturing patterns.  In the proposed scheme, the locations of the replaced systematic bits are also required to be optimized. For block codes, I think that it is not an easy job, and this paper does not discuss much on this part, too. It will be much interesting if some criteria or observation to determine the locations of replacing are provided.

Many typos and imprecise operations are found in this manuscript. For example,
a. Line 10 of paragraph 2, page 2, “ar the same time” should be “at …”
b. Some subscripts in Lemma 1 are not in correct form.
c. Line 2 in Lemma 2, “hwere” should be “where”
d. Line 5 in page 6, “…parity note being damaged” should be “… not being …”
e. Line 1 of paragraph 5, page 7, “The transmitter than get” should be “… then get…”
f. In Lemma 1, the authors write P_{rec}=(\bar{c}, r, \bm{H})-P_{err}(C)=n>0, where $n$ is number of errors while P_{rec} is the maximum recovery probability. How can the two quantities be compared?
g. In (1), the minus and plus operations are not well-defined. Are they corresponding to removing and appending of strings, respectively?

Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
This paper proposed a novel scheme to reduce retransmission latency by using a trimming code on LDPC. It would be better if the authors work on how to choose parity-checks and messages to improve the performance. Moreover, there are no examples to concretely illustrate how many time can the proposed method reduce the retransmission communicate. Last, a comparison with the method proposed in [6] may help to further investigate the ability of the proposed method to reduce retransmission latency.

Here are my detailed comments:
1)      Please briefly discuss the novelty of this paper compared with [6] and add some simulations to show the retransmission latency of the proposed method under different trimmed code conditions.

2)      As shown in Fig.7, the 5% trimmed code requires the almost least iterations compared with the other trimmed codes when the SNR level is larger than 7. However, when SNR level is smaller than 7, the 5% trimmed code requires the largest iterations compared with the other trimmed codes. Hence, it might be worth explaining the reason of the surge in the iterations of the 5% trimmed code.

3)      On page 9 ” The code reaches the limit of its ability for the 7% trimmed code condition. This is because when the SNR level is 6, the code cannot be corrected”. However, it does not show the iteration number of the 7% trimmed code at the SNR level of 6 in Fig.7. Please complete the curve of the 7% trimmed code and add the curve of the 10% trimmed code which is also mentioned in this paper.

4)      There are some minor mistakes in writing, for example:
"hwere" in Line 2 of the Lemma 2 of Page 3 should be "where”
In Line 8, Page 5, there are two “.”s.
"ar" in Line 7, Page 5 should be "at”
“Figure 8” in Line 10, Page 7 should be " Figure 5”

5) It would be better if the authors add more advanced techniques,  recent algebraic construction, decoding based on majority logic and low-complexity encoding based Galois FFT, in their description of LDPC codes to show that QC-LDPC codes are suitable for such retransmission scheme.

fields.subject: Seung-Han Kim - MIL-STD-1553B 데이터 버스 FPGA 시스템 설계 및 구현
fields.content:
심사위원 1

그림 1: Contro"nn"er --> Contro"ll"er
III 장 1.2 절 마지막 문장: 32 bit "프로세스"로서 --> 32 bit "프로세서"로서
IV 장 하부 절 구성이 균형이 잘 맞지 않음. (1절의 제목은 사실 "~환경"이 붙어야 2절과 명확히 구분이 됨)
         하부 절을 1. MIL~ 규정에서 요구하는 기준 요건, 2. 실험 환경 설정, 3. 실험 결과
        와 같이 다시 정리하고 1절에서 수신 레벨 규정, 출력 레벨 규정, 응답 시간 규정, 에러률 규정 등을 설명하고 나머지 내용을 정리하는 것도 좋을 듯.
        꼭 위와 같이 하지 않더라도 하부절 구성이 균형이 맞게 내용이 연결되게 정리할 필요가 있음. 



심사위원 2

본 논문을 기술논문으로 분류한 이유는 해당 논문의 초점이  MIL-STD-1553B 데이터 버스가 RT, BC, BM 등 다양한 모드를 지원하기 위해서는 비용 증가의 단점이 있기  때문에 이를 해결하기 위해 RT 모드 만을 지원하는 FPGA를 설계 구현하는 데 초점을 맞추고 있기 때문이다.

따라서 2장에서 서술한 기존 시스템의 문제점들이 기술적인 문제라기 보다는 비용 측면에 초점을 맞추고 있어, 본 논문이 기존의 복잡한 시스템을 줄여 비용을 줄이는 문제 외에 어떤 어려운 기술적인 문제가 있는지 알 수 없다. 이는 3장에서도 마찬가지다.
RT 서브 시스템을 MIL-STD-1553 controller IP와 CPU IP를 FPGA device로 합성하여 구현하는 방안을 제시하였는데,
참고문헌 등을 통해 이러한 시도가 기존에 없었거나 해결하기 어려운 문제임을 보이지 않았다.

또한 논문에서 주장한 이점들로는  1) 소형화, 2) 부품 단종 위험성 감소, 3) 시스템 확장 및 수정 용이 등이 있었는데,
1) 실험 등에서 언급이 없었음.
2) 해당 프로토콜이 사장되지 않는한 부품 단종의 위험이 있는 것인지
3) 어떤 의미에서의 시스템 확장인지. RT외 다른 모드를 지원하는 것이라면 기존 시스템과 결국 동일하게 되는 것인데.
4) 비용 측면에서 어느 정도 이득인지.

논문에서의 몇 가지 typo 및 수정권고 사항들은 다음과 같다.
*abstract에서 have been required --> have required
*abstract에서 were used to --> are used for
*abstract에서 favorable about --> favorable with respect to cost effectiveness.
* 그림1에서 contronner --> controller
* 결론에서 위섬-->위험



편집위원

본 논문은 MIL-STD-1553B 데이터 버스의 RT 서브시스템을 FPGA로 구현한 개발경험에 중점을 둔 기술논문으로 평가된다. 그러나 제목이 실제 구현한 내용을 명확하게 반영하고 있지 않고 모든 기능을 구현한 것으로 보여 제목을 한정지을 필요가 있을 것으로 보인다. 비용적 측면을 포함하여 자체 IP확보에 의한 장점은 일반적으로 이해할 수 있으나 동일한 기능이 구현되지 않은 상태에서 상용제품과의 비교 및 한계가 명확하게 제시되지 않고 있다. 기술논문의 관점에서도 구현시 발생하는 기술적 어려움과 해결방안을 제시할 필요가 있으나 본 논문에서는 기존 IP들을 특정 툴 환경하에서 연동시키는 방법에 중점을 두고 있어 기술적 기여도 또한 크지 않은 것으로 판단된다. 전체 시스템 구현에 있어서 새로 구현한 모듈과 최적화 내용 등을 중심으로 논문을 재구성 할 필요가 있다.
