fields.subject: Gabriel Amaizu, Danielle Agron, Jae-Min Lee, Dong-Seong Kim "Hybrid Deep Neural Network for Malicious DNS Infiltration Detection System" WCNC2021 (REJECTED)
fields.content:
Dear Mr. Amaizu,

We regret to inform you that your paper #1570690831, 'Hybrid Deep Neural Network for Malicious DNS Infiltration Detection System', has not been accepted for presentation at the IEEE WCNC 2021 Track 1 – Phy & Fundamentals.

The conference received a very high number of submissions and was thus very competitive. Each paper was carefully peer-reviewed by at least three TPC members. The reviews for your paper are given below and can also be found at https://edas.info/showPaper.php?m=1570690831.

We would like to thank you for submitting your manuscript to the conference. However, due to presentation slot limitations, many good and/or interesting papers could not be included in the program.

Understanding that the result is disappointing to you, we hope nonetheless that you will consider attending WCNC 2021 and submitting papers again to future editions of this conference.

Sincerely,
TPC Chairs
IEEE WCNC 2021

========================

======= WCNC Review 1 =======

> *** Strong Aspects: Comments to the author: What are the strong aspects of the paper?

In this paper, the authors proposed a deep neural network (DNN) architecture for classifying benign and malicious domain name system (DNS) over HTTPS (DoH) traffic.

> *** Weak Aspects: Comments to the author: What are the weak aspects of the paper?

1) The paper was not well written.  In the title, abstract, and Section I, the authors described the work as related to domain name system (DNS) over HTTPS (DoH).  However, it was unclear why the proposed deep neural network (DNN) architecture is appropriate for this problem. In Sections II and III, the authors did not justify the use of some of the parameters in the proposed architecture.

2) In the 4th paragraph in Section I, the authors mentioned that the proposed approach is based on unsupervised learning. However, in Section II.B, the authors used labeled dataset [8] for training.

3) Reference [8] was incomplete. The authors did not provide the name of the journal or conference proceedings.   

4) Although the authors compared the proposed scheme with Malportrait [6], Malportrait was not a state of the art technique. The authors should compare their proposed scheme with other algorithms.

> *** Recommended Changes: Recommended changes. Please indicate any changes that should be made to the paper if accepted.

Please refer to the comments in the "Weak Aspects" section. Moreover, there are many grammatical mistakes in the paper. Examples include the following:

- Abstract: "...malicious DoH CNN, )"

- 1st paragraph in Section 1: "internet of things" -> "Internet of things"

- 2nd bullet in Section I: The following sentence: "...the classifying accuracy and precision of the model in detecting malicious-DoH is significantly was" is NOT a complete sentence. 

- 4th bullet in Section I: "dropout layers is added" ->"dropout layers are added"

- In Figure 3, if the y-axis is in percentage, then the range should be from 0 to 100%, not from 0 to 1.

> *** Relevance and Timeliness: Rate the importance and timeliness of the topic addressed in the paper within its area of research.
Acceptable. (3)

> *** Technical Content and Scientific Rigour: Rate the technical content of the paper (e.g.: completeness of the analysis or simulation study, thoroughness of the treatise, accuracy of the models, etc.), its soundness and scientific rigour.
Marginal work and simple contribution. Some flaws. (2)

> *** Novelty and Originality: Rate the novelty and originality of the ideas or results presented in the paper.
Minor variations on a well investigated subject. (2)

> *** Quality of Presentation: Rate the paper organization, the clearness of text and figures, the completeness and accuracy of references.
Substantial revision work is needed. (2)

======= WCNC Review 2 =======

> *** Strong Aspects: Comments to the author: What are the strong aspects of the paper?

There is no strong aspects in this submission. Only the topic itself is interesting. Detection of DoH attacks (and DNS attacks) in general is a valid and important research problem.

> *** Weak Aspects: Comments to the author: What are the weak aspects of the paper?

The paper is superficial and poorly written. From little that is understandable, the authors just apply well known learning techniques offline on a publicly available data set. The methodology is poorly justified and full of unexplained "magic numbers". Why 3 convolution layers, and why not more or less? Why 128, 64 and 32 neurons in each? Why is the learning rate set to 0.001? Why (1), (2) and (3) and are there some other functions that result in even better performance?

Even the abstract contains broken and unintelligible sentences. Word "attacks" is missing twice. The introduction contains numerous grammar errors.

> *** Recommended Changes: Recommended changes. Please indicate any changes that should be made to the paper if accepted.

The study needs to be performed more thoroughly. There must be a formal model that leads to selection of optimum parameters for the convolutional network. This optimization of the CNN should be the gist of the work. The evaluation should be performed on diverse datasets, and even implemented on a real domain server. It must be clear whether the approach is implementable in real life and can it detect attacks in a timely manner.

> *** Relevance and Timeliness: Rate the importance and timeliness of the topic addressed in the paper within its area of research.
Good. (4)

> *** Technical Content and Scientific Rigour: Rate the technical content of the paper (e.g.: completeness of the analysis or simulation study, thoroughness of the treatise, accuracy of the models, etc.), its soundness and scientific rigour.
Questionable work with severe flaws. (1)

> *** Novelty and Originality: Rate the novelty and originality of the ideas or results presented in the paper.
Minor variations on a well investigated subject. (2)

> *** Quality of Presentation: Rate the paper organization, the clearness of text and figures, the completeness and accuracy of references.
Unacceptable. (1)

======= WCNC Review 3 =======

> *** Strong Aspects: Comments to the author: What are the strong aspects of the paper?

To improve the security, an unsupervised hybrid machine learning model is proposed for early detection and classification of benign and malicious DoH. The proposed scheme incorporates the swiftness of convolutional neural network (CNN) in extracting useful information and the ease of long short-term memory (LSTM) in learning long-term dependencies. From the simulation results, the proposed scheme was found to accurately classify benign and malicious DoH CNN, with an accuracy, precision and recall rate of 99.49\%, 99.23\% and 99.75\% respectively. Also, the model was compared to other contemporary algorithms.

> *** Weak Aspects: Comments to the author: What are the weak aspects of the paper?

1. The proposed method is simple and no mathematical analysis is provided.
2. The simulation results are not enough to show the performance of the proposed method.
3. CNN and LSTM are two classical deep learning methods. The application of them in DNS security is interesting. However, the motivation of doing this is not well explained.
4. The writing of this paper should be further improved.

> *** Recommended Changes: Recommended changes. Please indicate any changes that should be made to the paper if accepted.

1. The proposed method is simple and no mathematical analysis is provided.
2. The simulation results are not enough to show the performance of the proposed method.
3. CNN and LSTM are two classical deep learning methods. The application of them in DNS security is interesting. However, the motivation of doing this is not well explained.
4. The writing of this paper should be further improved.

> *** Relevance and Timeliness: Rate the importance and timeliness of the topic addressed in the paper within its area of research.
Acceptable. (3)

> *** Technical Content and Scientific Rigour: Rate the technical content of the paper (e.g.: completeness of the analysis or simulation study, thoroughness of the treatise, accuracy of the models, etc.), its soundness and scientific rigour.
Valid work but limited contribution. (3)

Some interesting ideas and results on a subject well investigated. (3)

Substantial revision work is needed. (2)

fields.content:
Manuscript Number: COMNET-D-20-00690   

Composite and Efficient DDoS Attack Detection Framework for B5G Networks

Dear Professor Kim,

Thank you for submitting your manuscript to Computer Networks.

I have completed my evaluation of your manuscript. The reviewers recommend reconsideration of your manuscript following major revision. I invite you to resubmit your manuscript after addressing the comments below. Please resubmit your revised manuscript by Jan 27, 2021.

When revising your manuscript, please consider all issues mentioned in the reviewers' comments carefully: please outline every change made in response to their comments and provide suitable rebuttals for any comments not addressed. Please note that your revised submission may need to be re-reviewed. 

To submit your revised manuscript, please log in as an author at https://www.editorialmanager.com/comnet/, and navigate to the "Submissions Needing Revision" folder.  

Computer Networks values your contribution and I look forward to receiving your revised manuscript.

Kind regards,     
Sabrina Sicari   
Area Editor  

Computer Networks

Editor and Reviewer comments:

Reviewer #1: The paper proposes a composite DDoS attack detection framework targeted to 5G and B5G. The envisioned solutions has been evaluated by means of an industry recognized dataset.

In general, the paper is well-structured and the motivations as well the methodology are clear.

However, some concerns must be addressed before publication:

* In Section 2, the authors should specofy the difference in their methodology (e.g., adopted algorithms) with respect to existing solutions. Moreover, the Reviewer suggests to cite the following related paper: "Miorandi et al, REATO: REActing TO denial of service attacks in the Internet of Things. Computer Networks: 137: 37-48 (2018)".
* Sections 3.2 and 3.6 could be mergefd together.
* Please try to refer to 5G components/network in Section 3, mainly with respect to Figure 3, which should represent the system model.
* In Section 4, the authors must specify the features of the considered network for simulation, in order to infer about scalability. More in detail, it is not clear how the chosen dataset has been practically used.
* Please check for some English mistakes, such as "When a user equipment (UE) send" should be "When a user equipment (UE) sends". In general, please carefully check che first part of Section 3.



Reviewer #2: The manuscript entitled "Composite and Efficient DDoS Attack Detection Framework for B5G Networks" discuss is some of the most interesting aspects related to secure communication in the context of 5G and beyond networks.
Despite the work carried out by the authors, the contribution has some weak points that must be addressed before the manuscript can be accepted for publication.

Overall opinion:
The way acronyms are introduced and used is misleading. In particular, the proper way to introduce an acronym is with the extended form i.e., Artificial Intelligence, followed by the short form, i.e., AI. From that point on, only the short form should be used. The comment must be conceived as a general consideration and addresses the proposed manuscript as a whole.
The quality of all the images presented is unacceptable for a journal, in general, even more so for one of this level. While Figures should provide further insight and a clarification of the proposed concepts, those presented in this work do not achieve at all such goals.
The authors should consider reporting measurement units behind square brackets. The Reviewer would like to point out that when a measurement unit is a pure number, the graph should report "[#]".
When reporting numbers and their measurement units, there may be a space between the two, or not. The two approaches are both correct since they are used uniformly throughout the whole work. The authors are advised to review the manuscript accordingly.
It is worth noting that the paper does not always follow template rules in terms of spacing and indentation.


Detailed comments:
In the Introduction:
The Y axis of figure 2 is unclear. It represents a percentage of what?

In Section II:
At the end of the introduction of this section, the authors argued that changes in topology may lead to an inefficient evaluation of possible attacks. Nevertheless, it is not clear if attackers are properly moving in order to change network topology or not. If it was so, there could be a pattern to be learned, and this could be used. If not, it is unclear what is causing movements, how many changes in topology are verified and out to study them.
It is quite odd to see only one subsection. Indeed, the subdivision is not needed since the authors envision artificial intelligence as a solution to the aforedescribed problems.

In Section III:
Figures 5 and 6 should be reviewed. The former reports some unclear measurement units on the Y axis. The ladder, instead, simply presents the way a data set can be split. Nevertheless, the figure doesn't add anything to a single sentence on the same topic. The authors should clarify the rationale for the choice instead of reporting useless figures.

In Section IV:
Figure 9 should be improved in quality.
At the end of the section, the authors should consider clarifying what the lessons learned are.

In Conclusions:
Future works are poorly discussed.

As for the references:
As for the references, the way references are reported should be the same for each of them. The authors should double-check the whole section.

Editor and Reviewer comments:

Reviewer #1: Overall, the literature survey is a positive and the described simulation results are well documented and positive. The real-world applicability is limited though by omission of some key simulation parameters, signs of over-fitting (e.g. Figure 8(h)). Overall, it is a positive paper and can be updated to a point of acceptance in my opinion.

Notes:

Performance and simulation discussion need much more detail as to what is included (e.g., SNR, motion, etc). No discussion of generalized behavior learning suggest the solution is brittle.
- Given you are operating int he 2.4 GHz ISM band, need to describe the conditions of other interfering signals in the spectrum; if none, that limits the extensibility of the observed performance.
- Figures appear largely out of place in the document
- Looking at figure 3/Table 3, the results appear "too" good. How have you ensured that you are not over-fitting? Why continue beyond epoch ~50?
- What SNR are you operating? This looks to be the case for an extremely high SNR. How does the performance degrade as function of SNR.
- Figure 4/5: the abrupt changes in accuracy / loss measurements suggest overfitting
Paper needs a thorough proof-reading: page 2 ("illegal's"), page 2/3 (paragraph "In addition..."), commas before clauses, ensure acronyms are spelled out ("NBC"), etc


Reviewer #2: 1. Original Submission

2. Comments to Author:
Mr. Ref. No.: COMNET-D-20-00771
Title: Convolution Neural Network Inspired Surveillance System for UAVs Detection and Identification
Overview and general recommendation:
Information security of aviation is very important to city management. Modelling an identification of UAVs in RF is still a great challenge. Due to its spatial and temporal variability, classifying UAVs in RF is looked upon to be a good tool for modelling an identification of UAVs.
The authors presented a convolution neural network based on surveillance system for drone detection and identification namely CNN-SSDI. The network architecture is designed based on the deep convolution layers to successively learn intrinsic feature maps of radio-frequency signals that are collected from three different types of drones. The authors performed careful and thorough modeling and training processing.
On the other hand, this study should add more experiments. It is recommended the type of UAVs increased to 5 or more. The description of the experiment should be more detailed, and the authors should show some insights about why the proposed method achieves the better accuracy than other methods. Furthermore, the study needs to be reorganized. Some paragraphs are too long and the position of the diagrams is not appropriate, resulting in low readability.

2.1. Major comments:
1. Page 3, Lines 5-6. The author claims that it is a feasible way to obtain signals by RF. The authors should provide a feasible reason or cite literature to support this argument.
2. The author should reorganize Section 2. The methods of related works in this section should be segmented to increase readability.

3. Section 3 and Section 5. The authors should present more detail of the data collection. What kind of sequences did the authors collect? Completely random? If possible, show some examples.

4. Section 4. Is the proposed system only suitable for identifying with three types of drones? If the recognized types are increased to 5, what is the performance of the model?

5. Section 4. The authors should show not only iteration, but also other parameter setting such as learning rate and dropout.

6. Section 4. A detailed description of Fig. 4 is necessary.

7. Section 4. How long does the model run 200 epochs? If the running time is too long, it is not efficient to retrain/update the recognition model.


8. Section 5.3. Regarding the processing of time series problems with deep learning models, LSTM is often applied. Authors should compare the results with it.

9. Section 5.3. The authors should show some insights about why the proposed method achieves the better accuracy than other methods.

For example:
The text description of Table 2 is on page 13, but the table is listed on page 6.
The text description of Fig. 1 is on page 8, but the figure is on page 4.

fields.subject: Saviour Igboanusi,"Low Latency VUH (VLC-UWB Hybrid) Network for Logistics Center Mobile Robots"
fields.content:
04-Dec-2020

Dear Dr. Kim:

I write you in regards to manuscript # JCN20-DIV3-022 entitled "Low Latency VUH (VLC-UWB Hybrid) Network for Logistics Center Mobile Robots" which you submitted to the Journal of Communications and Networks.

In view of the criticisms of the reviewers found at the bottom of this letter, your manuscript has been denied for publication in the Journal of Communications and Networks.

Thank you for considering the Journal of Communications and Networks for the publication of your research.  I hope the outcome of this specific submission will not discourage you from the submission of future manuscripts.

URL: http://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/jcommnet

Sincerely,

Dr. Klaus Witrisal
Editor, Journal of Communications and Networks
witrisal@tugraz.at

Reviewer(s)' Comments to Author:

Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
The authors proposed an hybrid network that consists of visible light communication (VLC) and ultra-wide band (UWB) technologies to reduce acknowledgment/feedback process for a mobile robot within a warehouse. Moreover, the authors also claimed that the proposed hybrid network architecture improves the communication security. Overall, the submitted manuscript does not provide any mathematical proof or equation that clarifies how the proposed system is able to achieve the claimed points. For more detailed comments, please see below.
1) "Reducing acknowledgment/feedback processing time": As only one technology (UWB) is used for the uplink transmission, this statement doesn't sound correct. Most of the acknowledgment and feedback signals are sent from UE/robot to BS/AP - so there is a bottleneck on the uplink transmission which will be the problematic for the proposed hybrid network.
2) There is no introduction regarding UWB. Why did you choose UWB? What is the motivation for considering UWB instead of any other RF technology? UWB also requires LoS link in order to have a reliable link performance. Thus, a clear motivation should be provided on considering UWB as the hybrid network part for VLC.
3) There are several statements that need justification. Few of these statements are as follows:
(i) "But the up-link is not efficient as upward illumination is not necessary and energy inefficient": this statement is not correct. You are not using visible light for the uplink, it is a infra-red link and it does not require illumination. So, it does not affect the energy efficiency etc.
(ii) "Other authors in [22] proposed the use of infrared for up-link and VLC for down-link, which did not have the problems associated peculiar with [16], but has limited data rate for up-link and worked in small LoS.": the referred paper can be considered as outdated as several recently published studies have provided more in-depth analysis for VLC uplink. Moreover, there are few VLC/LiFi products available in the market that achieves <40 Mbps for both uplink and downlink transmission.
(iii) "However, the paper focused on outdoor environments as against the idea of indoor scenarios in this paper.": This is not correct. The paper surveyed indoor and outdoor scenarios.
(iv) "Following the four steps significantly delay the arrival of the acknowledgment.": what is the other AP here? Is it non-VLC network element? It is not clear why there is a delay on acknowledgment.
(v) "Fig. 5 shows an example of how one cluster of LEDs can be inadequate for a warehouse.": The figure does not represent a realistic scenario as with the given LED distribution, there will be no or too little light/illumination on the position where the robot is shown. So, it will be a dark area in the warehouse. No need to show/discuss using single LED in such a big warehouse as it won't provide the required illumination level at all.
(vi) "The mechanism is incorporated to detect when one of the network is hack.": It is not clear how do you detect the network is hacked. If you can detect it there will be no problem, the actual problem is that the network is not aware of an eavesdropper.
4) Overall, the paper needs a major work on the language and organization of the paper. The abstract is composed of disconnected sentences. It is not easy to understand the contribution of the paper from the abstract. Also, there are lots of grammatical errors. At some parts, there is a sudden change from description given for VLC to UWB.

Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
In this paper, the author presents a hybrid RF-VCL network structure in which UWB technology has been adopted as bi-directional RF access.  The work is interesting, but anything is new. The VLC channel model is classic LOS-NLOS channel model. The simulation results on VLC channel are too optimal.  I did see any mechanism or processing about hybrid network with the combination of VLC and UWB.  and I don't see any discussion detailed about the security with choice of constituent network technologies that you mentioned at the beginning of your paper.   I think it has not enough novel points and not enough results for our journal of communications and networks.

Reviewer: 3

Comments to the Author
The paper proposes a combination of VLC and UWB for a network used in logistics.

Main concern: in Fig. 10 and the text, an SNR of 1350 dB is described. This has to be a mistake, and you should know that 1350dB is not a plausible value for any SNR!

Another problem not discussed in the paper is the fact that the UWB communication which is used for the uplink is prone to NLOS situations (especially in a warehouse with shelves, etc). In these cases, the acknowledgement does not arrive at the network. How is this handled in Algorithm 1?

In Fig. 6, the LED coverage area is shown. If I see it correctly, there are spots without coverage. How does that influence the algorithms?

In general, the introduction is too long compared to the main part of the paper (there are 5 columns of introduction, which is about the length of the rest of the paper). Furthermore, proof reading of the manuscript is necessary (Math in text if often wrong, e.g., tau without \,  foc and fof without subscript, etc.).

Dear Prof. Kim:

I am writing in regards to manuscript ID TCAS-II-08909-2020 entitled "NM500: An Artificial Intelligence Chip Based on Neuromorphic Technology" which you submitted to the IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems II: Express Briefs.

Your manuscript has been reviewed by several experts in the field. Thank you for considering the IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems II: Express Briefs for the publication of your research. I hope the outcome of this specific submission will not discourage you from your submission of future manuscripts.

jdelarosa@ieee.org


Editors' Comments to the Authors:

Associate Editor
Comments to the Author:
In view of the criticisms in the reviews that can be found attached, I recommend to reject the manuscript for publication in IEEE TCAS-II. The manuscript does not present enough novelty, and it is not even properly supported. Besides, the paper is not well written.


Reviewers' Comments to the Authors:

Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
The paper entitled “NM500: An Artificial Intelligence Chip Based on Neuromorphic Technology” presents the Neuromorphic chip NM500, suitable for developing many different artificial intelligence tasks. The authors present accuracy data related to the EMNIST dataset and compare the obtained results to other CNNs as AlexNet, VGGNet and GoogleNet. The paper tackles a trending topic in the research line of artificial intelligence, which is the hardware implementation of neuromorphic networks that could outperform GPUs and CPUs in terms of classification accuracy, energy efficiency and speed. However, the statements claimed by the authors are not properly explained and justified. The paper needs major revisions, but it could be suitable for publication after the correction of the following points:

1. The writing style of the paper should be slightly modified since some information provided by the authors are more suitable for an informative article than a scientific one (e. g. economic data and stakeholders instead of giving technical quantitative data and references).
2. Revise the particle “Neuro…” as many times the authors have written “Nuero…”. Correct other English mistakes (e. g. Line 52, page 3: “The EMNIST dataset is a balanced and improvement …”).
3. It is absolutely not clear how the authors have performed the comparison among AlexNet, VGGNet, GoogleNet and NM500. In addition, the authors do not include any experimental data or theory that could support the results presented. The accuracy data presented and the sentences “the system outperforms …” should be properly justified, explaining more in depth the architecture of the network (layers? MLP? CNN?), the kind of neuromorphic technology employed (supervised? unsupervised? SNN + maxpooling?) and, obviously, the technical novelties introduced by this new network (hardware implemented?) that make it so interesting.
4. “Parallel architecture” does not exactly imply “scalable”.
5. Explain the difference between “accuracy per image” and “accuracy per character”. Does not each image represent a different character?
6. References are poor.
7. Figures could be highly improved (e. g. Fig. 1 shows a book, or sheets below the boards).


Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
The paper does not contain any circuit or system level contribution. The provided material is good for a project report or a data sheet. Following main points are missing in the presented manuscript:
a) Overview is not a contribution of the work
b) Demonstrating performance without detailing circuit or system level design also is not contribution.
c) (Very important) To further improve the quality of the manuscript, it is crucial to make technical comparisons with state-of-the-art works. The overview, description, results, discussion, conclusion section do not make ANY comparison with the existing works. Also, it would be much better if quantitative comparison are made. A comparison table for the measurement results with state-of-the-art works will be good addition.

Reviewer: 3

Comments to the Author
TCAS-II-08909-2020 NM500: An Artificial Intelligence Chip Based on Neuromorphic Technology

This paper claims to present a framework to deploy an AI accelerator chip NM500 for general AI applications with evaluation results. The authors provide an overview along with some implementation details. Generally, it is useful for this community to know more about the use of NM500 through reading this manuscript. However, this paper is not well suited with the scope of TCAS2, because of the following concerns:

1. This paper is lack of novelty. The use of the existing chip NM500 for accelerating the NN computing is not new, as is already presented in the NM500 website. As I could understand, essential materials are provided mainly in Section III (implementation) and Section IV (results). However, there is no clear comparison between this work and others in terms of implementation novelty, which is critical to understand the key advances over existing designs.

2. This paper is lack of support. The authors claim NM500 applications, which include, quote, “finds ready application in surveillance, face recognition, industrial inspection and control, laser marking, and smart systems”. However, the evaluation results were only based on EMNIST, which is a rather low-complexity scenario compared with other tasks.

3. This paper is not well written. First of all, the title reads as a technical description of NM500 rather than a deployment framework; Second, for TCAS2 papers, the authors should spend the limited pages for the key technical idea and not the background; Third, many writing issues could be found, for example (not all listed here): in presented —> is presented; paper compared —> this paper compares; state of the art —> the state of the art. In addition, NeuroGrid is from Stanford University, not “standforth university”.

My suggestion for this work, is that the authors may consider providing more details, more technical innovations, more evaluation results and submit to a regular-length journal.

Reject with an invitation to New Submit - Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters

Body:

Dear Professor Dong-Seong Kim:

Your paper GRSL-00053-2021 LSTM Based Solar Irradiance Prediction from Remote Sensing of Meteorological Data has been carefully reviewed by the GRSL review panel and found to be unacceptable in its present form. The reviewers did suggest, however, that if completely revised the paper might be found acceptable. We encourage you to revise and resubmit this manuscript as a new paper to GRSL.

***If you do decide to resubmit the paper, please include a point-by-point response to the comments of the reviewers along with the new paper in order to expedite its review.  Use the "Submit a Resubmission" link in your author centre when you submit the new manuscript.  Your resubmission is due by 27-May-2021***


Below you will find comments from the review panel. Any attached files that may be referenced with these comments can be accessed in a copy of this decision letter located in your Author Center on ScholarOne Manuscripts.

Sincerely,
Dr Avik Bhattacharya
Editor-in-Chief
IEEE Geoscience and Remote Sensing Letters


Associate Editor Comments:
Associate Editor
Comments to the Author:
Dear Authors,
After a first round revision, your manuscript has been found not suitable for a final publication in its present form.
It is not fully clear the novelty introduced (methodology?) and the role of remote sensing data  (in situ measurements usually do not rely on the remote sensing principle).
Please carefully follow the suggestions of the reviewers.

Reviewer(s) Comments:
Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
The solar irradiance prediction is an indispensable area to the photovoltaic power management system. However, PV management may be subject to serious penalties due to the unsteadiness pattern of photovoltaic output power that depends on solar radiation. A high-precision LSTM based neural network model named SIPNet to predict solar irradiance in a short time interval is proposed to overcome this problem. Solar irradiation depends on the environmental sensing of meteorological information such as temperature, pressure, humidity, wind speed, and direction, which are different dimensions in measurement. LSTM neural networks can concurrently learn the spatiotemporal of multivariate input features via various logistic gates. Moreover, SIPNet can estimate the future solar irradiance given the historical observation of the meteorological information and the radiation data. The SIPNet model is simulated and compared with the actual and predicted data series and evaluated by the Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Mean Square Error (MSE), Root Mean Square Error (RMSE). The empirical results show that the value of MAE, MSE, and RMSE of SIPNet is 0.0413, 0.0033, and 0.057, respectively, demonstrating the effectiveness of SIPNet and outperforms other existing models. I recommend the following revisions. Besides, some questions need to be explained below:
1. In the manuscript, the Figures' quality is inferior; please replace the Figures with high-quality ones. (for example, figures 2, …)
2. The work's novelty must be clearly addressed and discussed, compare your research with existing research findings, and highlight novelty.
3. English language should be carefully checked, and carefully check the paper for language typos. The use of English must be improved.
4. The authors are requested to reconfirm that the references are in the IEEE style.
5. The authors must provide a detailed flowchart of the methodology of the paper.
6. The author must explain in more detail in Figure 1 the solar irradiance framework studied in this paper.
7. Section II focuses on solar irradiance, but the author spends most of his text explaining the principle of photovoltaic power generation.

Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
This paper proposed a solar irradiance prediction method, which is very important for PV power forecasting and PV power consumption.
However, although the authors mentioned Remote Sensing of Meteorological Data in the title, it seems that the meteorological data used in this research has nothing to do with Remote Sensing. Therefore, I think this paper is more inclined to the traditional irradiance prediction research which is not suitable for publication in GRSL.
Meanwhile, the contribution and innovation of this paper are not clear as well, as LSTM and its related algorithms have been widely used in the field of renewable energy power prediction.

Date Sent:

25-March-2021

fields.content:
IEEE Internet of Things Journal

Decision Letter (IoT-16075-2021)

Subject:

IoT-16075-2021 Decision and Suggestion

Body:

09-Apr-2021

Paper:IoT-16075-2021 Cost-Efficient DDoS Attack Detection: A Hybrid Filter-based Parameter Selection Approach
Authors:  Prof. Dong-Seong Kim, Amaizu, Gabriel; Akpudo, Ugochukwu; Lee, Jae; Kim, Dong-Seong
Editor: Prof. Yan Zhang

Dear Prof. Kim,

I am writing to you concerning the above referenced manuscript, which you submitted to the IEEE Internet of Things Journal.

Although it has merit, based on the enclosed set of reviews this manuscript has been rejected for publication in the IEEE Internet of Things Journal.

You may wish to consider the comments of the reviewers and submit it to another journal.

If you have any questions regarding the reviews, please contact the Associate Editor: Prof. Yan Zhang yanzhang@ieee.org.  Any other inquiries should be directed to the Administrative Assistant: Mariola Piatkiewicz m.piatkiewicz@ieee.org

Thank you for considering IEEE Internet of Things Journal for publication of your work.

Sincerely,
Prof. Honggang Wang
Editor-in-Chief, IEEE Internet of Things Journal
hwang1@umassd.edu, wanghbell@yahoo.com

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
• Associate Editor Comments, if any, are listed below:

Associate Editor: Zhang, Yan
Comments to Author:
This paper proposed a hybrid filter-based parameter selection approach for DDoS attack. Generally, there is not enough contribution. The feature selection scheme to mitigate the curse of dimensionality has been extensively studied. The most parts of the paper introduce the background and related works. The contributions are missing even in the introduction section. The authors also set important parameters, i.e., heuristic threshold, as fixed value, making it difficult for reproduce of the experiments. The reviewers also raised major concerns on the writing issues, the experimental settings, and the explanation of algorithms.

• Reviewer Comments, if any, are listed below:

Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
In this paper, a hybrid filter for feature extraction is proposed to reduce the computational complexity and improve the detection accuracy. In this paper, important features are extracted by chi-square and redundancy calculation. The experimental results show that the efficiency and precision of DDoS attack detection are improved by using the filtered features. However, this paper has the following problems:
1. Why set the heuristic threshold at -0.8? How did this number come about?
2. In Algorithm 1, why are features whose importance level attribute is lower than threshold P retained?
3. Some close related works, especially the new and important DDoS attack detection schemes should be reviewed, such as “A DDoS attack detection and mitigation with software-defined Internet of Things framework”, “DDoS Detection and Defense Mechanism Based on Cognitive-Inspired Computing in SDN”, “TDDAD: Time-Based Detection and Defense Scheme Against DDoS Attack on SDN Controller” and “Privacy-preserving DDoS attack detection using cross-domain traffic in software defined networks”.
4. Spelling errors are common throughout the paper, as are the descriptions in some of the figure.


Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
In this paper authors discuss a DDoS attack detection framework which involves the impact of curse of dimensionality. They discussed on elimination of redundant and highly correlated features followed by a wrapperbased feature ranking by importance. However, a few concerns in the paper.

1. The major contributions of the paper are missing in the Introduction section. The related work can be improved in the direction of the proposed work.
2. Few typos are in the paper. For example, “only relevant parameters with high discriminative power are retained wile redundant/irrelevant parameters are discarded.”

With reference to Eq.2 , please check and correct this sentence “It makes use of the euclidean distance formula given in Eq. (2) o makes i prediction. This algorithm is quite simple and comes with very love computational costs”

Check Eq.3, X and Y must be subscript.
1. Check Eq 4, stat and end index are missing. For measuring the accuracy of the model, it is essential to provide an accuracy equation.
2. With referring to the first line, Section IV (B). It seems very confusing. Equ 1. Bayse Theorem but the authors claim is different.
3. Algorithm 1 has not been properly explained. A stepwise explanation is much needed. Also, it must ensure, why the significance level and correlation threshold are selected as 0.05 and 0.9 respectively?
4. For proper evaluation sharing the dataset is essential.
5. Related to Feature set comparison with other datasets and CICD dataset is essential. Since feature selection is the major contribution of the paper. Since these data collected during the era of 5G, what are the extra feature, these new datasets contain?
6. Authors may consider few recent articles related to DDOS detection and feature selection.

a. Sahoo, Kshira Sagar, and Deepak Puthal. "SDN-Assisted DDoS Defense Framework for the Internet of Multimedia Things." ACM Transactions on Multimedia Computing, Communications, and Applications (TOMM) 16.3s (2020): 1-18.
b. Ravindranath, Vaishali, et al. "Swarm intelligence based feature selection for intrusion and detection system in cloud infrastructure." 2020 IEEE Congress on Evolutionary Computation (CEC). IEEE, 2020.
c. Sahoo, Kshira Sagar, et al. "An evolutionary SVM model for DDOS attack detection in software defined networks." IEEE Access 8 (2020): 132502-132513.


Reviewer: 3

Comments to the Author
This paper proposes a hybrid feature filter method. The paper is well written, clear and easy to read. However, I think there is no significant contribution.

All the provided information is known, and nothing new is provided.

Using one dataset in the experiments is not enough to evaluate the efficiency of the proposed method.

There is no comparison with other feature selection methods.


Note: If any of the reviews include an additional attached file, it will not be attached to this message. To access it, log in your Author Center and click on "Decision (View Letter)" -- this brings up this message, and at the bottom is the attached file. Click on that file name and you can see the attached comments from reviewers.

Reviewer 1:
Dear corresponding author,
the paper is interesting and it requires minor spelling revisions.
However, it requires a major revision before final submission:
1 - the Introduction is very poor. Add more research and compare the main pros and cons of other estimation techniques and other ANNs (as NARX , for example consider to include the following work that evaluates different kinds of ANNs: 
Bonfitto, A., Feraco, S., Tonoli, A., Amati, N., & Monti, F. (2019). Estimation accuracy and computational cost analysis of artificial neural networks for state of charge estimation in lithium batteries. Batteries, 5(2), 47.) Also please include a comparison to other works in current literature to highlight your  

2 - the experimental data is quite poor. The validation and training data are too similar. Try to present also another case for validation.

3 - A picture of the used hardware setup is useful for the reader. Consider to include it in the paper.

4 - An image of the actually estimated temperature versus the "target" one is needed. The indication about the error only is not sufficient to prove the results.
Reviewer 2:
This manuscript proposes a temporal convolutional network with a two-stage sliding window strategy (TCN-TS-SW) to predict the temperature of nozzle in a Fused Deposition Modeling (FDM) 3D printing process. The results demonstrate that he proposed methodology can predict the temperature more accurately than other existing machine learning models. This is a theoretical paper, but the proposed methodology could be embedded in a closed loop system to control the temperature of the nozzle, one of the process parameters.
Some issues and recommendations are listed below.
1. What can the authors present about current nozzle temperature control systems? What are their drawbacks?
2. The failure of a 3D printed product can have multiple causes, individual or combined. How do the authors establish that a possible failure is due to temperature?
3. Although the paper is not focused on the experiment, the experimental section should be presented in more detail, including pictures of the equipment.
4. The paper mentions the proposed strategy can serve to build a predictive maintenance system. The authors should clearly state, the proposed strategy is dedicated to a predictive maintenance system or can be used to prevent the thermal degradation of the printed components. These are two totally different problems.
5. Figure 3. Why the temperature varies, except for the slight fluctuations?
6. What does the “Accuracy” in Figures 4(b) and 5(b) mean?

Reviewer 3:
The idea may be of interest. However, the paper does not contain sufficient technical information as a journal paper. 
Reviewer 4:
The subject of the work is remarkable, but it is necessary that
some parts are detailed.
First of all, the use of the algorithm you have developed is not yet
a system for maintenance (as stated in lines 50 and 63), although it could be an essential element. Currently, the system stops the operations (line 72) in the case in which the forecast detects an "anomalous trend" of the expected temperature values. This countermeasure is not conclusive, as it blocks the production process and does not guarantee that, due to this interruption, the product will be free of defects at the end of the process.
Finally, the activation of the fan (line 105) prevents a possible degradation of the product, but not of the production plant.
It would then be better to explain the symbols of equation (1): if m_l is a quantity that depends on the layer (indexed by l), it is not clear how R_b can be independent of l. The vector d (formed by l elements) does not appear in equation (1).
The statement that R^2 is between 0 and 1 (line 151) would appear to be incorrect. In the definition of R^2 used in Python at the address https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.metrics.r2_score.html
R^2 can become less than 0, even less than -1.
Therefore, it would be clearer to report after equation (3) the definition of R^2 you used.
The values shown in table 1 have no validity from a statistical point of view. If you try to train the neural network again by choosing another training subset from the actual dataset; or acquire another dataset by printing another specimen, how much will vary the values shown in the table? This information is quite significant because the difference between the values obtained using the two methods under comparison is only a few thousandths (2 for RMSE, 9 for MAE, 4 for R^2). It would be significant to provide confidence intervals for the nine results to show that they are disjoint and that the variations between the values shown in table 1 are not due to a statistical fluctuation.
Furthermore, the method you have developed seems to perform better (albeit slightly) if the sample produced is Type I of the standard. You don't say anything about what might happen when printing a specimen of a different type, for which your code's performance may not be the best.

From:

Subject:

IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics - Manuscript No. TII-21-0888

Body:


Dear Authors (CC to Associate Editor, Reviewers),

Thank you very much for submitting manuscript No. TII-21-0888: "Malicious Activity Classification using Network Traffic Characteristics in Smart Industrial Factory" to the   IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics as a Regular Paper submission.

The review process of your manuscript  referenced above has been completed. Much to my regret, I have to inform you that in the opinion of the reviewers and Associate Editor in charge, the submitted manuscript  is not suitable for publication in the   IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics.

For your reference, these comments of the reviewers are enclosed.

I look forward for your contribution, and hope to work with you again.

With my best wishes for your success,


Sincerely yours,

Dr. Ren Luo
Editor-in-Chief
IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics
http://tii.ieee-ies.org/
renluo@ntu.edu.tw

****************************************************
Encl.:
Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
This paper shows Malicious Activity Classification using Network Traffic Characteristics in Smart Industrial Factory. The Malicious Activity Classification is important but the author does not clearly the research. 1) From the Technical point of view, this paper does not give more details about Algorithm and formula, rather than it looks like a report about the framework of Smart Industrial Factory. How to collect data? How to handle data? They are all missing. 2) The core method in section III SYSTEM MODEL is not clear. For my opinion, this section should show mathematical formula, algorithm and case study related to Malicious Activity Classification.
In all, the technical section is missing. And I would like to reject this paper.


Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
The paper lacks novelty of research, its just a comparison of three ML classifiers. The system model is not realistic. Why the three classifiers achieve 62.6% accuracy.


Reviewer: 3

Comments to the Author
The authors proposed the research based on anomaly detection in IoT Network Intrusion dataset from HCRLab, Korea. The proposed scheme seams interesting and novel. However, I have following suggestions to improve its overall quality.
1. In the fourth part, for the given dataset, the process of feature engineering implementation and machine learning algorithm selection was not fully described. Besides, the design basis of comparative experiment was not fully explained, and the evaluation indicators mentioned in the process was also not specifically introduced.
2.There are several related works which are similar to the author's research contents, so it is suggested that the author should make a comparative analysis.
10.3233/IDA-163137;
https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/9116932;
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.cose.2020.101863;
https://doi.org/10.1002/spy2.86;
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.future.2020.02.017;  
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.scs.2020.102177
3. This paper only compared the classification performance of existing supervised machine learning methods on specific data sets, which is not innovative enough.

Associate Editor

The paper has significant weaknesses as identified by the reviewers.

fields.content: Dear Prof. Kim: The review of your paper VT-2021-01073: RFDOA-Net: An Efficient ConvNet for RF-based DOA Estimation in UAV Surveillance Systems has been completed. Please find below comments from the reviewers. ------------------------------------------------------ Editor's Comments: The paper was evaluated by the three original reviewers. While one reviewer is satisfied with the revised manuscript, the other two reviewers still have some concerns that need to be properly addressed by the authors in a possible resubmission. ------------------------------------------------------ Based on the reviewers' comments, publication of the paper in its present form is not recommended. It is recommended that you resubmit your manuscript as a Correspondence, WITHIN TWO MONTHS from the date of this email, revised in accordance with the comments. If you fail to do so, your paper will be considered withdrawn from the review process. Please note that, for a Correspondence, your final manuscript (including main body, figures, tables, and references) should be in double-columned with fonts no smaller than 10pt in the final IEEE typesetting with maximum page length 5 pages and 7 figures and tables (a subfigure is counted as one figure). An additional page can be added with the cost of US$220, bringing the maximum to 6 pages. If your correspondence paper has 6 pages, you must pay this charge in order to have it published. Please note that this recommendation of resubmission should not be treated as an implication of eventual acceptance of your paper. It only refers to a deferral of the editorial decision to see whether the reviewers' comments could be addressed. In the event that your revision is accepted, it must be in a format that is in accordance with IEEE final submission requirements. For detailed final submission requirements, kindly refer to the information for IEEE Authors guidelines contained on the website http:/www.ieee.org/pubs/authors.html. To submit your revision, please first log onto Manuscript Central (https://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/tvt-ieee). In the Author Center, you will see the entry "Revised Manuscripts with Decisions" under "My Manuscripts". Click this entry and you will see an entry with the current paper ID included in the list "Manuscripts with Decisions" at the bottom of the screen. Then click the "Create a revision" button in the entry for this paper to start submitting your revision. Additionally, you MUST submit a response file alongside you manuscript that details the changes you have made and addresses the issues raised by the reviewers. REVISION WITHOUT THIS FILE WILL BE REJECTED. The file must be added in Step 2 of the submission as "OPTIONAL SOURCE FILE - MAIN DOCUMENT." As the system keeps all the files from your earlier submission(s) for this paper, please remember to delete any files which are not part of this new revised submission. Sincerely yours, Daniel Benevides da Costa Editor, IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology ============================================== Reviews for VT-2021-01073 *Please note that there may be attached files that contain additional comments from the reviewers. To see these files, please log on to your "Author Center" at the Manuscript Central web site (https://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/tvt-ieee) and select this paper to see and download the files. ============================================== Reviewer: 2 ADDITIONAL COMMENTS TO THE AUTHOR: Authors have replied to my queries convincingly. I have no further comments. Reviewer: 1 ADDITIONAL COMMENTS TO THE AUTHOR: The Reviewer thanks the authors for their time and efforts in revising the correspondence. After reading the revised correspondence and the authors’ response letter, unfortunately, the Reviewer still has to raise major comments on this work, as follows: 1. In previous comment 2, the Reviewer suggests the authors to theoretically discuss the complexity of the proposed CNN framework and examine the impacts of system parameters on the complexity. This comment expects the authors to provide an analytical expression to quantify the complexity and explicitly show the impacts of system parameters on the complexity. However, the authors did not do so. The authors use a figure to show the complexity for a specific scenario, which does not show generalized insights into complexity discussion. Thus, the authors’ response to the Reviewer’s previous comment 2 is not satisfying. 2. In previous comment 3, the Reviewer suggests the authors to evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed CNN framework. This comment expects the authors to provide results showing the proposed CNN framework (e.g. in a relatively simplified scenario) matches the performance achieved by some existing schemes (e.g. those designed for this relatively simplified scenario). However, the authors did not do so. The authors use a table to show the so-called accuracy being improved when the number of samples, the number of filters, and the SNR increase. This conclusion is self-obvious, but does not provide the expected insights into the effectiveness of the proposed CNN framework. Also, the accuracy of over 87% for a very large number of samples and filters, as well as the RMSE of 0.109 for a very high SNR of 25dB are not practically important. Also, the authors use a figure to compare the accuracy and computational cost of the proposed framework with existing schemes. It is quite surprising to see that the proposed framework achieves a much higher accuracy with a much lower computational cost. Specifically, what is the cost for gaining such benefits? Without the theoretical characterization of complexity, such evaluation does not show much insight. 3. The presentation quality of this correspondence is still low. For example, “was designed” in the Abstract needs to be revised as “is designed”. Also, “a advanced CNN architecture” in Section I needs to be revised as “an advanced CNN architecture”. Furthermore, the comma after “can be presented as” above Eq. (5) should be removed. Reviewer: 3 ADDITIONAL COMMENTS TO THE AUTHOR: I thank the authors for addressing my comments from previous round. However, I still have some concerns-- 1. The general problem is to apply machine learning/deep learning for communications. In the introduction section, I don't see a clear connection that motivates the current problem statement. It is important to provide the readers some idea on why we need AI for communication system. Adding prominent overview papers in references is a good way to address this. Please see such references below: [1] "Artificial intelligence-enabled cellular networks: A critical path to beyond-5G and 6G." IEEE Wireless Communications 27, no. 2 (2020): 212-217. [2] "The roadmap to 6G: AI empowered wireless networks." IEEE Communications Magazine 57, no. 8 (2019): 84-90. Date Sent: 30-May-2021

fields.content:
IEEE Communication Letters

From:

"IEEE Communications Letters" <onbehalfof@manuscriptcentral.com>

Subject:

Comm Letters CL2021-0990 Rejected - No resubmission allowed

Body:

Dear Author(s):

The review of the referenced manuscript, CL2021-0990, entitled Adaptive LRFU Replacement Policy for Named Data Network in Industrial IoT, is now complete. I regret to inform you that based on the enclosed reviews and my own reading of your manuscript, I am unable to recommend its publication in IEEE Communications Letters.

Your paper may not be resubmitted for review. The reasons for this are as follows: The contribution of this paper is low and not sufficiently explained nor motivated. The literature has not been adequately reviewed, and important related studies are missing. Simulation and evaluation settings are also not sufficiently clear.
Additional comments include:

The reviewers' comments are found at the end of this email.

Thank you for submitting your work to the IEEE Communications Letters.

Regards,

Dr. Miguel Sepulcre
Associate Editor
IEEE Communications Letters

Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
The authors present a cache replacement strategy for NDN using recency
and frequency information of data. A simulated environment compares
the proposed adaptive LRFU algorithm with other, prominent approaches.

1. The main contributions of this paper are vague. I can trace LRFU
back to a publication of Donghee Lee, et al. from 1996, yet this
reference is never given or mentioned.

2. The adaptive modification of LRFU in this paper seems to equalize
the sizes for the internally used heap and linked-list data
structures. Simulation results suggest that this adaptive method
increases the cache hit rate (at least for the configured traffic).
An explanation for why this modification yields improvements is
missing in this paper.

3. A measurement or a theoretical approximation or the overhead of
continuously balancing both data structures on cache entry and
cache eviction would be interesting.

4. This paper gives an intro to NDN which I appreciate as a reader.
However, it can be shortened drastically to gain some space for
better explaining the adaptive LRFU algorithm. This description
falls a little bit short. The work in [1] seems to be more complete.

[1] < https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/document/8978218 >

5. Figure 2 appears to be taken from the NDN paper, but is not
accordingly referenced. Instead of Figure 2, a figure that depicts
all compared cache replacement strategies would be more valuable.

6. The plot for cache miss is IMO superfluous. The cache hit ratio is
enough.

7. The document needs a language edit, especially in the first part of
the document.

Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
The proposed letter addresses an established, well researched subject: Caching policies in the IoT. A significant body of work appeared, in particular in premier conferences sa ACM-ICN, but are not considered here. Large testbed experiments have been performed in the last decade - without reflection in the present manuscript.
This work proposes a hybrid implementation of LFU and LRU policies, which are then simulated in NS-3. There is no clear explanation on what topology is used and what the content and traffic models are. Hence, simulation results do not mean much to the reader. Correspondingly, the reader is left puzzled with unsubstantiated claims such as "Our scheme is best suited for distributed content in the industrial field." in the conclusion.

Reviewer: 3

Comments to the Author
Overview:
- This paper proposes an adaptive LRFU replacement policy for enabling low latency communication in NDN based IIoT

Review suggestions:
- The authors state that the size of the heap and linked list in a Content Store is usually fixed, and the main aim of the paper is to adaptively assign different sizes to both. However, there are two main concerns with this manuscript: (1) the main motivation for making the sizes of heap and linked list adaptive is not explained, and (2) the details of how the sizes are adapted are not provided in the manuscript.

- Other important details that are missing in the manuscript are: how frequently are the sizes adapted, what is the complexity involved when sizes are adapted, and are there any potential limitations of adapting the sizes?

- Another important aspect to note is that there is a trade-off between the improvement offered by the adaptive LRFU and its deployment complexity. From the evaluation section, it is not clear whether the proposed approach offers significant improvements in comparison to its deployment complexity.

- It is not clear why the proposed approach is recommended only for Industrial IoT applications and not for other use cases of NDN. There is no discussion regarding this in the manuscript.

- The choice of simulation parameters listed in Table I is not justified. Content size of 1024 bytes is not common in Industrial IoT. It is not clear what is meant by IIoT Content Variation = 1000 and Content store size: 10 - 100 (is it number of packets, bytes?).

- The authors mention that there are 15 router nodes in the topology used for simulation. In that case, it is not clear the hit and miss ratio shown in Fig. 6 belongs to which router's Content Store.

- Part A in Section III does not add much value to the reader as it covers the basics of NDN.

- The manuscript has many typos and grammatical errors. It must be proofread.

Manuscript Number: ICTE-D-21-00186  
Improved Partial Transmit Sequence Based PAPR Reduction  in UFMC Systems  
Professor Dong-Seong Kim
ICT Express


Dear Prof. Kim,

Thank you for submitting your manuscript to ICT Express. 

I regret to inform you that the reviewers recommend against publishing your manuscript, and I must therefore reject it. My comments, and any reviewer comments, are below.   

For alternative journals that may be more suitable for your manuscript, please refer to our Journal Finder (http://journalfinder.elsevier.com).

We appreciate you submitting your manuscript to ICT Express and thank you for giving us the opportunity to consider your work.  

Kind regards,     

Oh-Soon Shin   
ICT Express  

Editor and Reviewer comments:     
Reviewer #1: This paper proposed a PAPR reduction for UFMC system by using PTS technique with threshold.

1. This paper proposed a low computational complexity PAPR reduction technique but it does not explain or show the comparison of computation complexity. It is very strange.
2. The result in Fig.4 is quite rough.
3. In FIg.5, it should be evaluated in non-linear channel.
4. In Fig.4, the proposed technique can reduce the PAPR a lot as compared with conventional PTS and original UMFC. However, it is nothing because the BER of the proposed technique as shown in Fig.5 can not be improved whihc is almost the same as that of original UMFC. There are a lot of processes in the proposed PAPR reduction while the original UMFC has nothing.



Reviewer #2: This manuscript should be rewritten. Therefore, I recommend [REJECT].


The explanation in the manuscript is poor and it is hard to understand.

1. There are symbols not fully introduced. For example, before (8), there are no description about $X^m$.
And there are many typos. For example, in (11), summation from $m=1$ to $m$ and $X^M$ are wrong.

2. First of all, It is hard to understand subSection 3.2, which is the main content of the manuscript
, and thus this should be clearly rewritten.

* "$L_f$ is the candidate signals" : what is the candidate signals? It needs to be explained exactly.

* "$L_f$ candidate signals are generated with partition and phase factor of sub-block $i^th$ : This sentence is ambiguous.

* "$M_f$ is sub-block number in $l^th$ stage" : It means the number of sub-blocks?

fields.subject: CNN-32DC: An Improved Radar-based Drone Recognition System based on Convolutional Neural Network
fields.content:
Manuscript No. CL2021-1258 EiC Rejected as Out of Scope  

Reference no.: CL2021-1258

Title: CNN-32DC: An Improved Radar-based Drone Recognition System based on Convolutional Neural Network
Authors: Prof. Dong-Seong Kim, Garcia, Ann Janeth; Lee, Jae; Kim, Dong-Seong


Dear Prof. Dong-Seong Kim:

As Editor-in-Chief I have rejected your manuscript without sending it for review because it is out of scope for Communications Letters. After a preliminary reading of your manuscript and in consultation with Professor Mark Flanagan (Executive Editor), we believe that the IEEE Communications Letters is not the right venue for its publication.

After analysis, we believe that the paper is on the borderline in terms of scope for submission to IEEE Communications Letters. This paper proposes a drone detection system based on a machine learning approach (more specifically, based on a convolutional neural network). The method is based on processing of radar data from a known database using the neural network, and does not explicitly consider communications aspects of the underlying system. In its current form, therefore, the paper does not treat a problem with focus on communications. Therefore, you are either invited to revise the paper and to make its contribution more appropriate for submission to IEEE Communications Letters or you may want to submit the paper to a journal that is more focused on the actual content of the paper, such as IEEE Sensors Journal, or to Pattern Recognition Letters (Elsevier).

Given limited interest from Communications Letters readers, the fact that the subject of your manuscript is not within the expertise of our editorial board, and in order not to delay publication of your work, we have decided to return the manuscript to you without further review. We would like to stress that this decision is not based on the quality of your work. It is entirely an editorial decision based on the fact that the subject material does not fall within the scope of IEEE Communications Letters.

Comments to the Author:

Reviewer(s) Comments:
Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
The authors proposed that solar irradiance prediction is an indispensable area to the photovoltaic (PV) power management system. However, PV management may be subject to severe penalties due to the unsteadiness pattern of photovoltaic output power that depends on solar radiation. A high-precision LSTM based neural network model named SIPNet to predict solar irradiance in a short time interval is proposed to overcome this problem. Solar radiation depends on the environmental sensing of meteorological information such as temperature, pressure, humidity, wind speed, and direction, which are different dimensions in measurement. LSTM neural network can concurrently learn the spatiotemporal of multivariate input features via various logistic gates. Moreover, SIPNet can estimate the future solar irradiance given the historical observation of the meteorological information and the radiation data. The SIPNet model is simulated and compared with the actual and predicted data series and evaluated by the mean absolute error (MAE), mean square error (MSE), and root mean square error (RMSE). The empirical results show that the value of MAE, MSE, and RMSE of SIPNet is 0.0413, 0.0033, and 0.057, respectively, which demonstrate the effectiveness of SIPNet and outperforms other existing models. Because of several concerns regarding the structure of this manuscript, content, and some technical issues that need to be addressed, I recommend minor revisions.

For scientific and research papers, it is not necessary to give several references that say the same. 2. Avoid using the first person.
3. Avoid using abbreviations and acronyms in title, abstract, headings, and highlights.

1. The title may be changed, due to the term Remote Sensing can be confused with the use of satellite or aircraft-based sensor systems of people’s conventional acknowledge.
2. The contribution and innovation of this paper need to be extracted well.
3. In introduction, there is lack of comparison with other researchers in term of the application of LSTM algorithm.

상기 심사대상 논문은 국방관련 적용을 위하여 사설블록체인기반에서 PBFT 합의 알고리즘을 사용하여 제시하였고, 시뮬레이션 결과에 대한 우수한 성능을 보여주고 있어 본 학회 논문에 적합하다고 판단됩니다.
아래 표현과 관련하여 일부 수정이 필요합니다.

1. Abstract 영문 : 첫번쨰 문단의 주어가 없습니다. "In this paper, we propose" 또는 "This paper propose" 형태로 수정바랍니다.
2. 한글논문에서 지나친 영문표현이 많이 나옵니다. 아래 내용을 포함하여 가능하면 영문을 한글화 또는 한글(영문) 병기가 필요하다고 봅니다.
- Topic > 주제(Topic) 또는 다른 한글 표현
- real-time, scalable, dependable, high performance > 실시간(real-time), 확장가능(scalable), 신뢰할 만한(dependable), 고성능(high performance)
- Domain > 도메인(Domain)
- Manager > 관리자(Manager)
- Resilience > 민첩성(Resillence) 또는 다른 한글 표현 등

Reviewer_R12767	
총평: 이 논문은 함정 전투 시스템의 신뢰성과 보안성 향상을 위해 새로운 블록체인 기반의 데이터 공유기법을 제안하였다. 제안하는 기술은 프라이빗 블록체인 기술을 이용하여 함정 전투 시스템에서 사용되고 있는 DDS 미들웨어 기반의 데이터 공유기술의 보안상의 취약점을 극복하고 동시에 DDS기술을 통해 프라이빗 블록체인 기술의 노드 수 증가에 따른 복잡도를 해결하였다. 전반적으로 기존 문헌 분석과 기술들에 대한 비교 분석이 잘 되어 있고 논문의 구조와 논리 전개가 양호한 편이나, 아래와 같이 몇 가지 해결되지 않은 이슈들이 남아있어 보완이 요구된다.

1. 챕터 IV 제안하는 기술을 설명하는 부분에서 제안하는 기술이 기존 DDS나 프라이빗 블록체인 기술 대비 어느 부분에서 어떻게 다른지 분명하게 설명되어 있지 않아 보완이 요구됨. 즉 제안하는 트랜즈액션 생성과정의 각 step이 기존 기술들 대비 어떻게 다르며 각 부분이 어떻게 보안취약점 극복과 실시간성, 노드수 제한(3n+1) 등에 기여하는지에 대한 보다 자세한 분석적 토의가 필요함.
2. 설정된 시험환경구성이 너무 제한적이라 결과에 대한 설득력이 떨어짐. 제안하는 기법의 성능을 입증하기 위해서는 보다 다양한 시뮬레이션 환경(시나리오)에서 결과를 보여줄 필요가 있음.
3. 그림 9는 글자가 너무 작아 가독성이 떨어지니 수정이 필요.

Reviewer_R12768	
1. 요악문을 통해 논문의 배경 및 필요성, 평가방법, 성능향상 등에 대한 내용을 알 수 있도록간략한 추가 보완이 필요해 보입니다.

1. 서론의 참고문헌 번호 1,2번의 인용표기된 문장은 평범한 문장임에 어떤 내용이 인용되었는지 알수 없습니다. 참고문헌의 인용번호의 표기에 신중을 기해야할 것으로 보여집니다.

1. 서론 도입부분에 있어, 논문의 배경과 현 문제점, 필요성, 제안내용, 성능의 향상과 효과 등의 내용이 간략히 소개되어져야 할 것으로 보여집니다. 현재 문맥과 표현 문장들이 어색하고, 본론에서 다뤄야 할 일부분의 내용들이 포함되어 있어 가독성을 떨어뜨리고 있습니다.

1. 관련연구의 내용들의 문맥이 부자연스럽고 문맥이 끊어져, 이해에 어려움이 있습니다.
이에 따른 수정이 필요해 보입니다.

1. 인용한 그림 및 표에 대한 설명이 보완되어야 할 것으로 보여집니다. 불필요한 그림 및 표가 있다면, 삭제하는 것을 권합니다.

1. 3장에서는 전반적인 내용의 흐름을 독자가 쉽게 이해할 수 있도록 수정되어야 할 것입니다. 저자의 기술시점이 아닌 독자의 이해를 목적으로하도록 수정및보완이 필요해 보입니다.

1. 2.4절의 내용에서 문제점 분석보다는 제안 내용을 제시하고 있어 보여집니다. 현재 문제점에 대한 실질적이고 구체적인 원인 및 배경 분석이 필요해보입니다.

1. 3장에서는 제안내용에 대한 체계적인 구성과 내용의 보완이 필요해 보입니다.

1. 통상적으로 3장은 제안내용을 4장은 성능비교를 하고 있습니다. 현재 3장의 내용이
모호하게 구분되어 있어 보여집니다. 재구성을 권합니다. 논증에 필요한 내용여부를 재검점해 보기를 권합니다.

1. 5장의 모의실험 및 성능평가부분에 있어, 문제 분석에 따른 평가가 이뤄져야 할 것입니다. 특히 시간측정보다는 신뢰성 향상을 위한 목적인 만큼 신뢰성 향상의 정도를 실험하고 측정, 비교되어야 할 것입니다.

1. 전반적으로 알아볼 수 없는 그림에 경우, 수정 또는 삭제가 필요해 보입니다. 알아보기가 어렵습니다.

1. 논문 전반적으로 논증에 필요한 부분의 내용정리가 있어야 할 것으로 보입니다.

1. 논문에서 제기하고 있는 문제점에 대해 문제가 되는지, 보완 및 향상이 필요한지에 관한
참고문헌의 추가 보완도 필요해 보입니다.

Reviewer_R12766	
The paper subject to examination above was presented using PBFT consensus algorithms on a private blockchain basis for defense-related applications, and it is considered suitable for this academic paper because it shows excellent performance for simulation results.
Some modifications are needed regarding the expression below.

1. Abstract English: No subject in the first paragraph. Please modify it to form "In this paper, we propose" or "This paper propose".
2. There are a lot of English expressions in the Korean paper. If possible, I think we need Korean or Korean (English) weapons, including the contents below.
- Topic> Topic or other Korean expression
- real-time, scalable, defensible, high performance > real-time, scalable, dependable, high performance
- Domain > Domain
- Manager > Administrator
- Resilience > Resilience or other Korean expressions, etc.

Reviewer_R12767	
Overall Review: This paper proposes a novel blockchain-based data sharing technique to improve the reliability and security of trap combat systems. Using private blockchain technology, the proposed technology overcomes the security vulnerabilities of DDS middleware-based data sharing technology used in trap combat systems, while simultaneously addressing the complexity of the increasing number of nodes in private blockchain technology. Overall, the comparative analysis of existing literature analysis and techniques is well-established and the structure and logic of the paper is good, but several unresolved issues remain as follows, requiring supplementation.

1. Chapter IV The technology you propose does not clearly describe how the technology differs from the existing DDS or private blockchain technology, requiring supplementation. This requires a more detailed analytical discussion of how each step of the proposed transaction generation process is different from existing techniques and how each part contributes to security vulnerabilities overcoming, real-time, node count limits (3n+1).
2. Configuration of the test environment is too limited to be persuasive about the results. To demonstrate the performance of the proposed technique, it is necessary to show results in more diverse simulation environments (scenarios).
3. The letters in Figure 9 are too small to read and need to be modified.

Reviewer_R12768	
1. Further supplementation is needed so that the background, necessity, evaluation method, and performance improvement of the paper can be learned through the yoak text.

1. References No. 1 and 2 to the introduction are ordinary sentences, so we don't know which ones are cited. It appears that we should err on the side of the notation of the citation.

1. In the introduction of the introduction, it seems that the background and current problems, needs, suggestions, performance improvements and effects of the paper should be briefly introduced. Currently, the context and expression sentences are awkward and contain some of the content that needs to be addressed in the main topic, making it less legible.

1. The context of related research is unnatural and disconnected, making it difficult to understand.
It seems that correction is needed accordingly.

1. It appears that the description of the figures and tables cited should be supplemented. If you have unnecessary pictures and tables, I recommend you delete them.

Chapter 3 should be revised so that readers can easily understand the overall flow of content. It seems necessary to revise and supplement it for the purpose of the reader's understanding, not the author's technical point of view.

Section 1.4. seems to suggest suggestions rather than problem analysis. It seems that a practical and specific cause and background analysis of the current problem is needed.

Chapter 3 seems to require systematic composition and supplementation of the contents of the proposal.

1. Usually, Chapter 3 compares the proposed contents with Chapter 4 performance. The current content of Chapter 3 is...
It appears to be vaguely separated. Reconfiguration is recommended. It is recommended that you recheck whether the content is required for the argument.

In the simulation and performance evaluation section of Chapter 5, the evaluation should be conducted according to the problem analysis. Especially for the purpose of improving reliability rather than time measurement, the degree of reliability improvement should be experimented, measured, and compared.

1. In the case of an unrecognizable picture, it seems that it needs to be modified or deleted. It's hard to recognize.

1. Overall, there should be a summary of the parts needed for the thesis.

1. As to whether the problems raised in the paper are problematic, whether they need to be supplemented and improved.
Additional supplements to the reference are also needed.

    New ideas are convincingly and logically described ------------------------------- [2 - I am neutral]
