Sincerely,

Dr. Razi Iqbal
Associate Editor, IEEE Access
razi.iqbal@ieee.org, razi.iqbal@ieee.org

Reviewers' Comments to Author:

Reviewer: 1

Recommendation: Accept (minor edits)

Comments:
1. Through editing is required especially in the Introduction.  Many places space after full stop is missing. Line 50-51 on page 1. Line 34-35 page 2, line 46 on page 2
2. Capitalization needed after full stop on line 51 on page 2
3. Authors say that unobtrusive wearable devices have undergone tremendous transformation in their usage. Then they quote First but there is no second to follow?
4. Define p-health system when first referred.
5. Fig.7 shows KPIs are interwoven. What is the reference or bases for the interconnection of KPIs in Fig.7?
6. What to authors mean by "As seen in Fig. 8, energy efficient B5G network
leverages on deploying hardware solutions with massive
Multi Input Multi Output (MIMO) antennas, millimeter
wave frequency band from ease access and communication,
full duplex and high network dense data rate for fast data
transmission and sleep modes for efficient resource usage"? B5G and its advantages are very vaguely written.
7. Authors have simply written repetitively 3-4 times that MIMO, full duplex in B5G would assist in wearables. However, how? Some details needed. Simply using these terms is not enough.
8. "Also, with energy-efficient B5G network, it is guaranteed
that there will be reduction in the total cost of ownership
[45] which is a critical cost component in determining the
overall cost per unit product of any information technology
device [46], including wearables." This sentence appears randomly. What is the meaning of cost of ownership? How is it critical in determining cost per unit product of any IT device?
9. What do authors want to convey these sentences: page 7 line 28-31, page 7 line 53-55, page, page 9 line 39-44.
10. The response letter to the earlier revision was very vague and it was left to the reviewer to fend the improvements over previous version. Clear representation would be helpful.

Additional Questions:
1) Does the paper contribute to the body of knowledge?: Yes

2) Is the paper technically sound?: Yes

3) Is the subject matter presented in a comprehensive manner?: Yes

4) Are the references provided applicable and sufficient?: Yes

5) Are there references that are not appropriate for the topic being discussed?: No

5a) If yes, then please indicate which references should be removed.:


Reviewer: 2

Recommendation: Reject (do not encourage resubmit)

Comments:
The paper is relevant and describes a review of the wearable market and tries to align it with the requirements of modern healthcare systems. This is based on the first sentence in the abstract. However, reading further I get confused since the authors are indicating: ''performance of unobtrusive healthcare wearable devices based on identified key performance indices (KPIs) in relation to their response to generation networks transformation.'' as their contribution. What is exactly the meaning of the statement?

Two notes here:
1. healthcare wearable devices - fitness bands, smartwatches, and smartphones are not healthcare devices or medical devices. So, what the market offers to consumers is not healthcare by default.
2. KPI == Key performance indicator and not index

Let me emphasize this is not the first review of its kind and the added value of the content appears in: * Identification of KPIs that should be considered Let me emphasize that the 5G and B5G  link is, I would have to agree with the previous reviewer, arbitrary.  Offcourse wearable devices will switch to 5G eventually and will become truly conencted and ubiquitous. Will 5G have an impact on their accuracy or applicability in healthcare?  Perhaps, however, it seems the apparent issue is that the wearables are not used in clinical practice and 5G does not solve that, since the issue is not only ''performance''. The authors should consider why wearables or patient gathered health data or even real-world data are used only in trials and not in practice and consider how 5G or B5G could contribute.

As for the comments:
R1. The abstract needs to be revised and very clear on what authors want to achieve
R2. This is a review paper, as stated in the abstract and under manuscript type, however, the review methodology is completely missing. I would suggest authors to adapt PRISMA or a similar methodology.
R3. The paper is missing clear goals and research questions, to highlight what the authors are trying to achieve.
R4. As mentioned this is not the first review of its kind thus what is the difference from those already published. And 5G is not the answer, since Honestly, I do not know how many wearables are already working on 5G.
R5.  A single work is used to identify KPIs? Those KPIs are I would assume well defined in the cited work, thus why repeated here?
R6. Subsection titles in section V (SMARTNESS is it intelligence?, SPEED is it bandwidth or throughput or responsiveness?)

Since the methodology is completely missing I did not go in-depth into the content. The theme however is appealing and interesting. Thus I would recommend the authors to clearly focus and carry out a review with a specific goal in mind and follow one of the standardized methodologies. Based on the abstract I would also recommend a proofreading service.



Additional Questions:
1) Does the paper contribute to the body of knowledge?: It could however a standardized review methodology is not followed

Comments:
The authors' own contributions to the body of knowledge are unclear.

Can they describe who they are targeting? How can this knowledge be used? What is the rationale for this review and is it even needed? I commend their work but wearables and B3G seems to be a forced link. Perhaps it would make sense if they draw up a couple of case studies to show how their review is useful for integrating wearables with B3G systems.

This paper presents a deep learning method for sensor data prediction, and adopts several metrics to evaluate the performance against some existing models.

Reviewers' Comments to Author:

Reviewer: 1

Recommendation: Accept (minor edits)

Comments:
1. Through editing is required especially in the Introduction.  Many places space after full stop is missing. Line 50-51 on page 1. Line 34-35 page 2, line 46 on page 2
2. Capitalization needed after full stop on line 51 on page 2
3. Authors say that unobtrusive wearable devices have undergone tremendous transformation in their usage. Then they quote First but there is no second to follow?
4. Define p-health system when first referred.
5. Fig.7 shows KPIs are interwoven. What is the reference or bases for the interconnection of KPIs in Fig.7?
6. What to authors mean by "As seen in Fig. 8, energy efficient B5G network
leverages on deploying hardware solutions with massive
Multi Input Multi Output (MIMO) antennas, millimeter
wave frequency band from ease access and communication,
full duplex and high network dense data rate for fast data
transmission and sleep modes for efficient resource usage"? B5G and its advantages are very vaguely written.
7. Authors have simply written repetitively 3-4 times that MIMO, full duplex in B5G would assist in wearables. However, how ? Some details needed. Simply using these terms is not enough.
8. "Also, with energy-efficient B5G network, it is guaranteed
that there will be reduction in the total cost of ownership
[45] which is a critical cost component in determining the
overall cost per unit product of any information technology
device [46], including wearables." This sentence appears randomly. What is the meaning of cost of ownership? How is it critical in determining cost per unit product of any IT device?
9. What do authors want to convey these sentences: page 7 line 28-31, page 7 line 53-55, page, page 9 line 39-44.
10. The response letter to the earlier revision was very vague and it was left to the reviewer to fend the improvements over previous version. Clear representation would be helpful.

4) Are the references provided applicable and sufficient?: Yes

5) Are there references that are not appropriate for the topic being discussed?: No

Reviewer: 2

Recommendation: Reject (do not encourage resubmit)

Comments:
The paper is relevant and describes a review of the wearable market and tries to align it with the requirements of modern healthcare systems. This is based on the first sentence in the abstract. However, reading further I get confused since the authors are indicating: ''performance of unobtrusive healthcare wearable devices based on identified key performance indices (KPIs) in relation to their response to generation networks transformation.'' as their contribution. What is exactly the meaning of the statement?

Two notes here:
1. healthcare wearable devices - fitness bands, smartwatches, and smartphones are not healthcare devices or medical devices. So what the market offers to consumers is not healthcare by default.
2. KPI == Key performance indicator and not index

Let me emphasize this is not the first review of its kind and the added value of the content appears in: * Identification of KPIs that should be considered  Let me emphasize that the 5G and B5G  link is, I would have to agree with the previous reviewer, arbitrary.  Offcourse wearable devices will switch to 5G eventually and will become truly conencted and ubiquitous. Will 5G have an impact on their accuracy or applicability in healthcare?  Perhaps, however, it seems the apparent issue is that the wearables are not used in clinical practice and 5G does not solve that, since the issue is not only ''performance''. The authors should consider why wearables or patient gathered health data or even real-world data are used only in trials and not in practice and consider how 5G or B5G could contribute.

As for the comments:
R1. The abstract needs to be revised and very clear on what authors want to achieve
R2. This is a review paper, as stated in the abstract and under manuscript type, however, the review methodology is completely missing. I would suggest authors to adapt PRISMA or a similar methodology.
R3. The paper is missing clear goals and research questions, to highlight what the authors are trying to achieve.
R4. As mentioned this is not the first review of its kind thus what is the difference from those already published. And 5G is not the answer, since Honestly, I do not know how many wearables are already working on 5G.
R5.  A single work is used to identify KPIs? Those KPIs are I would assume well defined in the cited work, thus why repeated here?
R6. Subsection titles in section V (SMARTNESS is it intelligence?, SPEED is it bandwidth or throughput or responsiveness?)

Since the methodology is completely missing I did not go in-depth into the content. The theme however is appealing and interesting. Thus I would recommend the authors to clearly focus and carry out a review with a specific goal in mind and follow one of the standardized methodologies. Based on the abstract I would also recommend a proofreading service.

The authors' own contributions to the body of knowledge are unclear.

Can they describe who they are targeting? How can this knowledge be used? What is the rationale for this review and is it even needed? I commend their work but wearables and B3G seems to be a forced link. Perhaps it would make sense if they draw up a couple of case studies to show how their review is useful for integrating wearables with B3G systems.

fields.content:
We regret to advise you that the Reviewing Committee is unable
to accept the subject paper for publication as a PES
Transactions paper.  

COMMENTS TO THE AUTHORS:
Editor's Comments:

Editor
Comments to the Author:
Based on the feedback received from the reviewers, a "Reject - Do Not Resubmit" is recommended. The following points were the primary basis for this recommendation: (1) The submitted manuscript has limited novelty/suitability for a TPWRS Research Paper. (2) There is lack of clarity regarding the type of stability being considered and the simulations (contingencies?) being performed. (3) An explanation of how the proposed approach is "time-aware" is missing (note that the term "time-aware" is in the title of the paper). (4) The results do not demonstrate the superior performance of the proposed method over the state-of-the-art.

Reviewers' Comments:

Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
The paper presented "Time-Aware CNN for Efficient Smart Grid Stability
Prediction"
1. What is the contribution of the authors? its not clear to me.
2. Have you done contingency analysis for testing the the system stability.
3. How you justify that this CNN is time aware?
4. What about computational complexity.
5. Mathematical Analysis of proposed structure and how it is different with other avilable algorithms?


Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
The paper proposes a time-aware CNN model for efficient smart grid stability prediction. The topic of the paper is interesting and timely. However, it is a bit disappointing that the concept of power system stability is not clearly understood and addressed in the paper. It seems that the authors have a mixed understanding on different stability issues. From the reviewer’s perspective, the contributions mentioned in the introduction are not quite convincing neither from the aspect of technical innovation nor application value. The study is a simple application of a common CNN-based model in a simple test power system. The results from the case study cannot properly support the conclusions in this paper. Therefore, it is difficult to justify the paper brings a significant contribution. Moreover, the writing of the paper should be significantly improved. Quite a few parts of the paper appear to be deviating from the main focus. Further comments are given in the following.
1. The language of the paper should be further polished. Please avoid putting many nouns together for better readability.
2. The length of abstract should be reduced. There are quite a few irrelevant contents, which seem to be deviating and make it difficult to follow.
3. You mentioned the frequency in the abstract. It is not clear in the paper which stability problems you are trying to tackle. In other words, what is the definition of stability in this paper? Transient stability, small signal stability, frequency stability or voltage stability? Etc. Different stability issues have their unique characteristics. The description of the relevant issue is ambiguous, and the significance of this paper is doubtful. This is the fundamental of the paper. Please carefully discuss and provide sufficient information.
4. The term ‘smart grid stability’ is used in the paper. Can you explain the difference between power system stability and smart grid stability? Is there any difference? If no, why not choose the commonly used term? Or it should be the microgrid stability for a smart factory? What is the concept of smart factory by the way?
5. From the reviewer’s perspective, the claimed contributions in the introduction are just a description/repeat of the work in the paper, which should be restructured. The 1D kernel and Max pooling are two very common technologies in CNN-based networks and have been widely utilized in existing research [r-1], [r-2]. Therefore, the innovation is marginal.
[r-1] X. Li, Z. Yang, P. Guo, and J. Cheng, "An intelligent transient stability assessment framework with continual learning ability," IEEE T. Ind Inform, vol. 17, no.12, pp. 8131-8141, 2021.
[r-2] S. K. Azman, Y. J. Isbeih, M. S. E. Moursi, and K. Elbassioni, "A unified online deep learning prediction model for small signal and transient stability," IEEE Trans. Power Syst., vol. 35, no.6, pp. 4585-4598, 2020.
6. The review of existing research does not have an in-depth discussion of research gaps and the description of the research target is puzzling.
7. The paper is titled “Time-Aware”, but the reviewer cannot find any description and explanation of this term in the manuscript.
8. Both SMOTE and PCC are very common technologies in existing research. The reviewer suggests that the introduction of SMOTE and PCC and their results should be reduced.
9. The demonstration of Fig. 2. is unnecessary because Bi-LSTM is irrelevant to the proposed CNN model.
10. Please further explain the construction of the loss function for the proposed model. It is unfair to compare the loss value between the model with different loss functions, or the other metrics under different test systems.
11. According to Table II, the accuracy values of LSTM and Bi-LSTM are very close to those of the proposed CNN (99.94% vs 99.88% vs 99.96%), and the F1-score values of LSTM and Bi-LSTM even are higher than those of the proposed CNN. Hence, the proposed model does not perform obvious advantages compared with the existing methods.
12. The comparison in Table II is unreasonable and doubtful, especially the computational time results. Is the computation time of LSTM [r-3] tested by authors or it is cited from the existing papers? If it is the latter one, this is a wrong citation because only a training time of 37.43 seconds is provided in [1] rather than a computation time of 37.43 ms.
[r-3] J. J. Q. Yu, D. J. Hill, A. Y. S. Lam, J. Gu, and V. O. K. Li, "Intelligent Time-Adaptive transient stability assessment system," IEEE Trans. Power Syst., vol. 33, no.1, pp. 1049-1058, Jan. 2018.
13. The proposed model is only tested in a very small system with 4 nodes. Even for a factory, the power system can be bigger than that. It is required to verify the applicability in much more complex scenarios.


Reviewer: 3

Comments to the Author
The title is not proper. Smart grid is a goal. The current  power grid maybe cannot be called a smart grid.
Hence, the title is suggested to change to Time-Aware CNN for Efficient Power Grid Stability Prediction.
The test system which is only made up of a central generation node and three consumption nodes is so small for the study of stability problem. At least 3-generator 9-node system is suggested to be used.
Stability have different types. The authors are suggested to clear which kind of stability is considered.

Please, take all their comments into account, highlighting the changes in the new version of your manuscript and providing a response letter with an answer and action to each individual comment.

Reviewer(s)' Comments to Author:
Reviewer: 1
Comments to the Author
Prospects and Challenges of Metaverse Application in Data-Driven Intelligent transportation systems
The authors investigate the concept of the Metaverse for the transport/automotive industry.
Specifically, the article reviews the concepts and features of the Metaverse with three major DDITSchallenges: (1) vehicle fault detection and repair, (2) testing new technologies, and (3) anti-theft systems.


Two major case studies are examined to demonstrate the utility of Metaverse in DDITS, and the authors finish by discussing the influence, limitations, and open issues of metaverse applications.
This topic of this article fits the venue and is of interest to its audience.
Overall, the methodology and grammar/spelling/wording of this paper need revisions.
The provided figures illustrate the idea/concept and prototype well.
The case studies are well presented and provide the reader with a better grasp of the topic.
The discussion and open issues section provide researchers and practitioners with a research agenda.
The length of the article is adequate for its contribution.
I suggest the following corrections/improvements:
- methodology: how did you find the challenges/opportunities etc.? Did you conduct a literature review? Expert workshop? Please clarify.
- spelling/grammar errors, for example on page 2:
"In this section, the layers and concepts of Metaverse were discussed and summarized in Fig. 3." ->... are discussed ...
"These includes the theories" -> include
- confusing text elements, for example on page 4:
"[enumerate, 1]label = ()"
- page 5: "...Holograktor (Metaverse on wheels) are proofs of the realization of Metaverse." ->please add "by WayRay" (otherwise one might think this technology was created by Nissan)


In order for this article to be accepted, I would strongly suggest improving the methodology of how you gathered the information (e.g., literature reviews, expert workshops), and enhancing the writing.
Overall, I enjoyed reading this article and look forward to future work in this field!
Reviewer: 2
Comments to the Author
This article provides an overview of the concepts and characteristics of the metaverse. Three major challenges for DDITS are presented: vehicle fault detection and repair; testing of new technologies; and anti-theft systems. In addition, it highlights potential metaverse solutions that can be applied. The authors summarize two main case studies to demonstrate the utility of Metaverse in DDITS: visible to the invisible and Metaverse on wheels techniques. In addition, the impact, limitations, and unresolved issues of metaverse applications are discussed, with some contributions to the connections and challenges of metaverse and DDITS.
But during the reading, I also found some limitations that exist
(1) Lack of specific elaboration of some related work, for example, in '' Layers of Metaverse'', why are they divided into these layers, what is the related survey, and what are the reference sources of some key technologies. There is a need for corresponding literature support. Moreover, do applicable Solutions'' have relevant work to support? If there is a supplement, it will be more convincing.
(3) What is the relationship between the two case studies and the current state of research and challenges summarized earlier?
(4) In the discussion section, I feel that the understanding of the metaverse is not deep and extensive enough. For example, the use of headphones as a way of sound feedback is mentioned in"Hardware Limitations". In fact, there are a lot of interaction techniques in metaverse and AR/VR, so the author may need to learn some related interaction techniques and the corresponding devices.
Some minor issues:
- There are some seemingly growing errors and writing mistakes in the article, such as missing punctuation, missing spaces, or "[enumerate, 1]label = ()", etc., which need to be rechecked.
Reviewer: 3
Comments to the Author
It was a very interesting topic as a study on metaverse and industrial application of metaverse, which is an important topic in various academic fields and industrial fields. In particular, the metaverse application to DDITS was intriguing.
It is expected that the value and contribution of this study will become clearer if more comprehensive references and considerations are supplemented.
1) In this study, treat "the Metaverse as a digitally simulated world that exists in parallel with its real-world replica". Metaverse is treated as a virtual simulation test environment related to ITS.
The research contributes to the industrial application of metaverse differentiated from the existing digital twin should be clearly presented.


2) Section 2 (Metaverse in Data-Driven Intelligent Transportation Systems) showed potential applicable Solutions to which Metaverse was applied. This will be an important contribution to this study. However, Applicable Solutions presented in this paper are solutions presented conceptually. The application method of the solution should be presented in more detail so that it can be applied to future research.
3) The authors argued that this study is the first attempt to provide a review of the potential applications of Metaverse in the transportation industry. However, the selection process of the research subject to review and the list of papers subject to review were not explained.
Two case studies were investigated to prove the usefulness of Metaverse in DDITS.
As a review of Prospects and Challenges, the contents and references are not comprehensive. This may be because there have not been many studies on the industrial application of metaverse yet. If so, the review study may still be premature.
If not, it is recommended to supplement the review target more systematically and comprehensively.
4) Two open issues were presented.
If the open issue is developed more comprehensively and specifically, it is expected that the contribution of this study will become clear.
Reviewer: 4
Comments to the Author
The Metaverse in Intelligent Transport Systems is a timely and important topic. Authors make useful observations and suggestions. However, the manuscript needs to address several issues to be considered for publication:
The literature review on virtual worlds should also include notable platforms such as Traveler, Croquet, and ActiveWorlds (Mystakidis, 2022). Another crucial development in this field is the proliferation of Open Simulator, an open-source software platform for stand-alone and networked virtual worlds (Kim & Ke, 2017). Minecraft is also an important and popular 3D virtual world platform (Cózar-Gutiérrez & Sáez-López, 2016) which is very popular in educational settings.
P02 “In 2021 The republic of Korea declared that it was going to build a national augmented reality(AR) and VR platform.” – Please add a source for this information.
In the definitions of the Metaverse, please add contemporary proposals based on recent publications e.g. (Kye et al., 2021; Mystakidis, 2022).
P03 The sentence “According to [18], XR fuses the physical and digital worlds to some certain degree while utilizing VR, AR and MR” conveys a vague message. XR is an umbrella term that includes VR, AR, and MR technologies (Tegoan et al., 2021).
P04 – Fig. 3: The origin of these 7 layers is reference 37 which is a web article. Why did the authors choose the particular framework? What is its validity? There are many other frameworks that are worth consideration, e.g. (Bhatia, 2021).
P04: The definition of the avatar is not accurate. An avatar is much more than an icon. It is the embodied representation of the user (Petrakou, 2010). Avatars can also represent non-player characters (Grivokostopoulou et al., 2020).
P04: I encourage authors to cite scientific publications on digital twins, e.g. (Batty, 2018).
P04: The definition of VR is also somewhat vague: users in VR enter an entirely new, synthetic environment that is completely separated from physical reality (Pellas et al., 2021).
P05: The Vehicle Fault Detection and Repair section miss one vital link with the Metaverse which is at the bleeding edge of manufacturing and industry research: digital twins for damage and catastrophic accidents’ prevention of costly equipment and vehicles (al Faruque et al., 2021).
P06: The suggestion that the Metaverse can be used in Anti-Theft Systems is arbitrary and without visible ground in literature. If no convincing evidence can be presented, I recommend removing this section entirely.
One suggested topic for exploration is the use of Metaverse technologies for innovations for intelligent safety solutions based on AR technologies, e.g. projecting information in the windshield(Mystakidis et al., 2022; Riegler et al., 2019).
P08: The Discussion section should be revised carefully for inaccurate statements such as the following:
“AR, as we know it now, might be used in the Metaverse to immerse users in an alternate world” (ARis based on the physical environment)
“The Metaverse mimics the real world” (it can also be used to create alternate fictitious worlds)
P08 – section 4.1.1: Valid points are identified. Beyond addiction, there are other ethical issues related to Metaverse technologies worth mentioning, e.g. see (Christopoulos et al., 2021; Slater et al., 2020).

Dear Mr. Sampedro:

I write you in regards to manuscript Pnp-0018-IEM-03-2022 entitled "Machine Learning-Based Fault Monitoring in Additive Manufacturing: Challenges and Opportunities" which you submitted to the Industrial Electronics Magazine.

I regret to inform you that, in view of the criticisms of the reviewer(s) found at the bottom of this letter, your manuscript cannot be accepted for publication in the Industrial Electronics Magazine.

Thank you for considering the Industrial Electronics Magazine for the publication of your research.  I hope the outcome of this specific submission will not discourage you from the submission of future manuscripts.

Sincerely,
Professor Éric Monmasson
Editor in Chief, Industrial Electronics Magazine
eric.monmasson@u-cergy.fr



Reviewer(s)' Comments to Author:

Reviewer: 1

Comments for Author
IEEE Industrial Electronics Magazine (IEM) publishes that present emerging trends and practices in industrial electronics product research and development, key insights, and tutorial surveys in the field of interest to the membership of the IEEE Industrial Electronics Society (IEEE/IES). The publication requirements in terms of work quality are high, IEM readers expect a more informative work in terms of current trends or product development through innovation and research.
In my opinion, the paper presented is a conventional Review on a specific topic, whose contribution is limited for the objectives or scope of the journal. I recommend that the work should be sent to other Journals or Transactions, which publish this type of traditional Reviews.
Additionally, some comments that could improve the review are:
•       The abstract must be significantly improved in order to show the review contribution in comparison with other similar works (reviews).
•       In the Introduction section, the paper does not provide a relevant idea regarding the objective of the Survey, it only mentions that it is a review of works on 3 topics, in FDM for plastics printing and SLM for metal printing.
•       In the last section of the Introduction section the contribution of the survey should be clear.
•       The information in the Table 1 is not relevant for the scope of the Journals
•       The paper requires a significant improvement in terms of the works discussion, they are only cited; and the advantages and disadvantages claimed by the authors are not described in detail.
•       The weak point is the lack of the authors’ own contribution in the form of their own assessment of the importance of individual problems and methods
•       The review is poor in tables and figures
•       Improve significantly the Conclusions


Reviewer: 2

Comments for Author
I think the survey in the manuscript provides a state-of-the-art overview in the field of automated manufacturing. However, it is strongly recommended to greatly improve English.
1. Acronyms. All acronyms must be defined the first time they appear in both the abstract and the manuscript. For instance, FDM and SLM are not defined in the abstract, whereas AM is not defined in the manuscript.
2. Language. The manuscript is readable in general; however, it is recommended that authors make an extensive English revision. There are some awkward sentences in the manuscript. For instance: “The energy melts the powdered metal materials to form the each layer of the 3D object [1].” Should be instead: “… to form each layer …” Other awkward phrases appear along the text.


Reviewer: 3

Comments for Author
(There are no comments. Please check to see if comments were included as a file attachment with this e-mail or as an attachment in your Author Center.)

Reviewer: 4

Comments for Author
the paper considers the implementation the machine learning for fault monitoring of AM products mostly by SLM. However, it does not provide in-depth analysis and research. it needs to consider the idea and AI and machine learning how to work first in-depth and then tries to consider it. recently AM is becoming a hot research topic. there is a lot of uncertain things in production that still need to develop further, it is good to develop the fault monitoring in parallel with it.
there is no information related to structural problems, thermal conductivity, electrical properties, and so on, how do you want to also find the solution to check and gather data about this, already there are various printers with various abilities and there are various papers which shows different maturity levels. in which field do you want to develop your fault monitoring< electrical machine, mechanical design...

Dear Prof. Kim:

I am writing in regards to manuscript ID TCAS-II-10931-2021 entitled "Fast Successive Approximation ADC With Series Time-Interleaved Architecture" which you submitted to the IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems II: Express Briefs.

Your manuscript has been reviewed by several experts in the field. Based on the recommendations given by the associate editor and in view of the comments and concerns expressed by reviewers found at the bottom of this letter, I regret to inform you that your manuscript is REJECTED for publication in the IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems II: Express Briefs.

Thank you for considering the IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems II: Express Briefs for the publication of your research.  I hope the outcome of this specific submission will not discourage you from your submission of future manuscripts.

Sincerely,

Prof. Jose de la Rosa
Editor-in-Chief, IEEE Transactions on Circuits and Systems II: Express Briefs
jdelarosa@ieee.org


Editors' Comments to the Authors:

Associate Editor
Comments to the Author:
Dear Authors,

Thank you for your submission to IEEE TCAS-II. The manuscript has been reviewed by three experts in the field and unfortunately, it has not been recommended for publication in TCAS-II. Please find the detailed comments of the reviewers. In overall, the manuscript is very short and the reported novelty is not sufficient. Besides, there are several technical concerns as described in the comments of the reviewers.


Reviewers' Comments to the Authors:

Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
Firstly, the results shown in this draft are lack of credibility due to the SAR ADC is only modelled in the Matlab without any practical circuit simulation and verification. Besides, the author states that the proposed technique solves the speed limit of conventional SAR ADC architecture, however, the results does not support his statement. The writing and the figures are also not the standard format of the TCAS-II. I think this draft doesn't meet the qualifications of the TCAS-II paper.
My major concerns are detailed as below
1. The proposed technique will suffers from much difficulty if the implementation is practical circuit level.
2. Section II, it is difficult to transfer the sample voltage to the following stage without loss in the practical implementation. If they are sampling in multi sampling capacitor, the different sampling capacitors suffer from mismatch.
3. Section II, the design complexity of the proposed fast-SAR far exceed the normal SAR ADC. The needed comparator number is N-times (N is the resolution of the SAR ADC) than the normal SAR ADC, that need to correct N comparators’ offset. The different DACs could leads to weight mismatch and reference mismatch. Most of the design concerns are not solved in this draft.  
4. The proposed fast-SAR closely resemble the pipelined ADC, like that a multi-stages pipelined ADC with one bit resolution in the each stage, the inter-stage gain is set 1, and the sampling voltage transfer to the backend stages without loss, the reference align is done through the different reference voltage handle in the different stages. However it does not get the benefit from redundancy to overcome the offset, the reference align of the multi-stages are difficult, and the noise of the backend stages is not relaxed.  
5. Fig. 2 and Fig.3 ought to be revised to have a clear description.
6. More simulation results with circuit design should be added.


Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
Through the limited description of this article, the reviewer cannot agree with the concept of interleaved architecture. Based on the reviewer's limited knowledge, this structure cannot be considered feasible in circuit implementation. If it is feasible, please provide silicon results or at least a transistor-level circuit. Otherwise, the reviewer believes that this is not a mature article.

Reviewer: 3

Comments to the Author
This manuscript does not follow TCAS-II guideline in terms of writing. Additionally, the proposed method can only be applied in the ideal system level simulation. In practice, the analog delay line would consume huge power. Multiple DACs and comparators would lead to mismatch problems, which are the major design bottlenecks for SAR ADCs. Unfortunately, the authors do not mention at all.

Dear Mr. Moallim,

I write you in regards to Manuscript ID CTA-22-0221 entitled "Fast Successive Approximation ADC With Series Time-Interleaved Architecture" which you submitted to International Journal of Circuit Theory and Applications.

In view of the criticisms of the referee(s) found at the bottom of this letter, your manuscript has been denied publication in International Journal of Circuit Theory and Applications.


Thank you for considering International Journal of Circuit Theory and Applications for the publication of your research.  I hope the outcome of this specific submission will not discourage you from submitting future manuscripts.


Sincerely,

Prof. Ahmed Elwakil
Editor-in-Chief, International Journal of Circuit Theory and Applications


Editor
Comments to the Author:
Dear Authors,

Thank you for your submission to IJCTA. The manuscript has been reviewed by four experts in the field. Although the main proposed idea to speed up the SAR ADC conversion by removing the conventional SAR logic control is interesting, but it needs more analysis, circuit level implementation details and some more clarifications. Please find the detailed comments of the reviewers. The authors are encouraged to re-submit it after providing some technical clarifications, analysis, and detailed circuit level simulations results as a full paper.

Referee(s)' Comments to Author:

Reviewing: 1

Comments to the Author
To increase the speed, the authors have removed the SAR register and opened the closed-loop system of a SAR ADC. Instead, some other blocks such as DACs, comparators, and delay blocks have been used to generate the required reference voltages for comparisons. According to Fig. 2, the authors have claimed that the speed of the proposed ADC has increased by a factor of N+1 compared to a conventional one (fs=fck). Although there is no circuit implementation for this work, I believe the idea is interesting and can be re-considered after a revision as a brief report since the manuscript is too short. Addressing the following concerns will increase the quality of this work.
1-      The estimated die area should be compared with the conventional one like power consumption in Table 1.
2-      How your new structure affects INL and DNL performance? Please briefly explain and comment on that.
3-      Regarding Fig. 2, the explanation is not enough to easily understand how a maximum frequency of fs=fck can be applied and why the speed is increased by (N+1)? This item is the important one and should be carefully clarified through the manuscript.
4-      As I searched, some more references have worked on speed, and can be added to this work.
5-      In conventional SAR ADCs, mismatch of capacitances results in inaccuracy. Did your design remove such mismatches?
6-      The complexity of conventional SAR logic can be compared with the complexity of your design.
7-      The simulation results are too simple. More details such as FFT can be added. 

Reviewing: 2

Comments to the Author
Thanks for your suggestion of this new concept of TI SAR ADC. You show the model results (Simulink). But further analysis is needed to prove the robustness of your idea. What is the impact of offset in the series of comparators involved in each step of the serial processing? What are the limitations from the successive DAC? What impact of the total power? One need details about all these points to validate the consistency of your idea and also to compare the benefit of this idea as you point it out in your introduction and in your table 1

Reviewing: 3

Comments to the Author
This paper presents an open-loop serialized SAR ADC. This architecture can have a higher sampling rate than the conventional SAR ADC designs. My opinions are as follows:
First, the proposed scheme seems completely similar to the already published loop-unrolled SAR ADC architecture. If there is any difference, the paper should mention it and improvements over state-of-the-art versions.
Second, the proposed scheme is only implemented in MATLAB and not in actual SPICE. The specific case of residue transfer to the DACs of the following stages is tough to implement in the actual circuit. It either requires an active buffer or a passive transfer, and both methods are challenging. Therefore, the paper fails to deliver a novel circuit and does not show the challenging part of its implementation.

Reviewing: 4

Comments to the Author
The manuscript claimed a fast SAR ADC. It seems interesting. My comments are as follows:
(1) For successive different samples,  does each DAC need to be reset?
(2) More discussions need to be addressed, such as requirements for DAC mismatch, the comparator accuracy.
(3) It is not reasonable to assume the power dissipation is linear with the DAC bit. Different outputs of the DAC can cause different power consumption.
(4) In such structure, the power consumption of the control logic can not be ignored.

Although there is no circuit implementation for this work, I believe the idea is interesting and can be re-considered after a revision as a brief report since the manuscript is too short. Addressing the following concerns will increase the quality of this work.
1-      The estimated die area should be compared with the conventional one like power consumption in Table 1.
2-      How your new structure affects INL and DNL performance? Please briefly explain and comment on that.
3-      Regarding Fig. 2, the explanation is not enough to easily understand how a maximum frequency of fs=fck can be applied and why the speed is increased by (N+1)? This item is the important one and should be carefully clarified through the manuscript.
4-      As I searched, some more references have worked on speed, and can be added to this work.
5-      In conventional SAR ADCs, mismatch of capacitances results in inaccuracy. Did your design remove such mismatches?
6-      The complexity of conventional SAR logic can be compared with the complexity of your design.
7-      The simulation results are too simple. More details such as FFT can be added. 

Reviewing: 2

Recommendation: Reject
Comments to the Author
Thanks for your suggestion of this new concept of TI SAR ADC. You show the model results (Simulink). But further analysis is needed to prove the robustness of your idea. What is the impact of offset in the series of comparators involved in each step of the serial processing? What are the limitations from the successive DAC? What impact of the total power? One need details about all these points to validate the consistency of your idea and also to compare the benefit of this idea as you point it out in your introduction and in your table 1

Reviewing: 3

Recommendation: Reject
Comments to the Author
This paper presents an open-loop serialized SAR ADC. This architecture can have a higher sampling rate than the conventional SAR ADC designs. My opinions are as follows:
First, the proposed scheme seems completely similar to the already published loop-unrolled SAR ADC architecture. If there is any difference, the paper should mention it and improvements over state-of-the-art versions.
Second, the proposed scheme is only implemented in MATLAB and not in actual SPICE. The specific case of residue transfer to the DACs of the following stages is tough to implement in the actual circuit. It either requires an active buffer or a passive transfer, and both methods are challenging. Therefore, the paper fails to deliver a novel circuit and does not show the challenging part of its implementation.

Reviewing: 4

Recommendation: Major Revision
Comments to the Author
The manuscript claimed a fast SAR ADC. It seems interesting. My comments are as follows:
(1) For successive different samples,  does each DAC need to be reset?
(2) More discussions need to be addressed, such as requirements for DAC mismatch, the comparator accuracy.
(3) It is not reasonalbe to assume the power dissipation is linear with the DAC bit. Different outputs of the DAC can cause different power consumption.
(4) In such structure, the power consumption of the control logic can not be ignored.

Dear Prof. Dong-Seong Kim:

Manuscript ID COM-2022-04-0126 entitled "Smart Auto Mining (SAM) for Industrial IoT Blockchain Network" which you submitted to IET Communications, has been reviewed. Some revisions to your manuscript have been recommended. Therefore, I invite you to respond to the comments appended below and revise your manuscript.

Editor-in-Chief Comments

Deadlines:
Because we are trying to facilitate timely publication of manuscripts submitted to IET Communications, your revised manuscript should be uploaded as soon as possible. If it is not possible for you to submit your revision in a month, we may have to consider your paper as a new submission. If you feel that you will be unable to submit your revision within the time allowed please contact me to discuss the possibility of extending the revision time.

Before submitting your revisions:

1.  Prepare a response to the reviewer comments appended below in point-by-point fashion in PDF format. In order to expedite the processing of the revised manuscript, please be as specific as possible in your response and indicate the page numbers in the manuscript where you have addressed each comment.

2. Prepare a revised manuscript in an editable format (not PDF), highlighting the changes you’ve made. Save this new document on your computer as you will be asked to upload it during the revision submission process. NOTE: Please be sure to keep in mind reviewer comments and incorporate your responses within the manuscript. There may well be areas where you disagree; for example, you may want to write, "A reviewer suggests that... However, I disagree because...". In any case, please try to address all of the concerns that are raised within the manuscript.

3. In addition to your revised manuscript with changes highlighted, please also save a “clean- editable” copy where the changes are not marked. If the source file is LaTeX make sure that clean PDF also uploaded.

4. Please include a separate title page with following details  :-
* Title of the manuscript
* All the authors' complete names
* Departmental & institutional affiliations of the authors
* Postal & e-mail address of the corresponding author
* Conflict of interest statement
* funding information
* Data availability statement

Please refer the below link and provide the data availability statement accordingly in the ScholarOne system and in the manuscript.

https://authorservices.wiley.com/author-resources/Journal-Authors/open-access/data-sharing-citation/data-sharing-policy.html#standardtemplates

5. Please note this, funding information provided in the ScholarOne should match with main manuscript.

To submit your revised manuscript:

1. Log in by clicking on the link below

*** PLEASE NOTE: This is a two-step process. After clicking on the link, you will be directed to a webpage to confirm. ***

https://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/theiet-com?URL_MASK=815d410b7d224bf394ee1d37886f149f

OR

Log into https://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/theiet-com and click on Author Centre. You will find your manuscript title listed under "Manuscripts with Decisions". Under "Actions," click on "Create a Revision." Your manuscript number has been appended to denote a revision. PLEASE DO NOT SUBMIT YOUR REVISIONS AS A NEW MANUSCRIPT.

2. Follow the on-screen instructions. First you will be asked to provide your “Response to Decision Letter”—this is the response to reviewer comments that you prepared earlier.

3. Click through the next few screens to verify that all previously provided information is correct.

4. File Upload:  Delete any files that you will be replacing (this includes your old manuscript). Upload your new revised manuscript file with changes highlighted, a “clean” copy of your revised manuscript file, any replacement figures/tables, or any new files. Once this is complete, the list of files in the “My Files” section should ONLY contain the final versions of everything.  REMEMBER: figures/tables should be in jpeg, tiff, or eps format. We hope that you will designate one of the figures in your paper to be considered for our online covers and potential publication on our blog.

5. Author Contribution Indication
The contributions of each author to this work must now be indicated when you submit your revised manuscript. To add Author Contributions using CRediT taxonomy (http://credit.niso.org/contributor-roles-defined/), simply click the “Provide CRediT Contribution” link for each author in the ‘Authors & Institutions’ step of the submission process. From there, you will be able to check applicable Author/Contributor Roles and, if available, specify the Degree of Contribution. You MUST provide this information as part of the revision process. Author Contributions will be published with the accepted article and cannot be edited after article acceptance. Therefore you must ensure the Author Contribution information you provide is accurate prior to final acceptance.

6. Review and submit: please be sure to double-check everything carefully so that your manuscript can be processed as quickly as possible.

Once again, thank you for submitting your manuscript to IET Communications and I look forward to receiving your revision.

Sincerely,
Prof. Liuqing Yang
Editor in Chief, IET Communications
iet.communications.eic@gmail.com

You can also check out Wiley’s collection of free article preparation resources for general guidance about writing and preparing your manuscript at www.wileyauthors.com/eeo/prepresources.

Associate Editor Comments to Author:

Associate Editor
Comments to the Author:
The review comments are mostly positive. The authors are required to clarify the concerns raised by the reviewers. For example, the introduction and motivation parts should be improved. The related literature studies could be better discussed and compared.

Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
This paper presents a novel smart auto mining for blockchain network. The overall paper structure and explanation is fine but it has some issues which need to be address before the publication.
1.      The introduction section can be improved as the motivation is not clear.
2.      The related work section lacks recent literature related to this topic. The authors are also suggested to make a comparison between the proposed approach with these existing researches.
3.      Section 3.1 can be removed as it presents general transaction workflow of a public blockchain. The text in Section 3.2 can be moved to the introduction section.
4.      Fig 1 is not clear and difficult for general readers to understand.
5.      Can this approach by applied in the production environment? The authors are suggested to add a feature application section.
6.      The limitation of this approach should be clarified.
7.      The English editing can be improved.

Comments to the Author
This is an interesting work and adding some new information in the existing research. I like the revised version to some extent, I appreciate their efforts but paper is still needs more quality. My comments for the further improvement are:
1. There is need to reduce the size of abstract, make it concise and effective.
2. Introduction is very long, please reduce and make it focused.
3. Motivation should be improved.

5. Problem definition need to be added after related work?

Summary: Please provide a summary of the paper (the contents and contribution of the paper). (1-3 sentences)
This work aims to reduce transaction time by integrating the mining process with the sending of transactions to reduce overall transaction time. This work also decreased the overhead of mining in a private network, by reducing the production of empty blocks in the network which saves energy, storage space, network bandwidth and computational complexity.

The authors proposed an Auto Integrated Mining (AIM) algorithm which starts the mining process only when there is at least one pending transaction in the network, and stops mining as soon as the pending transactions are mined. The results show that the AIM algorithm reduced the number of mined blocks in a 12 hour period by producing only 24% of the original number of blocks. The proposed algorithm is also able to reduce the storage used to save chain data by 16%. The experiment shows that the mining latency of AIM varied between 200-650ms when the number of pending transactions was between 1-1,000, and had a latency between 350-1,350ms when there were 1,000-10,000 pending transactions in the private blockchain network.

fields.content: From: yongmingli@cqu.edu.cn To: dskim@kumoh.ac.kr CC: yongmingli@cqu.edu.cn, anyanwu.goodnes@kumoh.ac.kr, cosmas.ifeanyi@kumoh.ac.kr, ifeanyi.nwakanma@futo.edu.ng, ljmpaul@kumoh.ac.kr, dskim@kumoh.ac.kr Subject: IEEE Access - Decision on Manuscript ID Access-2022-11785 Body: 17-Jun-2022 Dear Prof. Kim: I am writing to you in regard to manuscript # Access-2022-11785 entitled "Ensemble Random Forest-based Basic Safety Messages Falsification Detection in Internet of Vehicles." which you submitted to IEEE Access. Please note that IEEE Access has a binary peer review process. Therefore, to uphold quality to IEEE standards, an article is rejected even if it requires minor edits. Your manuscript has not been recommended for publication in IEEE Access in its current form; however, we encourage you to address the reviewers’ concerns, which can be found at the bottom of this letter and resubmit your article once you have updated it accordingly. When updating your manuscript, you should elaborate on your points and clarify with references, examples, data, etc. If you disagree with any technical points the reviewers have made, please include your counterarguments in your response to the reviewers (more information detailed below) and work this into the updated manuscript. Also, note that if a reviewer suggested references, you should only add those that are relevant to your work if you feel they strengthen your article. Recommending references to specific publications is not appropriate for reviewers and you should report excessive cases to ieeeaccessEIC@ieee.org. Please be advised that authors are only permitted to resubmit their article ONCE. If the updated manuscript is determined not to have addressed all the previous reviewers’ concerns, or if the Associate Editor has substantial technical concerns, the article may be rejected, and no further resubmissions will be allowed. When resubmitting, please submit as a new manuscript via our submission site, the IEEE Author Portal, and include the following 3 files: 1) A document containing your response to reviewers from the previous peer review. The “response to reviewers” document (template attached) should have the following regarding each comment: a) Reviewer’s concern, b) your response to the concern, c) your action to remedy the concern. The document should be uploaded with your manuscript files as a “Supplementary Material for Review.” 2) Your updated manuscript with all your individual changes highlighted, including grammatical changes (e.g., preferably with the yellow highlight tool within the pdf file). This file should be uploaded with your manuscript files as a “Supplementary Material for Review.” 3) A clean copy of the final manuscript (without highlighted changes) submitted as a Word or LaTeX file, and as a PDF, both submitted as the “Main Manuscript.” **IMPORTANT: Please see the attached Resubmission Checklist that details all the items listed above. Please utilize this checklist to ensure you have made the necessary edits to your manuscript, and to ensure you have all the necessary files prepared prior to resubmission. We sincerely hope you will update your manuscript and resubmit it soon. Please contact me if you have any questions. Thank you for your interest in IEEE Access. Sincerely, Dr. Yongming Li Associate Editor, IEEE Access yongmingli@cqu.edu.cn Reviewers' Comments to Author: Reviewer: 1 Recommendation: Reject (updates required before resubmission) Comments: The paper still requires further edits before acceptance. Please see my comments below. - Method: The authors use random forest classifier for classifying basic safety messages falsification in IoV. The comparison seems unfair since only random forest underwent hyperparameter tuning, while other algorithms' parameters were default. All benchmarked algorithms should be fine tuned. The number of estimators for RF is 40 seems too small. How did the author consider the hyperparameter search space? It should be mentioned clearly in the paper. - Validation technique was done by simple hold-out, it would be better to use cross validation and the final performance can be obtained by mean. fields.subject: Vivian Ukamaka Ihekoronye, Simeon Okechukwu Ajakwe, Dong-Seong Kim, Jae Min Lee 'KITYOLO: Aerial Detection and Recognition of Drones and Birds using Convolutional Neural Networks'. IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology
fields.content: Reviewer: 1 ADDITIONAL COMMENTS TO THE AUTHOR: The authors aim to accurate detect distant drones in clustered environments amidst other flying objects with CNN. It's an interesting idea for anti-drone systems to quickly identify threats in the air. However, the author's description of the model is insufficient, there are some additional comments. 1. The innovativeness of KITYOLO's model is unclear. 2. The dataset is unconvincing. Reviewer: 2 ADDITIONAL COMMENTS TO THE AUTHOR: The authors propose an approach for detection and recognition of drones and birds. The proposed approach is based on YOLOv5 and an additional bottom-up path. The related work section includes only three papers about drone detection, which is not sufficient. In literature, there exist several works about deep learning based drone detection. For instance: Drone-vs-bird detection challenge at ieee avss2019 Deep learning-based strategies for the detection and tracking of drones using several cameras Drone detection in long-range surveillance videos Deep cross-domain flying object classification for robust UAV detection The overview of the system design (Fig. 1) is confusing. The input images show crops of drones and birds, which gives the impression that the network is only used for classification. The authors should show instead a figure of the proposed KITYOLO (input image, YOLOv5 +PA-FPN, output). Page 5: Intersection Of Union -> Intersection Over Union The authors should provide links or references for Makesense software and the used drone images from Kaggle. What are the dimensions of the recorded images and the images taken from Kaggle? What is the average object size after scaling the images to 416 x 416 pixels? Is Fig. 6 correct? In case of Mavic_Enter_Cloudy (True) all predictions are classified as birds, which does not match with the corresponding description in the main text. Do false positives only occur in images with Mavic_Air_sunny? Background FN should be removed? The confusion matrix may give the impression that the approach classifies between six drone classes and the bird class. Which confidence score is used to compute the precision and recall in Table III and for the F1-score given in Table IV? The so-called efficiency graph given in Fig. 9 only provides the precision and recall values used to compute the F1-scores. Thus, the name efficiency graph is confusing. Page 7: The gap between the capture of Fig. 8 and the main text is too small. The authors state that the differences in F-score between KITYOLO and YOLOv5s and YOLOv5+FPN are significant. However, the number of images in the test set is small. It would be interesting to see how the results are in case of larger and more diverse test sets. For instance, the authors can use images from the Drone-vs-Bird challenge dataset. Reviewer: 3 ADDITIONAL COMMENTS TO THE AUTHOR: This paper proposed an aerial detection and recognition method for drones and birds. This idea is good. But the overall content of this paper is unclear. The logic of the detection method in the paper is confusing. Authors should organize a clear algorithm to show their model. In addition, the contributions of this paper are not clear, please reorganize the relevant content. The experimental analysis is not detailed, please make further extend.

fields.subject: Federate Learning Based Resource Allocation for V2X Communication
fields.content: Dear Prof. Kim: The review of your paper VT-2021-04088.R1: Federate Learning Based Resource Allocation for V2X Communication has been completed. Below please find comments from the reviewers. Based on the reviewers' comments, publication of the paper in its present form is not recommended. It is recommended that you resubmit your manuscript, WITHIN TWO MONTHS from the date of this email, as revised in accordance with the comments. If you fail to do so, your paper will be considered withdrawn from the review process. Please note that this recommendation of resubmission should not be treated as an implication of eventual acceptance of your paper. It only refers to a deferral of the editorial decision to see whether the reviewers' comments could be addressed. In the event that your revision is accepted, the manuscript must be in a format that is in accordance with IEEE final submission requirements. For detailed final submission requirements, kindly refer to the information for IEEE Authors guidelines contained on the website http:/www.ieee.org/pubs/authors.html. To submit your revision, please first log onto Manuscript Central (https://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/tvt-ieee). In the Author Center, you will see the entry "Revised Manuscripts with Decisions" under "My Manuscripts". Click this entry and you will see an entry with the current paper ID included in the list "Manuscripts with Decisions" at the bottom of the screen. Then click the "Create a revision" button in the entry for this paper to start submitting your revision. Please note that your manuscript (including main body, figures, tables, references) should be in double-columned with fonts no smaller than 10pt in the final IEEE typesetting with maximum page length 16 pages for regular papers. Additionally, you MUST submit a response file alongside you manuscript that details the changes you have made and addresses the issues raised by the reviewers. REVISION WITHOUT THIS FILE WILL BE REJECTED. The file must be added in Step 2 of the submission as "OPTIONAL SOURCE FILE - MAIN DOCUMENT." The revised manuscript should follow our submission policy. The complete revised manuscript (including main body, figures, tables, references, and appendix) of a Regular Paper should be in general limited to 35 pages. If the revised paper does not comply our submission policy, it may be considered withdrawn without the review process. As the system keeps all the files from your earlier submission(s) for this paper, please remember to delete any files which are not part of this new revised submission. Sincerely yours, Beatriz Lorenzo Editor, IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology ============================================== Reviews for VT-2021-04088.R1 *Please note that there may be attached files that contain additional comments from the reviewers. To see these files, please log on to your "Author Center" at the Manuscript Central web site (https://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/tvt-ieee) and select this paper to see and download the files. ============================================== Reviewer: 4 ADDITIONAL COMMENTS TO THE AUTHOR: This article still has many writing problems and typing mistakes, no matter in the manuscript or the response. It is suggested for authors proofread this work again and again, and the presentation of the manuscript should be further improved. For example: 1. Figure 1 is not very professional. In the left subfigure, due to improper placement of the vehicles, the lines of various colors are in disorder. It is suggested to modify the lines and colors to make them distinguishable when printed in white and black. Also, it is necessary to adjust the direction of all vehicles, maybe just like the orange car on the right. 2. There are some places where authors misspell the “Federated Learning” as “Federate Learning”. For example, the title, the second column in TABLE I and the title of Section II.B. 3. There are typos in the constraints of Problem (7). “;” should be “:”. 4. In Algorithm 1, there is no need to state “Pseudo code of Proposed Approach”, and FL-RA-V2X is enough. 5. In the paragraph above (15), it should be “Jain’s fairness” instead of “Jain,s fairness”. 6. In the paragraph below (21). It should be “From (17)~(21)”. It should be “SNR” instead of ”SNR”. The quotes are not in the right direction. 7. The reference to the formula in this paper does not conform to the specification, e.g., Eq. 22. Please check and correct all references to formulas according to Standard IEEE Transactions templates. 8. It is suggested for authors to change all fonts in the diagram to the format Times New Roman. 9. The format of the references needs to be uniform, such as whether the words in the title are uppercase or not. Also, the format of all conference papers is not uniform, such as [24] and [28]. Reviewer: 1 ADDITIONAL COMMENTS TO THE AUTHOR: In Section II. A, the author formulated the resource allocation problem in this paper, and then gave the details of the Federate Learning method in Section II. B and C. However, this paper does not explain how to use the FL method to solve the optimisation problem in (8) with constraints. The author is suggested to add one section to illustrate this point. Reviewer: 3 ADDITIONAL COMMENTS TO THE AUTHOR: This manuscript studies the federate learning based resource allocation for V2X communication. I have some doubts: 1. The motivations and contributions of this work are somehow inadequate. It is said that “The main goal of this paper is show that FL technique can be applied to the resource allocation for V2X, thereby improving the overall performance of the vehicle users in the presence of cellular user.” However, the FL technique is already shown can be applied to the resource allocation of wireless networks, referring to [20] and the references included. On the other hand, the advantages of applying of FL technique are not that clear, since the solution to the optimization problem is obtained through several transformations, and the improvement of the overall performance is not quantified. Besides, the optimality of the proposed algorithm is not analyzed theoretically. 2. The problem formulation with the objective of maximizing the throughput for all vehicle users is quite common in V2X communications. Moreover, why it is assumed that “A vehicle Vtv is connected to another vehicle via V2V and to a base station (BS) through V2I, i.e. each vehicle is connected to another vehicle and a BS”. Maybe a vehicle is connected to another vehicle or a BS. 3. In section II.C Federate learning over wireless networks, Algorithm 1 is proposed, which shows the pseudo code for the proposed FL-RA-V2X. I think this is not appropriate, since this subsection focuses on the background of application of FL over wireless networks. 4. In section III, the transformation of eq. (7) lack of theoretical analysis. 5. The descriptions of the proposed approach is incomplete. In page 6, the section III ends with the approximation of throughput. The how does the algorithm be performed? 6. Too much contents in section IV. Maybe some figures or descriptions should be removed. 7. Theoretically, how does the proposed approach improve the fairness of vehicles? 8. Please provide concise explanation on the effects of parameters a1, a2, b1, b2 on network throughput. 9. What do Fig. 9 and Fig. 10 illustrate? 10. Fig. 12 show the computing time comparisons. Then why the proposed FL-RA-V2X possesses the lowest computing time? Please supplement the theoretical analysis. 11. Some figures are too big. The equations quoted in the text should be parenthesized. The organization of the manuscript should be greatly improved.

fields.subject: Deep Q-Learning Based SCMA for URLLC in Industrial Wireless Networks
fields.content: Dear Prof. Kim, We have received the reports from our advisors on your manuscript, "Deep Q-Learning Based SCMA for URLLC in Industrial Wireless Networks", which you submitted to Telecommunication Systems. Based on the advice received, I have decided that your manuscript could be reconsidered for publication should you be prepared to incorporate major revisions. When preparing your revised manuscript, you are asked to carefully consider the reviewer comments which can be found below, and submit a list of responses to the comments. You are kindly requested to also check the website for possible reviewer attachment(s). In order to submit your revised manuscript, please access the journal's website. Your username is: ******** If you forgot your password, you can click the 'Send Login Details' link on the EM Login page at https://www.editorialmanager.com/tels/ Please make sure to submit your editable source files (i. e. Word, TeX). We look forward to receiving your revised manuscript before 22 Aug 2022. In order to add the due date to your electronic calendar, please open the attached file. With kind regards, Muhammad Khurram Khan, Ph.D. Editor-in-Chief Telecommunication Systems (Springer) COMMENTS FOR THE AUTHOR: Reviewer #1: I appreciate you for contributing your interesting research work. The following comments are suggested. 1) The paper is well written, however needs proofreading. 2) The quality and also the number of references can be improved. 3) A statistical model is suggested for comparison of its results with the simulation results. This allows to be able to duplicate the final outcomes. 4) A visual guide in the beginning of the paper in introduction section helps the readers to understand the approach better and faster. Reviewer #2: Authors propose an SCMA scheme based on deep Q learning (Q-SCMA), where the codebooks are adaptively constructed aiming at minimizing the bit error rate (BER), maximizing throughput while guaranteeing Reliability and low latency (URLLC mode). In the current format and content, the manuscript presents several critical issues and concerns that must be carefully addressed before receiving full consideration for publication. 1. The authors suggest comparing the Q-SCMA with conventional SCMA (C-SCMA) and deep neural network SCMA (D-SCMA). However, they did not define clearly the differences (a clear description of each scheme considered) among these three schemes, especially differences among D-SCMA and the proposed Q-SCMA. 2. Contribution bullets at the end of the introductory section must be re-stated. For instance, the second bullet does not sound like a paper contribution. Besides, it is more appropriate to change BER to Reliability. Also, pointing out the system performance comparison in different channel types as a contribution must be justified accordingly. 3. Channel modeling description must be clarified, especially regarding the Rician channel model: quat is the relation of eq. (4)_ and (5) with the vector h in eq. (3)? 4. The proposed Q-SCMA scheme appears at the first time in Fig. 2, section 2.1. Hence a clear and complete description of the proposed SCMA scheme pointing out features, advantages, and a complete set of equations governing such scheme must be presented. In the current format, Fig.2 and correspondent paragraphs offer a vague and introductory overview. Alternatively, the description of the proposed Q-SCMA presented in section 3 must be improved substantially (may be anticipated and moved to section 2). E.g., defining clearly the equations for reward, next state, action, type of loss function adopted, NN hyperparameters considered, etc. The relation among the constituent blocks and expressions must be accordingly explored since there is a lack of discussion regarding the novelty related to the proposed SCMA scheme. 5.Simulation results are provided and compared in terms of BER, bit error probability, and throughput. What is the difference between BER (bit error rate) and bit error probability? Such nomenclature/denomination generates confusion. It seems more appropriate to present the BER results as reliability R = 1-BER and call such figure-of-merit explicitly Reliability. 6. There is a problem with the definition of eq. (7). Why the SINR is the denominator of the argument of log(.) in the Shannon equation? Anyway, it is paramount to clearly define how SINR is calculated in such context. Please, offer a complete expression definition for SINR. 7. Supposedly, BER in Fig. 3 is better explored if the y-axis could be changed/adapted to Reliability R = 1-BER. Besides, why Fig. 4 appears BEFORE (on pag. 6) than Fig. 3 (on page 7)? 8. In section 3, please provide a complete description for the deployed C-SCMA and D-SCMA (including pseudo-codes for each one and a better and compact description); hence, one can understand their differences. 9. It seems apparent that the superior performance of the proposed Q-SCMA does not come with lower complexity. Hence, the authors must provide a clear and comparative performance-complexity trade-off analysis comparing the three SCMA schemes. 10. Provide a clear definition for Bit Error Probability in the numerical results section 11. Formating issue: argmin in eq. (6) must be re-written. Reviewer #3: The authors have to address all following comments: - Paper title: We suggest replacing the acronym "SCMA" and "URLLC" with words to make the title more clear and accurate. - Keywords: We suggest that the author should replace keywords such as "Deep Q-Learning" and "URLLC" because these keywords are already found in the letter paper title. It is better that they replace them with other keywords to increase the reach of the research. - There are many acronyms used before define it such SCMA ... etc. - Abstract: The abstract is not written correctly, the problem/purpose is not clear, the sentences are not connected. Furthermore, authors should add their findings at the end of the abstract. - Introduction Section: The first paragraph in the introduction is not properly structured. Authors should mention the actual researchers' names rather than the word "authors". Some of the references added in the introduction need a more nuanced critique. The third and fourth points in the main contributions are unnecessary and we recommend that they be removed. - Methodology Section: There is an incorrect subheading merge, why was the methodology merged with the results? For example, the first point "simulation parameters" and the second point "DQL Architecture" are not appropriate in this section. - Performance Evaluation Section: This section lacks fairness. The authors do not provide comparisons and discussions with existing research schemes. This section requires improvement. - Figures and Tables: All figures and table is drawn high resolution. Some Figures and Table are shown before use in text such as Figures 2, 3, 4, 5 …etc. and Table 1. Figure 4 are shown before Figure 3. - List of references: The references should follow accurately the Telecommunication Systems Journal style. For instance, some references do not contain enough information such as [2], [5], [10], [13], [18] [25] and [26]. All journal names should be italic. Some research titles begin with an uppercase letter for each word in the title, only an uppercase letter should be used for the first word. Also, the number of references is insufficient for this study. The names of researchers in the reference list are not follow the Telecommunication Systems Journal style. This paper requires an extensive check of the reference list. - English Writing: This paper requires extensive proofreading (typos and grammar). Authors have to carefully check the paper to be free from grammatical and typo mistakes. - Paraphrase Text: There are many sentences taken from previous papers (whether previous research of the same authors or that of other authors). Authors must paraphrase all sentences taken from the previous papers. The authors must avoid taking whole sentences from the original papers. They are obligated to paraphrase during the revision of the entire paper. o "how, in addition to an immediate reward for the dynamic environment, reinforcement learning (RL) takes into consideration the long-term objective." (page2). o "two parts: the encoder which learns to compress data from the input layer into a code, and the decoder" (page4). .. .. .. Etc. Reviewer #4: The manuscript under review supports ultra reliable low latency communication by proposing deep Q Learning based Sparse code multiple access. Code blocks which are adaptively constructed that minimizes bit error rate, maximize throughput while guaranteeing high reliability. Modeling is performed considering three channels - average white Gaussian noise (AWGN), Rayleigh fading channel and Rician fading channel for industrial wireless network environment. Presented results are discussed in terms of better bit error rate, low error probability as well as high throughput. Introduction is well written and previous up to date literature review works are well discussed. However, no work from Telecommunications systems journal is discussed. Few typos are found throughout the document like in abstract: "average weighted" which should be "average white" Results highlight that Q-SCMA outperforms to C-SCMA and D-SCMA in terms of error probability, latency, throughput for AWGN and Rayleigh fading channels. and Rician fading channel which mimic dynamical industrial environment also provides performances for Q-SCMA compare to C-SCMA and D-SCMA.
