I found the third reviewer who is a senior expert in this domain to arbitrate the disagreement between two reviewers with opposite opinions. The reviewer questioned the novelty of this work, especially on the comparison with the SOTA algorithms and immature experiments to test the effectiveness of invasion prevention. In overall, I concur with the third reviewer and have to reject this submission.


Reviewer(s)' Comments to Author:

Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
the author proposed a new drone detection model however, with no core innovation.
1. Table 6's result is not far behind YoloV5-tiny-s, and the improvement of fps and gflops is very limited.
2. Table 8 doesn't look right. The comparison between the classification network and the detection network of Vgg and resnet is a bit strange.
3. The Fig 1 is unclear.

Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
This paper presents an interesting work, i.e., an operation approach for detecting, localizing, and neutralizing UAVs under different scenarios. However, I think some of the descriptions and results are questionable. My comments are provided as follows.

1) The title “Drone Transportation System Security: A TEAS Paradigm for Countering Invasion” aims to investigate the Drone security. As we know, security means that defending the cyberattacks. But this manuscript seems to investigate the object detection rather than proposing security solutions against cyberattacks. So the title may be changed to better reflect the research topic of this study.
2) If the author insist on investigating cyberattack, some comment attacks on drones should be presented and which attack is adopted in this paper is also be clarified.
3) The TEAS seems to be a framework including four parts, i.e., timely, accurate, efficient and situation-aware manner. In fact, the author introduced different methods and models to define each part. So the innovativeness of this paper should be further clarified.
4) There are some formatting and other mistakes. E.g., Tables 3-5.


Reviewer: 3

Comments to the Author
This is essentially object detection work. It doesn't have to be drone images or conveyed objects. A different neural network structure does not mean it is novel. Actually, it would be easy to come up with a different neural network but the rate of getting a really good one is low. That's why Google tried thousands of structures before finding Transformer. The object detector was not compared to the state of the arts. The image data collection could also be largely improved., for example, the "toy drones" would not be the best samples for invasion.

2- Please justify why LSTM was used instead of GRU in your DL classifiers?

Reviewer #2: The authors describe a SCADA intrusion detection scheme using the fusion of a modified decision tree and Chi-Square feature selection. The work is interesting, and the proposed methodology is adequately explained. Moreover, the experimental results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed work. Nevertheless, despite the good work, the following remarks should be taken into consideration.

1. First, the introduction can include some more information about the motivation behind this work. Some cybersecurity incidents from the industry can be used for this purpose.

2. Section 2 can be divided into two separate sections: (a) Related Works and (b) Background. Also, the authors can add complementary information about signature-based detection systems and honeypots focusing on ICS/SCADA systems and smart grids. 4. The architecture of the proposed Intrusion Detection System (IDS) is not described adequately. The authors can include some more information about the technologies and the implementation details used for each module/technique.

5. The authors can provide a section about the attacks detected by the proposed solution.

6. The authors can include more information about the experimental results. For instance, the False Positive Rate (FPR) is not investigated. For each ML/DL method, the various evaluation metrics can be added to Table 9.

Dear Authors (CC to Associate Editor, Reviewers),

Thank you very much for submitting manuscript No. TII-22-1207: "FDPR: A Novel Fog Data Prediction and Recovery using Efficient DL in IoT Networks" to the IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics as a Regular Paper submission.

The review process of your manuscript referenced above has been completed. Much to my regret, I have to inform you that in the opinion of the reviewers and Associate Editor in charge, the submitted manuscript is not suitable for publication in the IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics.

For your reference, these comments of the reviewers are enclosed.

With my best wishes for your success,


Sincerely yours,

Dr. Ren Luo
Editor-in-Chief
IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics
http://tii.ieee-ies.org/
renluo@ntu.edu.tw

****************************************************
Encl.:
Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
The authors propose and evaluate a novel fog data prediction and recovery (FDPR)
using deep learning. The paper comes timely and is well motivated. Solutions are overall sound and results overall promising.

Presentation comes handy and it is easy to read and understand the paper

Related work needs more attention so that the reader is better presented with current state-of-the-art and how this paper advances the field

Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
This paper proposes a novel fog data prediction and recovery algorithm (FDPR) to predict and recover sensor data in IoT networks. The proposed algorithm uses a deep concatenated multiplayer perceptron (DC-MLP) and aims for fast and accurate sensor data prediction. Experiments are conducted to evaluate the proposed method on actual devices.

The authors implemented some simple algorithms (as described in Algorithms 1 to 3) and evaluated their implementations against similar approaches in literature. From an engineering perspective, this is good work. From a scientific perspective, I'm not convinced that this work (in its current form) has sufficient contributions to justify a journal publication.

Comments:
1. Please be explicit about the scientific contribution of this work: what does this work solve that previous work has not solved yet?

2. Are there no advantages to Edge on Table II? Please clarify.

3. Please describe what Historical Data Input (1), (2) and (3) in Fig. 2 are exactly. The explanation on page 5 (lines 39 to 49) is not very clear.

4. The accuracies for experimental data prediction for related work in Table III are 0%, 11.2% and 44.53%, whilst the proposed method has an accuracy of 99.86%. What is the cause of such a big difference in accuracy between the proposed method and the related work? This difference seems very high for methods that are somewhat similar/equivalent.

Reviewer: 3

Comments to the Author
The present manuscript introduces a fog based data prediction and recovery algorithm for use in IoT based applications. The proposed system was evaluated both via simulations and real testbed experimentation. The motivation for the research is noteworthy, however, there are a number of concerns, as follows:

1. The manuscript can benefit from a more thorough proofing in order to improve isolated areas of grammatical errors. Please kindly ensure that this is done to improve readability.

2. The authors distinguished 4 different layers in their architectural model, however, they consistently refered to the sensors as the edge devices. This is very confusing. The sensing layer contains the sensors, whereas the edge devices seem to be aggregators. If the edge devices perform sensing, then why the need for these two distinct layer? I believe there is a confusion of terminologies here. It is essential that a consistent description be maintained in this article.

3. What happens during the sleep state of the edge device? Is this the period responsible for missing data? And if so, how long is the sleep time? And how much data is missed in terms of number of samples? I believe this cannot just be two data points. Thus, this is very important to explain in order to appreciate the recovery power of the proposed algorithm.

4. It is not clear what the recovery method really is. The section on the FDPR algorithm is too trivial and not descriptive enough. My thought is that the authors have consumed so much space discussing existing methods, with little space left to talk about their own contribution. Presently, it looks too weak and heuristic for me.

5. It is important to discuss the exact recovery mechanism and show how it is unique from existing methods. The prediction approach was achieved by simply increasing the number of hidden layers, which is well known in the literature and it is therefore not a contribution.

6. The authors failed to discuss the training time. This must have contributed to the entire latency of their system. Why was this excluded?

7. The results are poorly discussed. Authors also presented results but failed to clearly explain why their method performed better than the existing ones. In this case, authors need to be aware of why their method performed well and others did not. This was missing and should be included throughout the results section.

AE Comments:
Associate Editor
Comments to the Author:
Although the idea is promising, the reviewers felt the work needs further development. We hope these comments can help improve the paper for submission to other venue.

fields.subject: Hierarchical Intrusion Detection System for Secured Military Drone Network: A Perspicacious Approach
fields.content:
Review 1
I think the paper was very good and current and relevant. My concerns are mostly administrative and/or language use issues. - Many acronyms, such as NSL-KDD, WSN, GNB and others are not defined. RSCV, one of your most important acronyms, is spelled wrong in the Abstract. - Use of certain words doesn't seem proper in various instances, to include: p1 -"secure.. towards", transcending, p2 - "fostered the compliance", notable (maybe use superior), very expensive and paramount (quantify), essential (this sentence right before section III is too long to understand the use of essential), exhaustively (unlikely to be true), "in-built" (usually see "built-in"), p3 - guarantee (again, not likely something guarantees something else), "ground-based, thus" (missing word?), squishes (is this a technical term?), p4 - "leveraging on", aid vice aids, time is not a luxury (technical term?), p5 - "Though ... however" (one doesn't follow the other), "objective function" (this sentence needs rewriting), RSCV-RF does not appear to me to be the "next runner-up" based on Table II, "results ... show, vice shows", p6 - "significant periods...." (should this be lowest, or best, or something else?), capitalize Forest, and finally, in the final sentence of the Conclusion section use of "some" and "several" isn't very specific, can you be more specific?


Review 2
The paper describes a lot of machine learning techniques, but it is not clear how these apply to stated problem. The bulk of the paper covers ML as it could apply to any problem, so it's not clear how it applies to the military drone network. The metrics provided are just a table of numbers, with no real discussion of what is happening or why. It's not even clear how the data set used corresponds to a military system, and what is perspicacious about the algorithm?


Review 3
In general I think this paper is good: the technical content is fine and citations are adequate. Some points where the paper could be improved: 1) Please limit the unnecessary use of acronyms/abbreviations. The paper becomes difficult to follow with so many. 2) Please review writing for syntax and grammar and try to make the writing more concise. Some language is unnecessarily ornate where more straightforward language could be used. 3) While you do compare your strategy to other strategies, it would be good to include a comparison table with references to other work to highlight the novelty of what you are doing as well as how performance of your strategy compares with prior work

Editor and Reviewer comments:    



Reviewer #2: The Authors proposed " ACS: Accuracy-Based Client Selection Mechanism for Federated Industrial IoT"

The paper is presented in a systematic and organized manner. I appreciate the organization of the paper and the coherent transition between the ideas. The paper discusses an interesting topic.

The authors should consider the following suggestions provided by the reviewer in order to improve the scientific depth of their manuscript, as well as they should address the following comments in order to improve the quality of the presentation of their manuscript:
1-      The author(s) have to further improve the technical writing of the paper. This manuscript needs careful editing by someone with expertise in technical English editing paying particular attention to English grammar, spelling, sentence structure, typos, spaces, and indentation errors so that the goals and results of the study are clear to the reader.
2-      In the Introduction part, strong points of this proposed article should be further stated.
3-      Motivations behind this work can be added in a separate sub-section of the introduction section.
4-      Not clear what is the originality of this work? What makes it different from existing work?
5-      The Literature review is not clear what is the objective behind it? Is it to show the shortage of work in this field? or to show the methods that the proposed approach is based on? What is it exactly?
6-      Past studies should be reviewed well. However, only the strong parts of the reviewed studies have been emphasized which makes the contribution of the proposed paper unconvincing. The disadvantages of reviewed studies should be highlighted. The new features of the proposed method and the main advantages of the results over others should be clearly described. The author(s) must highlight in 8-10 lines what gaps are observed in existing literature, which has led to the design of the proposed method in this paper.
7-      It is preferred to provide the related works in a tabular form with the specification of researcher name, title, methodologies used, year of publication, limitations, and so on. And state the position of the proposed work with respect to the related works in this table.
8-      The author(s) have to pay more attention to the writing of mathematical equations and their parameters.
9-      It's preferred to add the setting of parameters in a table that is used in the experiments.
10-     The results are not significant enough for publication yet. More comprehensive evaluations are needed for publication.
11-     The results of the proposed method are not compared against other methods. Why not any recent state-of-the-art? There have been many good works on this topic recently. So, how will we know about the efficacy of the proposed work with respect to recent works? This presents an important hindrance to the proposed work.
12-     The format of the reference should be improved. The following references are comparable and should be totally added in the Section "References":   

-       Al-Qurabat, A.K.M., Mohammed, Z.A. and Hussein, Z.J., 2021. Data Traffic Management Based on Compression and MDL Techniques for Smart Agriculture in IoT. Wireless Personal Communications, 120(3), pp.2227-2258.
-       Al-Qurabat, A.K.M., 2021. A Lightweight Huffman-based Differential Encoding Lossless Compression Technique in IoT for Smart Agriculture. International Journal of Computing and Digital System.
-       Saeedi, I.D.I. and Al-Qurabat, A.K.M., 2022. Perceptually Important Points-Based Data Aggregation Method for Wireless Sensor Networks. Baghdad Science Journal, 19(4), pp.0875-0875.
-       Al-Qurabat, A. K. M., & Abdulzahra, S. A. (2020). An Overview of Periodic Wireless Sensor Networks to the Internet of Things. IOP Conference Series: Materials Science and Engineering, 928(3). doi: 10.1088/1757-899X/928/3/032055
-       Al-Qurabat, A. K. M., Abdulzahra, S. A., & Idrees, A. K. (2022). Two-level energy-efficient data reduction strategies based on SAX-LZW and hierarchical clustering for minimizing the huge data conveyed on the internet of things networks. The Journal of Supercomputing, 1-47.
-       Al-Qurabat, A. K. M., Idress, A. K., Makhoul, A., & Jooude, C. A. (2022). A Bi-Level Data Lowering Method to Minimize Transferring Big Data in the Sensors of IoT Applications. Karbala International Journal of Modern Science, 8(2), 123-138. doi: 10.33640/2405-609X.3228
-       Jawad, G. A. M., Al-Qurabat, A. K. M., & Idrees, A. K. (2022). Maximizing the underwater wireless sensor networks' lifespan using BTC and MNP5 compression techniques. Annales Des Telecommunications/Annals of Telecommunications, 0123456789. doi: 10.1007/s12243-021-00903-6
-       Al-Qurabat, A. K. M., Salman, H. M., & Finjan, A. A. R. (2022). Important extrema points extraction-based data aggregation approach for elongating the WSN lifetime. International Journal of Computer Applications in Technology, 68(4), 357-368.





Reviewer #3: The authors propose a client selection mechanism named ACS which is based on federated learning. Unlike the FedAvg where the clients are randomly selected, in this paper the authors propose mechanism ACS which considers the previous performance of the clients, not choosing those clients with an overall low performance.
       The related work is well investigated; however, more related work can be added.
       Different from FedAvg FL algorithm, the proposed ACS mechanism uses client's accuracy to differentiate the clients, however the authors fail to mention how the clients are evaluated. 
       The subsection 3.2 where the ACS mechanism is introduced, should be further expanded so the reader can understand the concept more in detail and seize the relevance of the proposed mechanism since is not very clear and it is difficult to follow.
       In section 5, the authors evaluate their proposed system and mention several times that the processing time is increased with FedAvg + ACS as supported by Table 2,3, 4 and conclusions. However, at section 5.5 they contradict the same statement by stating "Based on all of the experiments performed to test the ability of the proposed ACS algorithm, it was discovered that implementing ACS to FedAvg on FL provided higher performance. Not just in terms of accuracy, but also in terms of processing time, which can compete with random client selection."(Section 5.5 p. 12).
I would recommend the authors to consider the above-mentioned suggestions.

Reviewer #3: The authors propose a client selection mechanism named ACS which is based on federated learning. Unlike the FedAvg where the clients are randomly selected, in this paper the authors propose mechanism ACS which considers the previous performance of the clients, not choosing those clients with an overall low performance.
       The related work is well investigated; however, more related work can be added.

fields.content:
Dear Prof. Kim,

I am writing to you concerning the above referenced manuscript which you submitted to the IEEE Internet of Things Journal.

Based on the enclosed set of reviews, this manuscript is not acceptable for publication at this time.  Please consider the comments of the reviewers and resubmit your reworked manuscript as quickly as you feel is appropriate.  Your revised manuscript will receive another peer review as a new submission.  Be sure to mention the original paper number in your cover letter and the Author Comments field.

As you revise the manuscript, please use the Track Changes feature of MS Word, or a similar method, to show the changes you have made.  The changes must be underlined or highlighted in the resubmitted manuscript.  This will expedite the re-review process.

Be sure to include a file with a detailed response to the reviews as well. You can use the following link to start your resubmission without logging in:

*** PLEASE NOTE: This is a two-step process. After clicking on the link, you will be directed to a webpage to confirm. ***

https://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/iot?URL_MASK=08add9702c63452a9fb7650277bbecc9

or you can resubmit by accessing your Author Center, going to the "Manuscripts with Decisions" queue, and then choosing the "create a resubmission" option.  Using the resubmission option will automatically link your resubmission to the previous version; please do not create an entirely new submission.  

If you have any questions regarding the reviews, please contact the Associate Editor: Dr. Hongwei Li hongweili@uestc.edu.cn.  Any other inquiries should be directed to the Administrative Assistant: Surbhi Tyagi surbhi.tyagi@ieee.org

Thank you for considering IEEE Internet of Things Journal for publication of your work.

Sincerely,
Prof. Honggang Wang
Editor-in-Chief, IEEE Internet of Things Journal
hwang1@umassd.edu, wanghbell@yahoo.com

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
• Associate Editor Comments, if any, are listed below:

Associate Editor: Li, Hongwei
Comments to Author:
The paper should be rejected (revise and resubmit)  according to comments of reviewers.

• Reviewer Comments, if any, are listed below:

Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
This paper shows that chi-squared to reduce the feature space and a decision tree with limited depth can achieve good IDS accuracy with low computation time.

Pros:
The paper is reasonably well-written, although some words are missing in places and the paper could use a good read through for editing.

The authors have done a lot of work to evaluate different classifiers and feature selection with SCADA datasets.

Cons:
Novelty of the approach is low. Ranked feature selection approaches are well-known and there are several to choose from. The choice of chi-squared compared to others is not justified, especially considering the RFE appears to perform better in terms of classification accuracy; why does computation time matter for the feature selection method since this is likely done offline like training? Trimming the maximum depth of a decision tree is also well-known, and the computation time of decision trees is known to be very small. It's not clear what is to be learnt from this paper. A recent paper has looked at similar concepts in (non-SCADA) IDS datasets: https://ieeexplore.ieee.org/abstract/document/9700654
If the SCADA aspects have an impact on what works well, then that should be discussed more in this paper. This paper may be better cast as a comparative study rather than suggesting that MDT-CHI is a novel concept, because it is not novel.

The experimental setup is not explained properly. How is computation time measured? Is it including both training/testing, and if so, why combine them? At least, they should be separately measured and reported since they are not both equally important in practical deployment. Were all the results obtained on the same platform by the authors, using the same methodology? It is not entirely clear. The training/testing approach needs to be explained. If the authors have re-implemented the prior work, then they should state so, and identify any deviations from performance results reported by prior work, if any.

The evaluation results are hard to interpret. The presentation of all classifier metrics in a table form would be easier to read than the presentation using bar graphs. This would also save more space in the paper to allow for more discussion and explanations.

The f1-scores appear to be calculated incorrectly. Double check experimental results and calculations.

Some typos like WSUTL instead of WUSTL and CICDS instead of CICIDS.


Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
The authors discussed an important topic. However, the contribution of this paper is very limited and there is novelty in the proposed model.

Reviewer: 3

Comments to the Author
This study presents a framework that employs the chi-square method for resource selection and a modified decision tree for intrusion detection in SCADA networks.

I leave below some comments that can help to improve the quality of the work.
The article presents the research problem, motivations, and contributions.
The set of references presented by the authors is interesting. However, few works from 2021 and 2022 are discussed and compared in Section II and Table 1. This may suggest that this research topic has cooled down, which is not the case. I suggest improving this table and the section with more recent work.
Figures 4 and 5 present very small incomprehensible information due to its size.
The comparisons made in Table IX regarding the cost of time raise some concerns for me about the fairness of this comparison. Did the authors carry out experiments with the techniques [4], [10], [11], [15], [16], and [17] in the same environment with similar situations of computational capabilities?
Section III.C regarding the datasets used in the evaluation was inserted into Section III, which deals with the proposed methodology. This seems to me to be wrong.
Section III is confusing, and it will be important to remodel it. It is necessary to provide a more complete, clear, and precise explanation regarding the proposed framework. It is important to follow a coherent flow in explaining the framework components to facilitate the reader's understanding.
The work brings experiments with 4 different datasets, which is a positive point.
Some Figures and Graphs of results were a little small and difficult to visualize, if possible, improve.
What are the next steps of the research? If possible, make it clear in conclusion possible improvements that can be made in weak points of the approach and possibilities for future work.

Dear Prof. Dong-Seong Kim:

The review of the referenced manuscript, WCL2022-2113, is now complete. I regret to inform you that based on the enclosed reviews and my own reading of your manuscript, I am unable to recommend its publication in IEEE Wireless Communications Letters.

Your paper may not be resubmitted for review. The reasons for this are as follows: Both Reviewers have raised major concern on the significance of the manuscript and the correctness of some technical details. In addition, the writing of the manuscript needs further improvement.

The reviewers' comments are found at the end of this email.

Thank you for submitting your work to the IEEE Wireless Communications Letters. I hope the outcome of this specific submission will not discourage you from the submission of future manuscripts.

Sincerely,

Dr. Chenxi Liu
Editor, IEEE Wireless Communications Letters
chenxi.liu@bupt.edu.cn

Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
In this paper, a PTS scheme combined with the WOA algorithm is proposed for UFMC systems, optimizing the PAPR and PSD performance. It is clear that this paper combines the existing technology to design a PTS scheme, which has a certain degree of innovation. However, it still has some problems to be considered.
1. Overall, the presentation and analysis of the simulation results are vague please consider elaborating more details.
2. In figure 3, a scenario exists as the probability greater than 1, please present a reasonable explanation.
3. Lack of theoretical analysis part
4. There are typos and format errors in the text and it is recommended to read through the whole paper to avoid these problems.

Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
In this paper, authors studied a partial transmit sequence (PTS) scheme combined with a whale optimization algorithm (WOA) for universal filtered multi-carrier (UFMC) systems  to tackle the high peak-to-average power ratio (PAPR).  
It is important to give clear motivation of the work and compare contributions in contrast to the state of the art works. Is whale optimization algorithm (WOA) used for the first time in this paper or studied earlier for such systems? Please describe it with appropriate references.
Analyze the complexity performance of the proposed algorithm in contrast to the existing algorithms.
It is very awkward to see the CCDF value is going above 1 i.e., even more than 10 in Fig. 3?
Why many terms and their full forms are repeated in the paper? For example, see "partial transmit sequence (PTS)" is repeated in the abstract.
Writing of the paper is poor. There are many grammatical mistakes.

Subject:	IEEE COMST: Decision COMST-00569-2022
Body:	15-Feb-2023

Dear Prof. Dong-Seong Kim,

We have completed the review of your Survey A Contemporary Survey of SCADA Intrusion Detection Frameworks: Approaches, Challenges, and Open Issues authored by Ahakonye, Love Allen Chijioke; Nwakanma, Cosmas Ifeanyi; Lee, Jae-Min; Kim, Dong-Seong, which you had submitted for consideration for publication in the IEEE Communications Surveys and Tutorials.

Unfortunately, the reviewers find significant problems with the publishability of the manuscript in its current form. I must therefore classify your manuscript as REJECTED.

The paper may not be resubmitted.

I am sorry the results of this review cycle could not be more positive, but I hope you will find the comments of the reviewers to be useful in helping you to understand what is needed.

I thank you once again for submitting your work to IEEE Communications Surveys and Tutorials.

Sincerely yours,

---------------------------------------------
Reviewer Comments:

Reviewer: 1

Recommendation: Reject

Comments:
This paper investigates the SCADA IDS works from 2018 and 2022 by examining related techniques and datasets. It also discusses the related open issues and future direction. However, the paper has a number of issues, as pointed out below.

1. None of the contributions is unique compared to other surveyed related studies. While Table I provides a comparison of surveyed related studies, some key aspects such as blockchain, feature selection and imbalance datasets are not well discussed in the paper. For example, there is no reference regarding how blockchain is related to SCADA IDS, the explanation is poor in regard to how important feature selection is to the performance of SCADA IDS, and the imbalance dataset issue is not clearly discussed.

2. It is mentioned in the paper that the other state-of-the-art related work still needs to present performance details on SCADA IDS. Unfortunately, the paper itself does not well demonstrate the performance evaluation either. The performance evaluation is mentioned in Table VI, considering the impact of feature selection on the performance. However, this comparison is not valid as different datasets are used across the compared approaches.

3.  At the end of Section II, the authors mention four points showing the major differences between this study and other works. However, the first two points are not convincing as they are common in survey research. The third point is not valid, as shown in my second comment above. The last point states that this study tries to build a correlation between several approaches, but it is unclear where is the discussion related to this point throughout the paper.

4. The “Open Issues” part does not provide any novel issues. The paper mentioned about the dataset and performance metrics but these are not new. These are well-known issues in the AI-based intrusion detection systems.

5. The “Future Direction” part only discusses the dataset and deep learning which are employed in much research. Instead, more useful directions for SCADA IDS should be provided, e.g., the impact of mobility, quantum computers, next generation networks, KPI for IDS, etc.

6. There are many presentation related issues:
i) Page 2, second last paragraph: “Section V” is missing.
ii) Page 2, third last paragraph: “AI-based IDS” --> “AI-based SCADA IDS”
iii) The text font sizes of Figs.3-7 should be increased.
iv) There are many acronyms in the paper. It is better to summarize them in a table for readers’ convenience.
v) Page 19, right column, second paragraph: It is stated that “Recent studies indicate a significant rate…”, but there is no citation supporting the claim.
vi) Page 20: The "Conclusion" section is too long.
vii) others: “systemic”, “F1Score”, etc.

1. The manuscript is full of language mistakes. 2. Several phrases are vague and need clarification. For instance: "Based on the investigation" --> conducted by whom?, "a more practical approach" --> how is this measured? what exactly the term "practical" means in this particular context?
3. Bad use of terminology: The authors confuse the terms ML, DL, AI, attack, threat, zero-day, etc. Deep learning is just a subfield of machine learning and machine learning is an application of artificial intelligence. For instance, the authors refer to AI-based IDS, while they mean ML-based IDS. The text contains several instances of this situation: "The learning algorithm of the IDS model based on ML or DL.",  "Furthermore, the application of DL and ML will enhance IDS performance", and so forth. They say about zero-day threats while they probably mean zero-day vulnerabilities.
4. The contribution of the paper at hand vis-a-vis the related work as given in the introduction (and again in section II) is convoluted.
5. Section II should be split in two sections.
6. Table II should be dropped.
7. Figure 2 does not offer something important to the text.
8. MiM in p.5 should be MitM (see https://csrc.nist.gov/glossary/term/man_in_the_middle_attack). Also, in the same bullet point, reference [39] refers to a blog article. In the era of TLS 1.3, SSLStrip, etc, are anymore obsolete.
9. "SCADA networks become more stable over time, as network
applications do not join or leave regularly." Do you claim that such networks were unstable in the past? It is well-known that such network components were quite closed. What do you mean by "applications do not join or leave regularly"? join/leave typically used for nodes in dynamic (wireless) networks.
10. Why federated learning, transfer learning, etc. are not mentioned in fig. 4?
11. What the word "SOME" means in Tables IV and V? Based on which criteria these ("some") works have been selected?
12. Ref. [163] is assumed to refer to the UNSW-NB15 dataset but it cites the AWID one, which however is not even included in the discussion provided in this section (along with AWID3 -- see the AWID dataset website).
13. Section IV is convoluted, while subsection IV.E just mentions the basic metrics used in such studies. This is very well-known information and contributes nothing new to the discussion.
14. Section V also does not contain nothing really new that provides the reader with fresh insights on this already very well investigated subject.

fields.subject: Esmot Ara Tuli, Mohtasin Golam, Dong-Seong Kim, and Jae-Min Lee, "A Metaverse Approach: Web Inside of Web", IEEE Communications Magazine Special Issue on Metaverse (R)
fields.content:
A Metaverse Approach: The Web Inside of the Web
COMMAG-22-00750

Dr. Kim:
Based on the judgment of a panel of reviewers, the above manuscript submitted to IEEE Communications Magazine has been rejected for publication.

The reviewers' comments are included below. **Please note: There may be files attached to the reviewer's comments. You will not be able to view attached files from this e-mail. To view attachments, please log into your account and click on View Letter.

Thank you for submitting this manuscript to IEEE Communications Magazine.

Mischa Dohler

Editor: Dohler, Mischa
Comments to the Author:
Thank you for submitting to the Metaverse IEEE Comms Mag Special Issue.

Based on the reviewers' comments after a careful review process and an independent in-depth reading of your manuscript, we are not able to recommend acceptance at this time.

Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
The article deals with a relevant and interesting topic, which fits into the scope of the journal. The paper is properly structured, references are appropriate and, in general, the used language is fine and easy to follow. However, there are several major concerns that need to be addressed:

(1) Blockchain is presented as a technology that must be used in conjunction with the metaverse, but it is not clear why (i.e., it is indicated that "any virtual platform that wants to be widely adopted has to have the unhackbility and immutability of blockchain" or that "the fact remains that blockchain technology and digital currency will have to be a substancial element of the metaverse's implementation"). There are other available technologies (some of them more efficient than blockchain in certain scenarios), why should not they be used instead of blockchain?

(2) Blockchain is presented in Section II.B as a repository that allows users to store data across a virtual world. This may be interpreted as if a blockchain is a technology to store data files, which is mostly not the case (blockchains store small amounts of data, like transactions or file hashes, but not data files).

(3) In Section II.B it is indicated, regarding the proposed solution, that authorities will have access to all the information, which poses privacy concerns and legal problems. How such problems would be prevented?

(4) It is not clear how the proposed private and consortium blockchains are communicated. How they are supposed to exchange data? What about their protocol compability and data synchronization?

(5) It is not clear why web searching can be useful in a 3D scenario. The whole idea of having a Metaverse is to change the way we interact with content, providing a realistic 3D experience. Why go back to 2D instead of proposing novel 3D ways for interacting with the content?

(6) The proposed WIW module is presented as a solution for "every metaverse user". This seems to be a pretty ambicious statement, which is not justified in the article. The concept may be extrapolated to any available metaverse, but the presented development is very specific (i.e., it is an ad-hoc development for a specific software plataform and hardware setup). What should be needed by the proposed solution to be compatible with the different metaverses so that it can be available for "very mevateverse user"?

(7) Were VR glasses actually used to test the developed software? In such a case, the model should be indicated in Table I. This is relevant, since the experience differs notably between a PC and VR glasses, specially when performing tasks like traditional web browsing.

(8) The presented proof of concept seems to be a mere integration of already available modules. As a consequence, it is not clear which is the actual contribution of the proof of concept. Moreover, Section IV.B presents a solution that is not specific for the metaverse, but a general solution, so it is not clear its contribution to the state of the art. Please clarify these concerns.

(9) It is not clear which entity generates the 16-digit DNA code. Is it a central authority (e.g., a government, a company)? In addition, how is prevented people impersonation? Are there any foreseen security mechanisms to avoid ADN code cloning or spoofing?

(10) Fig. 1 is not referenced in the paper. It seems that is the one referenced as Fig. 2 in page 2, in the Introduction. Nonetheless, it is not clear wether such a figure contributes to the understanding of the proposed WIW module.

(11) In general, language is fine, but it should be revised (ideally, by a native speaker), since there is a relevant number of grammatical minor errors. Most of such errors do not affect the understanding of the conveyed ideas, but others can be misleading (for instance, in the Abstract it is indicated that a proof of concept is "being developed", but in the paper it seems that the proof of concept was already developed).

Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
- The abstract seems to promise contributions on privacy in the metaverse, but the article does not address metaverse privacy (in fact, lack of privacy seems to be at the core of the proposed system, see below). The abstract is also not clear enough and does not give the reader a good enough idea what specifically the contents and contributions of the article are.

- The article makes several assumptions about blockchain technology that are questionable, or at least phrased much too strongly. For example, the article claims that:
-- it will be inevitable to use blockchain (opinion, not sufficiently well argued or substantiated)
-- blockchain is unhackable (so far, all software implementations have had errors which have often led to security vulnerabilities. Such a broad claim is not helpful and looks out of place in an academic publication)
-- transactions on blockchain are performed instantly (incorrect - transactions on Bitcoin, for example, do not happen instantly)
-- authentication based on smart contracts protects privacy (not clear without further detail why this should be the case)
-- it guarantees security ("security" is much too broad a term to be guaranteed by any single technology)

- The article seems to propose a kind of digital panopticon, i.e., a system where the "authorities" have unlimited surveillance powers over all users. The proposed model makes it technically impossible to adhere to data protection regulations like the GDPR: because information about users as well as their communications are recorded on the blockchain (where records are immutable!), users have no way to correct or delete their information. In addition, traceability of users and their actions as proposed in the article is not necessarily a desirable feature. From a human rights and human autonomy standpoint, anonymous access to public resources is extremely important, and would be completely eliminated by the proposed model.

- The article does not make it clear why blockchain is the most appropriate technology for the metaverse. In particular, some use cases mentioned by the authors would be better realized with other technologies. For example, a distributed immutable ledger is not required (nor the appropriate technology) to enable personal data storage. In addition, the use of permissioned blockchains generally indicates that other technologies would be more suitable than blockchain.

- The proposed model and proof of concept are very simple and described at a very abstract level. As a result, it is hard to see what exactly the novel contributions of this model are, and how they are realized. For example, the integration of a web browser in the metaverse seems trivial. If there were substantial challenges to overcome, the authors did not describe them clearly. In addition, the article mentions connection establishment between meta-humans as a contribution, but the details for this process do not become clear in the article.

Minor issues:
- The URL in reference [1] is incorrect (missing characters)
- Figure 1 is referenced as Fig. 2 in the text

Reviewer: 3

Comments to the Author
Paper COMMAG-22-00750:  The proposition of web inside web is interesting; and interesting to see the prototype of the concept. The authors have articulated the vision reasonably well. However, there are a few shortcomings: * In the introduction, the reference to 4bn people able to use the metaverse are misleading. First, it does matter little what they could do; rather, it matters what they do do: there are not even 100m people using the metaverse today. Second, there are not enough headset sold to accommodate for 4bn people using the metaverse. * In the introduction, it is not clear if “location” is meant to be the physical location of the person in the headset or the virtual location in the metaverse. It is claimed that the work is the first one but there is work on DNS servers for the metaverse which seems to be a fairly similar concept. * In the background section, there seems to be a mix up between virtual reality and augmented reality. It is not clear which is which: both are fundamentally different in terms of usage and applicability. This should be made clearer. * The section on blockchains is a complete mix up between blockchains and NFTs. These are really basics and the authors seem to rely a lot on blockchain. They should get this technically right and not confuse readers. * In the section on the proposed model, the used architecture / protocols are really confusing. It might be because there is a lot of confusion on public vs permissioned blockchains, on what NFTs are, how smart contracts are being used. * The usage of immutable ledgers to record web access in the metaverse is creepy, to say the least. Even smart contract rules can reveal browsing behaviour which is violating prominent privacy laws, such as GDPR. * The purpose of the prototype is not really clear. The WIW does not cater for the spatial and immersive capabilities of the metaverse. It is a 2D projection into a 3D space – not very innovative. Overall, the paper seems to be a quickly assembled concept study based on some emerging technologies. It requires more work to be suitable to the readership of the IEEE Communications Magazine. 

Reviewer Suggested References, if applicable:
Reviewer: 1
Suggested References: N/A

Reviewer: 2
Suggested References: N/A

Reviewer: 3
Suggested References: N/A

Editor and Reviewer comments:

paper has some shortcomings in regards to some concerns

Moreover, the authors mentioned that 4 sensors have been used, but I do not see any details on these sensors except pH sensor. I would like to suggest to rewrite Section 3.1 and Section 3.2.

3. Please add details on data acquisition, in particular , how the data is collected and what is the limitation during the data acquisition prosess.


Reviewer #3: 1. The following is a list of typos:
Page2: Section 3 delves into the proposed WQMS Design. "Section 3" explores the Water Quality Model and Methodology. Section 5 discusses the Results and Performance evaluation………..

Authors: Prof. Jae-Min Lee, Ajakwe, Simeon; Kim, Dong-Seong; Lee, Jae-Min
Editor: Dr. Massimiliano Albanese

Status: Major Revision

Dear Prof. Lee,

We have completed the review process of the above referenced paper for the IEEE IEEE Internet of Things Journal and recommend that your paper undergo a Major Revision.

Your reviews are enclosed. We would suggest that you revise your paper according to the reviewers' comments and resubmit the paper for a second round of reviews.

We hope you will be able to implement the comments of the reviewers.

** EFFECTIVE IMMEDIATELY ** All revised papers must have the changes highlighted or underlined so they are easy to see.  Make sure that the highlighting or underlining will be visible when the file is printed.  This will help to speed up the Final Decision process for the editor.

We would like to receive your revision within four (4) weeks, on  11-Apr-2023.  If this is not enough time, please request an extension so that we will know when to expect your revision.  

We expect to hear from you within four weeks regarding your revision plans, either by submission of a revised paper or an e-mail requesting an extension.  If we do not hear from you within 60 days, then we will assume that you are not planning a revision and will withdraw your entry from our database.

If this happens, you can of course resubmit the paper as a new submission and the review process will start all over again. However, we recommend that you revise your current manuscript and return it within the time period specified.  In this case, the revision will go to the same Associate Editor and Reviewers for reevaluation.  If you can satisfy their suggestions, it will enhance your chances for more rapid publication.

Please be sure to upload the revised manuscript in the Submitting Author's account.  That is the account that will have the manuscript number listed, with the extension .R1 if it is a first revision, .R2 if it is a second revision, etc.  Please do not submit your revised manuscript as new.  If you do not see this number listed with the proper extension or if you prefer to upload the revised manuscript in Prof. Lee's account, please send an e-mail to Surbhi Tyagi at surbhi.tyagi@ieee.org and she will assist you.

If you have any questions regarding the reviews, please contact the Associate Editor: Dr. Massimiliano Albanese malbanes@gmu.edu. Any other inquiries should be directed to the Administrative Assistant listed above.

Thank you for considering IEEE Internet of Things Journal for publication of your work.

Sincerely,
Prof. Nei Kato
Editor-in-Chief, IEEE Internet of Things Journal
eic-iot@it.is.tohoku.ac.jp

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
• Associate Editor Comments, if any, are listed below:

Associate Editor: Albanese, Massimiliano
Comments to Author:
The reviewers agree that the work has merit, but identified several aspects that need to be improved before the manuscript can be considered for publication.

• Reviewer Comments, if any, are listed below:

Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
In this manuscript, the authors presented a Drone Transportation System: Systematic Review of
Security Dynamics for Smart Mobility. The overall manuscript is well organized.
• Although the topic is important to the body of literature, but I have some concerns about the ‘scientific contributions’ of this manuscript. Authors are suggested to refine it to highlight the novelty of the work.
• Essentially, the technical discussion in this manuscript and the information is presented without a clear objective/foundation and motivation.  Authors are suggested to add one motivation subsection in the Introduction section.
• A thorough proofreading/restructuring/grammar/sentence formation and spelling checking of this article is essential.
• The article reports generic works and old references without any criticism or a clear message to conclude by the readers and add some latest references as shown below:
(i) Fusion of blockchain and artificial intelligence for secure drone networking underlying 5G communications
(ii) A taxonomy of blockchain-enabled softwarization for secure UAV network
• In my opinion, it is more important to think of the applicability aspect of the technology and the associated enablers.
• Authors are suggested to include a case study as part of this review work.
• Authors are suggested to refine the conclusion section and include future scope of the study.
• The presented scheme is well presented but lack supportive references. In fact, one should expect a reasonable number of references in order to support the claims by literature. The main purpose of the article is to guide the research community and direct their attention to the most urgent/uncovered research areas in the desired field of research.


Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
The major contributions of this paper are a systematic review of security dynamics for smart mobility in the context of the Drone Transportation System. The paper addresses the trustworthiness of data legitimacy, appropriation, and authorization during end-to-end communication between participating nodes in its network. The authors also discuss the challenges and opportunities associated with securing cyber-physical systems in the context of smart mobility. Overall, this paper provides insights into the security concerns that need to be addressed to ensure safe and reliable drone transportation systems for smart mobility.
The key conclusions of this paper are that securing the Drone Transportation System for smart mobility requires addressing several security challenges, including data legitimacy, appropriation, and authorization during end-to-end communication between participating nodes in its network. The authors also conclude that securing cyber-physical systems in the context of smart mobility requires a holistic approach that considers both technical and non-technical factors. Finally, the authors suggest that future research should focus on developing secure and trustworthy communication protocols for drone transportation systems to ensure safe and reliable smart mobility.
In general, the review paper is comprehensive and informative. However, the reviewer has the following question and comments that the authors need to address:
1. The article lacks clarity in defining and analyzing DTS. While the Introduction section defines it as a drone-assisted priority freight delivery system, which is DIFFERENT from single UAV applications and drones for smart cities. There is insufficient discussion and analysis of system-level security in later sections. Specifically, the article fails to address how an attack on a connected UAV or infrastructure in the DTS would impact system security.
2. The Introduction section proposes a triad relation between, cybersecurity, intelligence security, and airspace security. However, the later sections don’t strictly follow this taxonomy. Specifically, the research and policy effort on airspace security is barely touched.
3. The article fails to differentiate between research, technique readiness, and deployment. In Section V, the article discusses the evolutionary AI models across all domains, IAS, and DTS, and asserts that this is an analysis of deployment. However, most of these AI models were only tested and evaluated using collected datasets or in simulation environments. Some were tested in close sites, but only a few were actually deployed in the real world, and even fewer led to policy-level changes.
4. Section III addresses the increase of DTS violations over time, but what about the increase in UAV usage and penetration rates? Is the violation rate also increasing in tandem with these trends?
5. The authors attribute the "bell shape" distribution of the number of sighted drone violations over months to a Poisson distribution and provide equation (1) to support their claim. However, the reviewer is not convinced and requests further explanation of the model and analysis.
6. The color and legend of Fig. 2 needs to be refined. It is barely distinguishable now.
7. Section IV of the article primarily discusses the DTI counter-invasive approaches that focus on cognitive attacks and compares solutions using single sensors versus the fusion of multiple sensors. However, the article does not discuss defense against drone dynamics communication and decision-making attacks, nor does it cover research on anomaly detection, which is commonly discussed for cyber security research.


Note: If any of the reviews include an additional attached file, it will not be attached to this message. To access it, log in your Author Center and click on "Decision (View Letter)" -- this brings up this message, and at the bottom is the attached file. Click on that file name and you can see the attached comments from reviewers.

fields.subject: Vivian Ukamaka Ihekoronye, Simeon Okechukwu Ajakwe, Dong-Seong Kim, Jae Min Lee "Efficient Intrusion Detection Model for Securing the Communication Links of Internet of Drone Network" IEEE Internet of Things (Reject, submit elsewhere)
fields.content:
Paper Title: Efficient Intrusion Detection Model for Securing the Communication Links of Internet of Drone Network


Dear Prof. Lee,

I am writing to you concerning the above-referenced manuscript, which you submitted to the IEEE Internet of Things Journal.

Although it has merit, based on the enclosed set of reviews this manuscript has been rejected for publication in the IEEE Internet of Things Journal.

You may wish to consider the comments of the reviewers and submit it to another journal.

If you have any questions regarding the reviews, please contact the Associate Editor: Dr. Chia-Mu Yu chiamuyu@gmail.com.  Any other inquiries should be directed to the Administrative Assistant: Surbhi Tyagi surbhi.tyagi@ieee.org

Thank you for considering IEEE Internet of Things Journal for publication of your work.


Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
The authors optimize the random forest algorithm by leveraging the randomized search cross-validation technique. The aim is the development of optimal hyperparameter selections for modeling a robust model.

The topic is interesting, but I would suggest the following comments for improvements:

- Please improve and organize the review of related works, analyzing additional papers published in 
  2021 and 2022.
- In result analysis, the author must explain the results in detail, with observations and general 
  reasons. It is beneficial that the author includes the scientific basis for each finding.
- What is the outcome's substantial impact on the research field?
- Please, explain how the proposed solution and the results can prove that the research problem has 
  been solved.
- It is helpful that the author presents a real frank account of the proposed research method's 
  strengths and weaknesses.
- In my opinion, the conclusion section seems to rush to the end. The Conclusion is really much too 
  short, and the author will have to describe the research's impact and insights. The author needs to 
  rewrite the entire Conclusion section focusing on the implications and discernment of the 
  manuscript.

Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
The internet of drones (IoD) network is growing in demand for civil and military applications, but it is vulnerable to cyber threats on the network layer. Thus, a robust security framework is needed to integrate the IoD network into the airspace and safeguard it from lethal attacks. Anomaly-based intrusion detection systems (IDS) are used to secure the communication links of the IoD network from invaders. This paper proposed to build such an IDS system based on the random forest algorithm using the randomized search cross-validation technique for optimal hyperparameter selection. The proposed model was trained and evaluated on three standard intrusion detection datasets. Evaluation results validated its superiority over other models and state-of-the-art models in its precision and swiftness in detecting attacks with minimal false alarm rate.

On the positive side, this paper is well-written and easy to follow. This paper clearly motivates the problems in IoD network IDS in the introduction and related work sections. The system design section presents the RF model and shows the challenges and solutions for optimizing model parameters. The evaluation section systematically evaluated the model and baselines to show the effectiveness of the proposed system.

Although this paper has many strengths, there is still much space to improve this paper.

First, this paper lacks novelty. While the RF model is a well-known traditional ML algorithm, I was expecting some domain-specific challenges and insights in applying such a model to IoD network intrusion detection. Moreover, the parameter search problem is also a well-known problem. The proposed solution is generic to any model and dataset. Based on my knowledge, there are well-packaged implementations of both the RF model and RSCV algorithm in sciki-learn [1][2]. Applying existing models and algorithms to existing problems or datasets doesn’t means a lack of novelty, but the paper doesn’t present any domain-specific challenges in applying them to the problem of this paper.

Second, the datasets are not specific to IoD network. While the focused problem of this paper is IoD intrusion detection, the evaluation dataset should be specific to IoD network. However, the three datasets used in this paper don’t satisfy these requirements. For example, the CIC-IDS2017 dataset is collected on network topologies including Modem, Firewall, Switches, Routers, and the presence of a variety of operating systems such as Windows, Ubuntu and Mac OS X. It’s hard to convince readers that IoD devices will use the Windows OS. Therefore, it’s reasonable to believe that all the evaluation results and conclusions drawn from these three datasets won’t apply to IoD network intrusion detection. Moreover, even with these open datasets, the well-trained models should be evaluated in real-world or simulated IoD networks, which can reveal the distribution shift between open datasets and IoD network data.

Third, using the RF model isn’t a best choice while jointly considering both effectiveness and efficiency. As stated at the end of section II, a good IDS system should have a good tradeoff between effectiveness and efficiency. However, the evaluation results shown in section IV seem to show that the DT model is a better choice than the RF model considering both effectiveness and efficiency. For example, TABLE VII presents very close accuracies of DT and RF-RSCV models (e.g., 99.55% and 99.64%). However, the  RF-RSCV model is 45 times slower than the DT model for prediction. Similar observations can be obtained from the results of the other two datasets. Therefore, I would doubt the decision of model selection of this paper.

## Reference
[1] “sklearn.ensemble.RandomForestClassifier”, https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.ensemble.RandomForestClassifier.html, accessed on March 7th 2023.
[2] “sklearn.model_selection.RandomizedSearchCV”, https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.model_selection.RandomizedSearchCV.html, accessed on March 7th 2023.

Reviewer: 3

Comments to the Author
The research theme is current and the problem is relevant. The article proposes an RF model optimized by the randomized search cross-validation (RSCV) technique to adjust the hyperparameters. Furthermore, the Pearson correlation coefficient (PCC) technique was used to reduce the dimensionality of the features. Providing a security framework to counter attacks launched against the Internet of Drones command and data communication links.



-- Here are some comments that can help improve the quality of work:
-- The work is inserted in a theme that has a lot of prominence and is on the rise.
-- The work has good organization.
-- The innovation presented in the article is light. It would be good to make it clearer in the 
   abstract and introduction how the work advances in relation to the state of the art.
-- Most of the figures in the paper have some very small texts, which makes it impossible to read. 
   Image quality is poor.
-- The work presents a good evaluation section, experiments were carried out with 3 datasets, where 
   the proposed approach was compared with classic Machine Learning methods and state-of-the-art 
   works.
-- The layout of the Tables must be improved, they are not standardized.
   The paper is big. Sections 1 and 2 can be shortened to just the main points.

The many-to-one concepts are added to the deep concatenation based MLP (DC-MLP) algorithm to achieve fast computing time and total energy efficiency. My concerns of the paper are listed below:

Authors: Prof. Dong-Seong Kim, Nwankwo, Odinachi; Shin, Hee Jae; Ansori, Mohammad Rasyid; Kim, Young Won; Lee, Jae-Hyun; Kim, Dong-Seong; Lee, Jae-Min
Editor: Dr. Kim-Kwang Raymond Choo

Dear Prof. Kim,

I am writing to you concerning the above referenced manuscript which you submitted to the IEEE Internet of Things Journal.

Based on the enclosed set of reviews, this manuscript has been rejected for publication. Resubmission of this manuscript is not allowed in IEEE Internet of Things Journal. This extends to any revisions based on this manuscript. Such submissions will be rejected without review.

If you have any questions regarding the reviews, please contact the Associate Editor: Dr. Kim-Kwang Raymond Choo raymond.choo@fulbrightmail.org, raymond.choo@utsa.edu.  Any other inquiries should be directed to the Administrative Assistant: Surbhi Tyagi surbhi.tyagi@ieee.org

Thank you for considering IEEE Internet of Things Journal for publication of your work.

Sincerely,
Prof. Nei Kato
Editor-in-Chief, IEEE Internet of Things Journal
eic-iot@it.is.tohoku.ac.jp

• Associate Editor Comments, if any, are listed below:

Associate Editor: Choo, Kim-Kwang Raymond
Comments to Author:
While I don't like to proceed based only on one reviews, attempts to recruit reviewers for this manuscript has been challenging (with only one subject matter expert accepting the invitation out of 20 sent invitations). My independent assessment of the manuscript echoes the reviewer's concerns, particularly relating to security concepts and technical contributions. The manuscript also needs significant proofreading.

• Reviewer Comments, if any, are listed below:

Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
This paper describes the implementation of a system for protecting blockchain private keys using a fingerprint sensor in conjunction with a mobile phone. The private key is released to the phone when a correct biometric, in this case a fingerprint, is applied to the sensor which is connected to and controlled by an Arduino Nano 33 IoT node device. The private key is the secret part of the public/private key combination used to uniquely identify the user for activities on the associated blockchain.

Since the blockchain may be associated with a crypto currency, the need to protect the private key is of paramount importance. To this end various mildly crazy proposals have been made in the past, and this history is outlined here to contextualize the use-case for the device described here.

Significant typos often make it difficult to follow the text. For example “Cryptosteel is another option to store them and can hold up to extended characters”. How many characters? “The last step is while distributing key shares RSA creates an end-to-end.. ”. RSA is not defined before this mention. A major problem are the multiple references to 4-bit and 8-bit passwords, where what is intended (I assume and hope) is 4 decimal digit and 8 decimal digit passwords.

Unfortunately the device itself appears to be hopelessly insecure. Indeed the authors do not seem to have a grasp of security basics. The fact that the private key is actually displayed on the mobile phone screen, is really quite staggering. There is no reason to display it for prying eyes to see. The private key displayed in figure 7 is a puzzling 172-bits in length. I am unaware of any standard public key algorithm which has a private key of that length.

As to the device itself it is stated that the “private key is encrypted and stored in the EEPROM of the Arduino Nano 33 IoT”. Now a glance at the Nano datasheet indicates that in fact this device has no EEPROM. As to the encryption, what key is used? If its an 8-decimal digit password, then even that is hopelessly insecure. Now the Nano device does have a dedicated ECCX08 crypto chip which actually does support public key cryptography, AES encryption and secure memory. But inexplicably it is not mentioned here, and so we must assume that it is not used.

So from the description all an attacker needs to do is steal the device, break off the fingerprint sensor and read out the contents of the memory. The “encrypted” private key can be extracted and decrypted by trying all possible passwords until the discovered private key matches the public key.

In the diagrams there is mentioned a “2nd input password” and a “3rd input password”. But these are not explained. The software is unfortunately not made available for scrutiny.


Some typos

“perivate” → “private”
“there is non” → “there is none”

To access it, log in your Author Center and click on "Decision (View Letter)" -- this brings up this message, and at the bottom is the attached file. Click on that file name and you can see the attached comments from reviewers.
