fields.content:
Subject:	IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics - Decision on Manuscript ID TII-23-0127
Body:	12-May-2023

Dear Authors (CC to Associate Editor, Reviewers),

Manuscript ID TII-23-0127 entitled "Trees Bootstrap Aggregation for Detection and Characterization of IoT-SCADA Network Traffic" which you submitted to the IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics, has been reviewed.  The comments  are included at the bottom of this letter.

Much to my regret, I have to inform you that, based on the recommendation of the Associate  Editor in charge of this manuscript, the submitted manuscript has not been accepted for publication in the   Transaction on Industrial Informatics. However, a new manuscript may be submitted  which takes into consideration these comments.

Please note that resubmitting your manuscript does not guarantee eventual acceptance, and that your resubmission will be subject to re-review by the reviewer(s) before a decision is rendered.

You will be unable to make your revisions on the originally submitted version of your manuscript.  Instead, revise your manuscript using a word processing program and save it on your computer.

Once you have revised your manuscript, go to https://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/tii and login to your Author Center.  Click on "Manuscripts with Decisions," and then click on "Create a Resubmission" located next to the manuscript number.  Then, follow the steps for resubmitting your manuscript.

Please note that if your revised manuscript exceeds the page limit of TII (8 pages for regular and "Special Section" papers), extra page charge for the publication cost will be billed to you by IEEE Publication, 250 USD/page. In any case, the manuscript length cannot exceed 12 pages.

Throughout the review process with each intermediate review result stage, it is important for authors to follow 2018 IEEE PSPB Operations Manual mandate on Section 8.2.1 Publication Principles, including Section 8.2.1 Subsection 3 and 8. Once the list and order of authors has been established, the list and order of authors should not be altered without permission of all living authors and Co-authors have the right to withdraw their names from an article at any time before acceptance of the article by the editor. However, an author’s or co-author’s name should not be removed from an article without his or her permission. The responsible editor shall be notified of any change in authorship.

Because we are trying to facilitate timely publication of manuscripts submitted to the IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics, your revised manuscript should be uploaded within two months.  If it is not possible for you to submit your revision within TWO months, we will consider your paper as a new submission.

I look forward to a resubmission.

Sincerely,
Prof. Gerhard Hancke
Editor-in-Chief, Transactions on Industrial Informatics
g.hancke@ieee.org


****************************************************
Encl.:
Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
Thank you for taking the time to write this article
Trees Bootstrap Aggregation for Detection and Characterization of IoT-SCADA Network Traffic.
The reviewer would like you to take a look at these comments.
Page #1
pg1 col 2 ln 2. This is better to put (LAN) in a bracket instead...
pg1 col 2 ln 54. FAR, should be fully written.

Page #2
pg2 col 2 ln 38. IDS should be fully written.

pg3 col 1 ln 28. FAR is here defined...
pg3 col 1 ln 28. FAR is here defined...
pg3 col 2 ln 24. "This work created..., can the authors clarify this?

Page # 5
pg5 col 1 ln 36. False alarm rate, please define it first and just use FAR. Same for similar

Page # 6
pg6 col 1 ln 12.  bootstrapping aggregation (TBA), I suggest taking out (TBA)
pg6 col 1 ln 56. Table ??... missing table number?
pg6 col 2 ln 52,  Cross-validation... why capital C?



Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
1. Confusing and irregular citations throughout the paper, you should adjust the structural paper's order and reduce the number of citations in a single paper. Writing in an irregular format and indiscriminate use of punctuation. For example, the second paragraph of section IV C. has two question marks.

2. The abbreviations in the paper are confusing, some use acronyms such as LAN (Local Area Network), some do not, e.g., wide area network (WAN), the relationship between the acronym and the original term can not be understood, e.g., misclassification error (MCE), RUSBoost ( RUS-DT), AdaBoost (AD-DT), or the first appearance of the acronym without any explanation and reference, such as ISCX VPN-nonVPN, ISCX TOR-nonTOR, FAR, IDS, ENT. where TOR should be written as Tor.

3. In section II B. third paragraph, authors and dates do not have to be written out after the first reference and use the bracketed number.

4. In section II B, traffic detection and characterization work related to IoT-SCADA is summarized in about 10 articles, there are few references and people can not systematically understand the real level of development and potential research opportunities.

5. In section III A. 2) data reconstruction paragraph, you wrote "following data merging is the reconstruction of the raw network samples...". In Fig 1, the proposed benchmark dataset preprocessing shows that after the data merge is data reformation and the next step is data cleaning. what is the relationship between data reconstruction and reformation or cleaning?

6. In Fig 1, we learn that you sniff and save pcap files from the proposed layered framework layer 5 IEC-60870-5-104. How do you realize this function? In section III A. 1) data merge, you specify created two scenarios datasets from public benchmark datasets, what is the relationship between the benchmark datasets and your proposed layered framework? And is the audio, browsing, chat, email, video, or VoIP network application running based on SCADA IEC-60870-5-104 communication protocol? The analysis of IOT-SCADA network communication traffic is absent.

7. Why Table II and Table III contents are highly repetitive? Table III indicates it describes network traffic characterization, but has no correlation to its contents.

8. Why are the values in the confusion matrix shown in Figure 5 and Figure 6 different under the condition of using the same TBA algorithm?

9. Please explain why P2P class PPV only got 40.5% in Fig 10.

10. In the title and abstract of the paper, you indicate that the goal of this paper is to implement anomaly detection in the IEC-60870-5-104 communication protocol based IOT-SCADA network, but there is no analysis related to traffic detection performance in this paper, and it is more focused on the classification of network traffic types, which is not in line with the central thrust of the paper.

Reviewer: 3

Comments to the Author
The authors propose a TBA-based approach for the representation and detection of communication traffic in IoT-SCADA networks based on the IEC-608705-104 protocol. Several public datasets were used to benchmark the proposed TBA-based method. However, due to the following questions, I cannot recommend the acceptance of this paper in the journal. I suggest that the authors address these questions before resubmitting for consideration.
1. The authors propose a method for detecting the industrial IoT protocol IEC-60870-5-104, but the two public datasets used in the experiments, ISCN VPN-nonVPN and ISCX TOR-nonTOR, do not seem to have been captured in an IIoT scenario.
2. The authors use the existing traffic processing tool CICFlowmeter for the feature extraction of the traffic's temporal and spatial representations. Additionally, the ensemble learning part of the proposed TBA algorithm only seems to adopt the existing bagging technique. Thus, I think that the novelty of this paper is insufficient.
3. In the standardization of data processing,  λmax and λmin are required to standardize the features to [0,1]. Does this feature processing method have any data leakage problems?
4. The table on page 6, line 56 is unclear. It displays "Table ??."
5. The authors use ensemble learning in this paper. How are different weights allocated to each model in equation (2)? Can another set of experiments be added to compare and analyze the weight parameters?
6. The paper has selected few state-of-the-art approaches for comparison, and it does not seem to have demonstrated significant advantages. Therefore, I think that the experimental results cannot prove the practical performance of the proposed method.



Reviewer: 4

Comments to the Author
The authors propose a monitoring technique for detecting and characterizing the IEC-60870-5-104 IoT-SCADA network communication protocol using an anomaly detector that employs the Trees Bootstrap Aggregation (TBA) algorithm. However, the paper is lacking in some important aspects.

The research objective is not well-defined and requires further clarification on the authors' aims and the importance of their research to SCADA-based critical infrastructure.

In the abstract, the authors claim early detection using TBA, but the result discussion section does not provide significant evidence of early detection.

The proposed methodology includes several modules such as dataset composition, optimization, and classification. However, the authors should explain how they merged two datasets and the implications of using two different sets of datasets.

While hybrid IDS is generally more effective, the authors' selection of datasets may not be adequate for SCADA/IoT-based systems, which rely on network and application-related parameters. In this research, the authors have only focused on network-based parameters. Please justify your approach.

Furthermore, the reference to the datasets is not appropriate. The authors should provide a link where readers can download the existing datasets or, if they have generated their own dataset, provide it via a GitHub link. There is also no significant discussion on the features of the datasets used in this research.

The authors illustrated in Figure 1 that datasets are originally generated in the form of pcap files, but they did not describe the module that converts pcap files to CSV files while using ML modeling.

It is suggested that the authors provide more details on the novelty/research elements and discussion on features of datasets.

AE Comments:
Associate Editor
Comments to the Author:
According to the reviewers' comments the paper fails in fulfilling its main claim, since that analyzed data sets are not fully applicable and there is no line of argumentation substantiating on the contrary.
On the other hand the use of public data sets and the providing of performance benchmarks can be seen as an asset, hence, if the authos choose to carefully rework, they are offered the possibilkity of a resubmission. In this case, please also consider the formal aspects mentioned.

fields.subject: P. T. Daely, J. M. Lee and D.-S. Kim, "Wireless Node Localization Based on Wild Goats Algorithm for Industrial Internet of Things", KICS Journal, 2023 (Minor Revision))
fields.content:
Editor_R18331	
Thank you for your effort.
Please revise it by reflecting the review opinions of the three attached judges.

 Reviewer_R18382	
1. In this paper, the speed and error of the wireless sensor node location optimization algorithm were compared, and the advantages of the proposed WGA were explained.
2. When applying the proposed WGA, the computing time should be improved compared to other algorithms, but it is judged not to be a big problem at the current level.

 Reviewer_R18383	
The content of the paper you proposed is "Wireless Node Localization Based on Wild Goats Algorithm for Industrial Internet of Things".

I would like to point out two things about this paper:
1. In this paper, the parameters of scenarios 1 and 2 (Table 2 and Table 3) were defined in the performance analysis of the proposed algorithm, but there is no parameter definition for the LOS/NLOS wireless environment. In order to analyze the performance of a more practical algorithm, it is necessary to define the parameters for this.
2. In the title, it was expressed as "... Algorithm", but in the case of Chapter 3, it was expressed as "Proposed Localization Scheme". Please unify the terms.

 Reviewer_R18454	
In this paper, the authors presented a method for localizing nodes in an industrial IoT network.
(The proposed method is based on so-called wild goats algorithm which was already released in 2019.) Then, the authors evaluated the proposed method by using a simulation method.
Localization in IoT networks is an issue of interest.
For the publication of this paper, however, it is recommended to revise the paper with reference to the comments below.
- Wild goats algorithm is a core of the proposed method.
However, the algorithm is never stated in the introduction.
The algorithm should be addressed in detail in the introduction.
- In the 2nd scenario presumed for the simulation, no explanation is made on the locations of nodes.
In each simulation, it is highly recommended to determine such locations independently and randomly as well.
- In scenarios 1 and 2, communication ranges are set to 100 meter and 25 meters, respectively.
However, the standard deviations of distance measurement are commonly set to 1 meter.
It is needed to justify how such settings are possible in practice.
- There are some typos, which should be corrected.
- In the introduction, a full description of industrial IoT should be made.

First Review's concerns
- In Figures 5 to 10, letters is too small. In particular, Figures 5 to 8 describe the structures and algorithms of the proposed system, but letters cannot be recognized.

- The explanation and analysis of the simulation results are insufficient. Rather than simply describing the results of Figures 14 to 19, it is better to insert explanation as to why these results occurred.

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

The paper propose a hybrid smart demand-responsive public transport system has been proposed for integration into a conventional public-transport systems in city metropolitan areas.
The authors should include the references why the following factors have been examined.
• Passenger booking frequency at stops.
• Punctuality of passengers at stops.
• Driver patience in waiting for late passengers at stops.
• Traffic variability (Congestion).

What could be the novelty of the proposed system since the concept of the ITS have been already published in the case that the smart DRT system is not a novel idea?
In order to become a qualified paper in a certain area of research, are there any conventional approaches that could be compared with the proposed hybrid smart DRT system?
If not, common characteristics from the references should be summarized and compared for the reader to get the confidence on this proposed system.

The paper propose a hybrid smart demand-responsive public transport system has been proposed for integration into a conventional public-transport systems in city metropolitan areas.
The authors should include the references why the following factors have been examined.
• Passenger booking frequency at stops.
• Punctuality of passengers at stops.
• Driver patience in waiting for late passengers at stops.
• Traffic variability (Congestion).

What could be the novelty of the proposed system since the concept of the ITS have been already published in the case that the smart DRT system is not a novel idea?
In order to become a qualified paper in a certain area of research, are there any conventional approaches that could be compared with the proposed hybrid smart DRT system?
If not, common characteristics from the references should be summarized and compared for the reader to get the confidence on this proposed system.

fields.content:
From:	kf.tce.eic@gmail.com
To:	dskim@kumoh.ac.kr
CC:	kf.tce.eic@gmail.com
Subject:	Transactions on Consumer Electronics - Decision on Manuscript ID TCE-2023-03-0166
Body:	16-May-2023

Dear Prof. Kim:

I write you in regards to manuscript # TCE-2023-03-0166 entitled "Blockchain Private Key Storage System using Nano IoT" which you submitted to the Transactions on Consumer Electronics.

The criticisms of the reviewer(s) can be found at the bottom of this letter. With the inception of new EiC since January 2022, TCE is looking for innovative idea with inspiring theory development/model with insightful theoretical analysis, kindly revise along the captioned directions. As such, your manuscript may not fulfill the standards as captioned. As a result of the incompliance, your manuscript has been denied publication in the Transactions on Consumer Electronics.

Thank you for considering the Transactions on Consumer Electronics for the publication of your research.  I hope the outcome of this specific submission will not discourage you from the submission of future manuscripts.

Sincerely,
Dr. Kim Fung Tsang
Editor-in-Chief, Transactions on Consumer Electronics
kf.tce.eic@gmail.com

Editor(s)' Comments to Author:

Associate Editor
Comments to the Author:
This paper requires a lot of work to make it as a transaction worthy paper.  State-of-the-art needs a lot of work.  Authors should do conduct more research to understand the state-of-the-art and present their work relative to the state-of-the-art.  They will have to clearly bring out their contributions after assessing the need for such contributions.  Authors should improve their references and bring the state-of-the-art into the paper.  Authors should compare their contributions with the state-of-the-art and present the drawbacks and advantages in their work.  They need to develop a good structure for representing their work and at all times asking the following questions:  Why should this work be published, what aspects of existing knowledge does it improve, does it provide new knowledge and how is this  new knowledge going to improve the area of research in consumer technology?  Further, authors should also enquire if their approach is thorough.  Once authors' pear down their work in this fashion, they would be able to see gaps in their current presentation and improve the work.

Reviewer(s)' Comments to Author:

Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
Thank you for submitting your paper to IEEE Trans Consumer Electronics. Lets go down the paper:

1) The title makes no sense, what is "nano"? What is the novel step the authors are proposing?

2) The abstract says nothing about consumer electronics and what relevance the work has to consumer electronics.

3) Commercial - Arduino, Intel, Figure 1, SEN0348,  Android, and many of the figures, The instructions clearly states to avoid all commercialism. It makes no sense as mass market CE systems would not use such systems.

4) The large character at the start of the Introduction is missing.

5) Looking at the novel contributions:
1) " Proposes a key storage system by implementing an IoT device, Arduino Nano, as hardware storage" - mass market CE systems would not do that. It would have been better for the authors to be more hardware agnostic.
2) "The proposed system can assure the security of the private key, even though the device is missing, as the only way to retrieve the key is using the owner’s fingerprint" - but that is the point, and is not novel as many systems already require fingerprint access to retrieve.
3) "A private key can be linked to multiple fingerprints, making it possible to the user’s legacy to inherit the key from the previous owner" - is already known.

4) Poor citation style, "As mentioned in [3], there "

5) Poor citation style, ". Paper [4] presented a"

6) Poor citation style, "Research in [2] proposed"

7) Poor citation style, "Article [5] has proposed"

8) Poor citation style, "A study in [1] proposed"

etc. Please cite correctly.

After reading the paper, the authors have constructed an Arduino key storage device. Such devices are already on the market and the presented work is fundamentally not new.

It is rather strange, and perhaps describes the reason, the authors seem unaware of the current state of cryptography systems in the consumer research field. The authors do not cite or use any of the past research in the consumer field. If they had, they perhaps would have seen that what is presented is just not new or state of the art.

Having just 12 references in an IEEE Transactions paper these days clearly does not cover the state of the art.

Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
The core of the manuscript,  Blockchain Private Key Storage System using Nano IoT is an interesting topic for a broad audience, as it would trigger research from different areas. The paper concept is impressive, and this research work’s novelty is significant. My feedback on this paper is given below:
• The abstract needs to be rewritten to point out significance and impact of the paper.
• More illustrations can be included in the revised manuscript, mainly to show more results and betterment of the presented approach.
• Add more discussion on blockchain and authentication for that include quality research paper in the revised version. Author can read the following papers to get the details on blockchain and authentication process:
        10.1109/JAS.2021.1004003
        10.1016/j.jpdc.2021.03.011
         10.23919/SpliTech.2019.8783092
         10.3390/su142315659
• In Figure 3, the authors need to explain each and every component clearly.
• Avoid presenting with lengthy paragraph.
• Some more clarification regarding the motivation and challenges of the proposed approach, and how the prescribed scheme would overcome them must be added in the revised version.
• More recent references should be used or cited for better projection of the research problem and for absolute suitability of the journal's novelty.
• Future Scope and applications of the proposed scheme requires to be emphasized in the revised version.
• Some images are very small with poor quality; because of space, it would be good to zoom to the area the authors want to highlight.
• Please elaborate in detail about the proposed approach, focusing more on the relations between its components, as they are the core of the solution and need more justification for using them.
• The author needs to enrich the description of the system model by adding further details. Furthermore, I would suggest improving the discussion of the proposed methodology, since some parts of the discussion of Algorithm  are not entirely clear.
• Notations and acronyms used in this paper should be summarized in a table to organize this paper in a better way.
• The Author must talk about the computational overhead in the cost and complexity of the proposed work.
• I suggest adding more figures based on the proposed model/flowchart of the proposed model etc. to make strong to your paper.
• Finally, a final proof-reading is highly suggested, in order to correct some typos.

fields.subject: Philip Tobianto Daely, Jae Min Lee, Dong-Seong Kim, "Automatic Task Provisioning and Routing Framework for Carrier Robots in Smart Factory with Edge Computing", IEEE Access
fields.content:
Dear Prof. Kim:

I am writing to you regarding manuscript # Access-2023-09062 entitled "Automatic Task Provisioning and Routing Framework for Carrier Robots in Smart Factory with Edge Computing" which you submitted to IEEE Access.

Please note that IEEE Access has a binary peer review process. Therefore, to uphold quality to IEEE standards, an article is rejected even if it requires minor edits.
 
Your manuscript has not been recommended for publication in IEEE Access in its current form; however, we encourage you to address the reviewers’ concerns, which can be found at the bottom of this letter, and resubmit your article once you have updated it accordingly.
 
When updating your manuscript, you should elaborate on your points and clarify with references, examples, data, etc. If you disagree with any technical points the reviewers have made, please include your counterarguments in your response to the reviewers (more information detailed below) and work this into the updated manuscript. Also, note that if a reviewer suggested references, you should only add those that are relevant to your work if you feel they strengthen your article. Recommending references to specific publications is not appropriate for reviewers and you should report excessive cases to ieeeaccessEIC@ieee.org.
 
Please be advised that authors are only permitted to resubmit their article ONCE. If the updated manuscript is determined not to have addressed all of the previous reviewers’ concerns, or if the Associate Editor has substantial technical concerns, the article may be rejected and no further resubmissions will be allowed.

When resubmitting, please submit as a new manuscript via our submission site, the IEEE Author Portal, and include the following 3 files:

1) A document containing your response to reviewers from the previous peer review.  The “response to reviewers” document (template attached) should have the following regarding each comment: a) Reviewer’s concern, b) your response to the concern, c) your action to remedy the concern. The document should be uploaded with your manuscript files under "Author's Response Files.”

2) Your updated manuscript with all your individual changes highlighted, including grammatical changes (e.g. preferably with the yellow highlight tool within the pdf file). This file should be uploaded with your manuscript files under "Author's Response Files.”

3) A clean copy of the final manuscript (without highlighted changes) submitted as a Word or LaTeX file, and as a PDF, both submitted as the “Main Manuscript.”

**IMPORTANT: Please see the attached Resubmission Checklist that details all the items listed above.  Please utilize this checklist to ensure you have made the necessary edits to your manuscript, and to ensure you have all the necessary files prepared prior to resubmission.

*** AUTHOR LIST CHANGES: If your revised manuscript has an updated author list, you will need to submit a formal request to the Editor by completing the attachment labelled ‘Request for Byline Change,’ and uploading it as an additional Supplementary file. This should include a DETAILED justification explaining each author’s contribution(s) to the work. Change in the author list is considered rare and exceptional, and the decision to allow such changes rests with the Editor. Once the list and order of authors has been established, the list and order of authors should not be altered without permission of all living authors of that article.

We sincerely hope you will update your manuscript and resubmit soon. Please contact me if you have any questions.

Thank you for your interest in IEEE Access.

Sincerely,

Dr. Diego Oliva
Associate Editor, IEEE Access
diego.oliva@ieee.org

Reviewers' Comments to Author:

Reviewer: 1

Recommendation: Reject (updates required before resubmission)

Comments:
The authors investigated the problem of Pickup and Delivery (P&D) for carrier robots, and proposed a smart factory framework, which facilitates automatic provisioning of P&D tasks to multiple carrier robots and data gathering at the main server. In order to solve the problem, a discrete bio-inspired algorithm is proposed. Regarding the technical details of this manuscript, several major concerns are raised and listed as follows:
In real-world scenarios, carrier robots require energy consumption during the execution of tasks and the battery capacity of each robot may vary in real-world scenarios. Do the authors need to consider the energy consumption constraint to prevent the robots from stopping prematurely due to low battery levels.
In section IV, the authors proposed the task insertion algorithm which is designed based on DPSO algorithm as the main part, however the definition of F_(g,e) is not clear.
In section V, the proposed method is compared with some special cases of the proposed method. In this case, it is straightforward that the proposed method outperforms those methods. In other words, authors may further compare their method with some other methods to show the significance of their method.
Some latest studies about edge computing and task provisioning are missed in the related work, the authors need to add them and analyze the difference, e.g., Joint Optimization of Computing Offloading and Service Caching in Edge Computing-based Smart Grid, IEEE Transactions on Cloud Computing; Reverse Auction-based Computation Offloading and Resource Allocation in Mobile Cloud-Edge Computing, IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing; UAV-aided Computation Offloading in Mobile Edge Computing Networks: A Stackelberg Game Approach, IEEE Internet of Things Journal.

Additional Questions:
1) Does the paper contribute to the body of knowledge?: yes

2) Is the paper technically sound?: yes

3) Is the subject matter presented in a comprehensive manner?: yes

4) Are the references provided applicable and sufficient?: yes

5) Are there references that are not appropriate for the topic being discussed?: Yes

5a) If yes, then please indicate which references should be removed.:


Reviewer: 2

Recommendation: Accept (minor edits)

Comments:
This manuscript introduces a pickup and delivery task provisioning and vehicle routing framework for carrier robots in a factory with edge servers assisting as the intermediary
between robots and working stations, where the task requests come. The carrier robots must pick up and deliver each assigned load from and to designated locations with minimal traveled distance and without violating designated constraints. Edge servers are utilized to facilitate communication between the main server and delivery robots and assist the main server in deciding the best robot for each incoming task request and the updated route to facilitate the execution of tasks by each carrier robot.
Overall the manuscript is well-written and well-organized, and most importantly it is technically sound.
I have just a few minor comments:
-elaborate on how the parameters in Table 1 were chosen
-the text size is very small in Figure 5-10, which makes it difficult to read.
- some related works are missing:
[1] Cai, Xiaofeng, et al. "Robot and its living space: A roadmap for robot development based on the view of living space." Digital Communications and Networks (2020).
[2] Contini, Antonello, and Alessandro Farinelli. "Coordination approaches for multi-item pickup and delivery in logistic scenarios." Robotics and Autonomous Systems 146 (2021): 103871.
[3] Wang, Wenxi, et al. "A Survey of Hybrid Human-Artificial Intelligence for Social Computing." IEEE Transactions on Human-Machine Systems 52.3 (2021): 468-480.

fields.content:
Dear Prof. Kim,

I am writing to you concerning the above-referenced manuscript, which you submitted to the IEEE Internet of Things Journal.

Although it has merit, based on the enclosed set of reviews this manuscript has been rejected for publication in the IEEE Internet of Things Journal.

You may wish to consider the comments of the reviewers and submit it to another journal.

If you have any questions regarding the reviews, please contact the Associate Editor: Dr. Zhipeng Cai zcai@gsu.edu, zhipeng.cai@gmail.com.  Any other inquiries should be directed to the Administrative Assistant: Surbhi Tyagi surbhi.tyagi@ieee.org

Thank you for considering IEEE Internet of Things Journal for publication of your work.

Sincerely,
Prof. Nei Kato
Editor-in-Chief, IEEE Internet of Things Journal
eic-iot@it.is.tohoku.ac.jp

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
• Associate Editor Comments, if any, are listed below:

Associate Editor: Cai, Zhipeng
Comments to Author:
The paper suffers from the following issues, including lack of comparative analysis,  lack of real-world implementation consideration, insufficient evaluation metrics

• Reviewer Comments, if any, are listed below:

Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
Contributions of the Paper:

1. Proposed a deep learning-based aberrant intrusion detection framework specifically designed for the Internet of VR Things (IoVR) environment.
2. Introduced a novel approach to detect and classify network attacks in the IoVR system, addressing the unique security challenges in the context of virtual reality.
3. Utilized deep learning techniques, specifically convolutional neural networks (CNNs) and recurrent neural networks (RNNs), to learn and classify anomalous traffic patterns in real-time.
4. Evaluated the proposed framework using a comprehensive dataset and demonstrated its effectiveness in accurately identifying network attacks while minimizing false positives.
5. Provided insights into the performance metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score, showcasing the model's robustness and potential for real-world deployment in securing the IoVR ecosystem.
Logical Comments:

• Lack of Comparative Analysis: The paper lacks a thorough comparison with existing intrusion detection frameworks in the context of the IoVR environment. A comparative study could provide valuable insights into the strengths and weaknesses of the proposed framework compared to other state-of-the-art solutions.
• Limited Evaluation Metrics: While the paper highlights accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score as performance metrics, additional metrics such as false positive rate, false negative rate, and area under the receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curve could provide a more comprehensive evaluation of the proposed framework's effectiveness.
• Insufficient Discussion on Dataset Selection: The paper does not provide detailed justification or analysis regarding the selection of the dataset used for evaluation. A thorough discussion on the dataset's representativeness, diversity, and relevance to the IoVR environment is necessary to establish the credibility and generalizability of the results.
• Lack of Real-world Implementation Considerations: The paper lacks a discussion on the practical implementation aspects of the proposed framework in real-world IoVR scenarios. Factors such as resource constraints, scalability, deployment challenges, and integration with existing IoVR systems should be addressed to assess the feasibility and applicability of the framework.
• Inadequate Comparison of Deep Learning Models: The paper briefly mentions the utilization of both CNNs and RNNs in the proposed framework, but there is limited analysis on the advantages and limitations of each model in the context of IoVR intrusion detection. A more detailed comparison and justification for the selection of these specific deep learning architectures would strengthen the paper's contribution.
• Limited Insights into Training and Optimization Techniques: The paper lacks comprehensive details on the training procedures, hyperparameter optimization, and convergence criteria employed for the deep learning models. Providing insights into these aspects would enable better reproducibility and understanding of the proposed framework.
• Lack of Discussion on False Positive and False Negative Analysis: The paper does not sufficiently address the impact of false positives and false negatives on the proposed framework's performance. These errors play a crucial role in real-world deployment and should be thoroughly discussed, along with potential mitigation strategies.
• Limited Future Work Discussion: Although the paper briefly mentions future work, it lacks a concrete plan for addressing the identified limitations and potential directions for further research in the field of aberrant intrusion detection in the IoVR domain.


Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
1. The paper begins by mentioning that the hidden layer was artificially assigned 10 neurons after trying out different numbers of neurons. It would be helpful to provide more insight into the process of selecting the number of neurons and why 10 was chosen.

2. The trade-off between accuracy and computational efficiency is mentioned when increasing the number of layers. It would be beneficial to elaborate on the specific trade-offs observed in this research and provide quantitative data on the impact of increasing layers on accuracy and computational time.

3. The concept of "layer pruning" is introduced as a way to improve computational efficiency. It would be useful to explain the criteria used for removing two layers from the model and how this decision was made. Additionally, more details on the resulting accuracy after layer pruning would provide a clearer understanding of the model's performance.

4. The description of the model's architecture and the use of rectified linear unit (ReLU) activation function and softmax activation function is clear and informative. However, it would be beneficial to provide more details on why these specific activation functions were chosen and their impact on the model's performance.

5. The mathematical expression (equation 1) representing the artificial neural network logic is provided. It would be helpful to explain the significance of each component of the equation and how it relates to the model's decision-making process.[since DNN used in this work it would be better to  providing related equation will be good, instead of just ANN]

6. The paper introduces the IoVR architecture and the importance of security measures in IoVR applications. It would be useful to provide more details on how the proposed model contributes to enhancing security in the IoVR architecture and how it addresses specific security challenges.

7. The defense framework presented in the paper is briefly described. It would be beneficial to provide more details on how the framework operates, what types of attacks it can detect, and how it ensures the security of user data.

8. The paper mentions the use of AI-driven security systems and deep learning (DL) methods. It would be helpful to provide more information on how DL methods, specifically the proposed AI/DL-based framework, outperform traditional machine learning methods in detecting aberrations in the IoVR network architecture.

9. The use of the CIC-IDS2017 dataset for training the model is mentioned. It would be beneficial to explain why this dataset was chosen, its relevance to IoVR security, and any limitations or challenges encountered while using this dataset.
---

Other comments
Provide more detailed explanations and justifications for the choices made in the research, such as the selection of the number of neurons in the hidden layer and the activation functions used.

Include more quantitative data and analysis to support the claims made in the paper, particularly regarding the trade-off between accuracy and computational efficiency, the impact of layer pruning, and the performance of the proposed model.

Expand on the description of the proposed defense framework, providing more details on its operation, detection capabilities, and how it integrates with the IoVR architecture.

Clarify the contributions of the proposed AI/DL-based framework compared to other existing methods, highlighting specific advantages and improvements.

Discuss the limitations and potential challenges of the research, addressing issues such as dataset limitations, scalability, and potential real-world implementation challenges.

Include visuals, such as figures and diagrams, to enhance the understanding of the proposed model, the IoVR architecture, and the performance evaluation results.

Consider providing insights into future research directions, potential extensions to the proposed framework, and areas where further improvements can be made.

Proofread the paper for grammar, clarity, and coherence to ensure the ideas are effectively communicated to'


Provide a more detailed explanation of the feature selection and dimensionality reduction process. Elaborate on the criteria used to select the prominent features and how they contribute to improving the model's performance. Additionally, discuss any challenges or considerations encountered during the feature selection process.

Include a more comprehensive analysis of the dataset, such as visualisations or statistical insights, to better understand the underlying patterns and structures. This analysis can help in justifying the choices made in the model architecture and provide additional insights into the dataset's characteristics.

Discuss the generalisation capabilities of the proposed model. How well does it perform on unseen data or data from different sources? Address the potential limitations and challenges related to generalisation and suggest approaches to overcome them.

Provide more details on the hyperparameters used in the model training. Explain how the hyperparameters were selected, the rationale behind their choices, and the impact they have on the model's performance. Additionally, consider discussing any experiments conducted to fine-tune the hyperparameters and their results.

Elaborate on the evaluation metrics used to assess the model's performance. Discuss their strengths and limitations, and consider including additional metrics that provide a more comprehensive evaluation of the model's capabilities, such as precision-recall curves or ROC curves.

Expand on the comparative study with existing methods, providing more details on their performance metrics, datasets used, and the specific advantages of the proposed model over the existing approaches. Consider discussing the limitations of the existing methods and how the proposed model addresses those limitations.

Discuss the scalability of the proposed model. How does it perform with larger datasets or in real-time scenarios? Consider conducting experiments or simulations to assess the model's scalability and provide insights into its computational requirements.

Address any potential biases or limitations in the experimental setup or dataset preprocessing. Discuss the impact these biases or limitations may have on the results and suggest ways to mitigate them or future directions to explore.

Provide a conclusion that summarizes the main findings of the research, highlights the contributions of the proposed model, and discusses potential avenues for future research and improvements in the field.

fields.subject: P. T. Daely, J. M. Lee and D.-S. Kim, "Vehicle Routing Based Mining for Proof-of-Useful-Work Blockchain", KICS Journal, 2023 (Major Revision))
fields.content:
Editor_R18348
Please update the thesis according to the reviewers' comments.

Reviewer_R18528
In related work, authors should analyze more clearly the pros/cons of related work and , based on the analysis, clarify the problems that this paper tries to address. In Simulation Results and Analysis, authors need to compare the proposed mechanism with other PoUW approaches rather than original PoW. And the analysis on the simulation results is too simple to prove its superiority. And the analysis on attack possibilities would be better if it is described separately form the simulation part. In conclusion, authors need to clarify the problem statement of this paper and how this paper address the problem.

Reviewer_R18580
Overall, the manuscript presents an interesting concept of Proof-of-Useful-Work(PoUW) Blockchain by using Vehicle Routing Problem(VRP), but there are several points that need to be addressed. 
- The ordering of figures: Fig. 3 is mentioned earlier than Fig.2, which can cause confusion for readers. It is recommended to correct the ordering. 
- The proposed PoUW framework lacks an explanation of how and why VRP is used: it is rather described with much detail in Section I Introduction. It would be more appropriate to include some related information in Section III rather than in the Introduction. This will provide readers with a clear understanding of how VRP relates to the proposed framework. 
- The manuscript does not sufficiently explain how considering and solving VRP benefits the PoUW framework, compared to the other PoUW works that consider different problems. It is important to provide a comprehensive explanation of the advantages of using VRP in the context of PoUW. Especially, it would be beneficial to provide a comparison with other baselines PoUW that adopts different problems (not VRP). 
- The simulation scenario only considers a single problem pooling node and a single external party node. It would be better to explore the results with multiple nodes, providing insights into the scalability and performance of the proposed approach in more complex scenarios. 
- The manuscript introduces (in Section IV) the concept of a usefulness rate but lacks a clear definition of what "useful work" entails. Is it a commonly used metric in this area? Then, needs to include relevant references.

fields.subject: Love Allen Chijioke Ahakonye, Cosmas Ifeanyi Nwakanma, Jae-Min Lee, Dong-Seong Kim, "LIME Explainable Machine Learning for Intrusion Detection in the Industrial Internet of Things", IEEE Internet of Things Magazine (Major Revision)
fields.content: Dear Prof. Kim: Manuscript # IOTMAG-23-00086 entitled "LIME Explainable Machine Learning for Intrusion Detection in the Industrial Internet of Things," which you submitted to the IEEE Internet of Things Magazine (IEEE IoTM), has been reviewed. The comments of the reviewers are included at the bottom of this letter. I regret to inform you that your paper has been denied publication in the IEEE IoTM at this time, based on the reviews and the recommendation by Associate Editor . You can find the reviews at the bottom of this letter. However, you may submit a new manuscript, which takes fully into consideration the reviewers' comments. Please note that resubmitting your manuscript does not guarantee eventual acceptance, and that your resubmission will be subject to a full review process. If you decide to resubmit your manuscript, go to http://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/iotmag and log in to your Author Center. Click on "Manuscripts with Decisions," and then click on "Create a Resubmission" located next to the manuscript number. Then, follow the steps for resubmitting your manuscript. When submitting your revised manuscript, you should respond to the comments made by the reviewers in the space provided. You can use this space to document any changes you made to the original manuscript. Or, you may create a file containing your responses outside the system and upload it for review along with your revision. If you choose to do the latter, please select “Supplemental File for Review” as the file designation. In order to expedite the processing of the revised manuscript, please be specific in your response to the reviewer questions and comments. IMPORTANT: Your original files are available to you when you upload your revised manuscript. Please delete any redundant files before completing the submission. Sincerely, Dr. Rath Vannithamby Editor-in-Chief, IEEE Internet of Things Magazine rath.vannithamby@intel.com Vertical Area Editor: Vecchio, Massimo Comments to the Author: Based on the significant concerns raised by the reviewers and my personal evaluation of the manuscript, I am unable to recommend its acceptance in its current state. In addition to minor grammar and style errors, the manuscript exhibits numerous structural issues that must be addressed. These problems range from the lack of a clear contribution to the existing state of the art to deficiencies in the organization and presentation of the content, as well as shortcomings in the analysis of the results. Guest Editor: Jammal, Manar Comments to the Author: The paper needs to better discuss their work in comparison to the existing literature. It is crucial to highlight the novelty of their approach and the significance of their findings in relation to previous research. Additionally, it is claimed that this work can be generalized to Internet of Things (IoT) applications. However, this claim is not adequately substantiated in the paper. I suggest that the authors provide a more detailed discussion of how their findings and methodology can be applied to IoT applications, including potential challenges and limitations. Finally, there are concerns regarding the paper's evaluation and accuracy. The authors should reassess their methodology and results. Reviewer: 1 Comments to the Author 1. What exactly is the new contribution of the proposed LIME? I do not see any concepts that were not mentioned in the literature. 2. From Fig. 2 to Fig. 5, I do not see which part is LIME. Fig. 5 visualizes the decision tree in a global manner. Where is the local model-agnostic explanation? 3. Examining an IIoT dataset does not generalize the work to be applicable to all IIoT cases. 4. Maybe the first thing to explain is why a simple decision tree can achieve 100% accuracy. The dataset should be examined first. Is the dataset contaminated? That is, some features leak the classification information. It only happens in the dataset, not in the real world. Reviewer: 2 Comments to the Author This paper proposed a decision tree XAI framework to identify real-time IoT attacks. The proposed framework introduces more trust and transparency in the ML based-IDS and the personnel executing its decisions. In general, this is an interesting paper but is not solid enough in the current state. The followings are some comments: 1. The contribution of the proposed approach in the Introduction section is not well defined. Authors should clearly explain contributions of this study. 2. When the authors refer to other papers in Section 2, they need to use to the first author's last name or the proposed model name, not "authors". 3. Page 2, 2nd, line 18 ~ Page 3, 1st, line 6 “The proposed LIME framework explains the predictions of the ML for attack detection as in Fig. 1. ……” There is no correlation between Figure 1 and the five components. Also, no component can be found in figure 1. Authors need to describe the components in relation to figure 1 or briefly describe figure 1. 4. In Figure 2, what do the numbers from 0 to 4 used on the x-axis and y-axis of the confusion matrix mean? Authors need to mark this in figure 2. 5. Page 4, 2nd, line 3 The description of the target is missing. 6. The linguistic quality needs improvement. It is essential to make sure that the paper reads smoothly- this definitely helps the reader fully appreciate your research findings. Reviewer: 3 Comments to the Author The present study outlines a novel XAI framework employing a decision tree methodology to detect real-time IoT breaches, aiming to foster greater trust and transparency in machine learning-integrated intrusion detection systems, and enhancing the decision-making processes of its operators. However, the study, as it currently stands, leaves room for improvements and refinement. Here are a few observations and suggestions: The unique value contributions of the proposed method are inadequately defined. It is recommended that the authors pinpoint the distinct contributions of this research. The authors need to explain the novelty of such work given it already exists in the literature ref [10]. The evaluation section is not explained and it seems that there are issues with data, confusion matrix is not explained and the accuracy of 100% is not justified. The applicability/feasibility of this work on different IoT applications is not clear, the authors claimed it can be generalized, but it is not clear how. Lastly, the readability and linguistic precision of the paper require enhancement. Date Sent: 22-May-2023

fields.subject: Ahmad Zainudin, Made Adi Paramartha Putra, Dong-Seong Kim, Jae-Min Lee,"Federated Learning-Assisted Human Activity Recognition for Interactive Avatar in Metaverse",IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications,2023 (Rejected)
fields.content:
[JSAC-SI-HCM 2024] Notification of review result on your paper #1570895016 ('Federated Learning-Assisted Human Activity Recognition for Interactive Avatar in Metaverse')

Dear Ahmad Zainudin, Made Adi Paramartha Putra, Dong Seong Kim and Jae Min Lee,

Thank you for submitting your paper to the IEEE JSAC Special Issue on Human-Centric Communication and Networking for Metaverse over 5G and Beyond Networks.

We have received a very large number of submissions, many of which were of extremely high quality. However, given the tight publication schedule for this special issue and the limited number of papers that can be accepted, we are only able to accept papers with very positive reviews that can be revised in a sufficiently short time frame. This, in turn, meant that we had to reject many interesting papers of very high quality. Unfortunately, we regret to inform you that, based on the reviewers' comments and the Guest Editors' discussion, we could not recommend publishing your paper in this Special Issue. A summary of the rationale behind this decision is provided below, and the detailed reviews can be found in EDAS.

We regret that we cannot offer better news on this occasion and we hope that you find the feedback in the reviews useful. Thank you again for considering our special issue as a venue for publication of your work.

Indeed, rejection from this SI is not a reflection of the quality of your work, and it does not mean that this work cannot be submitted to future JSAC special issues to which it may be relevant. We hope that you would understand this decision, and thank you again for your submission.

Thank you again for your interest in the IEEE JSAC Special Issue on Human-Centric Communication and Networking for Metaverse over 5G and Beyond Networks.

Sincerely,

Guest Editors
—————————————
Peng Li
Song Guo
Lin Cai
Mehrdad Dianati
Nirwan Ansari
-----------------------------

======= 1st review 1 =======

> *** Summary: Please summarize the paper briefly.

This paper proposes a federated learning based human activity recognition framework by which the privacy of users could be guaranteed.

> *** Presentation clarity: Is the paper well-written; are ideas clearly expressed?
Adequate (3)

> *** Contribution: How much of a contribution to the field is made by the work presented?
Minor contribution (2)

> *** Impact: Will this paper be important over time?
Probably not (2)

> *** Novelty: How original and novel are the concepts presented in the paper?
Incremental (3)

> *** References: Is related work on this topic adequately recognized, barely mentioned, or neglected?
Poor (1)

> *** Relevance: How well-suited is the paper to this JSAC Special Issue on “Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning for Networking and Communications"
Good match (4)

> *** Detailed Comments: Please provide detailed feedback to the author(s).

Some nontrivial issues are given as follows:

1. Some references are not convincing enough, please cite some high-quality references to improve the manuscript.

2. To the best of my knowledge, CNN-LSTM model is outdated and some state-of-the-art works are not mentioned in this paper. Hence, the experiments are not solid and convincing.

3. The motivation of adopting federated learning in proposed scenario is indefensible, I do not make sense the necessity of privacy protection in HAR. Besides, the experiments do not illustrate advantages of proposed framework on the communication overheads.

4. In section V, a typo in the second line from the bottom: “MFLPOs” should be corrected to “MFLOPs”.

5. In section II.A, this paper mentions the reference [17] utilized the LSTM-GRU. This is a confusing issue, in fact, there is no essential difference between LSTM and GRU. Hence, the combination of these two models is baseless. It is necessary to check the quality of references more precisely.

6. In section II.A, this paper mentions the reference [9] leverages the MLP, however, I do not find MLP is adopted in reference [9]. Besides, the MLP is over simple and cannot be a comparison in experiments, therefore, the objectivity of the experiments is questionable.

7. The DNN is the abbreviation of deep neural network, hence, the comparisons between DNN and proposed AvatarNet is absurd in experiments. I advise authors to substantially revise this manuscript and provide more robust evidence to support the ideas.

8. The individual effects of the different modules, such as PreBlock Module, Depthwise Convolution Module, DepthGroup Convolution Module, are not analyzed and verified.

> *** Negatives: What are the most important reasons NOT to accept this paper, in order of importance? (e.g., the paper has serious technical mistakes, isn't novel, doesn't demonstrate its point by proofs, simulations or experiments, makes very unreasonable assumptions, etc.) If the overall conclusions are still likely to hold despite these flaws, please say so. Say whether the negatives dominate the positives. (1-3 sentences)

The motivation of this paper is ambiguous and the citations lack authority. The experiments are over simple and not rigorous.

> *** Positives: What are the most important reasons to accept this paper, in order of importance? Say whether the positives dominate the negatives (1-3 sentences)

This paper proposes an FL-aided human activity recognition (HAR) and metaverse platform integration to create a human-like interactive avatar.

======= 1st review 2 =======

> *** Summary: Please summarize the paper briefly.

This paper proposed an FL-enabled human behavior recognition and metaverse platform for building a virtual avatar. The authors used federated learning for the training of deep learning models, thus protecting user privacy. The authors proposed a CNN-LSTM network for human behavior recognition and integrated the human behavior recognition framework and metaverse platform by JavaScript and the WebSocket protocol.

However, there are many technical concerns in this paper.

> *** Presentation clarity: Is the paper well-written; are ideas clearly expressed?
Needs work (2)

> *** Contribution: How much of a contribution to the field is made by the work presented?
Minor contribution (2)

> *** Impact: Will this paper be important over time?
Probably not (2)

> *** Novelty: How original and novel are the concepts presented in the paper?
Derivative (2)

> *** References: Is related work on this topic adequately recognized, barely mentioned, or neglected?
Fair (2)

> *** Relevance: How well-suited is the paper to this JSAC Special Issue on “Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning for Networking and Communications"
Good match (4)

> *** Detailed Comments: Please provide detailed feedback to the author(s).

This paper proposes an FL-enabled human behavior recognition and metaverse platform for building a virtual avatar. The authors use federated learning for the training of deep learning models, thus protecting user privacy. The authors propose a CNN-LSTM network for human behavior recognition and integrate the human behavior recognition framework and metaverse platform by JavaScript and the WebSocket protocol. The experiment results demonstrate the effectiveness of the proposed algorithm.

However, there are many technical concerns in this paper.
(1) One technical contribution in this paper is that to introduce the federated learning to the field of human pose recognition. However, as the authors described in Section Ⅱ, there are already a lot of work in this area, so please explain the technical contributions of this paper compared with the previous work.
(2) The authors should improve the logic and organization of this paper, reorganize the introduction and analysis of federated learning theory in the manuscript.
(3) CNN-LSTM networks have been applied to human activity recognition widely, it’s better to provide further explanation of the contribution in terms of the design of the CNN-LSTM network.
(4) The heterogeneity of data can have a significant impact on the efficiency of federated learning. The authors proposed an accuracy-based user scheduling algorithm. However, while the algorithm will reorder the users after a certain number of communication rounds, how can the algorithm guarantee that there will be no dropouts of specific users to cause the performance loss?
(5)The authors should highlight the need for federated learning in this field, for example, are there still privacy concerns in the case of infrared camera scenarios? Because centralized learning frequently outperforms federal learning, the relevance and necessity of implementing federal learning need more explanation.
(6) In the experiments in Fig. 4 and Fig. 5, the authors should list the hyperparameters of the different algorithms for model training in the manuscript.

> *** Negatives: What are the most important reasons NOT to accept this paper, in order of importance? (e.g., the paper has serious technical mistakes, isn't novel, doesn't demonstrate its point by proofs, simulations or experiments, makes very unreasonable assumptions, etc.) If the overall conclusions are still likely to hold despite these flaws, please say so. Say whether the negatives dominate the positives. (1-3 sentences)

However, as the authors described in Section Ⅱ, there are already a lot of work in this area, so please explain the technical contributions of this paper compared with the previous work.
(2) The authors should improve the logic and organization of this paper, reorganize the introduction and analysis of federated learning theory in the manuscript.
(3) CNN-LSTM networks have been applied to human activity recognition widely, it’s better to provide further explanation of the contribution in terms of the design of the CNN-LSTM network.
(4) The heterogeneity of data can have a significant impact on the efficiency of federated learning. The authors proposed an accuracy-based user scheduling algorithm. However, while the algorithm will reorder the users after a certain number of communication rounds, how can the algorithm guarantee that there will be no dropouts of specific users to cause the performance loss?
(5)The authors should highlight the need for federated learning in this field, for example, are there still privacy concerns in the case of infrared camera scenarios? Because centralized learning frequently outperforms federal learning, the relevance and necessity of implementing federal learning need more explanation.
(6) In the experiments in Fig. 4 and Fig. 5, the authors should list the hyperparameters of the different algorithms for model training in the manuscript.

> *** Positives: What are the most important reasons to accept this paper, in order of importance? Say whether the positives dominate the negatives (1-3 sentences)

This paper proposed an FL-enabled human behavior recognition and metaverse platform for building a virtual avatar. The authors used federated learning for the training of deep learning models, thus protecting user privacy. The authors proposed a CNN-LSTM network for human behavior recognition and integrated the human behavior recognition framework and metaverse platform by JavaScript and the WebSocket protocol.

======= 1st review 3 =======

> *** Summary: Please summarize the paper briefly.

This paper proposed an FL-aided human activity recognition (HAR) and metaverse platform integration to create a human-like interactive avatar. The HAR framework utilized an infrared array sensor to capture human gesture and a lightweight CNN-LSTM model to recognize dynamic human activities. Authors also implemented a improved accuracy-based client selection method to select potential clients to improve the model performance. Moreover, a connection module based on JavaScript and the WebSocket protocol has been developed to integrate the HAR framework and the Unreal Engine (UE)-based metaverse platform to generate an interactive avatar.

> *** Presentation clarity: Is the paper well-written; are ideas clearly expressed?
Adequate (3)

> *** Contribution: How much of a contribution to the field is made by the work presented?
Worthwhile contribution (3)

> *** Impact: Will this paper be important over time?
Can't quite tell (3)

> *** Novelty: How original and novel are the concepts presented in the paper?
Incremental (3)

> *** References: Is related work on this topic adequately recognized, barely mentioned, or neglected?
Good (3)

> *** Relevance: How well-suited is the paper to this JSAC Special Issue on “Artificial Intelligence and Machine Learning for Networking and Communications"
Little relevance (3)

> *** Detailed Comments: Please provide detailed feedback to the author(s).

1. The article seems to have been repeating the comparison with existing methods. In addition to the Section II, a lot of space has been devoted to describing the problems of existing methods in the introduction and even the problem formulation. However, even so, it is still not described clearly. For example, [7] also uses infrared array sensors. Why is it classified as "adapted limited types of activities" and what is the difference between it and this paper?
2. The experimental part and text description are confusing, i.e., "the three highest performing clients are selected for the next 10 communication rounds", both want to indicate that client selection should be executed once every 10 rounds, but the code means that except for round one and tens, all other rounds need to do it.
3. The symbol usage of P_ {min} is confusing. The input of Algorithm 2 should be the number of selected clients, and the output should be the selected set. (Line 6 of Algorithm 1)
4. Acc-based client selection is a common practice, so I don't think it's new. Moreover, It needs to calculate the accuracy of each client in every round, which will take a lot of time. Authors should do an experiment on latency.
5. What does "2 local training rounds and 100 communication rounds" mean ? It means to aggregate the model after two local updates? Additionally, it is not clear what the value of local epoch ε is.
6. There're insufficient explanation of the results in Figure 5. Why is the random algorithm better than the first two algorithms?
7. The effect of MetaFi [4] is good, and the article emphasizes its high complexity, so it should be compared as a baseline.

> *** Negatives: What are the most important reasons NOT to accept this paper, in order of importance? (e.g., the paper has serious technical mistakes, isn't novel, doesn't demonstrate its point by proofs, simulations or experiments, makes very unreasonable assumptions, etc.) If the overall conclusions are still likely to hold despite these flaws, please say so. Say whether the negatives dominate the positives. (1-3 sentences)

1. It is unclear what the novelty of this paper is. E.g., the client selection scheme is one of the most common schemes in FL. It is also unclear whether the implementation has contributions.
2. The writing of this paper is not good. A lot of things are not very clear. Please see my detailed. comments.
3. The impact of this paper is not obvious. It is unclear whether this work is useful to the researchers or developers in industry, as the authors have not released the code, even the the authors highlight implementation of the WebSocket part.

> *** Positives: What are the most important reasons to accept this paper, in order of importance? Say whether the positives dominate the negatives (1-3 sentences)

1. It's interesting that this paper proposes an integrated FL-based HAR framework and metaverse platform to generate an interactive avatar.
2. The federated HAR framework utilized an improved federated averaging aggregation algorithm with client selection (FedAvg-iACS)
3. Applied a lightweight CNN-LSTM model to recognize human activities in the physical environment and the model section is described in detail.
4. Developed a communication module as the bridge to integrate the HAR framework and the metaverse platform to generate an interactive avatar.

fields.subject: Ebuka Chinaechetam Nkoro , Judith Nkechinyere Njoku, Cosmas Ifeanyi Nwakanma, Jae-Min Lee , and Dong-Seong Kim, "UDetect: Anonymous Network Traffic Classification in the Metaverse with Union Feature Selection", IEEE TNSM Decision (Reject).
fields.content:
22-Jul-2023

Dear Prof. Kim:

I write to you regarding manuscript # TNSM-2023-06271 entitled "UDetect: Anonymous Network Traffic  Classification in the Metaverse with Union Feature Selection," which you submitted to IEEE Transactions on Network and Service Management (TNSM).

I regret to inform you that your paper has been denied publication in IEEE TNSM, based on the reviews and the recommendation by Associate Editor Dr. Carol Fung. You can find the reviews at the bottom of this letter.

Thank you for considering IEEE TNSM for the publication of your research. We hope that the outcome of this specific submission will not discourage you from submitting manuscripts in the future.

Sincerely,
Dr. Hanan Lutfiyya
Editor-in-Chief, IEEE TNSM
hanan@csd.uwo.ca


Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
I think this study has some practical value, but Pearson correlation coefficient and decision tree belong to conventional machine learning methods, and the joint Feature selection method in this study has advantages. But is it necessary to compare with other machine learning algorithms or create new algorithms, which is beneficial for academic innovation.

Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
Paper Summary:
This paper investigated an approach to merge two feature sets to perform classification in the Metaverse context.
The paper has discussed an interesting topic of anonymous network classification in the Metaverse context, and derives the need to have a good approach to solve this problem.
The authors discussed the single-feature selection approach against the union feature method (essentially merging the feature sets generated by PCC and DT. ), and concluded the union feature method is a better choice for the Metaverse scenario according to experiments performed on a particular dataset.

Strength:
The paper captured the issue well that there needs to be a good way to perform classification in the for anonymous network classification, and told the story well. The paper explains the approach and background clearly, and demonstrates the data is organized well, thus well written.


Weakness:
* The approach of union-feature selection does not seem to have much relationship with Metaverse. Is there any reason that it is not a general approach? Or is there any reason that we should not generalize the approach to a broader class of classification problems? What's the downside of this union of features, in general?
* This is purely an empirical study, as a research paper, if the focus is on algorithms, then we need to theoretically analyze why the new approach is better than those alone and thoroughly understand the pros and cons. If the focus is on domain specific questions, then there would be expectation on more involved domain-specific analysis. But it seems the paper is not focusing on either, instead, it is a hypothesized idea with experiment data on limited dataset without thorough theoretical analysis nor strong domain specific technical explanation. This results in the paper to lack intellectual contribution or novelty.
* The paper pointed out the proposed approach is better than PCC/DT alone. But there is no context about how much better is great work, i.e., is the improvement really amazing or just a mediocre tweak, we do not know, and the paper did not cover the significance of the result improvement.
* The creation of F4 is very difficult to understand, why would one union the features that being excluded from PCC **and** DT? What's the reasoning behind this?

Nits:
Page-1,  SIEM is not Security Information and Identify Management
The paper mentions filter and wrapper. How about the embedded?
Fig-2 what does the black-solid line mean?
Page-6, why is 0.8 selected? any reasoning behind it?

Reviewer: 3

Comments to the Author
This paper proposes a  union feature selection method an ensemble classification approach for anonymous network classification. Though the topic is interesting, the methods proposed are very simple and will lead to increased time complexity. The classification accuracy of more than  93.1% has been achieved in many machine learning-based approaches. Even deep learning-based solutions with better accuracy and reduced time complexity are available. Hence, the work can be tried with deep learning based approach.

Associate Editor
Comments to the Author:
Based on the reviews received, there are some major issues with this submission, including 1) the approach of union-feature selection does not seem to have much relationship with Metaverse; 2)
the results in the paper lack intellectual contribution or novelty; and 3) the approach is simple and will lead to increased time complexity. Therefore, the editor believes the paper is not suitable to be published in TNSM.

Subject: IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics - Manuscript No. TII-23-2554 : Review result

28-Aug-2023


Dear Authors (CC to Associate Editor, Reviewers),

The review process of your manuscript No. TII-23-2554, entitled "Trees Bootstrap Aggregation for Detection and Characterization of IoT-SCADA Network Traffic" as a Regular Paper submission, has been completed.

Based on the opinions of the reviewers and the Associate Editor in charge, your manuscript requires some revision before it can be accepted for publication in the   IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics.

Please revise your manuscript to address the enclosed reviewers' comments, and highlight the changes in the manuscript. Your revised manuscript will be evaluated again by the same Associate Editor who handled your paper. Please return your revised manuscript as soon as possible using the S1M website: http://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/tii and follow the instructions for authors on http://tii.ieee-ies.org/o/Rejected.pdf.

- Please note that if your revised manuscript exceeds the page limit of TII (8 pages for regular and "Special Section" papers), extra page charge for the publication cost will be billed to you by IEEE Publication, 250 USD/page. In any case, the manuscript length cannot exceed 10 pages.

Throughout the review process with each intermediate review result stage, it is important for authors to follow 2018 IEEE PSPB Operations Manual mandate on Section 8.2.1 Publication Principles, including Section 8.2.1 Subsection 3 and 8. Once the list and order of authors has been established, the list and order of authors should not be altered without permission of all living authors and Co-authors have the right to withdraw their names from an article at any time before acceptance of the article by the editor. However, an author’s or co-author’s name should not be removed from an article without his or her permission. The responsible editor shall be notified of any change in authorship.

Your kind cooperation is greatly appreciated.

Sincerely yours,
Prof. Gerhard Hancke
Editor-in-Chief
IEEE Transactions on Industrial Informatics
http://tii.ieee-ies.org/
g.hancke@ieee.org

***********************

Encl.:
Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
The authors have rectified all the comments I made concerning the paper. I, therefore, do not have any more comments. Thank you.

Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
Thanks to the author's response and modification, many mistakes have been corrected. However, I remain skeptical about the structure and feasibility of the experiment in Fig 1. Fig 1 indicates that is a pipeline illustration or flowchart in a conceptualized layered IoT-SCADA IEC-60870-5-104 protocol network. How can we understand this concept? You were using many public datasets including CIC-Darknet2020, CMU-SYNTRAFFIC-2022, and WUSTL-IIOT-2021.  In section I study focus 2), you wrote: "To demonstrate an intelligent solution capable of monitoring for distinguishing different types of IoT-SCADA IEC-104 communication protocol encrypted network traffic in a stream of specific network activity." In section III, you specify "The study features the conceptual monitoring of layered IoT-SCADA network architecture with IEC-104 communication protocol....". In section IV A Dataset description, you wrote ".......which are consistent data features of the IoT-SCADA network traffic in addition to specific sensor data".  Combining your previous statements, we can learn that you're modeling or approximating the conceptual framework you're proposing with a lot of public datasets. But those datasets don't have anything to do with the IoT-SCADA IEC-60870-5-104 protocol network, and their simulation scenarios didn't use that protocol, although some of them use IIoT and industrial scenarios, the direct equivalence is unconvincing. You need to justify why the datasets you are using and the concepts you are proposing apply to each other, more details need to be provided. Otherwise, you will need to perform simulations for the IoT-SCADA IEC-60870-5-104 communication protocol, generate simulated traffic, or capture traffic in a real-world layered IOT-SCADA network.

Reviewer: 3

Comments to the Author
1. Pg1 col 1 ln 24. "11 n-estimator, 20 max ...", inconsistent font for numbers?
2. Pg1 col 2 ln 18. The abbreviation "IEC-101" should be explained when it first appears.
3. Pg2 col 2 ln 32. "IEC101" missing "-"?
4. Fig.1 still needs improvement. Please ensure that the text on the figure is not covered or obscured as much as possible.
5. Table IV and V. "TPR %)" missing left brackets.
6. Pg7 col 1 ln 18. The abbreviation "MCE" should be explained when it first appears.
7. Pg7 col 1 ln 25. Is the "#" symbol redundant in "MCE#"?
8. In section IV C, second paragraph, the author analyzes the time-exigency of the model. However, in Table V, there are two algorithms referenced as [19] and [25]. Why is only the comparison result with [19] mentioned? Additionally, the experimental results are not clearly explained.
9. In section IV F, the author only provides SHAP value visualization and does not provide specific discussions on the importance of features.


Reviewer: 4

Comments to the Author
The authors have responded to all my comments from Round 1 Revision. The only minor suggestion that I have is to improve the readability of the legends in some of the figures (especially Figure 1, 2 and 3).

AE Comments:
Associate Editor
Comments to the Author:
The submission has improved significantly compared to the initial submission. There is however still uncertainity if the experiments actually verify the proposed approach.

28-Aug-2023
