Dear Professor Lee,

Thank you for submitting your manuscript to Internet of Things.

I have completed my evaluation of your manuscript. The reviewers recommend reconsideration of your manuscript following major revision. I invite you to resubmit your manuscript after addressing the comments below. Please resubmit your revised manuscript by Sep 23, 2023.

When revising your manuscript, please consider all issues mentioned in the reviewers' comments carefully: please outline every change made in response to their comments and provide suitable rebuttals for any comments not addressed. Please note that your revised submission may need to be re-reviewed. 

To submit your revised manuscript, please log in as an author at https://www.editorialmanager.com/iot/, and navigate to the "Submissions Needing Revision" folder.  

Research Elements (optional)
This journal encourages you to share research objects - including your raw data, methods, protocols, software, hardware and more – which support your original research article in a Research Elements journal. Research Elements are open access, multidisciplinary, peer-reviewed journals which make the objects associated with your research more discoverable, trustworthy and promote replicability and reproducibility. As open access journals, there may be an Article Publishing Charge if your paper is accepted for publication. Find out more about the Research Elements journals at https://www.elsevier.com/authors/tools-and-resources/research-elements-journals?dgcid=ec_em_research_elements_email.


Internet of Things values your contribution and I look forward to receiving your revised manuscript.

Kind regards,   
Fatos Xhafa   
Editor-in-Chief  

Internet of Things

Editor and Reviewer comments:



Reviewer #1: Abstract
- a very good abstract. Clear and concise
Introduction
- The introduction is related and relevant to the current grid energy. Concise and very objective.
Related works
- Adequate
Methodology
- Adequate
Simulation Results and Discussion
- I doubt on the accuracy
o How accurate is the technique? I would suggest that the technique has to be tested using different sets of data. Fabricate/experiment and compare with simulated/calculated results.
Conclusion
- Adequate.



Reviewer #2:
In this article, the authors evaluated the time efficiency of 1-D kernel CNN for predicting Smart grid frequency stability. Although good numerical results have been obtained, there are concerns related to how the model is designed and verified. Therefore, it is necessary for the authors to consider the following
1. The main idea cannot be taken from the contributions of the introduction section.
2. The references are not up-to-date, there is no review of the 2022 and 2023 articles.
3. Why is computational cost important in mentioned scope? If the strength of the proposed method is computing time management, it should be addressed more. In the introduction of related methods, the strengths and weaknesses should be briefly mentioned.
4. Why is computational cost important in the training phase and what is its impact in real-time when model can train on dataset in offline phase? It is better to compare the number of optimal parameters in the investigated models.
5. The difference between the time of the proposed method and other methods is very large. Explain the reason theoretically. What is a main trade-off? Explain the reason theoretically. What is a trade-off? It should be verified in more detail. Authors should prove the superiority of their work with more experiments.
6. What is the dash symbol in the table 2? The Computational Time-cost of all models in Table 6 should be include for fair comparison (specially CNN).
7. In Table 6, indexes are not done (a-c). How the data set was divided into Train-Validation-Test sets?
8. For a more accurate evaluation, comparison with other methods, especially recent methods, should be added to the text in more detail.
9. The algorithm of the proposed method should be added to the text as pseudo code.
10. In what process are the parameters of the optimal model set? The choice of hyperparameters has a direct effect on the performance of the final model. How did you set them?

Dear Prof. Dong-Seong Kim:

Manuscript ID COM-2023-07-0290 entitled "Whale Optimization-based PTS Scheme for PAPR Reduction in UFMC Systems" which you submitted to IET Communications, has been reviewed. Some revisions to your manuscript have been recommended. Therefore, I invite you to respond to the comments appended below and revise your manuscript.

Editor-in-Chief Comments

Deadlines:
Because we are trying to facilitate timely publication of manuscripts submitted to IET Communications,your revised manuscript should be uploaded as soon as possible. If it is not possible for you to submit your revision in a month, we may have to consider your paper as a new submission. If you feel that you will be unable to submit your revision within the time allowed please contact me to discuss the possibility of extending the revision time.

Before submitting your revisions:

1.  Prepare a response to the reviewer comments appended below in point-by-point fashion in PDF format. In order to expedite the processing of the revised manuscript, please be as specific as possible in your response and indicate the page numbers in the manuscript where you have addressed each comment.

2. Prepare a revised manuscript in an editable format (not PDF), highlighting the changes you’ve made. Save this new document on your computer as you will be asked to upload it during the revision submission process. NOTE: Please be sure to keep in mind reviewer comments and incorporate your responses within the manuscript. There may well be areas where you disagree; for example, you may want to write, "A reviewer suggests that... However, I disagree because...". In any case, please try to address all of the concerns that are raised within the manuscript.

3. In addition to your revised manuscript with changes highlighted, please also save a “clean- editable” copy where the changes are not marked. If the source file is LaTeX make sure that clean PDF also uploaded.

4. Please include a separate title page with following details  :-
* Title of the manuscript
* All the authors' complete names
* Departmental & institutional affiliations of the authors
* Postal & e-mail address of the corresponding author
* Conflict of interest statement
* funding information
* Data availability statement

Please refer the below link and provide the data availability statement accordingly in the ScholarOne system and in the manuscript.

https://authorservices.wiley.com/author-resources/Journal-Authors/open-access/data-sharing-citation/data-sharing-policy.html#standardtemplates

5. Please note this, funding information provided in the ScholarOne should match with main manuscript.

To submit your revised manuscript:

1. Log in by clicking on the link below

*** PLEASE NOTE: This is a two-step process. After clicking on the link, you will be directed to a webpage to confirm. ***

https://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/theiet-com?URL_MASK=a5f9f5d82fe14ae4af6f227c60d4a5cc

OR

Log into https://mc.manuscriptcentral.com/theiet-com and click on Author Centre. You will find your manuscript title listed under "Manuscripts with Decisions". Under "Actions," click on "Create a Revision." Your manuscript number has been appended to denote a revision. PLEASE DO NOT SUBMIT YOUR REVISIONS AS A NEW MANUSCRIPT.

2. Follow the on-screen instructions. First you will be asked to provide your “Response to Decision Letter”—this is the response to reviewer comments that you prepared earlier.

3. Click through the next few screens to verify that all previously provided information is correct.

4. File Upload:  Delete any files that you will be replacing (this includes your old manuscript). Upload your new revised manuscript file with changes highlighted, a “clean” copy of your revised manuscript file, any replacement figures/tables, or any new files. Once this is complete, the list of files in the “My Files” section should ONLY contain the final versions of everything.  REMEMBER: figures/tables should be in jpeg, tiff, or eps format. We hope that you will designate one of the figures in your paper to be considered for our online covers and potential publication on our blog.

5. Author Contribution Indication
The contributions of each author to this work must now be indicated when you submit your revised manuscript using CRediT taxonomy (http://credit.niso.org/contributor-roles-defined/). If not provided already you MUST provide this information as part of the revision process. Author Contributions will be published with the accepted article and cannot be edited after article acceptance. Therefore you must ensure the Author Contribution information you provide is accurate prior to final acceptance.

6. Review and submit: please be sure to double-check everything carefully so that your manuscript can be processed as quickly as possible.

Once again, thank you for submitting your manuscript to IET Communications and I look forward to receiving your revision.

Sincerely,
Prof. Jian Ren
Editor in Chief, IET Communications
renjian@msu.edu

Wiley Editing Services Available to All Authors
Should you be interested, Wiley Editing Services offers expert help with manuscript, language, and format editing, along with other article preparation services. You can learn more about this service option at www.wileyauthors.com/eeo/preparation. You can also check out Wiley’s collection of free article preparation resources for general guidance about writing and preparing your manuscript at www.wileyauthors.com/eeo/prepresources.

Associate Editor Comments to Author:

Associate Editor
Comments to the Author:
For your submission, I have collected comments from two experts. They both pointed out the novelty and contribution should be better summarized and the proposed algorithm should be fairly compared with existing intelligent algorithms, such as GA and PSO. Based on my own reading, I agreed with the them and thereby invite you to revise your manuscript according to the detailed comments from the reviewers.


Reviewer(s)' Comments to Author:

Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
In this paper, the authors propose a new PAPR reduction strategy called whale optimization algorithm-based partial transmit sequence (WOA-PTS) to reduce the PAPR of universal filtered multicarrier (UFMC) system. Due to its interesting topic, the paper has the potential to be considered for publication in this journal. However, some changes are required in the paper to be accepted for publication.
1. Please give the main contributions of the paper as a list in the Introduction Section.
2. The paper should be reviewed by a professional language expert. There are many grammatical and syntax errors.
3. In the paper, please clearly explain the reason of choosing the whale optimization algorithm for PAPR reduction in the UFMC system. What are the unique features and superiorities of WOA over the other intelligent optimization algorithms?
4. The computational complexity analysis of each technique must be carried out by expressing their computational loads in terms of the number of multiplications and the number of additions needed throughout the PAPR reduction process.  
5. Apart from the classical PTS and IWO-PTS, please add at least two more intelligent optimization algorithm-based PTS strategy for comparison to clearly demonstrate the efficiency of WOA-PTS proposed in this paper.
6. Please compare the convergence performance of the considered optimization algorithms by obtaining the convergence graph of each one.
7. Please use Monte Carlo method in the simulations to acquire smoother PAPR curves with minimal fractures. Besides, please obtain the PAPR curves for at least CCDF=10^-3.
8. Bit error rate (BER) performance of the considered PAPR reduction methods under the usage of nonlinear high power amplifier (HPA) is missing.
9. The figure resolutions are insufficient, which reduces the paper quality.
10. There is a problem with the PSD performance comparison in Figure 4. The PSD improvement must be acquired in the side lobes, not at the top of the PSD graph. You should obtain the PSD curve of each strategy under the usage of nonlinear high power amplifier (HPA) to be able to demonstrate the amount of suppression achieved by each technique on the side lobes of UFMC waveform. We cannot see any side lobe suppression in the Figure 4. So please revise the codes and repeat the simulations to obtain more accurate results in Figure 4.









Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
This letter proposes a Whale Optimization Algorithm (WOA)-based Partial Transmit Sequence (PTS) scheme, named WOA-PTS, for reducing the high Peak-to-Average Power Ratio (PAPR) in Universal Filtered Multi-Carrier (UFMC) systems. The application of PTS-based PAPR reduction with heuristic algorithms like Genetic Algorithms (GA) and Particle Swarm Optimization (PSO) has been extensively studied. However, this letter is considered lacking in contribution and novelty. The detailed comments are as follows:

-Section 2.2 should provide more details about the PTS technique.

-The author should also present the PTS-OFDM scheme in Fig. 3.

-Can the author compare the proposed scheme with GA or PSO-based optimization?

-It would be interesting to analyze the performance loss of the proposed scheme.

-There is room for improvement in terms of content and clarity, especially in section (10).

Paper: IoT-32520-2023 PureFed: An Efficient Collaborative and Trustworthy Blockchain-Assisted Federated Learning Framework
Authors:  Prof. Jae-Min Lee, Putra, Made Adi Paramartha; Zainudin, Ahmad; Alief, Revin; Kim, Dong-Seong; Lee, Jae-Min
Editor: Prof. Ruidong Li

Dear Prof. Lee,

I am writing to you concerning the above-referenced manuscript, which you submitted to the IEEE Internet of Things Journal.

Although it has merit, based on the enclosed set of reviews this manuscript has been rejected for publication in the IEEE Internet of Things Journal.

You may wish to consider the comments of the reviewers and submit it to another journal.

If you have any questions regarding the reviews, please contact the Associate Editor: Prof. Ruidong Li liruidong@ieee.org.  Any other inquiries should be directed to the Administrative Assistant: Surbhi Tyagi surbhi.tyagi@ieee.org

Thank you for considering IEEE Internet of Things Journal for publication of your work.

Sincerely,
Prof. Nei Kato
Editor-in-Chief, IEEE Internet of Things Journal
eic-iot@it.is.tohoku.ac.jp

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
• Associate Editor Comments, if any, are listed below:

Associate Editor: Li, Ruidong
REQUIRED: Comments to Author:
According to the comments from the reviewers, this paper is considered to be rejected.
The problem definition is unclear;  writings need to be improved;  experiments should be put more effort to convince the readers.

• Reviewer Comments, if any, are listed below:

Reviewer: 1

Comments to the Author
This paper proposes an innovative Federated Learning (FL) framework designed for efficiency, collaboration, and trustworthiness, PureFed. In particular, it employs smart contracts (blockchain technology) to enhance the security of the framework by using symmetric key encryption and dual digital signature mechanisms using the Elliptic Curve Digital Signature Algorithm (ECDSA). A dynamic aggregation scheme from 3 methods and dynamic incentive, as well as punishment mechanisms, are also used. To this end, the reviewer has major concerns as follows:

1. The main concern is the application of this paper. This journal specializes in IoT systems, however, the reviewer does not see any IoT explanation in this manuscript. Please justify.

2. In the Abstract, there are several information related to the contributions. However, they need to be smoothly written. Please make the contributions coherent. Additionally, the authors should highlight the most important contributions among them both in the Abstract and Section I.

3. Additionally, the authors are encouraged to provide the motivations and background related to problems of using IoT systems.

4. The current writing structure of Section I seems confusing, incoherent, and too long. Please revise Section I and make it concise.

5. Section III. A explains Problem Formulation. However, the reviewer does not see any equations or formulations in this Section. Please revise.

6. Upon the equation, if the sentence continues, it should use a comma not a dot. Please check all equation parts.

7. The authors utilize dynamic aggregation schemes with 3 methods. Nonetheless, the authors do not explain in which conditions each method will apply and provide the best model performance.

8. It seems that the reward and punishment mechanisms are not an optimization problem, thus hindering the contribution of this mechanism. Please clarify the importance of such a mechanism.

9. It is very common for researchers to use a standard dataset, i.e., MNIST, to show the efficacy of their proposed frameworks. To this end, the authors are encouraged to provide one more IoT-related dataset.

10. The authors are encouraged to provide/explain the utilized neural networks and main hyperparameter settings for the FL implementation, e.g., learning rate, optimizer, batch size, etc.

11. In the Abstract, the authors mention the comparative simulations. However, the reviewer does not see any accuracy or loss comparison with other baseline methods, e.g., conventional FL or other FL methods.

12. The number of references is insufficient. Please add more relevant references, e.g., up to 35-40 references.

Reviewer: 2

Comments to the Author
N/A

Reviewer: 3

Comments to the Author
1. The author proposed a federated learning framework and verified its performance using the MNIST dataset. What machine learning method did the author use to classify handwriting data? What is the performance of the proposed framework in processing time series data, which has different type of MNIST dataset? In order to more fully illustrate the performance of the proposed framework, it is recommended to increase the type and number of data sets in the experimental part.

2. In the reward distribution represented by formulas (3)-(5), it seems that only the performance of accuracy is considered? Why not consider other performance, such as precision and recall?

3. In the paper, the author describes the performance of each part of the proposed framework in great detail, but the description of the performance of the entire framework is insufficient. Therefore, it is recommended to add descriptions about the performance of the overall framework, including computing overhead, operation time, etc.

4. In this paper, the LM method is compared many times. Please note that the full name of LM is not given. Furthermore, adding contrasting methods, not just LM, would be better practice.

5. In the Table II, the Loss-based scheme achieves the best precision, recall and F1 score while taking the least time. why is that? At the same time, compared with the schemes based on FedAvg and Accuracy, the performance of the proposed method is doubled and the time is also shortened by half. Why is this? A kind reminder, it will help readers' understanding if relevant references for schemes based on FedAvg, Accuracy and Loss are given.


Note: If any of the reviews include an additional attached file, it will not be attached to this message. To access it, log in to your Author Center and click on "Decision (View Letter)" -- this brings up this message, and at the bottom is the attached file. Click on that file name and you can see the attached comments from reviewers.
